headline: Two Arrested in Killings of Transgender Women in Puerto Rico

headline: No Graduation Ceremony? You Get Oprah!

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Public beaches have become a flashpoint as the U.S. begins to emerge from stay-at-home restrictions.
lead_paragraph: As Americans wrestle with how to emerge from weeks of social-distancing restrictions, tensions are building between those who remain desperate to suppress the coronavirus and those who are desperate to get out of the house. And the nation’s beaches have become a flash point.

headline: Closing Number of a Musical
abstract: Trenton Charlson raises the curtain on our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle by Trenton Charlson is another Friday dazzler worth showing up for. Not only does it have a generous sprinkling of high-score Scrabble letters (just take a gander at the four Z’s in the northeast!), the entries are flashy and fun. The topics covered in the puzzle are plentiful, giving even a Friday-averse solver a chance at conquering it. And overall, the tone of the puzzle is cheery and optimistic, the perfect antidote to what we are all going through right now during the pandemic.

headline: Labs Across U.S. Join Federal Initiative to Study Coronavirus Genome

lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday announced a national initiative to speed research into how the coronavirus was spreading around the country, bringing together at least 75 public health, academic and commercial institutions studying its genome.

abstract: At least three boats carrying Rohingya refugees have been adrift for more than two months. As of this week, rights groups that had been tracking the boats lost sight of them.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Somewhere in turquoise waters, perhaps where the Bay of Bengal meets the Andaman Sea, wooden boats filled with Rohingya refugees are listing, adrift now for more than 10 weeks.

headline: Michigan Governor Reinstates State of Emergency as Protests Ramp Up
abstract: The governor’s moves were in response to the Republican-led Legislature’s refusal to extend the original emergency declaration.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan, a prime political target in partisan clashes over stay-at-home orders during the coronavirus outbreak, signed three executive orders on Thursday to reinstate a state of emergency during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Tennis Coming Back Slowly With Exhibition Matches
abstract: The small-scale events could create a road map to help the men’s and women’s tours return.
lead_paragraph: Tennys Sandgren, who was on a roll before professional tennis shut down, has had enough of video games and self-isolation in his home near Nashville, Tenn.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Hollywood’ and ‘Prop Culture’
abstract: A soapy period drama from two creators of “Glee” debuts on Netflix. And a new series on Disney Plus showcases famous film props.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD Stream on Netflix. Hollywood’s golden era is viewed through a gilded but piercing lens in this soapy new mini-series, from Ryan Murphy and Ian Brennan, both of “Glee.” Set in a sumptuous version of 1940s Los Angeles, “Hollywood” imagines a more inclusive version of that era’s Tinseltown. Many characters are people to whom the real Hollywood would have been hostile. They include Archie (Jeremy Pope), an aspiring screenwriter who is black and gay, and has a movie to sell. He teams up with a young director (Darren Criss) to make that dream a reality. “The bid to make Archie’s movie starts as a glitzy, funny, gimlet-eyed dissection of bigotry and power,” James Poniewozik wrote in his review for The New York Times. “Then it lurches, halfway through, into a pep talk about what some kids can accomplish if they gather up their moxie and put on a show.”

headline: Locked Inside, We’re Like Whitman, Finding Joy in Smallness
abstract: Interpreting lines from “Leaves of Grass” about the beauty and wonder to be discovered in the minuscule and routine.

headline: Racing Against the Virus From Inside Australia’s Healthcare System
abstract: An emergency room doctor in Melbourne describes the terror and relief of waiting for a tsunami of coronavirus patients that never arrived.
lead_paragraph: When my director cut short his camping holiday on Australia Day, to come back to the emergency department at the Melbourne hospital where I work as an emergency physician, I thought he was unnecessarily sacrificing his life for the sake of his work. Covid-19 was still mainly confined to China. Italy was not yet in crisis and New York wasn’t even on our radar. But in hindsight, his return was prudent.

headline: ‘Hospital Needs to Be Quarantined,’ but Works On in Country at War
abstract: Twenty percent of the staff at one hospital is quarantined, but doors remain open as the war wounded are brought in.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Even when their city was repeatedly overrun by the Taliban and fighting reached their doorsteps, the doctors and nurses in the northern Afghan city of Kunduz kept working. They dressed wounds and saved lives at the main government hospital even as a nearby trauma center was bombed, killing more than 40 people.

abstract: From New York to Los Angeles, tenant groups are encouraging millions of renters to withhold May rent, which landlords warn would be devastating.
lead_paragraph: As unemployment soars across the country, tenants rights groups and community nonprofits have rallied around an audacious goal: to persuade the government to halt rent and mortgage payments — without back payments accruing — for as long as the economy is battered by the coronavirus.

lead_paragraph: ROME — Rome turned 2,773 last week.

headline: ‘All Day and a Night’ Review: Growth Behind Bars
abstract: In this drama from one of the screenwriters of “Black Panther,” a young man embarks on a journey of belated self-discovery.
lead_paragraph: In the early moments of “All Day and a Night,” a gut-wrenching drama now streaming on Netflix, comes an emotional courtroom scene. Jahkor Lincoln (Ashton Sanders) sits with a look of stoic resignation in a room packed with the loved ones of the two people he has murdered. Before the judge delivers Jahkor’s life sentence, the mother of one of the deceased stands to speak. “My granddaughter is only 10 years old,” she says. “You took away her whole family and never even given a reason why. That’s all I want to know. Why?”

headline: ‘The Half of It’ Review: Being Yourself (and That Person, Too)
abstract: In this comedy from Alice Wu, love letters reveal everything about a person, except their identity.
lead_paragraph: Every generation gets its own “Cyrano de Bergerac,” from the Steve Martin comedy “Roxanne” to Netflix’s “Sierra Burgess Is a Loser.” But Alice Wu’s new high school-set film, “The Half of It” (also on Netflix), transcends the limitations that frequently serve as obstacles to ingenuity in young adult movies. By exploring issues of race and queerness with emotional complexity, it treats teenagers with the sophistication they deserve.

lead_paragraph: The 2015 finale of “Parks and Recreation,” the NBC comedy set in a small-town bureaucracy, took place in the future. I would not suggest that you watch it right now. I say that not so much as a judgment of its quality but because its vision of the years it flash-forwarded to — from 2017 to 2048 — is, in retrospect, painfully optimistic.

abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: LOST AND WANTED, by Nell Freudenberger. (Vintage, 336 pp., $16.95.) In this ghost story in which scientific metaphors abound, a physics professor is haunted by the death of a close friend whom she never truly knew. “The effect is beautiful,” wrote our reviewer, Louisa Hall, evoking the gravitational pull of dormant, unobservable attachments and discarded hopes.

headline: How to Run for President in the Middle of a Pandemic

lead_paragraph: Is it possible to run for president during a pandemic, without the handshaking and the baby-kissing? Can Joe Biden and Donald Trump stay a safe six feet from their own campaigns? Ever since the arrival of the coronavirus, we’ve all wondered whether democracy can operate at such a distance.

abstract: How Billy Eichner, Lizzie Asher and Andrew Saffir are not partying.
lead_paragraph: With the New York party scene on hiatus, here is how some patrons and society figures are spending their time and resources during the coronavirus crisis.

headline: The Big Impact of a Small Hobby
abstract: Drawing mundane things like my dish rack had helped me survive job loss. Could it be helping me through the coronavirus?
lead_paragraph: When I would tell people that drawing saved my life, I thought I was being hyperbolic. Then the coronavirus hit. Drawing had helped me survive another very dark period of my life, earlier. Could it now be helping me to stay healthy?

headline: A Significant, Yet Ordinary, Sunday in Chicago
abstract: Sophia Newman and Jason Leverett were married on a city sidewalk, then they walked back to their apartment and watched one of their favorite Marvel movies. It wasn’t what they had planned for their wedding day, but it was all they needed for now.
lead_paragraph: Marielle Sophia Newman and Jason Leverett had originally planned on having their March 29 wedding and reception at Schubas Tavern in Chicago, a live-music spot in the couple’s Lakeview neighborhood. “We can walk to our wedding,” said Ms. Newman, 37, a manuscript editor at the Journal of the American Medical Association, explaining her choice.

headline: Nobody Has Seen Kim Jong-un for 19 Days. What Does It Mean?
abstract: Pyongyang has adhered to a long tradition of maintaining silence on speculation about its leader and his family.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Nineteen days have elapsed since North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, was seen on his country’s state media, on April 12, a day after he presided over a meeting of the Politburo of the ruling Workers’ Party.

headline: Could ‘Innate Immunology’ Save Us From the Coronavirus?

lead_paragraph: As the world waits for a coronavirus vaccine, tens of thousands of people could die. But some scientists believe a vaccine might already exist.

headline: Documenting All the Small Things That Are Easily Lost
abstract: An assignment for all of us to help capture an extraordinary time.

headline: Why Americans Need a Guaranteed Income
abstract: The pandemic makes painfully clear that our economy must be reconfigured to be resilient in the face of disruption and change.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, on Monday said what many in her caucus have been saying for weeks: A guaranteed income to help Americans struggling because of the coronavirus pandemic is “worthy of attention.” As recently as just a few months ago, an income guarantee was widely written off as unrealistic. But two-thirds of the members of the House Democratic caucus now support the idea of some kind of cash payment that would continue until the end of the crisis.

headline: How Coronavirus Shifted the Stakes of Teenage Rebellion
abstract: Living with an invisible outside threat, and no visible outlet, forced my daughter and me to negotiate and reconcile — and fast.
lead_paragraph: The weekend before New York City’s stay-at-home order went into effect, my 15-year-old daughter and I had an argument. She asked if she could hang out with friends in our neighborhood, promising to “be very careful” and “bring Purell.” Acknowledging the necessity of friends and fun, I said yes and sent her off.

headline: Biden Denies Tara Reade’s Assault Allegation: ‘It Never Happened’

lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Friday denied an allegation of sexual assault by a former Senate aide, Tara Reade, breaking a monthlong silence that had frustrated some Democratic activists as his presidential campaign navigated issues of gender that are vitally important to many members of his party.

headline: Art Biennials Were Testing Grounds. Now They Are Being Tested.
abstract: As the pandemic clears the calendar, curators around the world reimagine how — and if — we will gather for art.
lead_paragraph: The Prospect New Orleans art triennial in October has been postponed to next year. So has the Liverpool Biennial. São Paulo’s Bienal is delayed by at least a month. The Dakar Biennale has yet to set new dates. Front International, in Cleveland, has decided to skip 2021 altogether and return in 2022.

headline: A Pandemic Isn’t a Reason to Abolish the SAT

lead_paragraph: Because of the threat posed by the coronavirus pandemic, the College Board, which administers the SAT and Advanced Placement exams, has canceled spring and summer testing and raised the possibility of offering SATs online in the fall.

headline: How New Mexico Is Beating the Virus
abstract: It has two things missing elsewhere: political leadership and a strong health system.
lead_paragraph: LAS CRUCES, N.M. — On March 13, the same day that a reluctant President Trump admitted that the coronavirus pandemic was a national emergency, a storied New Mexico hospital established the nation’s first drive-through testing for the virus.

abstract: In times of crisis, stark images of sacrifice or consequence have often moved masses to act.
lead_paragraph: Recently, a friend, colleague and mentor, the cultural historian and critic Maurice Berger, died at 63 of complications from the coronavirus.

headline: Find a Vaccine. Next: Produce 300 Million Vials of It.
abstract: Scaling up the manufacturing of syringes and other medical products required to deliver a vaccine to millions of Americans will be just as important as the vaccine itself.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of national shortages of testing swabs and protective gear, some medical suppliers and health policy experts are looking ahead to another extraordinary demand on manufacturing: Delivering a vaccine that could potentially end the pandemic.

abstract: Ben Casselman of the Business desk uses new and traditional tools to understand the financial landscape during the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: For Most Food Stamp Users, Online Shopping Isn’t an Option
abstract: Rules and store technology can impede Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program recipients, but a pilot effort to expand access is picking up speed.
lead_paragraph: Whether they need more yeast for stress baking or the comfort of Kraft macaroni and cheese, Americans sequestered by social distancing are shopping for groceries online. But for many low-income households using food stamps, that can happen only in person.

headline: ‘This Feels Very Different’
abstract: For over a decade, the Permian Basin has been the epicenter of the American oil boom. Now, it’s the epicenter of its demise.
lead_paragraph: MIDLAND, Texas — In just over a month, scores of drilling rigs have been dismantled and tucked away in storage yards. Pump jacks, those piston pumps that lift crude out of the ground, have seesawed to a standstill as operators shut down wells.

headline: 3 Africans in Mexico City Grave Tell Stories of Slavery’s Toll
abstract: The men might have been among the earliest to be stolen from their homeland and brought to the Americas.
lead_paragraph: The three skulls were unlike hundreds of others in the 16th-century mass grave uncovered at the San José de los Naturales Royal Hospital in Mexico City. Their front teeth were filed decoratively, perhaps as a ritual custom, unlike those of “los naturales,” the Indigenous people who made up the majority of bodies at the colonial burial site. Archaeologists concluded the three individuals were most likely enslaved Africans, but they needed more evidence to be certain.

headline: A Life and Death Battle: 4 Days of Kidney Failure but No Dialysis
abstract: At the peak of the pandemic in New York, a longtime city employee joined a crush of patients in desperate need of treatment.
lead_paragraph: Orphaned as a youth in Bangladesh, Jamal Uddin worked in a ribbon factory in Lower Manhattan while attending high school, before graduating from college and ultimately finding a career helping people with H.I.V./AIDS.

headline: Streets Should Be Car-Free During Lockdown. And After.
abstract: Cholera changed the face of Paris. Will Covid-19 change the streets of New York?
lead_paragraph: Late Tuesday afternoon, New York’s City Council speaker, Corey Johnson, was on a nine-mile walk, one the current crisis has him taking everyday — the quest for fresh air and decompression. Beginning from his boyfriend’s apartment in Williamsburg, he heads north into Queens over the Pulaski Bridge and through Hunter’s Point South Park. That is where he was when I caught up with him by phone, watching people for the most part diligently perform the choreography of social distance without, he noted, the interventions of the police.

headline: How De Niro Gave Us Sinatra’s ‘New York, New York,’ Our 7 P.M. Anthem
abstract: Frank Sinatra can thank Robert De Niro and two annoyed songwriters for the song that revived his career and now is the theme music of the city’s nightly tribute.
lead_paragraph: The old friend shows up every night, big and brawny as ever. He’s on a Brooklyn family’s seventh-floor balcony in Windsor Terrace, and above the Portofino Ristorante in Forest Hills, and bellowing out of a truck rolling slowly up and down the empty canyons of Manhattan’s avenues, right on time to — with the crash of a cymbal — start spreadin’ the news.

abstract: Most pantries are closed on Sundays, but Jorge Negron opens his to make and provide brown-bag lunches.
lead_paragraph: As a food programs manager at New York Common Pantry, a poverty reduction nonprofit, Jorge Negron works the Sunday shift in East Harlem, making sure that hungry New Yorkers can pick up a brown-bag meal on a day when most pantries and soup kitchens are closed.

headline: Street Art Confronts the Pandemic
abstract: From Norway to Colorado, street artists depict a world of masks and hand-washing (and toilet paper). One recurrent theme: a deep appreciation of health care workers.
lead_paragraph: Street art is the ultimate visual source of social commentary and the pandemic has lit a fire under the feet of muralists around the world.

headline: We the People, in Order to Defeat the Coronavirus
abstract: There are times when government must curtail individual freedoms to protect the public. But those measures must end once the threat passes.
lead_paragraph: The tension between private liberty and public health in the United States is hardly new. Americans have demanded the latter in times of plague and prioritized the former in times of well-being since at least the Colonial Era. Politicians and business leaders have alternately manipulated and deferred to that tension for about as long.

abstract: Never has the cheer of homegrown color been more essential. Here’s how to get it — even if you haven’t started planting yet.
lead_paragraph: My farmer-florist neighbor Jennifer Elliott’s 15-acre organic operation in the Hudson Valley is like a giant cutting garden from April to November. So it was to Ms. Elliott and another flower-focused friend that I turned for a strategy in a year when having some version of what she has, at least in miniature — the cheer of homegrown color — seemed like just the thing.

lead_paragraph: The White House and some Republican governors are angling toward a cautious reopening of the economy, while G.O.P. leaders in Congress have tried to pump the brakes on future federal stimulus spending.

headline: New York Closes Schools Through End of Academic Year
abstract: Governor Cuomo said it was impossible to reopen schools “in a way that would keep our children and students and educators safe.”
lead_paragraph: Schools throughout New York State will remain shuttered through the end of the school year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced Friday, confirming what educators, union leaders and Mayor Bill de Blasio had said was inevitable weeks earlier.

headline: Film Club: ‘What My Spacewalk Taught Me About Isolation’
abstract: How can we learn to be connected even when we are feeling alone during the pandemic?
lead_paragraph: We’re over a month into social distancing and many of us are feeling that time and space have lost all meaning. Perhaps no one understands this better than astronauts, who spend months drifting in isolation.

headline: Are You an Optimist or a Pessimist?
abstract: Is either outlook on life better suited to these difficult times? Or maybe both?
lead_paragraph: Would you say you are more of a “glass is half-full” or a “glass is half-empty” type of person? That is, are you generally an optimist, someone who tends to see the positive sides of situations, or a pessimist, someone who more often sees the negative?

headline: Can Street Artists Survive a City in Lockdown?
abstract: Buskers, musicians and muralists have been entertaining London for centuries. But now the capital has gone quiet and the future of their activities looks uncertain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One recent Friday, Nathan Bowen, a graffiti artist, was spray painting a boarded-up storefront in East London.

headline: ‘All Day and a Night’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The writer and director Joe Robert Cole narrates a sequence from his film featuring Ashton Sanders.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Joe Robert Cole narrates a sequence from his film featuring Ashton Sanders.

headline: In Philanthropy, Race Is Still a Factor in Who Gets What, Study Shows
abstract: Nonprofit groups led by black and Latino directors lag behind peers with white leaders, but two leading philanthropic organizations hope to change that.
lead_paragraph: Philanthropy often sets out to mitigate inequality. But a research report set to be released next week by two leading philanthropic organizations shows that race remains a defining factor when looking at which organizations get funded and how much they receive.

headline: Health Savings Accounts Add Options in Pandemic, Including Telehealth
abstract: Insurance plans with H.S.A.s may also cover coronavirus testing while keeping the tax perks.
lead_paragraph: People with a health savings account now have more flexibility in how they use the money because of rule changes prompted by the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: How ‘All Day and a Night’ Dazzles With a Street Scene
abstract: Joe Robert Cole, the writer and director of a new Oakland-set Netflix drama discusses a high-energy sequence that takes place at a party-car-stunt display called a sideshow.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: How to Spend Your Weekend Outside
abstract: Friday: You probably can’t go to the beach. But restrictions on other activities have been loosened. Also: A remembrance, and photos of poppies.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: A Record Sale in Brooklyn Among April’s Closings
abstract: As the pandemic hobbled the real estate industry, several huge deals crossed the finish line, including a record sale at Brooklyn Bridge Park and another Jeff Bezos acquisition in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s real estate market reached new highs in April, even as the coronavirus outbreak threatened future home sales.

headline: Tanzanian Cartoonist Has a Stick for Every Powerful Eye
abstract: Godfrey Mwampembwa, popularly known as Gado, has been holding politicians accountable for nearly 30 years. Now, his concern has shifted to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — In a quiet office on the third floor of a building in Nairobi’s central business district, the cartoonist known by his pen name, Gado, was sketching a satire  about the coronavirus.

headline: Sheltering in Place in an R.V. Is Not as Fun as It Sounds
abstract: With parks shut down and utilities harder to come by, drivers of motor homes are finding themselves trapped in the vehicles meant to liberate them.
lead_paragraph: In the six years since they decided to sell their house and move into a 40-foot motor home, Julie and Marc Bennett have crisscrossed the country and become masters of the R.V. lifestyle — all while “still working and saving for retirement,” as they note on their website, RVlove.com. They even wrote a book, “Living the RV Life,” with tips on how to choose the right vehicle, how to get mail and how not to get electrocuted.

headline: Setback for Harry and Meghan in Legal Battle With U.K. Tabloids
abstract: A judge ruled that The Mail on Sunday would not be judged on whether it had acted dishonestly in publishing a letter from the Duchess of Sussex to her father, Thomas Markle.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a setback to Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, in their bitter legal battle against the British tabloids, a high court judge struck down key claims on Friday in a lawsuit that Meghan brought against The Mail on Sunday for publishing a letter she sent to her father.

headline: Job Interviews Are Broken. There’s a Way to Fix Them.
abstract: Instead of focusing on credentials, let’s give candidates the chance to showcase their will and skill to learn.
lead_paragraph: Within the first few minutes of the interview, I knew the candidate was a bad fit for a sales position. His résumé had tipped me off: He was a math major and built robots in his spare time. Now we were sitting face-to-face in my office, but he hardly made any eye contact. When I told my boss I wasn’t going to hire him because of that, she said, “You know this is a phone sales job, right?”

headline: A Private Equity Firm Is Blocked From Buying .Org
abstract: The deal for the internet domain for nonprofit organizations had set off fierce opposition.
lead_paragraph: A private equity firm will not gain control of dot-org, the digital real estate that is home to millions of nonprofits, nongovernmental organizations and community groups.

headline: The ‘Credibility Bookcase’ Is the Quarantine’s Hottest Accessory
abstract: The bookcase has become the preferred background for applying a patina of authority to an amateurish video feed.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that you are a member of the expert class — the kind of person invited to pontificate on television news programs. Under normal circumstances, your expertise might be signaled to the public by a gaudy photograph of skyscrapers superimposed behind your head. But now the formalities of the broadcast studio are a distant memory, and the only tools to convey that you truly belong on television are the objects within your own home. There’s only one move: You talk in front of a bookcase.

headline: A Composer and Her (Very) Long String Instrument
abstract: Ellen Fullman is sheltering in place with the 40-string, 45-foot-long droning instrument she created decades ago.
lead_paragraph: Like most people these days, the sound artist Ellen Fullman is sheltering in place. But she has an unusual roommate: a massive installation she calls the Long String Instrument.

headline: What Rights Do Pregnant Workers Have in a Pandemic?
abstract: Here’s how to ask for accommodations.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of March, when it was clear coronavirus shutdowns were imminent, Anna, 29, was at her obstetrician’s office for a pregnancy well visit. She was supposed to travel from her home in the Midwest to Florida that weekend to see her in-laws, but her doctor advised against it. Anna’s obstetrician also recommended that she work from home going forward — pregnant women’s immune systems are already taxed, and experts can’t say with certainty how the coronavirus might affect them.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Celebrate the end of the week with a cocktail, if that’s your speed, and the beginning of the weekend with pancakes or waffles.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The mailbag’s been interesting these days, missives from all over the world, from up and down the socio-economic ladder: people eating rillettes in the Alps and canned beans in rural Maine; front-line medical workers craving fresh strawberries, unemployed car salesmen grilling pork ribs and wondering what’s going to happen next.

headline: The Healing Power of Baseball
abstract: During epidemics, war and national tragedy, baseball was medicine for the masses. During this crisis, we’re still waiting for the prescription to be filled.
lead_paragraph: A friend and fellow baseball fan recently sent an email and an old photo to offer his appreciation to our medical staff. Gleaned from the archives of the National Baseball Hall of Fame, the image showed an exhibition game played in Pasadena, Calif., in Jan. 1919. The scene shows the batter, catcher and umpire all wearing surgical masks, as are those watching from the grandstand. The image was captured just a few months before the third and final wave of the devastating influenza pandemic that emerged in 1918.

headline: Beyoncé Amps Up ‘Savage,’ and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Oasis, Haim, Kenny Chesney and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Porches, Yards, Driveways, Parking Lots: Where the Neighborhood Is Now
abstract: How we come together when we can’t go very far.
lead_paragraph: We walk the dogs across the meadow in the rain. We don’t talk much. We say the same things over and over, and yet somehow there’s comfort in the repetition. Yesterday someone wrote on the town listserv that certain dog owners had been spotted in the meadow less than six feet away from each other. Suddenly, everybody’s a cop, yardsticks in their minds.

headline: Behind the Cover: Race and Covid-19
abstract: For this issue, a look at the deadly racial disparities of Covid-19 in America.

headline: Congress Calls on Jeff Bezos of Amazon to Testify
abstract: Lawmakers want to question Mr. Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, as part of its antitrust investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Judiciary Committee on Friday called on Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, to testify before Congress, in a major escalation of its investigation into the country’s largest technology companies.

headline: At New York’s ‘Museums of Plants,’ the Art Is Blooming Lonely
abstract: Spring remains colorful, but unusually quiet, at some of the city’s botanical gardens as crews work to prune the beauty behind closed gates.
lead_paragraph: Phil Macaluso, a gardener, bikes to work at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden four days a week from his home about a five-minute ride away. The garden is closed, but the trees and everything else in Brooklyn are still growing, even if other aspects of the city’s life have come to a standstill.

headline: Why Trump Is Obsessed With the Flynn Case
abstract: It’s the perfect combination of distraction, fear-mongering and red meat for his base.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of the coronavirus crisis, a cratering economy and plummeting approval ratings, perhaps it’s not surprising to see President Trump return to a favorite theme: abusing the rule of law.

headline: To the Readers of This Newsletter
abstract: Thank you.
lead_paragraph: This article originally ran as part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter, which will be named Opinion Today starting May 4. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Full Transcript: Joe Biden Addresses Tara Reade Allegations on ‘Morning Joe’
abstract: The former vice president was interviewed about the allegation made by his former Senate aide that he sexually assaulted her in 1993.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. appeared on MSNBC’s “Morning Joe” on Friday to publicly address, for the first time, Tara Reade’s allegation that Mr. Biden sexually assaulted her. Mr. Biden denies the allegation.

headline: Farewell to the Friendly Cheek Kiss
abstract: The moratorium on “la bise,” as it’s known in France, brings sorrow, but also relief.
lead_paragraph: I never meant to kiss Miuccia Prada. Not on the lips, anyway. It was a muggy afternoon in the spring of 2015, and I was in Tokyo at the opening of her new Miu Miu store. I had been waiting in line to congratulate her. The lights above me hung bright and hot, and I knew without looking that I had sweated through the tailored suit I’d been given to wear for the occasion. A famous French actress stood two people ahead of me at the front of the line. Her arms Pietà’d out as she approached the Italian designer, hands landing confidently on Mrs. Prada’s shoulders, and, as if tracing the line of a toppled-over parabola, she kissed her — mwah — on the left cheek, and then again — mwah — on the right. The next person followed suit, making it through the exchange without incident. Then it was my turn. I kind of cranked forward and cupped Mrs. Prada’s waist the way a high school junior might initiate a slow dance. Then I lurched even closer, barely grazing one side of her cheek on the first try. On the second, determined this time to make contact, I touched the hinge of her lips to mine.

headline: Introducing Rhubarb Bars, Lemon Bars’ Pinker Cousins
abstract: With a crunchy shortbread crust and tangy curd filling, this rhubarb-filled confection is perfect for spring.
lead_paragraph: Is it me, or have rhubarb desserts gotten pinker and more vivid in the last few years?

headline: Life in Trump’s Coronavirus Ghetto
abstract: A vast majority of Americans are confined in stagnant, stressful places whose prospects have vanished overnight.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, I wrote an Op-Ed for this paper under the headline “We’re All in the Ghetto Now.” I criticized Donald Trump’s flagrant disregard of constituents and constituencies he didn’t like or consider allies.

headline: Bonds Beat Stocks Over the Last 20 Years
abstract: Over the long run, stocks are supposed to beat bonds. But they haven’t managed to do that uniformly since 2000, a sign of how difficult things have gotten for ordinary investors.
lead_paragraph: You can count on stocks to beat bonds over the long haul. That, at least, is the common wisdom, and much of the time it has even been true.

headline: The C.E.O. at the Center of New York’s Coronavirus Crisis
abstract: “It’s something I’ve never witnessed in 40 years of medicine,” said Dr. Steven Corwin, the chief executive of NewYork-Presbyterian.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Steven Corwin was a doctor during the AIDS crisis. He was the chief medical officer at NewYork-Presbyterian on Sept. 11, 2001. He has never seen anything like this.

headline: Fatigue Is Here, but the Economic Fight Is Just Beginning
abstract: Precious public support will be squandered if the economic relief effort isn’t handled with full transparency and accountability, a former presidential adviser says.
lead_paragraph: As early as we are in the fight against the Covid-19 virus, I fear that many Americans may already be exhausted by it.

headline: Blood Pressure Drugs Don’t Increase Coronavirus Risk, Studies Find
abstract: People taking widely used medicines did not face higher rates of infection or more severe illness, new research indicates.
lead_paragraph: Drugs that are widely prescribed to treat high blood pressure do not make patients more susceptible to coronavirus infection, or to severe illness if they do become infected, researchers reported on Friday.

headline: Murals Send a Message of Hope in Grim Times
abstract: A campaign, “Back to the Streets,” aims to create 1,000 murals by 1,000 artists in 100 cities, on walls offered by business and property owners.
lead_paragraph: On Wilshire Boulevard in Santa Monica, five artists gathered recently, with appropriate social distancing. They painted “Togetherness” in huge letters vibrantly embellished across the plywood panels protecting the windows of the shuttered kitchenware store Sur La Table.

headline: Bill de Blasio Finds His Scapegoat
abstract: The mayor’s gift for doing exactly the wrong thing was on full display when he put all Jewish New Yorkers on notice.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio was hankering for a scapegoat. The need was entirely understandable.

headline: The Hunt for Moby Dick Moves Online
abstract: Every year, the New Bedford Whaling Museum hosts a marathon reading of “Moby-Dick.” For the social distancing edition, volunteers are recording performances from home.
lead_paragraph: If these were normal times, Ger Tysk, a sailor, would be getting her tall ship ready for an expedition along the coast of New England.

headline: 7 Savory Pancakes for Any Time of Day
abstract: Prepare this easy savory pancake mix, pull a few items from the fridge and you’re just minutes away from breakfast, lunch or dinner.
lead_paragraph: Simple to assemble, savory pancakes are a universal comfort food. Their versatility is indicated by the many variations served around the world: Turkish zucchini pancakes, Korean vegetable pajeon and Japanese okonomiyaki. Fluffy and light or crisp and pan-fried, savory pancakes are a natural vehicle for using up leftovers or pantry ingredients.

headline: Parmesan! Crusted! Chicken!
abstract: Take those boneless chicken breasts and give them a crispy, cheesy exterior you won’t soon forget.
lead_paragraph: Welcome back to Five Weeknight Dishes. This week, I’ve been thinking about The Times’s original weeknight columnist, the French chef Pierre Franey, who wrote “60-Minute Gourmet.” (He pretty much invented boneless chicken breasts, and before chicken nuggets were a thing, he had us making goujonettes for dinner parties.) When he started in 1975, the ingredients available to most home cooks were pretty limited, as they are right now: a lot of dried, canned and frozen staples; the most basic fresh produce; and only the occasional fresh herbs or tomatoes or raspberries.

headline: Now Is the Time to Learn to Play Bridge
abstract: It’s easier to pick up the world’s best card game at home on your own.
lead_paragraph: Bridge will reward you early on — but the first few hours are utterly disorienting. Using a combination of apps, books and computer players who won’t berate you for mistakes is the easiest way to power through that vicious learning curve into the fun part.

headline: ‘Hollywood’ Offers Alternate History, and Glimpses of a Real One
abstract: Ryan Murphy’s new period melodrama, debuting Friday on Netflix, uses real figures from the past to tell an invented history of 1940s Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: “Let me guess,” Patti LuPone says as she plinks olives into a martini. “You came here to be a movie star.”

headline: David Najem Has Been Reading a Lot, but He’d Rather Be Playing Soccer
abstract: With his league suspended, the professional defender stays fit by kicking the ball wherever he can — like on the parking deck in his apartment building.
lead_paragraph: People throughout the sports world, from athletes to arena staff members, tell The New York Times how their lives have changed during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: This Snickerdoodle in Poundcake Form Is Your Next Baking Project
abstract: Warming and gently spiced, this easy loaf cake comes together in just about an hour — and may not last nearly as long.
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s called a loaf cake, tea cake, poundcake or one of those slyly named “breads” of the banana-pumpkin-zucchini variety, if I can bake it in a 9-by-5-inch pan, it will find a place in my lockdown kitchen. There’s something about loaf cake's sturdy, bricklike shape that makes it feel like a bulwark against the chaos of the moment.

headline: An Eerily Prescient Pandemic Novel That’s Guaranteed to Terrify
abstract: In Lawrence Wright’s “The End of October,” a virulent flu races around the globe, killing millions and plunging society into disarray.
lead_paragraph: THE END OF OCTOBERBy Lawrence Wright

headline: Elon Musk Says Tesla Share Price Is Too High
abstract: The electric car company’s stock fell 10 percent after the chief executive took to Twitter to try to talk down its recent surge.
lead_paragraph: Tesla’s chief executive, Elon Musk, said on Twitter on Friday that the company’s stock price, which had been surging in recent weeks, was “too high” in his opinion. The stock fell sharply after the post, and closed 10.3 percent down.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: The deadly racial disparities of Covid-19. Stephen King on Joe Biden and the pandemic. The beauty of Easter Island. The new Saturday night. The big lasagna. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend and to a new month. Maybe this is the weekend for a big lasagna, or to catch a film starring Irrfan Khan or Rishi Kapoor, both great Indian actors who died this week. You also might want to start looking at what you can send Mom because Mother’s Day is next weekend in the United States. Whatever you’re doing, make time for some great journalism.

headline: Big Tech’s Worries Should Worry You
abstract: When the most successful companies are anxious, you know we’re in scary times.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: As Students Put Off College, Anxious Universities Tap Wait Lists
abstract: Uncertain that campuses will reopen, students are reluctant to commit for the fall. For schools, enrollment drops and lost revenue could be devastating.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of the traditional May 1 deadline to decide where she would go to college, Tiffany Tang had four schools to choose from. Then on Tuesday, the University of California, Los Angeles emailed to offer her a spot off the wait list. That evening, she received a call from a Houston area code — an admissions officer from Rice. On Wednesday, Cornell got in touch.

headline: Hotelier’s Push for $126 Million in Small-Business Aid Draws Scrutiny
abstract: Monty Bennett says the government should help companies like his. Now, Senator Chuck Schumer is asking for a review of use of the Paycheck Protection Program by Mr. Bennett’s companies.
lead_paragraph: Monty Bennett’s sprawling hospitality company is the biggest known applicant of the government’s small-business relief program. The Texas conservative has remained unwilling to return his loans even as public anger builds over large companies getting the funds — a fact now drawing the scrutiny of a key lawmaker.

headline: Canada Bans Assault Weapons in Wake of Deadly Mass Shooting
abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said the government had been in the process of introducing the ban when its agenda was overturned by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Nearly two weeks after the deadliest mass shooting in Canada’s history, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Friday introduced an immediate ban on what he described as “military-style assault weapons.”

headline: What Is ‘Covid Toe’? Maybe a Strange Sign of Coronavirus Infection
abstract: Dermatologists say the lesions should prompt testing for the virus, even though many patients have no other symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Before the coronavirus outbreak, Dr. Lindy Fox, a dermatologist in San Francisco, used to see four or five patients a year with chilblains — painful red or purple lesions that typically emerge on fingers or toes in the winter.

headline: Democrats Seek Investigation Into Claims of Meddling at Consumer Bureau
abstract: A memo from a Consumer Financial Protection Bureau employee who described pressure by political appointees over a payday lending rule prompted lawmakers’ request.
lead_paragraph: Democratic lawmakers called on Friday for a formal investigation into allegations that President Trump’s political appointees at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau improperly interfered in the drafting of a planned regulation on payday lending.

headline: Love Letter: Living With Loneliness
abstract: Plus, how to stay connected.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has forced many of us into isolation; now family gatherings and weekend brunches with friends are a thing of the past. While we’re all finding ways to cope — and maybe even trying to channel some optimism — living alone presents its own unique challenges (and possibly benefits too!).

headline: The New York City Wine and Food Festival Moves Online
abstract: The annual festival is raising money for the Restaurant Relief Fund with a continuing series featuring food celebrities and chefs.
lead_paragraph: The annual summer Food & Wine Classic in Aspen, Colo., has been canceled. But the New York City Wine and Food Festival, a four-day fall fund-raiser that sprawls across the city in restaurants and event spaces? Not so fast. Lee Schrager, the organizer and founder, is going digital with it, starting this week, and still hopes the festival will return in October. (He was able to slip in the South Beach edition in Miami just under the wire in February.) Now with the gala atmosphere at tastings, lunches, cocktail gatherings and dinners falling victim to social distancing, the festival has added NYCWFF at Home, with sessions, mainly classes, featuring food celebrities and chefs a few times a week. Participants, up to 300 per session, pay $20 each and can join via Zoom. There will even be a 15-minute Q. and A. at the end of each event. All the money goes to the National Restaurant Association’s Restaurant Employee Relief Fund. First up on Monday at 2:30 p.m. will be Neil Patrick Harris cooking with his husband, David Burtka; Wednesday will feature Alex Guarnaschelli and her daughter. Plans are for it to continue for months to come.

headline: Blood Samples, Vital for Antibody Tests, Sold at Exorbitant Rates
abstract: In short supply, the samples are essential for the creation of coronavirus antibody tests that can help end lockdowns. Several companies are racing to capitalize on that.
lead_paragraph: After 10 terrible days of chills, nausea, a fever of 103 and a headache of such intensity that her nose bled, Aleacia Jenkins knew she had been stricken with the coronavirus even before she tested positive.

headline: Fauci, Leading Fight Against Coronavirus, Misses Baseball, Too
abstract: A devoted Yankees fan fell in love with the Washington Nationals. But Dr. Anthony S. Fauci concedes it’s going to be a while before he goes to another game.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the federal government’s top infectious disease expert, spends 19-hour days helping to lead the fight against the coronavirus.

headline: Bolsonaro Fights for Survival, Turning to Empowered Military Elders
abstract: A flailing leader has given Brazil’s generals an opening to insert themselves onto the front lines of politics.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Jair Bolsonaro ascended to Brazil’s presidency with a sweeping set of promises, like cutting out the rot of corruption, firing up the economy and doing away with the country’s notorious pork-barrel politics.

headline: The Coronavirus Still Is a Global Health Emergency, W.H.O. Warns
abstract: Even as some governments contemplate reopening, the spread of the virus has accelerated in countries in Africa and South America.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization extended its declaration of a global health emergency on Friday amid increasing criticism from the Trump Administration about its handling of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The Best Part of the Campaign Trail (the Food!) Comes Home
abstract: By ordering in, a political reporter continues to enjoy his favorite dishes from around the country.
lead_paragraph: It started on my birthday. I received, on the same blessed day in April, a package of ribs from the Memphis restaurant Central BBQ, courtesy of my brother and sister-in-law, and a box of Eastern North Carolina barbecue and hush puppies from Kings BBQ Restaurant, by way of my parents.

headline: A Suicide Highlighting the Stresses Doctors Face
abstract: Two doctors reflect on Dr. Lorna Breen’s death and the need for doctors to care for themselves as well as patients. Also: Jared Kushner on the virus; nursing home safety; schools and student anxiety.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Odd Turn With Israel, Gazans Get Economic Adrenaline Shot from Virus
abstract: With demand for masks and protective gear soaring worldwide, Israeli merchants have flooded Gaza garment factories with new orders since early March.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Ziad Qassem’s 25 years as a tailor seemed worthless in the cruel economy of the blockaded Gaza Strip: Unemployed for eight months, piling up debt, he sat idle in his apartment, worried how he would provide for his wife and five children.

headline: Drive-Throughs Are Now a Lifeline for Fast-Food Chains
abstract: With dine-in restaurants shuttered and social distancing paramount, drive-throughs are now providing a crucial source of revenue during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the fast-food drive-through has been a greasy symbol of Americana, a roadside ritual for millions of travelers with a hankering for burgers and fries.

headline: Pride at the Plate for a Little League All-Star
abstract: In Phil Bildner’s “A High Five for Glenn Burke,” the inventor of the world’s most popular celebratory gesture helps a budding baseball player accept himself for who he is.
lead_paragraph: Fairly often one of my students raises a hand in class just as I’m saying something that feels important. When the palm hangs there, imploring but impertinent, I turn and ask, “You have a question, or you want a high-five?” The joke, however middling, cuts the tension. Almost always, the student replies, “Both.” We slap a high-five. The question is asked and answered. Class gets back to business.

headline: Your Life or Your Livelihood: Americans Wrestle With Impossible Choice
abstract: As states begin to loosen restrictions, the act of reopening will be carried out not by governors or the president, but the millions of individuals being asked to do it.
lead_paragraph: When Maine finally announced this week that hair salons could reopen, Sarah Kyllonen, a stylist in Lewiston, stayed up late wondering what to do, feeling overwhelmed.

headline: In a City Frozen in Fear, Time Freezes, Too
abstract: Unusually clear skies, sunny days and empty parks beckon, but in a city locked down by the coronavirus, almost no one is heeding their call.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The first thing that disappeared was the annoying sound of a power drill up the street, from a house under construction.

headline: Lawrence Wright on Researching a (Fictional) Pandemic
abstract: Wright talks about “The End of October,” and Dalia Sofer discusses “Man of My Time.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: What the Proponents of ‘Natural’ Herd Immunity Don’t Say
abstract: Try to reach it without a vaccine, and millions will die.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus moved so rapidly across the globe partly because no one had prior immunity to it. Failure to check its spread will result in a catastrophic loss of lives. Yet some politicians, epidemiologists and commentators are advising that the most practical course of action is to manage infections while allowing so-called herd immunity to build.

headline: How to Also Keep Your Car Healthy
abstract: Along with making medical equipment, the car industry is finding ways to keep their customers safer, like coming to you when your car needs service.
lead_paragraph: The response of the auto industry in times of national peril is legendary. Detroit’s reputation as the Arsenal of Democracy, producing the tens of thousands of bombers and tanks that helped the Allies win World War II, is well-deserved.

headline: Fertility Clinics Stay Open Despite Unclear Guidelines
abstract: Many providers have continued seeing patients through the pandemic, forcing them to choose between clients and staff safety.
lead_paragraph: Since March, fertility clinics across the country have halted treatments for tens of thousands of people because of Covid-19, forcing patients to suspend their family planning. In recent days, some clinics have reopened, resuming services and procedures despite ongoing coronavirus concerns.

headline: Helen McGehee, a Martha Graham Dancer and Teacher, Dies at 98
abstract: She was known as a fierce and powerful dancer. Her teaching style was similarly demanding.
lead_paragraph: Helen McGehee, a powerful dancer in Martha Graham’s company since the 1940s and a prominent teacher known for her tough-love rigor, died on April 9 in Lynchburg, Va., where she lived. She was 98.

headline: Your Chicken Is No Longer Pink. That Doesn’t Mean It’s Safe to Eat.
abstract: Next time you cook chicken, don’t rely on the color of the meat to tell you if it’s cooked enough to avoid food poisoning.
lead_paragraph: As we wait out this pandemic, chances are you’re at home, cooking. Perhaps you’ve baked a million loaves of bread and your sourdough starter is overflowing. If Google Trends is any indication of what comes next, after “banana bread” and “pancakes,” people are seeking “chicken recipes.”

headline: The Courage to Be Alone
abstract: On our daily walks together, my young daughter and I begin to navigate a new reality.
lead_paragraph: My youngest daughter has told me that Annabelle, her baby doll, might have the coronavirus. We talk about it as we take a daily walk up the road. She’s not sure yet whether it is diabetes or the virus. Annabelle’s symptoms vary, but she has not left the small cradle by the side of my daughter’s bed in days. I have been told I can babysit for Annabelle, but only if I promise to hold her gently and not give her candy. My daughter holds my hand as we walk. She wants to talk about her doll’s sickness every day. Not surprisingly, she’s not sure when or if Annabelle will get a test.

headline: Tara Reade’s Sexual Assault Claim Against Joe Biden
abstract: Readers discuss how voters should regard Ms. Reade’s account of a 1993 incident in the Senate building.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Bit of Relief: Tea and Toast
abstract: “Quite honestly, one of the most disheartening things about American life is not the politics, not the incredible social division — it’s the way you make tea.”
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Is Physics on the Wrong Track? And Other Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Matty Simmons, a Force Behind ‘Animal House,’ Is Dead at 93
abstract: He helped get National Lampoon off the ground and was a producer of the Lampoon franchise’s hit movies.
lead_paragraph: Matty Simmons, who helped launch National Lampoon magazine and was instrumental in bringing into being its most famous side project, the 1978 movie “National Lampoon’s Animal House,” died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 93.

headline: May: The Month That Sports, Kind of, Come Back
abstract: This month, fans may finally get a chance to see some real live sports on television, if not in person.
lead_paragraph: The month of April in sports was almost barren. Live events amounted to a ragtag collection of badminton from Armenia, short-format ice hockey from Russia and video games.

headline: Lynn Harrell, Acclaimed American Cellist, Is Dead at 76
abstract: Critics called him a “gentle giant,” a 6-foot-4 internationally renowned musician and frequent soloist whose playing could be sensitive and subtle.
lead_paragraph: Lynn Harrell, a leading American cellist whose acclaimed playing, begun when he was 8 years old, combined robust sound, insightful musicianship and feeling for nuances, died on April 27 at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 76.

headline: The Berlin Philharmonic Tests a Musical Path Out of Lockdown
abstract: The orchestra’s concert on Friday used few players and observed social distancing guidelines.
lead_paragraph: On March 12, the mighty Berlin Philharmonic went ahead with a concert it had scheduled before the coronavirus outbreak. I watched it from my apartment in New York, and it was like little I had ever seen: a livestreamed performance in an empty hall. It was uncanny, and intensely moving, to realize that the only audience was us watching in our homes around the world.

headline: Scholars’ Plea: U.S. and China, Work Together on the Pandemic
abstract: More than 70 scholars urge leaders in Washington and Beijing to put partisan interests aside and coordinate their responses to Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.K. Virus Tests Surpass Target, but Britain’s Deaths May Overtake Italy’s
abstract: There was good news and bad news for Britons on Friday in the statistical barometers of the pandemic, which experts say have become an understandable but misplaced fixation in the country.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For Britons looking to judge their government’s desperate response to the coronavirus pandemic, the verdict has increasingly come down to two numbers: 100,000, the number of tests that officials promised to conduct every day by the end of April; and 27,510, the latest death toll.

headline: Kitchen Confidential: Three Culinary Memoirs
abstract: The passions of these professional foodies — chefs, bloggers, journalists — shine in these new books.
lead_paragraph: EVERYTHING IS UNDER CONTROL

headline: A Texas-Size Reopening Has Many Wondering: Too Much or Not Enough?
abstract: Texas opened a wide range of malls, restaurants and businesses just a day after the state reported its highest death toll from the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Texas pushed its way out of a statewide coronavirus lockdown on Friday, a wide-ranging reopening of restaurants, businesses and beaches in the midst of an ongoing outbreak that still left at least one local official hoping for even more.

headline: Is It Safe to Come Out of Lockdown? Check the Sewer
abstract: Wastewater could provide early, painless and localized data about the rise or fall of coronavirus levels.
lead_paragraph: The world is eager to come out of lockdown. But if countries simply return to business as usual, new outbreaks of Covid-19 will follow. The only solution that public health experts see is to keep careful track of the coronavirus and clamp down on new flare-ups.

headline: The Immunity of the Tech Giants
abstract: When the pandemic is over, we most certainly should fear the industry more than ever.
lead_paragraph: If power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely, how can we best describe the kind of power Big Tech will wield when the coronavirus crisis is over?

headline: Will Biden Play by the Rules?
abstract: Or will Democrats handle Tara Reade’s allegation the way Republicans would?
lead_paragraph: So here we Democrats have it, a nightmare spun from the looms of Steve Bannon’s imagination: The problem of Tara Reade.

headline: Barr Defends Response to Virus in Stormy Twitter Session
abstract: Given a chance to ask questions of the attorney general, many users opted for insults or accusations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr defended the Justice Department’s response to the pandemic on Friday in a rare online question-and-answer session that was marred by vitriolic criticism directed at him over the treatment of inmates in federal prisons ravaged by the coronavirus and other issues.

headline: A Matter of Taste
abstract: 21st century soccer is as much about the pursuit of style as success. But what defines what any of us find good to watch? And do we all have to enjoy the same thing?
lead_paragraph: Enjoying this newsletter? Tell a friend to sign up at nytimes.com/rory and then you’ll have something new to talk about every Friday.

headline: SpaceX to Bring Crew to Short-Staffed Space Station for Longer Stay
abstract: Two NASA astronauts will now stay for more than a month and not two weeks during their first flight aboard the Crew Dragon capsule.
lead_paragraph: What was intended as a two-week test flight of SpaceX’s new astronaut-carrying capsule will now be a mission planned to last more than a month to help a short-handed crew aboard the International Space Station.

headline: Zev Buffman, Prolific Theatrical Producer, Is Dead at 89
abstract: He brought both Elizabeth Taylor (in “The Little Foxes”) and Muhammad Ali (in a memorable flop) to Broadway. He was even busier in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Zev Buffman had been a prominent Broadway producer for two decades when he met Elizabeth Taylor in 1980 at the opening night of his revival of “Brigadoon,” the Lerner and Loewe musical, at the National Theater in Washington.

headline: Lace Up Your Running Shoes
abstract: Whether you’re taking on a new challenge or were training for a canceled race, you can virtually chalk up a personal best.
lead_paragraph: With gyms and spin studios closed, running has become the de facto sport of enthusiastic and reluctant athletes. And as more people find new joy in it, and more die-hard runners see races canceled or postponed, virtual races, in which you record your time for a particular distance via an app and compete against others doing the same, are on the rise.

headline: Kim Jong-un Resurfaces, State Media Says, After Weeks of Health Rumors
abstract: The North Korean leader was said to have visited a factory on Friday, after a series of unsubstantiated news reports suggested that he was gravely ill.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, resurfaced in public view on Friday, the North’s state news media reported Saturday, controverting three weeks of rumors and unconfirmed news reports that he was in grave danger after undergoing heart surgery.

headline: Takuo Aoyagi, an Inventor of the Pulse Oximeter, Dies at 84
abstract: The medical device, which clips onto a patient’s finger, has saved millions of lives and is a vital tool in the fight against the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Takuo Aoyagi, a Japanese engineer whose pioneering work in the 1970s led to the modern pulse oximeter, a lifesaving device that clips on a finger and shows the level of oxygen in the blood and that has become a critical tool in the fight against the novel coronavirus, died on April 18 in Tokyo. He was 84.

headline: Harvard Kept Ties With Jeffrey Epstein After ’08 Conviction, Report Shows
abstract: A university review found that the disgraced financier, who killed himself last year, visited Harvard more than 40 times after he was convicted of sex charges involving a minor in Florida.
lead_paragraph: He had no official Harvard affiliation, yet Jeffrey Epstein had his own office, key card and Harvard phone line. He would often swing by on weekends to host dinners with academics he wanted to meet.

headline: Colleges Won’t Refund Tuition. Autumn May Force a Reckoning.
abstract: Educators at schools from Brown to Northern Arizona know the experience is lacking. So why won’t they give some money back?
lead_paragraph: If you didn’t get what you paid for, and the thing you bought cost five figures, it stands to reason that you’d get some of your money back.

headline: States Reopen, Joe Biden, Street Art: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Think Twice, Mnuchin Tells Prep Schools Seeking Virus Loans
abstract: The Treasury secretary ordered elite schools with “significant endowments” to return loans intended to help small businesses pay employees during the coronavirus pandemic. Some are resisting.
lead_paragraph: As a number of elite private preparatory schools consider taking federal stimulus loans, they received a stark warning on Friday that they risked invoking the ire of the country’s top financial official.

headline: Two Medical Systems, Two Pandemic Responses
abstract: A health economist who has taught on both sides of the border examines the difference between Canada and the United States.
lead_paragraph: After lamenting in a recent Canada Letter about my inability to find an expert who could offer an informed comparison of how the medical systems in Canada and the United States were responding to the coronavirus pandemic, I soon heard from Prof. Peter Berman.

headline: A Onetime Leader of Fox News Returns to the Murdoch Fold
abstract: David Rhodes, a news executive who has held leadership roles at CBS News and Bloomberg, has been advising the media empire’s British operation.
lead_paragraph: David Rhodes, a former Fox News executive who also led CBS News, has quietly begun consulting for Rupert Murdoch’s media empire.

headline: Doctor Who Promoted Malarial Drug Draws Scrutiny of Federal Prosectors
abstract: In an interview, Dr. Vladimir Zelenko said he was guilty of nothing more than sloppy wording.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal prosecutor has opened a preliminary inquiry into whether an obscure New York doctor who won White House attention by claiming he could treat the coronavirus broke the law by falsely claiming that a hospital study of drugs he had promoted had won federal approval.

headline: Marvin Schick, Advocate for the Orthodox Community, Dies at 85
abstract: Because of his work, society began to accommodate those who kept kosher and observed the Sabbath.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Schick, a pioneering advocate for the rights of Orthodox Jews to maintain their religious practices in the places they worked, died on April 23 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 85.

headline: Transcending Space and Time Through Tape
abstract: Audio gems that bring a moment into focus.
lead_paragraph: READER CALLOUT: Want relationship advice from Esther Perel? Submit a question about your personal relationships during the pandemic, and the therapist and author may answer it in a future episode of The Daily.

headline: Some Trump Officials Take Harder Actions on China During Pandemic
abstract: Since the coronavirus spread from a metropolis on the Yangtze River across the globe, hard-liners in both Washington and Beijing have accelerated efforts to decouple elements of the relationship.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some top Trump administration officials are moving to take a more aggressive stand against China on economic, diplomatic and scientific issues at the heart of the relationship between the world’s two superpowers, further fraying ties that have reached their lowest point in decades.

headline: Should Surfing Be Allowed During the Pandemic?
abstract: It has been widely banned, even though it can be therapeutic and done in accordance with social distancing rules.
lead_paragraph: MILL VALLEY, Calif. — Many surfers like me believe that surfing is more than just a sport; we consider it a way of life. Being in the ocean and riding waves can be ecstatic and spiritual.

headline: Olympic Gymnast Recalls Emotional Abuse ‘So Twisted That I Thought It Couldn’t Be Real’
abstract: Laurie Hernandez won medals at the 2016 Games. But she said her love of the sport was tainted under training with Maggie Haney, who is now suspended by the sport’s American federation.
lead_paragraph: For the longest time, Laurie Hernandez, an Olympic champion gymnast, thought she was crazy for thinking that her coach had emotionally abused her.

headline: How Remdesivir, New Hope for Covid-19 Patients, Was Resurrected
abstract: The drug failed as a treatment for hepatitis and Ebola. With federal funding, scientists trained it on the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Remdesivir, an antiviral drug designed to treat both hepatitis and a common respiratory virus, seemed fated to join thousands of other failed medications after proving useless against those diseases. The drug was consigned to the pharmaceutical scrap heap, all but forgotten by the scientists who once championed it.

headline: Blue Bell’s Ex-C.E.O. Charged in Conspiracy to Cover Up Listeria Outbreak
abstract: The ice cream company pleaded guilty and agreed to pay more than $19 million in fines and settlements related to the 2015 episode, federal prosecutors said Friday.
lead_paragraph: The former chief executive of Blue Bell Creameries was charged with conspiracy in connection with his repeated efforts to cover up what became a deadly outbreak of listeria in some of the company’s products in 2015, federal prosecutors said on Friday.

headline: ‘I Will Never Lie to You,’ McEnany Says in First White House Briefing
abstract: But Kayleigh McEnany, the president’s fourth press secretary, found that vow tested almost immediately.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kayleigh McEnany stepped on the podium in the White House Briefing Room on Friday, 417 days since a press secretary for President Trump last held a news briefing, with a promise to the sparse group of journalists allowed in the room under the current social distancing guidelines.

headline: Capitol Lacks Tests for Returning Senators While White House Tests Many in Trump’s Circle
abstract: As senators prepare to return on Monday, Congress’s doctor warned that he does not have the capacity to test all 100 for coronavirus. At the White House, the president and many of his aides are tested repeatedly.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dr. Brian P. Monahan, the tight-lipped doctor who attends to Congress, sent up on Thursday what some have construed as a warning: His office, he told senior Republican officials on a private conference call, cannot screen all 100 senators for the coronavirus when they return to work on Monday.

headline: A Shortage of Steak? Yes, and Ranchers Knew It Was Coming
abstract: The pandemic has laid bare the instability of the industrialized food chain.
lead_paragraph: PERKINS COUNTY, S.D. — I live on a ranch. When I stand on the gravel road that runs along the section line by my house I can look in any direction across the waving grass and, other than the modest huddle of buildings and fencing that compose our ranch, see little evidence of human development. To say it is remote is like saying water is wet. We aren’t Iowa remote or Wisconsin remote. This is the American steppe, where the population density is one person per square mile.

headline: As Businesses Resurface After State Shutdowns, So Does Divisiveness
abstract: Nearly a dozen states resumed portions of public life as a debate over the safety and timing of reopening grew louder.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Texas lifted stay-at-home orders for its 29 million residents. Hair salons in Maine welcomed customers back inside. In Alabama, clothing boutiques flung open their doors.

headline: U.S. Women’s Soccer Team’s Equal Pay Demands Are Dismissed by Judge
abstract: The players’ claims about unequal working conditions can continue, but the ruling was a serious blow to a yearslong campaign by the women.
lead_paragraph: The judge in the United States women’s soccer team’s equal pay lawsuit rejected the players’ most important claims on Friday, delivering a crushing blow to the team’s four-year legal campaign against the United States Soccer Federation.

headline: ‘No One Needs Botox in a Pandemic.’ But Some in Beverly Hills Are Now Getting It.
abstract: The city on Tuesday rescinded a moratorium on elective surgery, clearing the way for some cosmetic surgeons to reopen.
lead_paragraph: With a hoodie over her ears, a surgical mask over her nose and an eye on the clock — “I have four boys under the age of 12, and they’re home-schooling” — 42-year-old Ally Sample was making up for lost time at her Beverly Hills plastic surgeon’s office on Friday.

headline: Wild Ideas to Bring Back Sports Might Say More About Cities Than Leagues
abstract: MGM Resorts International, in hard-hit Las Vegas, has proposed audacious plans to the leagues to come back in a quarantined environment.
lead_paragraph: Sports leagues are desperate for a safe way to start playing games again. Las Vegas has tens of thousands of empty hotel rooms and a tourism-based economy that has been wracked by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Who Knows Where the Time Goes
abstract: We are all in a box, and in those boxes we are grieving.
lead_paragraph: Absent any other marker, nature indicates the passage of time. Daffodils and hyacinths give way to roses. Blossoms fall, new leaves bud, pink petals are gone from empty New York streets. Frozen figures in rumpled clothes may note some slight change in the canvas. Who knows where the time goes?

headline: Judge Vacates Oil and Gas Leases on 145,000 Acres in Montana
abstract: A federal judge, rapping the Trump administration for its weak environmental assessments, has vacated hundreds of oil and gas leases across a large swath of Montana.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Friday vacated 287 oil and gas leases on almost 150,000 acres of land in Montana, ruling that the Trump administration had improperly issued the leases to energy companies in 2017 and 2018.

headline: Native American Tribes Sue Treasury Over Stimulus Aid as They Feud Over Funding
abstract: A dispute among native populations over $8 billion in federal coronavirus relief has delayed aid to tribes that are among the hardest-hit by Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A group of Native American tribes is suing the Treasury Department for failing to provide billions of dollars in coronavirus relief allocated for tribes in the $2.2 trillion stimulus package, setting off one of the most significant legal battles between tribal governments and the United States in years.

headline: Joe Biden and the Presumption of Innocence
abstract: Being heard is not, and should never be, the same thing as being believed.
lead_paragraph: Regarding Tara Reade’s allegation that she was sexually assaulted by Joe Biden in 1993, and what the allegation could mean for Democrats this fall, some stock phrases come to mind. Hoisted on their own petard. What’s sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander. Be careful what you wish for.

headline: What Does Modern Love Mean in a Pandemic?
abstract: At first we thought the column could be a break from the coronavirus. A flood of submissions told us that wasn’t possible.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Investigate Tara Reade’s Allegations
abstract: Americans deserve to know more about a sexual assault accusation against the likely Democratic Party nominee.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joe Biden, the Democrats’ presumptive nominee for president, has forcefully denied allegations of sexual harassment and assault made against him by Tara Reade, a former staff assistant in his Senate office.

headline: Poker-Faced
abstract: Paolo Pasco’s Saturday puzzle protects its mysteries.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a really cool-looking and inviting grid from Paolo Pasco; it might be a slightly sloppy smiley face, or a postmodern dollar sign. The actual solve is hard to break into, but the middle portion winds up being pretty doable. The stepping stacks at the top and bottom are almost all debuts, including a bit of lingo, so you need a good ear for catchphrases and a little luck to finish.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Risky New Phase Brings Discord and Unease
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 2, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “It is like having a smoking section on a plane or in a restaurant. It doesn’t work.”

headline: Trump Moves to Replace Watchdog Who Identified Critical Medical Shortages
abstract: The president announced the nomination of an inspector general for the Department of Health and Human Services, who, if confirmed, would replace an acting official whose report embarrassed Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump moved on Friday night to replace a top official at the Department of Health and Human Services who angered him with a report last month highlighting supply shortages and testing delays at hospitals during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Photos of Life Transformed by a Pandemic
abstract: People are seeking a bit of normalcy as governments wrestle with the shutdowns aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Restaurants are receiving patrons into dining rooms that are partially cordoned off for social distancing, friends are seeking safe conversation in the sunshine and some people are trying to continue a productive path forward in isolation.

headline: Corrections: May 2, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 2, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the overnight closing of New York’s subway referred imprecisely to the city’s public transit schedule. It is the only system in the United States that runs all of its train lines 24 hours a day; it is not the only system in the country to operate 24 hours a day.

headline: As Restrictions Lift, Countries Brace for a New Reality
abstract: As lockdowns begin to ease for millions of Europeans, Italy reports a spike in deaths. Migrants face roundups in Malaysia and surging infections in Singapore’s dormitories.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Beanpole’ and ‘The Half of It’
abstract: A gripping historical drama comes to Mubi, while a coming-of-age tale streams on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: BEANPOLE (2020) Stream on Mubi; rent on Kino Now. The young Russian director Kantemir Balagov wowed critics with this, his sophomore feature, a drama set in Leningrad in 1945. World War II is over, but the wounds it sowed are still fresh and apparent in every frame. Iya (Viktoria Miroshnichenko), nicknamed Beanpole because she is unusually tall, was once on the front lines, but a concussion made her unfit for battle. Now she tends to soldiers at a military hospital and cares for the child of her friend and former fellow soldier, Masha (Vasilisa Perelygina), who returns to the city only to hear devastating news. Together, the women try to heal themselves and find hope. Manohla Dargis named the movie a Critic’s Pick in her review for The New York Times, calling it “a brilliantly told, deeply moving story about love — in all its manifestations, perversity and obstinacy.”

headline: With No Kentucky Derby, Live and Virtual Substitutes Emerge
abstract: The Kentucky Derby was originally scheduled for Saturday. An animated race airing on NBC may be the most prominent replacement, even though horses will race elsewhere in the country.
lead_paragraph: There will be a derby on Saturday. Three of them, in fact. Churchill Downs is hosting a virtual Kentucky Derby, one pitting all 13 Triple Crown winners against one another in a simulated race, while Oaklawn Park will run the Arkansas Derby. Twice.

headline: Track Where Your Money Goes
abstract: First step, actually open up those bank and credit card statements.
lead_paragraph: Where does your money go each month? Now, especially, with financial goals and priorities in flux, it’s important to know in granular detail.

headline: French Muslims Face a Cruel Coronavirus Shortage: Burial Grounds
