abstract: For many immigrant families, the pandemic has halted the tradition of repatriating bodies to their country of origin, and finding a plot in France has become ever more difficult.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The middle-aged men, some wearing masks and gloves, leaned over a freshly excavated grave and gingerly slid a coffin into it. Arching their backs and bending their knees, they were burying a 60-year-old French-Moroccan woman in the Muslim section of a cemetery in a town north of Paris.

headline: Kim Jong-un Is Back. What Happens When He’s Really Gone?
abstract: Weeks of speculation about Mr. Kim’s health brought home an alarming fact: No one knows who will control North Korea, or its nuclear weapons, should he die.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, reappeared in dramatic fashion this weekend when he was shown on North Korean media after three weeks of unexplained absence, cutting the ribbon on a fertilizer factory — and quieting rumors that he was gravely ill.

headline: With Over Two Dozen Deaths, London Bus Drivers Fear Coronavirus Risk
abstract: At least 28 bus drivers have died since the coronavirus outbreak began. And while new measures have been put in place to protect them, some worry it’s too little, too late.
lead_paragraph: London is a city gone quiet. Yet, with a stringent coronavirus lockdown in place and the normal bustle largely halted, bold red buses are still winding their way through the sprawling capital offering frequent service.

headline: A Wedding Under the St. Louis Arch
abstract: Sean Gottlieb and Matthew Kerns met, fell in love, intended to marry in New Orleans. And then the coronavirus made them think very soberly about their options.
lead_paragraph: Sean Gottlieb and Matthew Kerns met for the first time on gay pride day last year in St. Louis, after finding each other on Scruff, a site that helps gay men connect.

headline: Their Perfect Date: April 25 (and Each Other)
abstract: They and their officiant rode their bicycles to their wedding in Stuyvesant Cove Park along the East River in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Ariel Ball and Ross Weinstein held fast to their original wedding date, and were married April 25 in Stuyvesant Cove Park along the East River in Manhattan. Mark Stokely, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, rode his bicycle from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to officiate.

headline: A Delayed Yes From Each of Them
abstract: The couple met in 2016 in Bedford Hills, N.Y., on a Thanksgiving weekend, and married in Quebec, Canada, in April.
lead_paragraph: Adrianna Kruyt, a Canadian in the first year of graduate studies in Manhattan at the New School, didn’t have plans for Thanksgiving in 2016. So her parents arranged for her to spend the long weekend celebrating the American holiday with friends in Bedford Hills, N.Y.

headline: Standing on a Step Stool to Kiss the Groom
abstract: A 5 foot 4 lawyer and a 6 foot 5 physicist were first taken by each other’s smile.
lead_paragraph: Martin Schmaltz, a physics professor at Boston University, preferred to study the rate of the expansion of the universe over dating.

headline: Seeing an Old Friend With New Eyes
abstract: Ebba Palmstierna and Bennett Eastham first met in 2008 when she was a foreign exchange student living on his family’s farm.
lead_paragraph: When Bennett Eastham needed a mental-health break last June from working long hours at a Virginia law firm, he made plans to travel to Copenhagen to see Andrew Bird, an American singer, perform there.

headline: They Shrunk a 450-Plus Guest List. For Now.
abstract: Ayana Coston and Clinton Jordan Jr. were forced to significantly scale down their wedding plans, but still hope to eventually have a big reception.
lead_paragraph: Ayana Coston and Clinton Jordan Jr., friends for 17 years who began dating about 18 months ago, had set a wedding date for May 23 with a guest list that kept growing.

headline: Melville’s Whale Was a Warning We Failed to Heed
abstract: “Moby-Dick” contained the author’s diagnosis, prognosis and prescription for the human condition. We didn’t listen.
lead_paragraph: In 1841, while aboard the whaler Acushnet, Herman Melville met William Chase among another ship’s complement. William lent Melville a book by his father, Owen Chase: “Narrative of the Most Extraordinary and Distressing Shipwreck of the Whale-Ship Essex.” Melville had read Jeremiah Reynolds’s violent account of a sperm whale “white as wool,” named — for his haunt near Mocha Island, off the coast of Chile — Mocha Dick. It’s unknown what led Melville to tweak Mocha to “Moby.” Good thing he did, and that Starbuck was the name he gave his first mate rather than his captain. Otherwise the novel would follow Starbuck’s obsession with a Mocha.

headline: New York Is Wounded. I Miss It More Than Ever.
abstract: A former city reporter went to the Middle East, looking for the big story. Now she yearns for the city she thought she was happy to leave behind.
lead_paragraph: I live in Beirut, Lebanon, but in this season of confinement I could be anywhere. I have left my apartment eight times in six weeks; my brushes with the city where I’ve lived for a year and a half are so brief, I forgot that I lived near the sea until I went up on a roof and my eyes confronted the blue fact of the Mediterranean. In my apartment, with friends nine time zones away as accessible as friends down the block, I Zoom far and wide. I could be anywhere, but some part of me wants to be in New York.

headline: Stark Symbol of Pandemic in N.Y.: Homeless People Huddled on the Subway
abstract: New Yorkers with no better place to go keep riding and sleeping on otherwise empty trains, stirring public health fears and prompting a nightly shutdown for cleaning.
lead_paragraph: Every No. 2 train that lumbered into the last stop in the Bronx late Wednesday night had, at most, a couple of dozen passengers. And when the doors swooshed open, half of them had no intention of getting off.

headline: Married Doctors Learn to Meet in the Middle
abstract: Monique Collier Nickles and Leroy Nickles, physicians on the front line of the coronavirus pandemic, share why it’s more important than ever to have frequent relationship check-ins.
lead_paragraph: Because marriage is an ever-evolving experience, we constantly shift, change and, in some cases, start over. In It’s No Secret, couples share thoughts about commitment and tell us what they have learned, revealing their secret to making it work. (Answers are edited for context and space.)

headline: Is This the Future of the Fashion Show?
abstract: The first “high fashion runway show entirely from home” just took place, complete with famous models and designers. The clothes were the least of it.
lead_paragraph: The next round of fashion shows will be virtual fashion shows. This is not in doubt.

headline: ‘Murder Hornets’ in the U.S.: The Rush to Stop the Asian Giant Hornet
abstract: Sightings of the Asian giant hornet have prompted fears that the vicious insect could establish itself in the United States and devastate bee populations.
lead_paragraph: BLAINE, Wash. — In his decades of beekeeping, Ted McFall had never seen anything like it.

headline: Play This: The Paperback Game
abstract: All you need is some pulp fiction and a good imagination.
lead_paragraph: My family didn’t invent the paperback game (I don’t know who did), but we’ve played it for years. It’s for four to 10 people and perfect for lockdown. You can play at the table after dinner, after the dishes have been cleared and everyone is loosened up. An Earl Hines record on in the background sets the mood perfectly. Here’s how to play:

headline: 9/11 Prisoners May Get Video Chats to Bridge the Coronavirus Divide
abstract: With the Sept. 11 hearings delayed, prosecutors and defenders are looking for ways to let lawyers talk with the prisoners at Guantánamo Bay.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

headline: Jewish Characters Star in Saudi TV Show, Igniting an Arab Debate
abstract: Fans have praised a hit TV series for promoting religious diversity. Critics say it encourages “normalization” with Israel and betrays the Palestinian cause.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In a mud-walled village in the Persian Gulf, a Christian woman sheds tears of love for a Muslim merchant. But he is stuck in a miserable marriage to a woman who longs for another Muslim man. But she can’t have him, because he is crazy about the local rabbi’s daughter.

headline: After a Lifetime Together, Coronavirus Takes Them Both
abstract: Across the country, reports are surfacing of long-term couples dying from Covid-19 in quick succession, redoubling the pain for those they leave behind.
lead_paragraph: For most of her life, Maranda Lender, 32, has lived with her parents in Lewisberry, Pa.

headline: Fearing Political Peril, Republicans Edge Away From Trump on Pandemic Response
abstract: Moderate Republicans in competitive districts are navigating a careful balance in addressing the coronavirus crisis, eager to put some distance between themselves and a president whose response has been criticized.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Every evening from his kitchen table in southwestern Michigan, Representative Fred Upton, a moderate Republican running for his 18th term in office, posts a coronavirus dispatch for his constituents, highlighting his own efforts to respond to the crisis and the news from Washington, often with cameos from Democrats.

headline: My Retirement Plan Is You
abstract: Americans without retirement savings are increasingly moving in with their millennial children.
lead_paragraph: Sian-Pierre Regis, 35, is used to living with roommates. For the past 10 years, he has split the rent on his apartment in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan with two (in some cases, three) friends. But in June, he’s getting a co-tenant of a different sort: his 78-year-old mother, Rebecca Danigelis.

headline: ‘I Could Solve Most of Your Problems’: Eric Schmidt’s Pentagon Offensive
abstract: The former Google C.E.O. has reinvented himself as the prime liaison between Silicon Valley and the military-industrial complex.
lead_paragraph: In July 2016, Raymond Thomas, a four-star general and head of the U.S. Special Operations Command, hosted a guest: Eric Schmidt, the chairman of Google.

headline: Antarctica vs. Science
abstract: For researchers using delicate, one-of-a-kind equipment, the extreme conditions at the bottom of the planet pose special challenges.
lead_paragraph: At the start of January, the same month the world marked the 200th anniversary of the discovery of Antarctica, scientists on snowmobiles were zipping across its diamantine ice, dragging a rig of metal detectors in their wake. Researchers were hoping to discover a hypothesized cache of iron-rich meteorites, the remnants of ancient asteroids and would-be planets, under the frozen wastes.

headline: A Family Rallied on 2 Continents as a Loved One Fought Covid-19
abstract: Family members gathered on conference calls to send her messages of courage, and prayed together for a miracle.
lead_paragraph: Family members gathered on conference calls to send her messages of courage, and prayed together for a miracle.

headline: Grandma Rocket, the Virus and a Family Whose Love Bridged 2,500 Miles
abstract: A matriarch to generations, both in the United States and Colombia, she struggled with the coronavirus on a ventilator. They gathered online and in the I.C.U. to prepare for the end.
lead_paragraph: When Eliana Marcela Rendón was finally able to visit her grandmother, who had spent four weeks at a Long Island hospital, a staff member met her in the lobby to ask if the 74-year-old patient had a favorite song.

headline: Can Golden Boy Bring Boxing Back?
abstract: Oscar De La Hoya has a hope — live boxing on July 4, probably with no fans, but a 10-card event to get the sport back. The fighters he promotes are training in garages and living rooms.
lead_paragraph: Oscar De La Hoya, the boxing champion turned promoter, spends a part of each day running up and down his half-mile long driveway in Pasadena, Calif., to stay in shape.

headline: Relaxed Rules and Warm Weather Test States
abstract: Congress declined the administration’s offer of rapid testing, saying tests were needed more elsewhere. Former President George W. Bush urged unity in a video message.
lead_paragraph: Warmer weekend temperatures and fatigue over weeks of confinement lured millions of Americans outside on Saturday, adding to the pressure on city and state officials to enforce, or loosen, restrictions imposed to limit the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Coronavirus Deaths in New York Increase Slightly, Cuomo Says
abstract: Balmy weather in the New York area brought flocks of people to parks, presenting a challenge for efforts to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo arrived on Saturday to the New York City Transit’s Corona Maintenance Facility in Queens to deliver a sliver of bad news in the fight against the coronavirus: The state’s daily death toll went up slightly after a consistent decline in the past few days.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway Lost $49.7 Billion in First Quarter Stung by Coronavirus
abstract: The huge loss reflects the hit that the crisis has inflicted on Warren E. Buffett’s vast conglomerate.
lead_paragraph: Not even Warren E. Buffett was spared financially from the coronavirus, as his conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway, reported a $49.7 billion loss in the first quarter on Saturday, reflecting the outbreak’s toll on an investment portfolio that includes big stakes in major airlines and financial firms.

headline: Filmmaker Who Mocked Egypt’s President Dies in Prison
abstract: Shady Habash had been held without trial at a maximum-security prison for two years. His lawyer said the cause of death was unknown.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian filmmaker imprisoned over a music video that mocked President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi died at a maximum-security facility on Friday after two years in detention without trial, his lawyer said.

headline: Put Your Children to Work
abstract: Also: why some parents are giving their kids CBD.
lead_paragraph: As noted earlier this week, I do not enjoy generating fun for my children. So I was very pleased to read our piece from Michaeleen Doucleff, an NPR correspondent who has spent years reporting on how different cultures around the world raise cooperative and generous children. “In these cultures, you find a striking commonality: Mothers and fathers do not feel the need to constantly entertain and play with children,” Michaeleen wrote. “Instead parents give children an opportunity that many American kids do not have — to participate in adult work.” How do we get our American children to behave this way? She has suggestions.

headline: Houston Helicopter Crash Kills 1 Police Officer and Injures Another
abstract: The officers were investigating a report of bodies in a bayou when the helicopter crashed near an apartment building, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A Houston police officer was killed and another critically injured after their helicopter crashed early Saturday morning as they were responding to a report of bodies in a bayou, the city’s police chief said.

headline: 41 Classic Dishes You Should Master
abstract: Simplest roast chicken, chocolate chip cookies and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: It might be time to brush up on some of the basics: Mark Bittman’s simplest roast chicken, Alison Roman’s eggs Benedict (above), Julia Moskin’s classic French toast and more recipes in the collection below.

headline: No More Jenga, No More ‘Amen’ as Cities Learn to Live With Coronavirus
abstract: In parts of Asia and Australia, people are going out — but social distancing and other restrictions have become the new normal.
lead_paragraph: Worshipers at one of Seoul’s largest Catholic churches must refrain from singing hymns or saying “amen” for fear of spreading saliva. Priests sanitize their hands during communion. Holy water has been removed from the chapel.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Daniel Rayman’s cryptic puzzle dances into Sunday.
lead_paragraph: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — For the record, I declared 2020 the Year of the Cryptic Crossword well before we got quarantined, and now there are still more reasons to show them some love.   Many of us find that our lives are moving at a slower pace, perfect for mulling and letting the problem-solving part of our brain get a chance to work with less commotion.

headline: Let’s (Not) Shake on It
abstract: The simple handshake, once an offer of peace, now carries a threat of contagion.
lead_paragraph: Handshaking for self-protection became anachronistic long before Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation’s leading infectious-disease expert, said wistfully in early April that as far as even greeting one another, “we may never shake hands again.” As a personal defense mechanism and for sealing deals, though, it was outdated as soon as people began openly brandishing guns and hiring lawyers to vet contracts.

headline: The War Between Middle Schoolers and Their Parents Ends Now
abstract: The coronavirus lockdown is an opportunity for a reset.
lead_paragraph: Millions of American parents are now stuck at home with their middle schoolers and becoming intimately reacquainted, in far too close quarters, with the look, smell and feel of life — 24/7 — in the sixth, seventh and eighth grades.

headline: The Father I Never Forgave
abstract: He left my life when I needed him most. And then he came back.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1980, I was 7 years old and crazy about the Pittsburgh Pirates. The team had won the World Series the year before, and because the Steelers won the Super Bowl in 1979 and 1980, people started calling the place “City of Champions.” To a kid, this was the center of the world.

headline: How Do You Fight the Coronavirus Without Running Water?
abstract: Entire communities around the country face this terrifying virus without being even able to wash their hands.
lead_paragraph: Several weeks ago, Larry Welch and his mother, Mary Ann, contracted Covid-19 and died. In the midst of a pandemic in which one of the first lines of defense is vigorous hand washing, they were among more than two million Americans who lack running water.

headline: The New Great Depression Is Coming. Will There Be a New New Deal?
abstract: After the coronavirus, political transformation may be inevitable.
lead_paragraph: Until very recently, Andrew Yang thought that the need for a universal basic income would be a big issue in the 2024 election, as “many of the trends that I campaigned on were going to become completely clear to more and more Americans” over the next four years. He was arguing, for example, that between now and then, “30 percent of our stores and malls were going to close because of Amazon.”

headline: Some Small Businesses That Got Aid Fear the Rules Too Much to Spend It
abstract: Requirements for using federal coronavirus loans are complicated and confusing for owners. “It’s chaos,” one lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: When a $192,000 loan from the federal government’s small-business aid program arrived in his bank account last month, George Evageliou, the founder of a custom woodworking company, felt like one of the lucky ones.

headline: Exiled Pakistani Journalist Found Dead in Sweden
abstract: The police said an initial investigation did not suggest foul play in the death of Sajid Hussain, but journalism groups expressed skepticism and concern.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD — A Pakistani journalist forced into exile in Sweden after covering violence, crime and a simmering insurgency in his home country was found dead on Friday in a river north of Stockholm, the Swedish police said.

headline: Go Ahead, Blow Out the Candles on Zoom
abstract: You or your loved one is another year older no matter what, so why not celebrate?
lead_paragraph: In a strange twist, a pandemic birthday party might actually be the easiest party you ever throw.

headline: Votes, Deployment and Now Parenthood in the Middle of a Pandemic
abstract: Representative Max Rose of New York and his wife welcomed a son and are now juggling parenthood and Congress during the age of coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers gathered in the well of the House in the early hours of March 14 to vote on a sweeping coronavirus relief bill, Representative Max Rose, Democrat of New York, felt that the pandemic that had already begun spreading through the ranks of Congress was about to upend life as he knew it.

headline: The Allegation Is Against Joe Biden, but the Burden Is on Women
abstract: Even with the progress of #MeToo, women are called upon to defend their male colleagues. In the 2020 election, that can mean putting the movement itself on the line.
lead_paragraph: He may not have been their first choice.

headline: Peter Jonas, Innovative Opera Impresario, Is Dead at 73
abstract: He ran first the English National Opera and then the Bavarian State Opera, emphasizing vibrant theatrical interpretations as well as high musical values.
lead_paragraph: Peter Jonas, an impresario who turned the English National Opera in London and the Bavarian State Opera in Munich into influential hotbeds of innovation, died on April 22 in Munich. He was 73.

headline: Profits and Pride at Stake, the Race for a Vaccine Intensifies
abstract: Governments, companies and academic labs are accelerating their efforts amid geopolitical crosscurrents, questions about safety and the challenges of producing enough doses for billions of people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four months after a mysterious new virus began its deadly march around the globe, the search for a vaccine has taken on an intensity never before seen in medical research, with huge implications for public health, the world economy and politics.

headline: 10 Florists Delivering Vibrant Bouquets for Mother’s Day
abstract: During this time of self-isolation, when the floral industry, too, is hurting, a colorful missive feels more meaningful than ever.
lead_paragraph: Sending flowers on Mother’s Day has long been a way to convey closeness despite physical distance. Now, with many people self-isolating away from their families, this small act feels especially poignant. But as businesses have closed on account of the coronavirus, and as events have been postponed or canceled, the demand for flowers has withered and growers have been forced to destroy millions of blooms. “Flowers are a very low-margin, high-labor, perishable medium, and our supply chains are complex and vulnerable,” explains the Manhattan-based floral designer Emily Thompson, who hopes to reopen soon.

headline: Can U.S. Soccer and Its Women’s Team Make Peace on Equal Pay?
abstract: A federal judge’s rejection of the players’ equal pay claims cost the team their leverage, but it is in the federation’s interests to find a settlement both sides can embrace.
lead_paragraph: After a federal judge dismissed the equal pay claims of the World Cup-winning women’s national team on Friday night, it was not the words in the United States Soccer Federation’s response that stuck out. It was the ones that weren’t there.

headline: Afghanistan Investigating Claims Migrants Were Killed by Iranian Guards
abstract: About 50 Afghan migrants crossing into Iran illegally were beaten and thrown into a river, local news media and witnesses say. As many as half did not survive, they said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The foreign ministry of Afghanistan on Saturday said it was investigating claims that dozens of Afghan migrants detained in Iran were tortured by that country’s border guards and thrown into a river, where many of them drowned.

headline: A 27-Year-Old Doctor’s Fight Against Coronavirus
abstract: Dr. Andres Maldonado was on the front lines treating patients. Then he got sick too.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Andres Maldonado was on the front lines treating patients. Then he got sick too.

headline: Joe Says It Ain’t So
abstract: With partisan goggles, we plunge back into the muck.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of my quarantine diversions was revisiting the first season of “Mad Men,” where women in the workplace were sexual playthings and where a young woman’s assay at writing ad copy was so unorthodox that it was, as one ad man marveled, like watching a dog play the piano.

headline: Did Closing Schools Actually Help?
abstract: Researchers have a plan to find out.
lead_paragraph: As different countries and states tentatively start reopening their economies, there seems to be no clear plan, and no clear way to figure out which of the lockdown measures made a difference in slowing the spread of Covid-19.

headline: She Predicted the Coronavirus. What Does She Foresee Next?
abstract: Laurie Garrett, the prophet of this pandemic, expects years of death and “collective rage.”
lead_paragraph: I told Laurie Garrett that she might as well change her name to Cassandra. Everyone is calling her that anyway.

headline: A Young Doctor, Fighting for His Life
abstract: “I just went down on my knees,” his mother recalled later. “I just implored God for mercy.”
lead_paragraph: Dr. Andres Maldonado normally bounded into the Emergency Department, fit and vigorous, but this time he had to be escorted in, pale and fighting for breath, with a patient bracelet on his right wrist. A nurse, seeing her colleague struggle, burst into tears.

headline: How Coronavirus Made Our Church Stronger
abstract: We may not be able to worship together, but that doesn’t mean we can’t act in concert.
lead_paragraph: In public life we spend a lot of time talking about what should be done. When it comes to who should do it, the discussion often becomes an impersonal, contentious and dehumanizing debate that reduces people to “the poor” or “the middle class” or “the 1 percent.” No one really likes it, but that’s the way we talk about politics.

headline: Balmy Weekend Presents a Challenge: New Yorkers Rushing to Parks
abstract: After weeks spent indoors, people ventured outside in droves. But worried officials warned them to wear masks and keep social distance.
lead_paragraph: On the second day of May, New Yorkers were greeted with sunny skies and the warmest weekend so far this spring. People got up off their couch, put on their shoes, donned their face coverings, and left their cramped houses and apartments for the nearest park — desperate for fresh air and a little exercise.

headline: ‘We Had to Do Something’: Trying to Prevent Massive Food Waste
abstract: Some producers acknowledge the efforts are “just a drop in the bucket” of what farmers can’t sell and are destroying instead.
lead_paragraph: While millions of Americans are worried about having enough to eat and lines at food banks grow, farmers have been plowing under vegetable fields, dumping milk and smashing eggs that cannot be sold because the coronavirus pandemic has shut down restaurants, hotels and schools.

headline: Pence’s Virus Role Enhances His Profile While Showing Limits of His Influence
abstract: “Task forces and vice presidents don’t get to decide things,” said Tim Pawlenty, the former Minnesota governor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The paradox of Vice President Mike Pence getting in trouble for failing to wear a mask is that perhaps no member of the Trump administration is more shrouded behind an invisible one of his own making.

headline: Kansas Primary Election Results 2020
abstract: Detailed results from the Kansas presidential primary election.
lead_paragraph: Detailed results from the Kansas presidential primary election.

headline: Shifting Sounds
abstract: Ben Zimmer makes his crossword debut, with Brendan Emmett Quigley, and it’s no stroll in the park!
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is probably a celebrity puzzle for a lot of word lovers out there; Ben Zimmer is a prolific writer on language, formerly at the Times, currently at The Wall Street Journal and The Atlantic. According to Will Shortz’s print introduction, Mr. Zimmer and Brendan Emmett Quigley met about 12 years ago while working on the Visual Thesaurus. (Mr. Zimmer had a column there as well, “Word Routes,” which we have cited before in Wordplay.) This grid is a collaboration from start to finish, a fusion of two maven brains on a molecular level, if you will.

headline: Hamilton Bohannon, Driving Disco Drummer, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Bohannon’s steady four-on-the-floor beat kept dancers moving, and many of his tracks became hip-hop samples long after disco’s heyday.
lead_paragraph: Hamilton Bohannon, a drummer whose disco records propelled people onto dance floors in the 1970s and ’80s, and then lived on as popular samples for major hip-hop artists, died on April 24 at his home in Atlanta. He was 78.

headline: Tony Allen, Drummer Who Created the Beat of Afrobeat, Dies at 79
abstract: With the Nigerian bandleader Fela and later on his own, he merged West African styles with American jazz and funk, reaching listeners worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Tony Allen, the drummer who created the steadfast, subtle beat of the Nigerian protest funk known as Afrobeat, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 79.

headline: Was That a Cough? Going Back to the Movies in Texas
abstract: A few movie theaters in Texas opened on Saturday, early experiments in back-to-normal living after a long coronavirus lockdown.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — It happened early inside the cool, darkened cineplex, before Vin Diesel even had a chance to turn superhuman, as people sat munching popcorn and sipping sodas in their plush recliner seats.

headline: Colorado Paramedic Who Came to Help New York Dies From Covid-19
abstract: For three weeks, Paul Cary transported coronavirus patients to hospitals by ambulance. He had already signed up for a second 30-day deployment in New York when he started feeling sick.
lead_paragraph: On the same day that New York City’s 911 dispatchers fielded a volume of calls not seen since the Sept. 11 attacks, Paul Cary, a paramedic, set out for the nearly 1,800-mile drive from Denver to New York City in an ambulance.

headline: N.F.L. Players Union Will Review Disability Benefits
abstract: Under the collective bargaining agreement ratified in March, more than 400 retired players are set to see reductions to their monthly benefits.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. Players Association announced plans to review provisions in the collective bargaining agreement ratified in March that are set to take away tens of thousands of dollars in benefits from permanently disabled former players.

headline: Hotel Group Will Return Tens of Millions in Small Business Loans
abstract: Ashford Inc., which has come under scrutiny after receiving at least $70 million in Paycheck Protection Program loans, said on Saturday that it would return the money.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest beneficiaries of the government’s small business lending program said on Saturday that its companies will return at least $70 million in loans received through the Paycheck Protection Program.

headline: Antivaccination Activists Are Growing Force at Virus Protests
abstract: Public health experts fear that their messaging could further harm the country’s response to the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The protest on Friday in Sacramento urging California’s governor to reopen the state resembled the rallies that have appeared elsewhere in the country, with crowds flocking to the State Capitol, pressing leaders to undo restrictions on businesses and daily life.

headline: Sam Lloyd, ‘Scrubs’ Actor, Dies at 56
abstract: Mr. Lloyd appeared in dozens of television shows and films in his career, including “Seinfeld,” “Modern Family” and “The West Wing.”
lead_paragraph: Sam Lloyd, a longtime television and film actor who appeared in the television shows “Scrubs” and “Desperate Housewives,” died on Thursday at the Barlow Respiratory Hospital  in Los Angeles. He was 56.

headline: North and South Korea Exchange Gunfire Across Demilitarized Zone
abstract: The reports of gunfire came two days after the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, reappeared in public after three weeks of absence and rumors about his health.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Gunshots fired from North Korea struck a guard post in South Korea on Sunday inside the Demilitarized Zone separating the two countries, and South Korean soldiers fired back, the South’s military said.

headline: Pompeo Blames Wuhan Lab for Coronavirus As Backlash Against China Grows
abstract: European plans for reopening have prompted protests and sown confusion, and the band U2 has helped get protective gear to Ireland.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus pandemic here.

headline: Quotation of the Day: As Last refuge for Homeless, Subway Is Risk
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 3, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “At the end of the day, we understand that this is a very dangerous situation people are going through. But before this, homeless people were already going through a dangerous situation.”

headline: George W. Bush Calls for End to Pandemic Partisanship
abstract: In a video, the former president, who generally avoids speaking out on current affairs, urged Americans to “remember how small our differences are” in a time of crisis. President Trump swiped at him in response.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President George W. Bush called on Americans on Saturday to put aside partisan differences, heed the guidance of medical professionals and show empathy for those stricken by the coronavirus and the resulting economic devastation.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Billions’ and ‘Westworld’
abstract: Paul Giamatti and Damian Lewis return for the fifth run of Showtime’s drama, while the third season of HBO’s sci-fi series wraps up.
lead_paragraph: BILLIONS 9 p.m. on Showtime. “Billions,” a critics’ darling about power politics and high finance in New York, returns just in time to fill the “Homeland”-shaped void in Showtime’s schedule. Last season’s détente between the federal government watchdog Chuck (Paul Giamatti) and the hedge-fund king Axe (Damian Lewis) did not last long. In Season 5, the pair are yet again determined to take each other down, while new foes complicate matters. Julianna Margulies (“The Good Wife”) and Corey Stoll (“House of Cards”) join the show as recurring cast members. She plays a professor and author on sex and relationships; he takes the role of a social impact pioneer that challenges Axe’s power. And as Chuck butts heads with a dogged district attorney (Roma Maffia), his increasingly independent wife, Wendy (Maggie Siff), forges unexpected alliances.

headline: ‘As I Came Up the Stairs to Street Level, I Spied a Shining Lincoln Head’
abstract: A lucky penny in Midtown, navigating slushy streets and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: One Bright Thing: Reader Edition
abstract: After 18 of our writers shared a silver lining during the pandemic, more than 300 people sent in submissions of their own luminous moments. Here’s a selection.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: As Putin Dallies, Russia’s Small Businesses Are Withering Away
abstract: The Russian president, who seems to share the traditional Soviet view of entrepreneurs as “swindlers,” is doing little to help them through a coronavirus lockdown.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Two weeks into the coronavirus lockdown, Aleksandr B. Zatulivetrov, a Russian businessman, had had enough.

headline: Andy Warhol, Superstar
abstract: Blake Gopnik’s mammoth biography traces the life and career of the original King of Pop.
lead_paragraph: WARHOL

headline: Concert for One: I.C.U. Doctor Brings Classical Music to Coronavirus Patients
abstract: Dr. Rachel Easterwood, a professionally trained musician-turned-physician, has found a unique way to help her patients with Covid-19 — live classical music concerts.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Rachel Easterwood, a professionally trained musician-turned-physician, has found a unique way to help her patients with Covid-19 — live classical music concerts.

headline: The Coronavirus Becomes a Battle Cry for U.S. Extremists
abstract: White supremacists seek to stoke the fear and disruption caused by the pandemic to push their agenda and to recruit.
lead_paragraph: America’s extremists are attempting to turn the coronavirus pandemic into a potent recruiting tool both in the deep corners of the internet and on the streets of state capitals by twisting the public health crisis to bolster their white supremacist, anti-government agenda.

headline: These Are the Bedside Concerts Comforting Virus Patients
abstract: An I.C.U. doctor felt despair at how little could be done for the sick. Soon, she had musicians playing over the phone in hospital rooms.
lead_paragraph: In chaotic emergency rooms and intensive care units around New York City, coronavirus patients struggle to survive in isolation, with masked doctors and nurses keeping their distance and family visits barred. Alarms, monitors and overhead announcements blare incessantly.

headline: One of Amazon’s Most Powerful Critics Lives in Its Backyard
abstract: Representative Pramila Jayapal of Washington tried to keep her concerns about the company private. Now she’s going public.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Pramila Jayapal was walking a fine line when she arrived at Amazon’s Seattle headquarters on a chilly day last October to meet with some of the company’s top executives.

headline: Percival Everett Has a Book or Three Coming Out
abstract: “Telephone,” a novel whose multiple versions were originally intended as a secret before the coronavirus pandemic, is the latest from a rule-breaking writer.
lead_paragraph: Once you’ve finished “Telephone,” the latest book by Percival Everett, you may be talking about it with another reader and finding that you disagree on what happened.

headline: Trump Nominee Is Among Judges Opposed to Banning Membership in Conservative Group
abstract: Judge Justin Walker joined a bevy of judges, many appointees of the president, in railing against an ethics proposal on the Federalist Society.
lead_paragraph: As the Senate this week considers elevating a politically connected judge to an influential federal appeals court, the judge has stepped into a fierce ideological debate about a legal group shaping President Trump’s rightward overhaul of the judiciary.

headline: I Bought a Car From Northern Italy as the Pandemic Took Hold
abstract: The little blue coupe’s journey shows how ordinary things played out in extraordinary circumstances.
lead_paragraph: Imagine what it would have been like to unwittingly arrange to buy an oxcart in Pompeii on or about the 23rd of August, 79 A.D. — I’m the 21st-century version of that guy.

headline: The Covid-19 Riddle: Why Does the Virus Wallop Some Places and Spare Others?
abstract: Experts are trying to figure out why the coronavirus is so capricious. The answers could determine how to best protect ourselves and how long we have to.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has killed so many people in Iran that the country has resorted to mass burials, but in neighboring Iraq, the body count is fewer than 100.

headline: Reopening, Vaccine, Spring Gardens: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: Maintenance Tips for a Virus-Idled Car
abstract: Advice from Dad, and some experts, on what to do now that we’re driving so much less.
lead_paragraph: Every January during my early teenage years, my parents would fly to Miami to spend about six weeks in the sun. They’d leave the car — usually a Pontiac, one time a Cadillac — in our driveway in Boston, along with some instructions.

headline: My Co-Anchor Is Pawing at the Door: Back to You in the Studio
abstract: As TV meteorologists and reporters work from home, pets have become a part of their reports — often by accident, and always to delightful effect.
lead_paragraph: Scott Connell, a Missouri weatherman, was trying to record a tease last month, but Maple, his Cavalier King Charles spaniel, had other plans.

headline: Global Backlash Builds Against China Over Coronavirus
abstract: As calls for inquiries and reparations spread, Beijing has responded aggressively, mixing threats with aid and adding to a growing mistrust of China.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Australia has called for an inquiry into the origin of the virus. Germany and Britain are hesitating anew about inviting in the Chinese tech giant Huawei. President Trump has blamed China for the contagion and is seeking to punish it. Some governments want to sue Beijing for damages and reparations.

headline: The Week in Business: Who’s Ready to Go Shopping?
abstract: The country’s economy is starting to reopen. But health officials warn against moving too fast.
lead_paragraph: Limping businesses are preparing to reopen across the country, and some Americans are raring to get out of the house. Is this the beginning of the economy’s recovery or will it lead to a resurgence of coronavirus infections? Here’s the business news you need to know for the week ahead.

headline: Kashmir Gun Battle Kills at Least 7
abstract: Fighting between the Indian Army and militants threatened to heighten hostilities in the disputed region, where near-daily skirmishes have raged for weeks.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A gun battle between the Indian Army and militants in Kashmir left at least seven people dead, Indian officials said on Sunday, and the violence threatened to heighten tensions in the disputed region.

abstract: Defending his response to the pandemic, the president told a Fox News town hall that initial intelligence briefings suggested the outbreak was “not a big deal.”

abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
