Kennedy, Berry Gordy and Pelé, and was married on and off to Willem de Kooning, gave Mr. Haze brushes and told him to paint. She also taught him how to stretch canvasses.

headline: Why 1.4 Million Health Jobs Have Been Lost During a Huge Health Crisis

headline: 5 New Comedy Specials to Remind You of the Old Normal
abstract: The featured comedians, including Jerry Seinfeld, developed much of their material before the quarantine. Their bits can lighten your mood in unexpected ways.
lead_paragraph: “Laughter is the best medicine” is a cliché that has been skewered so many times it’s easy to forget the animating truth behind it. No, a joke will not save us, but it can provide solace, and not just by lightening the mood. In a time when many are isolated and suffering, it’s easy to get stuck in destructive mental patterns. The utility of jokes is that they are perfectly engineered to trick minds out of ruts, manipulate thoughts in one direction or another, a Rube Goldberg device delighting through distraction. The day will come when all the new comedy will have been made in a world after the pandemic, but we are not there yet. Most of the new specials, developed before the crisis, seem like they arrived from another world. For those tired of this one, it can be nice to visit. Here are a few recent examples.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Cook for mom, and make pancakes, a springy asparagus soup, or a carrot cake, or cook for yourself, and make a flawless bacon, egg and cheese sandwich.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. A long time ago, when I used to ride an electric motorbike through crowded traffic so I could get to a subway station where I shared a rickety elevator with a lot of people before getting on a train car with even more, so that I could travel into the heart of Times Square to go to work, making my way down 40th Street against a heaving tide of people coming from the Port Authority, I sometimes stopped at the deli across the street from the newspaper and ordered a bacon, egg and cheese sandwich.

headline: Working for Social Change, High School Students Find a Social Life

headline: Young BFFs, Looking for Likes in All the Wrong Places

lead_paragraph: All hail the best friend! That person we confide in and listen to without fear or judgment. The one with whom we share in-jokes. The one who holds our hand, metaphorically and sometimes literally, through the murky patches. As the cliché goes, we don’t always know where this person ends and we begin. During a time of insecurity, surging hormones and confusion about who we are (I’m talking about adolescence, though it can go on forever), the best friend may be the most stabilizing force in our lives. Pinky swear.

headline: Golfers Embrace CBD, Even as Its Gentility Is Questioned

lead_paragraph: Billy Horschel went six months without a top-eight finish last year before he found a remedy for his ailing golf game from a surprising source: the hemp plant. Horschel, a five-time PGA Tour winner, began using cannabidiol, or CBD, products shortly after he missed the cut at the British Open in July. He had four top-eight finishes in the next four months and was playing some of the most consistent golf of his career before the season was suspended in March because of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: A Vibrant Celebration of Moroccan Design
abstract: In February, the hotelier Philomena Schurer Merckoll toasted her new creative showcase, Design Marrakech, with a gathering at her guesthouse, Riad Mena.
lead_paragraph: As a few faint rain drops began to fall in the courtyard of Riad Mena, a seven-room guesthouse in the Marrakesh medina, the hotelier Philomena Schurer Merckoll looked skyward, assessing the likelihood of a downpour. This was in February, when a seasonal shower was the biggest threat to a social gathering, and at risk beneath the citrus trees were white linen sofas and red silk-embroidered floor cushions, laid out for cocktail hour before a dinner in honor of Marrakesh’s design talent. But with artworks arriving and her guests expected, she shrugged at the massing clouds, determined the evening should go on. The furniture was taken inside and then reassembled an hour later once the shower had passed. Looking back now, from a radically altered world of shelter-in-place orders and social distancing, guests fondly recall the evening as one of the last when they were able to mingle freely with friends old and new. “It’s wonderful to remember that dinner now,” said Schurer Merckoll late last month. “It feels so special because it gives me hope for more positive times to come.”

headline: The First Signs of Travel’s Return?
abstract: As Australia announces plans to revive tourism, we look at 10 top travel destinations and their timetables for reopening. The challenge: balancing safety with the need to reboot.
lead_paragraph: Covid-19 has upended daily life in much of the world for so long that the idea of traveling to another country or state seems like the stuff of dreams. But in the last week or so, as the idea of opening up to travelers has gained traction, some countries are taking concrete steps. Yesterday, Australia announced a three-stage plan to reopen the economy, which includes a focus on tourism. And some countries are forming regional alliances designed to minimize the risk of the virus, including an Australia-New Zealand travel “bubble,” and, in Europe, a travel “corridor” shared by Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.

headline: After Fanfare for Baseball, Soccer Is Also Back in South Korea
abstract: A 1-0 win for Jeonbuk over the Suwon Bluewings got unusual attention because of the pandemic, as crowd noise was pumped in and those on the sidelines wore masks.
lead_paragraph: Jeonbuk 1, Suwon Bluewings 0.

headline: A Question of Theme
abstract: An author offers an alternative perspective for his novel, while readers revisit Moynihan and comment on the literary tastes of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How to Make the Most of Potatoes
abstract: This simple tuber is delicious just about any way you prepare it. But David Tanis has three especially good ideas.
lead_paragraph: Cheap, nourishing, eminently available and fuss-free, the humble potato is just the thing for these days and weeks of stay-at-home, nearly nonstop cooking.

headline: Love Letter: A Mother-Daughter Bond Enhanced by Stillness
abstract: Plus, how motherhood changed them. everything.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up here to receive Love Letter, a weekly newsletter about relationship highs, lows and woes, in your inbox every Friday.]

headline: With ‘Four More Shots Please!,’ India Gets Its Own ‘Sex and the City’
abstract: The Amazon series has become a hit in India for its frank depictions of modern Mumbai women and sex, in a country where even kissing has been rare onscreen.
lead_paragraph: When the HBO series “Sex and the City” first arrived on TV screens in 1998, sex had become “the reigning political story,” according to the writer Julie Salamon. The show was a product and a catalyst of a zeitgeist in which financially independent and imperfect women had carved out a space for themselves and their casual, raging sex lives.

headline: This Rich Challah May Be as Good as a Hug From Mom
abstract: This simple, satisfying baking project, perfect for Mother’s Day (or just for yourself), is cause enough to celebrate.
lead_paragraph: After several weeks of hospitalization (unrelated to Covid-19), my mother is back home, snug and settled in the same Brooklyn house where I grew up. To celebrate that, and Mother’s Day, I baked her a challah.

headline: Paul Shelden, Clarinetist and Classical Music Advocate, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Shelden, who had the coronavirus, played under Leonard Bernstein and was inspired by his Young People’s Concerts.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Talking to Children About Job Loss During the Pandemic
abstract: How parents can be honest with children about financial stresses while avoiding making them feel too burdened.
lead_paragraph: Even as some states are reopening, many parents face telling their children that things they were looking forward to are effectively still canceled for them — because they can no longer afford them.

headline: Plan to Remove a Million-Pound Granite Sculpture Draws Fire
abstract: Museum leaders and others are asking the National Geographic Society to find a way to expand its Washington headquarters without dismantling the art work.
lead_paragraph: Explorers affiliated with the National Geographic Society have a long history of surmounting stone in places like Mount Everest. But the 130-year-old organization has decided that more than a million pounds of artfully placed granite are in the way of plans to expand its headquarters in Washington.

headline: White-Collar Companies Race to Be Last to Return to the Office
abstract: Google, Facebook, Amazon, Capital One and others are extending work-from-home policies to September and sometimes far beyond.
lead_paragraph: Even as President Trump has said “we have to get our country open again,” much of corporate America is in no rush to return employees to their campuses and skyscrapers. The companies are racing not to be the first back, but the last.

headline: With Hollywood Productions on Hold, Documentary Filmmakers Keep Going
abstract: Ron Howard has been overseeing a nonfiction film from afar, while other documentarians have gone into the coronavirus epicenter.
lead_paragraph: Jehane Noujaim and Karim Amer know about putting themselves at risk for their work. While they were shooting thousands of hours of footage for “The Square,” the 2013 documentary directed by Ms. Noujaim and produced by Mr. Amer on the popular uprising in Cairo, they were often in the middle of the action in Tahrir Square, where the military shot protesters and dispersed crowds with tear gas. Some of their footage was confiscated, and Ms. Noujaim was arrested and held for 36 hours.

headline: Arrests in the Killing of Ahmaud Arbery
abstract: Readers react to articles about the killing of a black jogger in Georgia. Also: Defending Israel; the “Bridgegate” decision; a plasma recipient’s story; Pakistan’s religious minorities.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Forget Pancakes. Pay Mothers.
abstract: One lesson from the pandemic: Child care is work. And it should be compensated.
lead_paragraph: After just six days of sheltering in place, I found myself thinking about all the women I’d taken for granted.

headline: 7 Tips for Watching Birds During the Spring Lockdown
abstract: Here are some principles you can apply to any form of nature study.
lead_paragraph: We find comfort in nature. The psychological benefits are well documented: Spending time with grass and trees and birds, even through a window, makes us feel happier and more relaxed. It’s inspiring and reassuring to remember that birds are migrating north right now, as they have for millenniums. The earth turns, and birds follow the rhythms of daily and yearly cycles.

headline: Federal Watchdog Says Coronavirus Whistle-Blower Should Be Reinstated as It Investigates
abstract: The Office of Special Counsel has found “reasonable grounds” to investigate whether Dr. Rick Bright was ousted from a senior science post for questioning Trump administration actions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal investigative office has found “reasonable grounds to believe” that the Trump administration was retaliating against a whistle-blower, Dr. Rick Bright, when he was ousted from a government research agency combating the coronavirus — and said he should be reinstated for 45 days while it investigates, his lawyers said Friday.

headline: Inside a House in Queens, a Dark Side of the Immigrant Story
abstract: Francesca Momplaisir’s debut novel, “My Mother’s House,” examines the depths of depravity from three perspectives, including a home’s.
lead_paragraph: MY MOTHER’S HOUSEBy Francesca Momplaisir

headline: No Return to the ‘Old Dispensation’
abstract: The monster of modernity must be slowed.
lead_paragraph: In T.S. Eliot’s “Journey of the Magi,” the three wise kings, having witnessed the birth of Christ at the end of a long and difficult journey, return home to find themselves “no longer at ease here, in the old dispensation.”

headline: On Ahmaud Arbery’s Birthday, Thousands Say #IRunWithMaud
abstract: People documented their 2.23-mile runs on Friday using the hashtag to show solidarity with Mr. Arbery, who was killed on Feb. 23.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Ahmaud Arbery would have turned 26.

headline: For Canada, Finding a Vaccine Will Only Be Part of the Equation
abstract: While researchers across Canada are among the scientists working on coronavirus vaccines, the country doesn’t have the means to quickly produce any successful result.
lead_paragraph: As many provinces ease up on some coronavirus restrictions — notably in Quebec, which has decided to reopen some schools — the discussion about vaccines has been increasing.

headline: Myles Coker, 69, Dies; Freed From a Life Term in Prison
abstract: A sentencing rule change, a spotless prison record and his standing as a “true father” to his sons led to his release after 23 years behind bars for selling heroin.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: With Push From Trump, Senate Moves to Install Contentious Filmmaker at U.S. Media Agency
abstract: A key Senate committee has scheduled a vote on the long-stalled nomination of Michael Pack, an ally of Stephen K. Bannon, to run the agency in charge of the Voice of America. Employees are worried.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republican leaders, under pressure from President Trump to install an ally who would dictate more favorable news coverage of his administration, are moving to swiftly confirm a conservative filmmaker to lead the independent agency in charge of state-funded media outlets.

headline: Chess Thrives Online Despite Pandemic
abstract: The world’s top chess players are competing online with in-person tournaments shut down. Millions of amateurs are joining in, too.
lead_paragraph: It was 8 a.m. Tuesday in St. Louis when the American chess grandmaster Fabiano Caruana, ranked second best in the world, moved his pawn to E4.

headline: When ‘Murder Hornets’ Are Better News
abstract: You know it’s bad when talking about giant, deadly hornets comes as a relief.
lead_paragraph: When should The Daily not be about the pandemic? We’ve been wrestling with that question. The coronavirus is, perhaps, the biggest story we’ve covered since the show was launched in 2017. It has disrupted and upended every corner of our lives. And there is no end in sight.

headline: What Is the Best Book a Teacher Ever Recommended to You?
abstract: To commemorate Teacher Appreciation Week, we asked writers this question, and we’d love to hear from you, too.
lead_paragraph: Those of us who are readers often owe a lot to our teachers. To mark the end of Teacher Appreciation Week, we thought we’d take a moment to reflect on the most influential books we picked up thanks to a teacher who slipped a book into our hands, assigned a particular novel or reached out with a thoughtful recommendation.

headline: Protests, Calls for Justice in Georgia Over Ahmaud Arbery Killing
abstract: A crowd of protesters gathered outside the Glynn County Courthouse in Georgia to demand a thorough investigation into the killing of Ahmaud Arbery after a father and son were arrested, and charged with murder.
lead_paragraph: A crowd of protesters gathered outside the Glynn County Courthouse in Georgia to demand a thorough investigation into the killing of Ahmaud Arbery after a father and son were arrested, and charged with murder.

headline: Denis Goldberg, South African Freedom Fighter, Is Dead at 87
abstract: He was the only white defendant to be convicted alongside Nelson Mandela and others in 1964 for resisting apartheid. He spent 22 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Denis Goldberg, one of two surviving political activists convicted in the so-called Rivonia Trial, which put Nelson Mandela and seven others in prison for many years and proved a turning-point in South Africa’s long struggle against apartheid, died on April 29 in Cape Town. He was 87.

headline: Ohio State Pays $41 Million to Settle Claims From Doctor’s Abuse
abstract: The university said it had reached settlements with 162 people who were sexually assaulted when they were sent to the team doctor Richard H. Strauss.
lead_paragraph: Ohio State University said Friday it would pay $41 million to resolve some of the lawsuits stemming from several hundred sexual assault claims made against a doctor for the school’s athletic department. The payouts to 162 people represent close to half the former athletes and other students who have filed lawsuits against the university because of assaults committed by Richard H. Strauss during his nearly 20 years as a team doctor.

headline: California to Mail All Voters Ballots for November Election
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom on Friday made California the first state to alter its plans for the general election in response to the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California on Friday ordered ballots to be sent to the state’s 20.6 million voters for the November election, becoming the first state to alter its voting plans for the general election in response to the public health concerns wrought by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Haphazard Rollout of Coronavirus Drug Frustrates Doctors
abstract: Remdesivir was shipped to small hospitals even as besieged medical centers were denied access.
lead_paragraph: When the Food and Drug Administration granted an emergency approval last week for an antiviral drug, remdesivir, to treat hospitalized coronavirus patients, many doctors were overjoyed. The drug is the first shown to be even mildly effective against the virus.

headline: Daisy Lucidi, a Radio Voice With a Telenovela Following, Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Lucidi had a large following in Brazil for her radio show “Hello Daisy!,” a mix of gossip, recipes and urban muckraking. She died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: 10 Eclectic Homes to Get Lost In
abstract: Rooms that are not just different than those you’re self-isolating in but unlike most others, too.
lead_paragraph: Months into collective efforts to flatten the curve, those of us lucky enough to be working remotely may be feeling overly familiar with our own homes, rooms once traveled through quite casually on our way to somewhere else and that must now function as our entire world. Inevitably, they fall short, and we start to imagine ourselves — worry-free — in different, better versions. Zoom calls and Instagram Live clips taunt us with small slivers of alternatives — intimacy has, in so many ways, been curtailed, and yet we’re getting glimpses into spaces we’ve never seen before. Perhaps you, too, have been distracted by the poster, stack of books or unusually colored wall behind the person on the other end of the platform and wondered about what is just out of view and what it might reveal about its owner’s true essence.

headline: Millie Small, ‘My Boy Lollipop’ Singer, Is Dead at 73
abstract: Her 1964 smash hit was a breakthrough for Jamaican music. But she later became “one of the most elusive performers in pop history.”
lead_paragraph: Millie Small, the Jamaican singer whose 1964 hit, “My Boy Lollipop,” introduced the upbeat rhythms of ska to international audiences, died on Tuesday in London. She was 73.

headline: 6ix9ine Returns With New Song and Defiant Livestream: ‘I Ratted’
abstract: The rapper was released from prison early because he was vulnerable to the coronavirus. He released his first new track, “Gooba,” then spoke candidly to an audience of two million.
lead_paragraph: On Friday afternoon, the rapper and Instagram star 6ix9ine released a new song, “Gooba” — the first new music he has put out since a federal judge in April allowed him to finish the remaining months of his two-year sentence for racketeering and other charges in home confinement.

headline: Satish Gujral, Versatile Indian Artist, Is Dead at 94
abstract: After losing his hearing as a child, he became one of his country’s best-known painters, sculptors and architects.
lead_paragraph: Satish Gujral, one of India’s best-known artists, was always game to try something new.

headline: Jobs Report, Ahmaud Arbery, Mother’s Day: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Be Your Own Spin Class
abstract: Even without a $2,000-plus Peloton bike it’s possible to get your  endorphin fix from indoor cycling. Or even take it outdoors.
lead_paragraph: Rooms full of dozens of bikes packed together, music blaring, instructors shouting a mix of directions and motivational messages, and participants whooping as if they are at a sold-out concert at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Soccer Arrives at a Fork in the Road
abstract: The coronavirus seemed to offer the game the chance to take one of two paths, toward two very different futures. Fairly predictably, it is hurriedly turning down the wrong one.
lead_paragraph: Enjoying this newsletter? Tell a friend to sign up at nytimes.com/rory and then you’ll have something new to talk about every Friday.

headline: Ahmaud Arbery Shooting: A Timeline of the Case
abstract: A look at the major moments between Mr. Arbery’s killing in a Georgia suburb and the arrest of two suspects, both charged with murder.
lead_paragraph: Ahmaud Arbery loved to run. A former high school football standout, he had been jogging near his home on the outskirts of Brunswick, Ga., when he was shot and killed after being pursued by two white men with guns, according to the authorities.

headline: Argentina Teeters on Default, Again, as Pandemic Guts Economy
abstract: Even before the coronavirus deepened Argentina’s recession, the country was on track to default on $66 billion in debt.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina is hurtling toward default on international loans in two weeks, a prospect that threatens to revive its reputation as a serial deadbeat and global financial pariah that could haunt the Latin American country long after the coronavirus pandemic is over.

headline: Ben Benson, Who Put Singles in a Bar and Steak on the Tables, Dies at 89
abstract: He got his start with TGI Fridays, a ’60s hit on the bar scene, helped start Smith & Wollensky, then opened his own Midtown steakhouse, drawing a tony crowd.
lead_paragraph: People used to call Ben Benson’s the most famous steakhouse nobody’s ever heard of.

headline: Tesla Tells Workers It Will Reopen California Factory Despite County Order
abstract: The electric car company told employees to report to work Friday, but a county official said Tesla did not meet the requirements for resuming production.
lead_paragraph: Tesla told employees it would restart its factory in Fremont, Calif., on Friday. But the electric car company’s plans do not comply with a local government order that has not cleared large manufacturers to resume operations.

headline: In Flynn Case, Barr Again Takes Aim at Mueller Inquiry
abstract: The Justice Department’s move was the latest example of the attorney general’s effort to chisel away at the special counsel investigation and emphasize an alternate narrative.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly after admitting guilt to a federal judge in December 2017 for lying to the F.B.I., Michael T. Flynn issued a statement saying what he did was wrong, and “through my faith in God, I am working to set things right.”

headline: Motoko Fujishiro Huthwaite, 92, Last of the ‘Monuments Women,’ Dies
abstract: An American who was sent to Japan after Pearl Harbor, she was one of 345 people from 14 countries who helped preserve cultural treasures.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: ‘You Will Not Live to See Your Next Birthday’
abstract: Life and fate, 75 years after Mauthausen.
lead_paragraph: New Year’s Eve, 1943. Lajos Stillmann is celebrating his 22nd birthday with friends in a Budapest apartment. Someone suggests paying a visit to a nearby palm reader. Stillmann goes along, reluctantly. The palm reader takes a look at his hand, then tells him she would rather not say what she’s seen.

headline: Overlooked No More: June Almeida, Scientist Who Identified the First Coronavirus
abstract: In 1966, she used a powerful electron microscope to capture an image of a mysterious pathogen — the first coronavirus known to cause human disease.
lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: N.B.A. Opens for Practice, but Few Show Up
abstract: About half of the league’s 30 teams were allowed to open their facilities Friday, but only two did. Players and teams wonder if it’s worth the risk.
lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Cavaliers and the Portland Trail Blazers were the only clubs to unlock their practice facilities Friday, reflecting the cautious approach many franchises and players adopted on the first day that roughly half of the N.B.A.’s 30 teams had clearance to reopen after a shutdown of nearly two months.

headline: After a Killing, ‘Running While Black’ Stirs Even More Anxiety
abstract: Black runners have long taken steps to avoid racial profiling and violence. After the shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery, many say their fear has taken on a new urgency.
lead_paragraph: Tell us about your experience “running while black” in the form at the end of this article.

abstract: “This virus can stop our travel plans, but it cannot stop our travel dreams.”
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Dropping of Flynn Case Heightens Fears of Justice Dept. Politicization
abstract: Across the country, rank-and-file prosecutors cringed at another extraordinary intervention by Attorney General William P. Barr.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and his supporters on Friday praised Attorney General William P. Barr’s decision to drop the prosecution of Michael T. Flynn, even as career law enforcement officials warned that the action set a disturbing precedent and Democrats accused the administration of further politicizing the Justice Department.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The coronavirus is not going to simply vanish after restrictions are lifted — instead, it may come back in waves.
lead_paragraph: It’s becoming clear that the coronavirus is not going to simply vanish after restrictions are lifted, epidemiologists say, despite the recent optimistic forecast from the White House.

headline: Two White House Coronavirus Cases Raise Question of if Anyone Is Really Safe
abstract: If it is so hard to maintain a healthy environment at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, then how can businesses across the country establish a safe space for their workers?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his eagerness to reopen the country, President Trump faces the challenge of convincing Americans that it would be safe to go back to the workplace. But the past few days have demonstrated that even his own workplace may not be safe from the coronavirus.

headline: Roberts Rejects Request for Inquiry into D.C. Appeals Court Vacancy
abstract: The top circuit court judge had asked the complaint be transferred and investigated, but the chief justice’s office said it did not qualify.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. on Friday turned down a request from the chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit to designate another court to conduct an ethics inquiry into the circumstances surrounding a retirement from what is widely viewed as the second-most important court in the nation.

headline: Ahmaud Arbery Video Was Leaked by a Lawyer Who Consulted With Suspects
abstract: The lawyer, Alan Tucker, declined to comment on his conversations with the suspects, citing attorney-client privilege. He later said he would not be representing them.
lead_paragraph: For weeks after Ahmaud Arbery was killed while running down a road in coastal southern Georgia, there were few public developments in the case of a 25-year-old unarmed black man who was shot while being pursued by two white men with weapons in February.

headline: The Man Who Taught Australia How to Mix a Proper Drink
abstract: Vernon Chalker helped to turn what was once considered a menial job, bartending, into a celebrated career.
lead_paragraph: A couple of decades ago, I took the long trip from New York to Queensland to visit my family for Christmas. My birthday falls in early January, and I told my brother that I’d like to go out for some cocktails to celebrate. He looked perplexed — there weren’t many cocktails to be found in Queensland back then.

headline: What Colombia Did With American Spy Tools
abstract: Under pressure to curb the drug trade, the Colombian army turns to old tricks.
lead_paragraph: Old habits die hard, so there’s something sadly unsurprising in the news that a Colombian army unit used American surveillance equipment, provided to fight Marxist guerrillas and drug traffickers, to spy on journalists, political opponents and public figures. It’s entirely possible that one important goal was to conceal that the fight was dirty and not going particularly well.

headline: A Drug Cocktail Hastens Recovery in Some Coronavirus Patients
abstract: A combination of three antiviral drugs, including interferon, seemed to speed recovery, researchers reported.
lead_paragraph: Patients with mild to moderate Covid-19, the illness caused by the coronavirus, appeared to improve more quickly if they were treated with a three-drug cocktail, compared with a group receiving just a two-drug combination, scientists reported on Friday.

headline: Georgia Killing Puts Spotlight on a Police Force’s Troubled History
abstract: The shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery has renewed criticism of the police agency that released the two suspects. They were charged by the state months later.
lead_paragraph: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — When the Glynn County Police Department arrived at the scene of a fatal shooting in February in southeastern Georgia, officers encountered a former colleague with the victim’s blood on his hands.

headline: No Charges for Parents of 5-Year-Old Who Took to the Highway in an S.U.V.
abstract: The couple were at work and had no idea that their son had sneaked out while his teenage sister watched him, a prosecutor said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The parents of a 5-year-old boy will not face charges after their son was pulled over while driving on a Utah highway, hoping to make it to California to buy a Lamborghini, a prosecutor said Friday.

headline: 2 Fugitives Arrested in Fatal Dispute Over Mask at Family Dollar Store
abstract: The authorities said the two men had been sought since May 1 in the shooting death of a security guard at the store in Flint, Mich.
lead_paragraph: Two fugitives sought in connection with the fatal shooting of a security guard at a Family Dollar store in Michigan over a dispute about a customer not wearing a face mask have been arrested, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Disquisition
abstract: Miriam Estrin makes her crossword debut, in collaboration with Erik Agard.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Today we have another fun themeless grid from Erik Agard and a new sidekick, perhaps more evidence that his Crossword Collaboration efforts are paying off. I’m biased, but I love Saturday and Sunday debuts. Lately I’ve been thinking of how nice it would be to have one more day between Saturday and Sunday to create a three-day weekend, and to have a spot to put really hard daily puzzles. Maybe we could pull something off like this while everyone’s distracted.

headline: Roy Horn, Who Dazzled Audiences as Half of Siegfried & Roy, Dies at 75
abstract: He and his partner mesmerized crowds for decades, using a stunning mix of magic, costumes and exotic animals. He died of complications of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Churches Weigh the Risk of Reopening Their Doors
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 9, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “We’ve somehow maintained a real intimacy and sweetness because we leaned into the values that always held us.”

headline: What Time is U.F.C. 249? Streaming and Full Details
abstract: The U.F.C. is to stage the first major American sporting event in nearly two months on Saturday night. On Friday, however, one of the bouts had to be canceled because a fighter tested positive for the virus.
lead_paragraph: The Ultimate Fighting Championship is back.

headline: Corrections: May 9, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 9, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about countries’ efforts to safely reopen their economies misstated the surname of the director of the Center for Health Security at Johns Hopkins University. He is Tom Inglesby, not Tom Inglesbury.

headline: Coronavirus Forces Gulf States to Reckon With Their Scores of Migrant Workers
abstract: A new cluster of cases in Seoul tests South Korea’s easing. Belarus held a tank parade.

headline: Andrés Iniesta Plots a Return to Barcelona, Where the Beauty Is Gone
abstract: Iniesta turned from aspiring schoolboy to soccer icon on a Barcelona team that captivated the world. Now in Japan, he hopes for a return to a club plagued by infighting.
lead_paragraph: From 6,500 miles away, Andrés Iniesta has been contemplating his return. He doesn’t know when it will be, or under what circumstances, but he is sure he wants to go back to F.C. Barcelona.

headline: One-Third of All U.S. Coronavirus Deaths Are Nursing Home Residents or Workers
abstract: In at least 14 states, more than half of coronavirus deaths are tied to long-term care facilities for older adults, according to a New York Times database.
lead_paragraph: In at least 14 states, more than half of coronavirus deaths are tied to long-term care facilities for older adults, according to a New York Times database.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Spaceship Earth’ and ‘Valley Girl’
abstract: A documentary on the sci-fi-esque Biosphere 2 experiment arrives on Hulu, and a jukebox-musical remake of the 1983 movie “Valley Girl” debuts on Amazon.
lead_paragraph: SPACESHIP EARTH (2020) Stream on Hulu. This documentary takes viewers inside Biosphere 2 (known as No. 2 because Biosphere 1 is the Earth), an experimental research facility that was built by a Texas oil tycoon to prove that humans could remain healthy while quarantining in a bubble. Built in Oracle, Ariz., with its own mini-rainforest, desert and ocean with a living coral reef, the idyllic bubble was meant to prepare scientists for space colonization. But in 1991, when the first eight scientists sealed themselves inside the terrarium-like habitat for the two-year experiment, things went awry. Directed by Matt Wolf (“Teenage”), this film looks at the odd and dark twists that took place in the utopian biosphere.

headline: The Collateral Damage of the Coronavirus
abstract: As shopping centers emptied, shows were canceled and office towers turned dark, millions of people suddenly found themselves without jobs.
lead_paragraph: They are ad executives, handymen, servers and wedding D.J.s. They worked in law firms and hotels and retail stores and concert halls. As the outbreak spread, the coronavirus sucked workers from every corner of the American economy.

headline: ‘It’s Hard When You Can’t Go Anywhere’: Life Inside an Assisted Living Facility
abstract: We gave disposable cameras to six residents of Evergreen Gardens, a long-term-care residence in Colorado, so they could document their days during the coronavirus pandemic. These are their photographs.
lead_paragraph: We gave disposable cameras to six residents of Evergreen Gardens, a long-term-care residence in Colorado, so they could document their days during the coronavirus pandemic. These are their photographs.

headline: The Book That Shaped Foreign Policy for a Generation Has More to Say
abstract: Hans Morgenthau’s “Politics Among Nations” taught thinkers from George F. Kennan to Henry Kissinger to put national interest above idealism. America is still learning that lesson.
lead_paragraph: Lurching from crisis to crisis and assailed even by allies for its handling of the coronavirus pandemic, the United States has rarely seemed more absent from the international stage, or more urgently in need of defining its role in world affairs. This may be a good time, therefore, to look back at a book from another era when fundamental questions about foreign policy were being asked — and answered.

headline: Fight Over Virus’s Death Toll Opens Grim New Front in Election Battle
abstract: Elements of the right have sought to bolster President Trump’s political standing by turning scientific questions into political issues.
lead_paragraph: The claim was tailor-made for President Trump’s most steadfast backers: Federal guidelines are coaching doctors to mark Covid-19 as the cause of death even when it is not, inflating the pandemic’s death toll.

headline: There’s Money Stuck in Your Dependent Care Account. Now What?
abstract: After-school programs are closed. Day care centers are shut down. Summer camp might not happen. If you’re stuck with money you can’t use, you’ll lose it.
lead_paragraph: You did everything right. You read the email from human resources and signed up for a dependent care account. Your employer siphons pretax money from your paycheck, and you’ll get a little back upon request after paying each day care bill, or in a lump sum after covering summer camp costs.

headline: Will Coronavirus Kill Astrology?
abstract: The pandemic has affected all of us. Who saw it coming?
lead_paragraph: If ever there was one, Susan Miller would be a blue-chip astrologer. So, in January, when she appeared on CBS New York and predicted that 2020 would “be a great year, and it will be a prosperous year,” people listened.

headline: As Job Losses Mount, Lawmakers Face a Make-or-Break Moment
abstract: The United States just lost 20 million jobs. The wrong federal response could make those layoffs a permanent fixture of the U.S. economy and sentence thousands of companies to bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the nation confronts unemployment levels not seen since the Great Depression, Congress and the Trump administration face a pivotal choice: Continue spending trillions trying to shore up businesses and workers, or bet that state reopenings will jump-start the United States economy.

headline: A Novelist Breaks the Code of Being a Woman in Japan
abstract: Mieko Kawakami, whose novel “Breasts and Eggs” was just published in English, has become something of a feminist icon in her male-dominated country.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — To explain the pressure felt by women in Japanese society, the novelist Mieko Kawakami recalls a playground prank from elementary school.

headline: Singles Have to Think Outside the Screen
abstract: Matchmakers are seeing higher demand for advice and coaching services now that drinks and dinner are on hold.
lead_paragraph: Before the coronavirus pandemic hit, Cedric DuBose of Houston was completing a nine-week online course called “Love Alchemy.” The workshop, intended to get him thinking about his relationship skills, was a prerequisite to hiring Amari Ice, a Washington-based matchmaker.

headline: The Class Divide: Remote Learning at 2 Schools, Private and Public
abstract: Some private schools provide online luxury learning during the pandemic. As many public schools struggle to adjust, the nation’s educational gaps widen.
lead_paragraph: For Rachel Warach’s class, the 133rd morning of first grade, numbered on a poster board behind her, was similar to all of the previous mornings.

headline: The Grapelord of Napa Faces a Threat Worse Than Plague
abstract: For 50 years, Andy Beckstoffer drove up the price of wine. Did the strategy work too well?
lead_paragraph: One balmy winter afternoon, Andy Beckstoffer, a grape grower who has done more than nearly anyone to shape the premium U.S. wine industry, was sitting in Mustard’s, a restaurant in Napa Valley that is a kind of clubhouse for the vintner class. Although Beckstoffer Vineyards, the largest private grower in California, had recently set a sales record with a blockbuster harvest of $55 million worth of cabernet sauvignon, its founder was not in the mood to celebrate. The wine industry was in trouble, facing its worst outlook in generations — and that was before the coronavirus struck.

headline: Make Ice Cream, in a Mason Jar
abstract: If you are over quar-baking, iced confections might be the next thing.
lead_paragraph: Making ice cream at home feels like alchemy, a complex process of mixing and cooling.

headline: Will the Coronavirus Crisis Trump the Climate Crisis?
abstract: The battle over how to spend recovery funds — to quickly restore the old economy or invest in a greener one — will define the post-pandemic world.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — With the global paralysis induced by the coronavirus, levels of pollution and carbon emission are dropping everywhere — leaving bluer skies, visible mountains, splendid wildflowers. Even Venice’s famously murky canals are running clear.

headline: These Are the Things That New Yorkers Achingly Miss
abstract: The crowds, the big-ticket blockbusters that were a subway ride away, “just everything”: What’s gone has transformed the city.
lead_paragraph: To hop on the train, any train, earbuds intact, alone in the crowd on the way somewhere else. To walk out of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, exhausted as if from a march. The sweet-potato fries and a beer at Tubby Hook Tavern in Inwood; the coffee-cart guy on West 40th Street who remembers you take it black.

headline: How 5 Friends Helped a Tulip Farm Make It to Mother’s Day
abstract: A group of old high school friends moved home and bought a tulip farm, just as the coronavirus threatened to devastate the industry. Here’s how the power of friendship and innovation saved them.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT VERNON, Wash. — When the Mount Vernon High School Bulldogs faced off against their basketball rivals a generation ago, five friends from the class of 1994 were the spark plugs, game after game. Three were on the cheer squad, stoking school spirit; two were on court, scoring points.

headline: Anxious About the Virus, Older Voters Grow More Wary of Trump
abstract: Surveys show the president’s standing with seniors, the group most vulnerable to the coronavirus, has fallen as he pushes to reopen the country.

headline: Nightly Applause Is Nice, but Some Doctors Think Votes Would Be Nicer
abstract: “My day job is talking people into getting colonoscopies,” one doctor said. So how much harder could the campaign trail be?
lead_paragraph: Maxine Dexter, an intensive care physician, remembers exactly where she was sitting the Thursday morning her political ambitions were born. She was looking out her bedroom window toward northwest Portland — the snow-capped peak of Mount Adams winking at her from across the valley. She clutched a coffee her husband had brought upstairs in her favorite mug, the one that read: “Well yes, I’m overqualified.”

headline: Sister Fights to Free Uighur Businessman Held in China After U.S. Trip
abstract: Ekpar Asat came to the United States for the State Department’s most prestigious program for foreign citizens. Chinese security officers detained him weeks after he returned home.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Ekpar Asat saw his older sister for the last time one winter night in Manhattan, he promised her he would return to the United States in a few months with their parents to watch her graduate with a master’s degree from Harvard Law School — the first ethnic Uighur to do so.

headline: Taiwan’s Weapon Against Coronavirus: An Epidemiologist as Vice President
abstract: Chen Chien-jen has embraced a rare dual role, using his political authority as vice president to criticize China’s response to the virus even as he hunkers down to analyze trends in transmission.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — The calls come at night, when Taiwan’s vice president, Chen Chien-jen, is usually at home in his pajamas. Scientists seek his advice on the development of antiviral medications. Health officials ask for guidance as they investigate an outbreak of the coronavirus on a navy ship.

headline: Sparks Flew Before the Curtain Call
abstract: Lindsay Murphy and Julianne Miller developed a friendship on an online message forum that turned romantic shortly after they met.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay Murphy was trying to become a better writer when she joined an online message forum on that subject in January 2017, and encountered Julianne Miller, who had already clicked into the forum to pick up a few writing tips.

headline: It was an On-Time Proposal
abstract: He proposed at the TWA hotel at JFK using the old arrivals departures board from the former midcentury modern terminal.
lead_paragraph: Peter Harrison knew the newly opened TWA hotel at Kennedy Airport in Queens was just the place to propose to Jennifer Markas.

headline: A ‘Big Fat Greek Wedding’ Will Have to Wait
abstract: Vungelia Glyptis and John Damianos, both from Greek families and graduates of Dartmouth, were forced to considerably scale down their wedding plans.
lead_paragraph: When John Damianos’s cellphone began buzzing on the Dartmouth campus in September 2015, he realized he was being FaceTimed by Vungelia Glyptis, a fellow student whom he had not talked to in two years.

headline: A Groom, by Proxy, on Zoom
abstract: Veronica Wickline and Taylor Barker were determined to find a way to wed, even if he couldn’t be there for the ceremony.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, April 17, Veronica Wickline, 26, a part-time Latin teacher and writer, stood at the altar at St. Peter, a Roman Catholic church in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains in Little Washington, Va. Dressed in her wedding dress, veil and pearl earrings, she was there to get married. But the man standing next to her was not her beloved groom. Rather, it was his high school best friend, who was serving as a proxy.

headline: No Debating Their Love
abstract: Sparks flew at their initial meeting, as he criticized her style of activism. They quickly realized their attraction wasn’t just about politics.
lead_paragraph: A disagreement about the politics of confrontation was at the heart of the first conversation that Kelly Witwicki Faddegon and Jacy Reese Anthis had when they met, at the beginning of summer in 2014.

headline: A New Lease With More Space Than They Needed
abstract: They were roommates, then friends, then had a first date just a few days before they planned to become roommates again.
lead_paragraph: Renata Certo-Ware and Tristan Graham, both 34, met in 2016, when she and her roommates at the time posted on Craigslist about an extra bedroom in their Philadelphia apartment for sublet.

headline: Hospitals Struggle to Restart Lucrative Elective Care After Coronavirus Shutdowns
abstract: The nation’s medical centers were forced to stop offering many surgeries, and sustained severe financial losses. Reopening is a daunting task amid the threat of more infection.

headline: Breanna Stewart’s Comeback Is Going to Take a Little Longer
abstract: The 2018 W.N.B.A. most valuable player’s return from a torn Achilles’ tendon was stalled by the coronavirus pandemic. Now she’s just trying to cope with being stuck inside.
lead_paragraph: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year.

headline: U.S. Hits Back at China With New Visa Restrictions on Journalists
abstract: The Trump administration is imposing 90-day limits on work visas for Chinese journalists, raising the threat of further retaliation by the Chinese government.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is imposing new restrictions on Chinese journalists working in the United States, escalating its conflict with China over the news media as the two countries battle for economic, geopolitical and messaging dominance worldwide.

headline: Top Health Officials to Quarantine After Being Exposed
abstract: Three children have died of a mysterious syndrome linked to the virus. Trump’s support among seniors slips as the pandemic becomes more political.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Three Children Have Died in New York of Illness Linked to Virus
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said New York was working with the C.D.C. to investigate a mysterious illness linked to the coronavirus that causes life-threatening inflammation in children.
lead_paragraph: Three young children have died in New York of a mysterious, toxic-shock inflammation syndrome with links to the coronavirus, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Saturday.

headline: How to Have a Picnic, Safely
abstract: The winter chill is lifting. So are some of the strictest stay-at-home orders. Here are strategies to dine outside while still protecting yourself and those around you.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe that it’s already May and that we’re approaching several months of sunny, sweater-less weather. Like flower petals, some states are slowly opening, too, including many once-closed parks, which means it’ll be hard to resist the urge to picnic.

headline: How to Make Your Own Coronavirus Piñata (and Then Smash It)
abstract: Join the craft renaissance and cope at the same time.

headline: New York City Covid Map and Case Count
abstract: A detailed ZIP code map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.
lead_paragraph: A detailed ZIP code map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.

headline: Israel Cracks Down on Banks Over Payments to Palestinian Inmates
abstract: An Israeli military order forbids banks in the occupied West Bank from processing payments that the Palestinian Authority distributes to the families of Palestinians who have spent time in Israeli jails.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Even as Israel is collaborating with West Bank officials to fight the coronavirus, a new Israeli military order taking effect on Saturday forbids banks in the occupied territory from processing payments that the Palestinian Authority distributes to the families of thousands of Palestinians who have spent time in Israeli jails.

headline: The Many Ways Moms Grow
abstract: Motherhood is all about changing. Continually. Sometimes as a parent, many times as a person. Since no two moms are alike in their transformations, we asked 16 of them to share their stories.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: One-Pot Vegetarian Spicy Red Beans Are #1
abstract: Punjabi-style beans, sheet-pan gnocchi and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include Tejal Rao’s Punjabi-style red beans with cream or mozzarella (above), Samin Nosrat’s big lasagna and Melissa Clark’s rhubarb custard bars. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: Little Richard, Flamboyant Wild Man of Rock ’n’ Roll, Dies at 87
abstract: Delving deeply into the wellsprings of gospel music and the blues, and screaming as if for his very life, he created something new, thrilling and dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Richard Penniman, better known as Little Richard, who combined the sacred shouts of the black church and the profane sounds of the blues to create some of the world’s first and most influential rock ’n’ roll records, died on Saturday in Tullahoma, Tenn. He was 87.

headline: Obama Warns That Dropped Charges Against Flynn Put ‘Rule of Law’ at Risk
abstract: Speaking to 3,000 supporters, the former president took a sharper line toward the Trump administration than he typically does in public.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President Barack Obama said on Friday that the Justice Department’s decision to drop charges against former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn jeopardized the “rule of law,” adding his voice to the criticism of the extraordinary move.

headline: Virus Forces Persian Gulf States to Reckon With Migrant Labor
abstract: The Mideast’s wealthiest countries depend on foreigners to do jobs their citizens won’t. But the virus has hobbled the arrangement and drawn attention to its inequities.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon remind us of someone, if that someone happens to be a tough cookie.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Argh, another difficult acrostic, agreed? If you happen to be here still hoping for hints and no spoilers, remember that Sunday is a holiday and this savage puzzle pays suitably wild homage to those we celebrate. Oh, also, if you’re feeling at all fraught today and hope to avoid anything emotionally charged, you might skip the video.

headline: My Son Is a Nurse. I Worry Every Day About Losing Him to the Coronavirus.
abstract: His New York City hospital has been all pandemic, all the time.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — “Can you hear that?” my son, Sam, asked me a month or so ago, interrupting our conversation to hold his phone up to his open car window. “It’s for essential workers.”

headline: I Survived Vietnam. Will I Survive This Pandemic?
abstract: Chance rules. Leaders lie. Deaths become statistics. The parallels between the disease and the war are everywhere.
lead_paragraph: SARNANO, Italy — A very long time ago, I was one of more than two million American men and women who served their country in Vietnam. We fought; too many of us became casualties and died. We were gone from home and half forgotten, living and dying in an alternative reality.

headline: Why America Loves U.F.C., the First Sport to Return
abstract: In an age of trolls, economic insecurity and social isolation, mixed martial arts gives fans a rush of harsh reality.
lead_paragraph: It comes as no surprise to its ardent followers that the Ultimate Fighting Championship, known as U.F.C., will be the first organization to stage a major professional sports event in the United States since the spread of Covid-19 induced a monthslong live sports hiatus. Its brash president, Dana White, never wanted to cease operations in the first place.

headline: 10 Films to Watch With Mom
abstract: Remind her that she’s the best: You can stream these shorts right here, from the safety of home.
lead_paragraph: Some of us may be far from family this year, but we can still celebrate Mom, wherever she is. We’ve put together a collection of our favorite short documentaries for Mother’s Day, by some of the best filmmakers around. Even if you’re not watching together, these are films to stream with family and then jump on the phone or Zoom to ask each other: Which one moved you most?

headline: Andre Harrell, Executive Who Bridged Hip-Hop and R&B, Dies at 59
abstract: He founded the influential label Uptown Records and gave a first break to Sean Combs, who would go on to become one of hip-hop’s signature moguls.
lead_paragraph: Andre Harrell, an innovative music executive who in the late 1980s founded Uptown Records, a crucial bridge between the worlds of hip-hop and R&B, and who gave the first career break to Sean Combs, today one of hip-hop’s signature moguls and global ambassadors, died on Thursday night at his home in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 59.

headline: Back to College in the Fall?
abstract: Students, parents and professors express their wishes and worries. “Parents are not going to play games with the lives of their children,” one reader says.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: An Ode to the Humble Balcony
abstract: It is private, yet public; exposed, yet secluded. It offers company without the demands of intimacy, and we should never take it for granted again.
lead_paragraph: My toddler and I have a new favorite activity: craning our necks to catch a glimpse of the neighbors. Since we have been instructed to stay at home in our apartment in a triple-decker in Somerville, Mass., we have gotten quite good at it.

headline: Will We Face Depression-Era Job Losses? Let’s Not Find Out
abstract: Congress should enact a federal jobs guarantee.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, the Labor Department announced that over 20.5 million Americans lost their jobs in April, bringing the unemployment rate to 14.7 percent. This level of devastation has not been reached since the Great Depression. With more than one in four companies shuttered to minimize the pandemic’s death toll and at least 30 million workers seeking unemployment benefits, we are in the throes of an unprecedented jobs crisis.

headline: F.D.A. Approves First Antigen Test for Detecting the Coronavirus
abstract: The test offers medical workers and health authorities an inexpensive tool for fast, mass screening.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first antigen test that can rapidly detect whether a person has been infected by the coronavirus, a significant advancement that promises to greatly expand the nation’s testing capacity.

headline: Whistle-Blower Exposes Infighting and Animus in Trump’s Coronavirus Response
abstract: The allegations suggest personal clashes influenced how the administration responded to the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The call in early February from the White House Situation Room came as a surprise to Rick Bright: Peter Navarro, President Trump’s trade adviser, wanted him to come present his ideas for fighting the coronavirus, alone.

headline: ‘Nerve-Racking and Very Unusual’: Snow in May Worries Growers
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic was already making life on the farm unpredictable, and then came an Arctic blast.
lead_paragraph: Across New York and New England, farmers and growers watched with worry on Saturday morning as a late season blast of Arctic air and even snow descended on fragile fruits and vegetables that had just begun to poke through.

headline: As South Korea Eases Limits, Virus Cluster Prompts Seoul to Close Bars
abstract: With no vaccine in sight, the country is urging people to reclaim more of their daily lives, while bracing for new waves that are all but inevitable.
lead_paragraph: Go out, socialize and have fun, South Korea’s government told its people, declaring the start of “a new daily life with Covid-19” — while keeping a vigilant eye out for any sign of backsliding, any need for restrictions to snap back into place.

headline: Why Some Women Call This Recession a ‘Shecession’
abstract: A majority of the jobs lost in April were held by women, a sharp reversal of gains in the labor market.
lead_paragraph: — C. Nicole Mason, president and chief executive of the Institute for Women’s Policy Research

headline: Live and Let Die, Trump-Style
abstract: The world’s greatest con artist has finally come up against a foe he can’t fool.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This is not a good time for vampires.

headline: William Barr’s Perversion of Justice
abstract: The attorney general is turning the Justice Department into a political weapon for the president.
lead_paragraph: “History is written by the winners,” William Barr, the attorney general, said Thursday when asked how he thought future generations would assess his decision to drop all criminal charges against Michael Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, who had pleaded guilty twice to breaking the law. “So it largely depends on who’s writing the history.”

headline: Hillary Never Married Bill
abstract: A new novel hypothesizes a different history — and future — for a trailblazing woman.
lead_paragraph: Curtis Sittenfeld likes to imagine the sex lives of presidents.

headline: Losing My Mom to Alzheimer’s, Then Finding Her Again
abstract: I wish someone had told me about the beauty that waited at the end of this journey.
lead_paragraph: I lost my mother at about this time last year, after her 10-year struggle with Alzheimer’s disease. During this past year, kind friends have checked in at holidays and birthdays, understandably assuming these first landmark occasions without my mom would be difficult. The truth is something that I was at first ashamed to admit, let alone articulate: Grieving her now, when the loss is complete, feels nothing like I had expected. It feels easy.

headline: For Flynn, Dropped Charges Are the Latest in a Life Full of Reversals
abstract: For most of his life, Michael Flynn has swung from being “a good soldier” to an agent of disruption.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There have always been two sides to Michael T. Flynn. There was the rebellious teenager who surfed during hurricanes and spent a night in juvenile reformatory. Then there was the adult who buckled down, joined the Army and rose to become a three-star general.

headline: Elon Musk Lashes Out at Officials Keeping Tesla Plant Closed Over Virus
abstract: He says he’ll move the headquarters of his electric car company out of California to Texas or Nevada.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk and local health officials in California clashed on Saturday over the timing of the reopening of Tesla’s factory in Fremont, with the company’s chief executive pushing for an immediate return and the county’s government seeking a delay of about a week.

headline: Jimmy Glenn, Ex-Boxer Whose Times Square Bar Endures, Dies at 89
abstract: A fighter, trainer, cutman and manager, he once owned both a bar and a gym. Only the bar survives. He died of coronavirus complications.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: A First Among Gerber Babies: She’s Adopted
abstract: Magnolia Earl, a 1-year-old from California, was selected from among more than 327,000 entrants to represent Gerber in marketing campaigns.
lead_paragraph: After featuring nearly a dozen tiny brand ambassadors as the face of its baby food and other early childhood products, Gerber announced on Friday it had selected the first adopted “spokesbaby” in its 92-year history.

headline: Divorcing Parents Have a Right to Post Their Stories Online, Court Says
abstract: A ruling in Massachusetts finds that involuntary nondisparagement orders, commonly used to keep spouses from discussing their cases on social media, are unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: The acrimonious split of Masha and Ronnie Shak ended up where many divorces do these days — on Facebook.

headline: Border Crossings
abstract: Adam Fromm’s Sunday puzzle gets through customs.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Everyone here loves to find the theme, and there’s something special about a theme that exposes something hidden in plain sight. Today we have an example of this phenomenon that takes “I can’t believe nobody ever noticed this before!” to the nth degree.

headline: How Justin Gaethje Won the Interim Lightweight Title at U.F.C. 249
abstract: Justin Gaethje beat Tony Ferguson in the fifth round to win an interim lightweight belt at U.F.C. 249. It was the first major American sporting event since widespread shutdowns because of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Justin Gaethje and Tony Ferguson were matched to provide action.

headline: Virus Conspiracists Elevate a New Champion
abstract: A video showcasing baseless arguments by Dr. Judy Mikovits, including attacks on Dr. Anthony Fauci, has been viewed more than eight million times in the past week.
lead_paragraph: In a video posted to YouTube on Monday, a woman animatedly described an unsubstantiated secret plot by global elites like Bill Gates and Dr. Anthony Fauci to use the coronavirus pandemic to profit and grab political power.

headline: Mysterious Coronavirus Illness Claims 3 Children in New York
abstract: A baffling ailment linked to Covid-19 has killed three young children and sickened 73 others across the state.
lead_paragraph: A mysterious syndrome has killed three young children in New York and sickened 73 others, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Saturday, an alarming rise in a phenomenon that was first publicly identified earlier this week.

headline: Angelina Jolie: A Mother’s Strength
abstract: This year, I’m remembering my mom’s spirit, and the power of so many women I’ve met around the world.
lead_paragraph: Mother’s Day is hard for anyone who has lost their mom, but this year must be particularly so because of coronavirus. So many people have lost a parent suddenly, without being by their side, able to care for them and return their love in the way they’d always imagined.

headline: In Chicago and Los Angeles, Virus Spread Is Slower, but Persistent
abstract: Cook County, Ill., which includes Chicago, added more new cases than any other U.S. county on some recent days.
lead_paragraph: As cases of the coronavirus spiraled upward in New York City, leaders of other big cities watched with worry, searching for ways to avoid an escalation of the magnitude that might overwhelm hospitals. In Chicago, the nation’s third-largest city, fear of explosive growth — the kind that overtook New York City, Detroit and New Orleans — has faded in recent days, but the Chicago area has faced its own stubbornly high numbers.

headline: Teenager, an Aspiring Detective, Returns $135,000 He Found
abstract: Jose Nuñez Romaniz, a criminal justice student, turned over the money to officials and was invited to apply for an entry-level job at the Albuquerque Police Department.
lead_paragraph: Jose Nuñez Romaniz was headed to the bank to deposit money so he could buy socks online for his grandfather when he came upon a large clear plastic bag filled with cash next to an A.T.M. in Albuquerque.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Deep Yearning for Hometown Lost to a Virus
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 10, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Just everything. I miss everything.”

headline: Victoria Hammarskjold, George Lemmon III
abstract: The couple met and began dating as high-school students.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Frances Hammarskjold and George Blackmore Lemmon III were married May 9. The couple self-united, as allowed by Pennsylvania law, at their home in Devon, Pa.

headline: Corrections: May 10, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 10, 2020.
lead_paragraph: A capsule summary of an article on Saturday about prosecutors’ concerns over Attorney General William P. Barr’s handling of the criminal case against President Trump’s former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn misstated the action taken by Mr. Barr. The attorney general dropped the case; Mr. Flynn was not pardoned.

headline: Boris Johnson Announces a Coronavirus Quarantine for Travelers to U.K.: Live Coverage
abstract: Coronavirus cases soar past 4 million as China finds a new cluster near Russia. Ethiopian troops may have shot down an aid plane in Somalia.
lead_paragraph: Worldwide, the officially reported number of coronavirus cases has soared above four million people across 177 countries, and more than a quarter million people have died, according to a New York Times database.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘I Know This Much Is True’ and ‘Call Your Mother’
abstract: Mark Ruffalo stars alongside himself in a new HBO limited series, and Comedy Central introduces us to the mothers who raised famous comedians.
lead_paragraph: I KNOW THIS MUCH IS TRUE 9 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. This limited series, based on Wally Lamb’s 1998 novel, stars Mark Ruffalo as the twins Dominick and Thomas Birdsey. Written and directed by Derek Cianfrance (“Blue Valentine,” “The Place Beyond the Pines”), the six-episode series follows Dominick as he tries to care for his brother, who has schizophrenia, and who cuts off his right hand in the opening scene of the book. To embody two distinctly different identical twins, Ruffalo told The New York Times that he gained 30 pounds during a six-week filming break before shooting his scenes as Thomas. As the twins deal with familial trauma and mental illness, they grapple with the messy nature of care and conflict.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Salutes Mothers as Baldwin’s Trump Gives Advice to Graduates
abstract: Tina Fey joined the Mother’s Day tribute in the remotely-produced season finale, which also featured Kristen Wiig and Boyz II Men.
lead_paragraph: A “Saturday Night Live” season that was more abrupt than intended and still more generous than it had to be came to a bittersweet end this weekend.

headline: Bangkok Opens Up as Virus Caseloads Drop, and Pretty Pups Benefit
abstract: Bangkok is crazy for purebred dogs. Some wear nail polish, and many wear clothes. Our overheated schnauzer needed a trim, and the government opened up pet groomers just in time.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — When the coronavirus lockdown in Bangkok eased a bit after six weeks, the first appointment my family made was not for a medical checkup or a walk in a park.

headline: Why the Path to Reopening New York City Will Be So Difficult
abstract: The factors that made the city one of the hardest hit on the planet — its density, mass transit and tourism — complicate a return to normalcy.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 190,000 people were tested for the coronavirus in New York City over the past two weeks, a record number. The increase in testing, crucial for curbing the outbreak, came as Mayor Bill de Blasio announced plans to hire a small army of 1,000 disease detectives to track down the contacts of every infected New Yorker.

headline: The Death of James Jordan: What We Know
abstract: Two men are serving life sentences in prison for the death of Michael Jordan’s father, James, in 1993. One has maintained his innocence, and the other is now under review for parole.
lead_paragraph: Update Aug. 18: Larry Demery, who pleaded guilty to first-degree murder in the death of James Jordan, has been granted parole and is scheduled to be released on Aug. 6, 2023.

headline: Keeping Online Testing Honest? Or an Orwellian Overreach?
abstract: The rise of proctoring software to deter cheating alarms privacy advocates. Some students and professors find it invasive, too.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — As Daniel Farzannekou prepared to take an online exam late last month in his naval science elective at the University of California, Los Angeles, the software directed him to pick up his laptop and scan his room, his desk, his ID and his face.

headline: Democrats’ Vote-by-Mail Effort Won in Wisconsin: Will It Work Elsewhere?
abstract: After winning by a surprising margin in a key Wisconsin judicial race, Democrats are hoping they can replicate the same game plan.
lead_paragraph: It was a shocking margin of victory in what was expected to be a close race: an 11-point blowout by a liberal judge over a conservative incumbent for a seat on the Wisconsin Supreme Court.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Lost Your Job but Still Have a 401(k)? Here’s What to Do With It
abstract: Many newly unemployed Americans may have to dip into retirement funds to cover expenses. Even if you don’t, you have some decisions to make.
lead_paragraph: Tens of millions of Americans have lost their jobs as the coronavirus ravages the economy, bringing the unemployment rate to a Great Depression-level 14.7 percent — and many are looking for emergency lifelines to meet living expenses.

headline: Franklin Graham Is Taking Down His N.Y. Hospital, but Not Going Quietly
abstract: His critics accuse him of discriminating against L.G.B.T. people. “Just because I don’t agree doesn’t mean I’m against them,” he said.
lead_paragraph: The last patients have been discharged from the Central Park field hospital run by Samaritan’s Purse, the evangelical organization led by the Rev. Franklin Graham. Its white tents will soon be dismantled and sent to new makeshift coronavirus wards as far away as Ecuador and Alaska.

headline: How Pandemics End
abstract: An infectious outbreak can conclude in more ways than one, historians say. But for whom does it end, and who gets to decide?
lead_paragraph: When will the Covid-19 pandemic end? And how?

headline: Pork Chops vs. People: Battling Coronavirus in an Iowa Meat Plant
abstract: After President Trump’s executive order, meat plants are reopening. Can they do so without endangering their low-wage workers and their communities?

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Make Dorie Greenspan’s latest, an elegant icebox cake, or a comforting alphabet soup.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. How are you doing? I know it’s not easy, not if you’re flying solo, not if you’re crammed into a too-small apartment with two dogs and a baby, not if you’re on a saltwater farm 17 miles from town with grandchildren romping in the soft spring grass. It’s not easy if you’re not working. It’s not easy if you’re working or going to school, either. It’s not easy for any of us. The future’s still out there, mirage-like in the distance. Sometimes it looks promising — as if summer could bring normalcy, a haircut, a trip to the crowded farmers’ market, a swim at the beach, at the pond, at the rec-center pool in town. But it’s often the opposite. Fear’s like that: awful and menacing. There’s so much we don’t know, can’t know, can’t imagine.

headline: In U.K., Hard-Hit Minority Communities Struggle to Bury the Dead

Treating scores of critically ill patients, we all observed similar patterns: Many of the patients we saw in our emergency rooms had advanced cases of Covid-19 pneumonia when they arrived — and many of those critically ill patients came from nursing homes.

headline: The Elites Were Living High. Then Came the Fall.
abstract: Modern cities can learn from the fate of the collapsed civilizations at Ugarit and Mycenae.
lead_paragraph: About 3,190 years ago, a merchant in Emar, a trading outpost in what is now northern Syria, sent a desperate letter to his boss, Urtenu, who lived in the rich metropolis of Ugarit, a city-state on the coast of Syria. “There is famine,” he wrote. “If you do not quickly arrive here, we ourselves will die of hunger.”

headline: Colorado Hair Salons Are Reopening, With New Rules
abstract: At one salon, beauticians are now wearing face masks and gloves, and no walk-ins are allowed.
lead_paragraph: LOVELAND, Colo. — Last Tuesday, during the first few days that this state loosened restrictions on businesses that were temporarily closed because of the novel coronavirus, Blush Beauty Bar reopened for appointments. It was the first time that customers had been allowed inside the hair salon in 48 days, and the stylists were booked solid. (They remain so through the end of the month.)

headline: Jason Isbell, Self-Doubt and the Album That Tested His Marriage
abstract: The 41-year-old musician is known as one of the best songwriters in the country. And that just may have been the problem.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks into coronavirus-compelled self-quarantine at his home on a rolling patch of land 30 minutes south of Nashville, Jason Isbell did something he hadn’t done in more than eight years.

headline: Fulfilling the Promise of Our Cities
abstract: It’s a dark hour for America’s cities, but they’re critical to building a better nation.
lead_paragraph: It turns out that New York does sleep, or, at least, that it can be induced to. Through the collective efforts of its people, its racing pulse has been slowed to a deep, muffled beat, one they strain to hear as they walk by padlocked playgrounds, down emptied streets.

lead_paragraph: How much money is a life worth?

lead_paragraph: Six years ago, when President Barack Obama had to replace his departing attorney general, he offered the job to Kamala Harris, who led the California Justice Department — the first woman to occupy that role in its history.

headline: How Do You Enforce a Law That Tramples the Land of the Free?
abstract: Angela Alvarado, a veteran prosecutor in the Santa Clara district attorney’s office in California, has to weigh safety, freedom and the law as she fields complaints about stay-at-home violations.
lead_paragraph: LOS ALTOS, Calif. — A veteran prosecutor in Northern California has turned her kitchen table into an improvised command post where she is enforcing Santa Clara County’s strict lockdown order.

headline: Why Economic Pain Could Persist Even After the Pandemic Is Contained
abstract: Plunging revenue at many businesses, whether they close or not, could ripple through the economy and block a quick return to prosperity.
lead_paragraph: The one great reason for economic optimism during this pandemic is that once public health concerns are addressed, the economy could quickly return to something like pre-crisis levels.

headline: A Pandemic Benefit: The Expansion of Telemedicine
abstract: Medical practice over the internet can result in faster diagnoses and treatments, increase the efficiency of care and reduce patient stress.
lead_paragraph: Even if no other good for health care emerges from the coronavirus crisis, one development — the incorporation of telemedicine into routine medical care — promises to be transformative. Using technology that already exists and devices that most people have in their homes, medical practice over the internet can result in faster diagnoses and treatments, increase the efficiency of care and reduce patient stress.

headline: The Night the Lights Went Out in Nashville
abstract: This year has brought tornadoes, plague and weather patterns we’ve never heard of. On the bright side, no murder hornets yet.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — By March 22, the day Mayor John Cooper issued a safer-at-home order here to slow the transmission of the coronavirus, the city had already been in crisis mode for nearly three weeks. Monster tornadoes had ripped through this region, killing 25 people and demolishing hundreds of buildings, including nearly 400 homes in Nashville alone. And it’s pretty hard to shelter in place when your shelter has just taken a ride through the sky.

lead_paragraph: Bob Grewal recently began testing a new health-screening setup for workers at a Subway restaurant he owns in Los Angeles near the University of Southern California.

headline: They Fled the Coronavirus. Now They’re in Scenic Limbo.
