headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Heartbreak for Children: When the County Fair Is Canceled’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the importance of annual summer fairs and livestock shows and how local farm clubs are adapting in the face of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “A Heartbreak for Children: When the County Fair Is Canceled” by Dionne Searcey

headline: Appeals Court Allows Emoluments Suit Against Trump to Proceed
abstract: The court rejected the president’s request to dismiss a case brought by the State of Maryland and the District of Columbia regarding his Washington hotel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court in Virginia on Thursday revived a lawsuit accusing President Trump of violating the Constitution by profiting from his Washington hotel, a decision that will most likely lead the Justice Department to appeal to the Supreme Court to keep the plaintiffs from gathering evidence in the case.

headline: Should National Service Be Required for All Young Americans?
abstract: Do you think that serving your country — for example, by working with children or training for emergencies — should be mandatory?
lead_paragraph: In Ghana, all young adults who graduate from an accredited university, college or trade school must complete one year of service in agriculture, health, education, local government or rural development.

headline: Months After Louisville Police Kill Woman in Her Home, Governor Calls for Review
abstract: The police said officers shot and killed Breonna Taylor, 26, in a March raid after her boyfriend shot an officer in the leg.
lead_paragraph: Two months after Louisville police officers fatally shot a woman as they raided her home, Gov. Andy Beshear of Kentucky said on Wednesday that local, state and federal prosecutors should review the police investigation into the shooting.

headline: I Left My Husband Before the Pandemic. Can I Go Back to Him Now?
abstract: In the midst of a global health crisis, my old life is looking pretty good.
lead_paragraph: In February, I left my husband after being married for 18 years. We were teen parents who managed to keep it together, and our three amazing kids are almost grown. We were a heck of team, but we put each other through too much. Now, add the coronavirus! Sometimes, I just want to go home to the safety of my husband and have our kids under one roof again. I can’t be sure how I would be doing if this virus hadn’t come along. But if I go back, I’m afraid I won’t be able to leave him twice. What should I do?

headline: The Show’s Delayed, but They’re Still Keeping ‘Company’
abstract: By trans-Atlantic email, Patti LuPone and the Broadway director Marianne Elliott talk fear, sadness, camaraderie and the ethics of buying eggs from a Trump supporter.
lead_paragraph: The revival of “Company” was in previews and 10 days from opening when Broadway shut down. And opening night was meant to be especially special, timed to the 90th birthday of the musical’s composer Stephen Sondheim. Soon after, the show’s director, Marianne Elliott, returned to her husband and producing partner, Nick Sidi, and their daughter in London, while one of its stars, Patti LuPone, headed to the Connecticut home she shares with her husband, Matthew Johnston, and their son.

headline: A Cop Gets Away With Murder, Italian Style
abstract: The Criterion Channel is revisiting “Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion,” Elio Petri’s Oscar-winning movie from 1970.
lead_paragraph: A sleekly self-assured police chief pays an afternoon call on his slinky, kinky mistress. “How are you going to kill me today?” she purrs. Not only does he do so, but he also takes care to leave incriminating evidence everywhere around her place — daring his minions and superiors to find him guilty. (Is the killer an “idiot” or what, one investigator wonders.)

headline: G.O.P. Defiance of Pennsylvania’s Lockdown Has 2020 Implications
abstract: Gov. Tom Wolf, a Democrat, said it was a “cowardly act” for Republican officials to flout his virus stay-at-home orders. But conservatives see rising anger that could lift turnout in November.
lead_paragraph: [Read our 2020 presidential election electoral college explainer.]

headline: An African Literary Festival for the Age of Coronavirus
abstract: Book events worldwide are on hold, but Afrolit Sans Frontieres uses social media to host frank discussions around writing, creativity, sex and violence.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — For the novelist Maaza Mengiste, the coronavirus lockdowns and stay-at-home measures that have taken hold around the world have brought back the sense of exile she felt when she and her family fled Ethiopia in the 1970s.

headline: W.T.O. Chief Quits Suddenly, Adding to Global Turmoil
abstract: Roberto Azevêdo, director-general of the World Trade Organization, has been a proponent of international cooperation, putting him at odds with the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The head of the organization charged with bringing a semblance of order to international trade relations resigned unexpectedly Thursday, adding another element of uncertainty to commerce in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic and escalating trade conflicts.

headline: Jonathan Adewumi, Who Made Everyone Feel at Home, Dies at 57
abstract: Proud of his Nigerian heritage, he brought Africa to New York and, at his Brooklyn restaurant, united a community.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: My Kids Are Allergic to Video Chats
abstract: Many children are struggling to find their footing in the land of virtual friendships, one that involves unfamiliar technology and face-to-face communication skills online.
lead_paragraph: Since entering the world of pandemic parenting, I’ve found most of my kids’ behaviors to be reasonably predictable. For example, I knew my strong-willed 8-year-old would not love having me as his teacher; that my attached-at-my-hip 4-year-old would be especially clingy; and that they would both be asking me seemingly nonstop for a snack or to watch a TV show. This has all checked out. But there has been one behavior that has left me puzzled: their disinterest (and often downright disdain) for communicating with their friends online.

headline: The Drama Behind “Mad Max: Fury Road” Nearly Rivaled the Action Onscreen
abstract: Delays, fatigue, squabbles and harrowing stunts: Our reporter talked to the actors and director about the making of the action masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: Delays, fatigue, squabbles and harrowing stunts: Our reporter talked to the actors and director about the making of the action masterpiece.

headline: For Farmers of Wine Grapes, the Pandemic Sows Doubts
abstract: As wineries face disruptions in sales and cash flow, growers seek creative solutions to help their customers and themselves.
lead_paragraph: Ann Kraemer’s vineyard, Shake Ridge Ranch, covers 46 acres of rocky hillsides near Sutter Creek, in the Sierra Foothills of California.

headline: To Fight Waste and Hunger, Food Banks Start Cooking
abstract: As farmers throw away produce and other Americans line up for food, relief groups are connecting the two by turning those ingredients into meals.
lead_paragraph: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla. — The new kitchen was still under construction here at the Palm Beach County branch of Feeding South Florida, a food bank, when Chrissy Benoit walked through the warehouse in March. Fruits and vegetables had started arriving in unusually large amounts from nearby farms, which got her thinking about the cooking she would do when the kitchen was finished.

headline: As Coronavirus Overruns Russia, Doctors Are Dying on the Front Lines
abstract: Facing dire shortages of protective gear and amid fears that the worst is yet to come, more than 180 medical workers are reported to have fallen victim so far and thousands have been infected.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Dr. Rimma Kamalova says her hospital’s leadership ignored her warnings about an unexplained pneumonia outbreak back in March. She kept working.

headline: The New Museum Is Offering Strange Stories for Trying Times
abstract: The conceptual artist Maurizio Cattelan conceived of the “Bedtime Stories” series as a way to foster a sense of connection during the coronavirus crisis.
lead_paragraph: It is no surprise that the storytelling series Maurizio Cattelan initiated doesn’t include “Goodnight Moon” or “The Tale of Peter Rabbit.” As an artist, Mr. Cattelan is known for skillfully subverting the expectations of his audience. Instead “Bedtime Stories,” a new digital offering from the New Museum, features cultural luminaries like David Byrne, Takashi Murakami and Elizabeth Peyton sharing selections from their favorite books, many of which are not standard nighttime fare for children or adults.

headline: G.D.P. Doesn’t Credit Social Distancing, but It Should
abstract: A better measure of economic growth would count our efforts to protect public health and refocus the debate about how to “reopen the economy.”
lead_paragraph: The United States is in a deep recession, but the official numbers are missing something big.

headline: Music, Theater and More to Experience at Home This Weekend
abstract: Our writers offer suggestions for what to watch or listen to while we’re housebound.
lead_paragraph: A stalwart of the traditional album cycle, Taylor Swift tends to juice her releases harder, and longer, than most artists. With the exception of her debut, she followed up each of her albums with a monthslong, intercontinental stadium tour. “Lover,” her seventh record, demanded an extra special touch: “open, fields, sunsets, + SUMMER,” Swift posted on Twitter. Shortly after delivering the album in August, she announced that she would once again be making the rounds with a string of European dates and so-called Lover Fests in the United States, all of which was to start in June.

headline: Now Streaming: French Movies for Every Niche
abstract: In honor of the Cannes Film Festival, which would have been playing now, stream these titles that celebrate the diversity of contemporary French cinema.
lead_paragraph: While various European film industries were decimated over the decades, France still stands strong, cranking out dozens of movies a year in every genre imaginable.

headline: Poor Americans Hit Hardest by Job Losses Amid Lockdowns, Fed Says
abstract: Fully 39 percent of former workers in households earning $40,000 or less lost work, and a new Federal Reserve survey shows many families have few resources to make it through.
lead_paragraph: Households entered the coronavirus shutdown in precarious economic positions that have only worsened as workers are furloughed by the millions, and the challenges are especially acute for the poorest Americans, according to a Federal Reserve survey released Thursday.

headline: The Art Collections Are Real; the Owners Are Not
abstract: Fanny Pereire is the curator behind many eye-popping paintings you see in movies and TV shows like “Succession” and “Mrs. America.”
lead_paragraph: Episode 2 of “Mrs. America,” the new TV show dramatizing the battle over the Equal Rights Amendment, features a glamorous party at the Guggenheim Museum. It’s 1972, and Gloria Steinem is launching her new magazine, Ms. She mingles, dances and then talks shop with a fellow women’s movement leader, Bella Abzug. As the two walk up the museum’s ramp, artworks on the walls peek out behind them.

headline: Richard Burr Steps Back From Senate Panel as Phone Is Seized in Stock Sales Inquiry
abstract: The move is a major escalation in the investigation into the senator’s sale of stocks that came as President Trump and other Republicans were playing down the threat of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Richard M. Burr of North Carolina temporarily stepped down on Thursday as chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, a day after F.B.I. agents seized his cellphone as part of an investigation into whether he sold hundreds of thousands of dollars’ worth of stocks using nonpublic information about the coronavirus.

headline: 33 Teen-Chosen Quarantine Reads: The Results of Our Special April Challenge
abstract: We asked students to tell us what they’re reading in The Times right now, and learned that, like many of us, they are both trying to understand this crisis — and distract themselves from it.
lead_paragraph: When The Times announced in early April that all high school students in the United States could get three months of free digital access, we created a Special April Challenge to encourage students to first, explore NYTimes.com, and then, tell us what they read, watched or listened to and why. Over 200 teenagers participated, and our judges have chosen favorites, below.

headline: E.P.A. Opts Against Limits on Water Contaminant Tied to Fetal Damage
abstract: A new E.P.A. policy on perchlorate, which is used in rocket fuel, would revoke a 2011 finding that the chemical should be regulated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration will not impose any limits on perchlorate, a toxic chemical compound that contaminates water and has been linked to fetal and infant brain damage, according to two Environmental Protection Agency staff members familiar with the decision.

headline: Quartz to Lay Off 80 Employees
abstract: Nearly half the employees at the international business news site will lose their jobs as the eight-year-old outlet emphasizes paid subscriptions over advertising revenue.
lead_paragraph: Quartz, a business news site with offices around the world, is laying off nearly half its staff in a substantial restructuring after the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic drastically cut into its advertising revenue.

headline: The Joys of Fixing Your Own Stuff
abstract: With jobs lost and stores closed, people are now reviving their old gadgets on their own.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Jerzy Glowczewski, Polish Pilot in a Spitfire, Dies at 97
abstract: He fled Warsaw when the Nazis invaded, flew 100 combat missions, and made a life as an architect in Poland, Egypt and the United States. He died of the coronavirus in New York.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: National Service: An Idea Whose Time Has Come
abstract: Readers agree enthusiastically with David Brooks and offer their own twists.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fear, Trauma, Hope and Calm
abstract: For two months, I shot New Yorkers responding to the pandemic. I’m still processing what I saw.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Viewing Party! Let’s All Watch ‘What’s Up, Doc?’
abstract: Does this 1972 farce — starring a madcap Barbra Streisand and a flustered Ryan O’Neal, and directed by Peter Bogdanovich — still have the screwball goods?
lead_paragraph: We’re feeling loopy and a little loony tunes under lockdown, and bet you are, too. We want to run around in the great outdoors, chase after a pizza-delivery guy and maybe throw a cream pie in someone’s face, all of which happens in the madcap comedy “What’s Up, Doc?”

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: I participated this week in a virtual “Battle of the Books,” hosted by my local bookstore and moderated by James Mustich, the author of “1,000 Books to Read Before You Die.” The premise: Persuade the audience to vote for a book that Jim should have included on his list but didn’t. The format: Five contestants get four minutes each to make the case for a book of their choosing, from how-to (a cookbook, a feng shui decorating book) to fiction (José Saramago’s “Blindness,” Anton Myrer’s “Once an Eagle”) to — my pick — “The Journals of John Cheever,” which I consider his crowning achievement.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Easing Lockdowns
abstract: When easing social-distancing rules during the pandemic, should certain businesses and public places reopen first, while others remain closed?
lead_paragraph: Note: This is our final graph for the 2019-20 school year. Please visit our archive to find dozens of other graphs you can use between now and September, when we will resume this feature. You can also sign up for our free weekly newsletter to make sure you don’t miss any of our new graphs.

headline: Canned Cocktails in Quarantine Make Mixing a One-Step Process
abstract: Already on an upswing in recent years, the sales of pre-mixed drinks are now booming.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Wuslich, a founder of Cardinal Spirits in Bloomington, Ind., looked over a stack of more than 100 cases of canned cocktails at the distillery. There are three varieties: a Bramble Mule, made with vodka, raspberry juice, hibiscus and ginger; a Maui Mule, made with vodka, passion-fruit juice and ginger; and a vodka soda.

headline: Amazon’s Showdown in France Tests Its Ability to Sidestep Labor
abstract: The pandemic has intensified the push-pull between labor and the retail giant, which is required by European law to deal with unions — and has prospered anyway.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Workers at Amazon’s six mammoth French warehouses won some concessions from the company in late March: After hundreds of employees threatened to walk out unless the company better protected them from the coronavirus, the internet giant strengthened social distancing measures, provided masks and hand sanitizer and took employee temperatures.

headline: Trump’s Criticism of Fauci
abstract: The health care expert told the Senate “what Donald Trump did not want them to hear,” a reader writes. Also: The president’s tax records; the Colombian government, on alleged army spying.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: On Second Viewing, First Impressions Don’t Always Hold
abstract: Watching familiar plays online can be a comfort — and sometimes a revelation.
lead_paragraph: I hadn’t expected Simon Stephens’s “Sea Wall” to come to the rescue. Then suddenly there it was, saving me. A play that ran on Broadway just last summer, it also exists as a quietly gorgeous little film that feels like a gift from the past arriving exactly on time.

headline: How to Preserve and Store Your Hearty Greens
abstract: Blanch and freeze kale, collards and other leafy greens to maintain their bright flavor and texture.
lead_paragraph: Whether you’re returning from an overambitious trip to the supermarket or organizing an unruly haul from your C.S.A. or farmers’ market, storing your seasonal bounty can be a challenge. Sturdy greens like kale, collard greens, Swiss chard, mustard greens and others can take up a lot of valuable real estate. You can store them in a fraction of the space — and prolong their life — by simply chilling them raw or cooked, or blanching and freezing them. Here’s how.

headline: This Atlas of Art and Memory Is a Wonder of the Modern World
abstract: With nearly 1,000 images, Aby Warburg’s radical form of visual study is also an artwork itself. Now you can see it online.
lead_paragraph: For most of us, it’s natural to look at many pictures at the same time. We do it every day via internet searches and digital pinup boards — even refrigerator doors have become ad hoc photo albums.

headline: Italian Hostage’s Release Erupts Into Clashes Over Islam and Ransom
abstract: The conversion to Islam by Silvia Romano, an Italian aid worker kidnapped by a group said to be linked to the Shabab, was met with insults and threats.
lead_paragraph: ROME — When word surfaced last weekend that a kidnapped 24-year-old Italian aid worker had been released after 18 months in captivity in Africa, Italians were overjoyed after weeks of relentlessly gloomy coronavirus-driven news.

headline: Laurie Anderson and Michael Stipe on Music, Art and New Chapters
abstract: “You’ve got to fall on your face to sit at the table,” says the erstwhile R.E.M. frontman.
lead_paragraph: At 72, no one would fault Laurie Anderson, the avant-garde multimedia icon — an inventor, performance artist, musician, writer, filmmaker, painter and more — for being nostalgic. She is best known for her 1981 surprise hit song, “O Superman,” a visionary tirade against American imperialism, built on looped vocal effects that seemed to predict the next three decades or so of pop music. In recent years, Anderson has been moonlighting as an archivist, shaping the legacy of her husband and collaborator, Lou Reed, who died in 2013. (His archives, which include letters, photographs and recordings, are now housed at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts and are available to anyone with a library card.) But the experience of looking backward, immersed in another’s oeuvre, has only made Anderson’s own work more forward-looking.

headline: Richard Gilder, Donor to Parks, Museum and History, Dies at 87
abstract: A successful investor, he was a major benefactor of Central Park, the New-York Historical Society and the Museum of Natural History.
lead_paragraph: Richard Gilder, a billionaire investor and benefactor who was instrumental in revitalizing two neglected exemplars of American democracy — the study of American history and Central Park — died on Tuesday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 87.

headline: Martin Lovett, Last Living Member of the Amadeus Quartet, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Lovett played cello in the celebrated ensemble, which performed together for 40 years. He died of complications of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The Amadeus, a string quartet of extraordinary longevity, set the gold standard in chamber music for four decades after World War II. Their style was a burnish on the Viennese tradition of smooth, lush string playing; they shone above a foundation provided by the solid, undemonstrative voice of their cellist, Martin Lovett.

headline: Will the Pandemic Make the West More Vulnerable to Wildfires?
abstract: The fight against Covid-19 has disrupted preparations for the fire season.
lead_paragraph: The last thing we need right now is another risk to worry about. But across much of the American West, wildfires should be a big concern as summer approaches. This is especially true in Northern California, where the winter of 2019-20 was exceptionally dry and has set the stage for a potentially frightening wildfire season.

headline: What Churches Really Think About Opening Up
abstract: Pastors who ignore coronavirus restrictions grab headlines. But most are being very careful about worship during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: I pastor a church in Sonoma County, Calif., under what has been one of the strictest shelter-in-place orders in the country. We haven’t met for in-person worship services since March 8. We’ve spent the past two months with services, prayer times and Bible studies online. Gov. Gavin Newsom has announced that churches will not be meeting in large assemblies for some time. So with God’s help, prayer and encouragement from one another, we’re drawing upon deeper spiritual and relational resources as we seek to grow in patience, learn to wait and find new ways to minister to those in need.

headline: ‘I Wish I Could Do Something for You,’ My Doctor Said
abstract: Young, healthy people like me are getting very, very sick from the disease caused by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The day before I got sick, I ran three miles, walked 10 more, then raced up the stairs to my fifth-floor apartment as always, slinging laundry with me as I went.

headline: Goodbye to One of the Most Complex Black Women on TV
abstract: “How to Get Away With Murder” is coming to an end, leaving behind a groundbreaking legacy.
lead_paragraph: It was the gasp heard in millions of living rooms around the country.

headline: Want to Try a Robert Bresson Film? Look to Clint Eastwood
abstract: One of the most original French filmmakers of his era can also be theoretical. Take his “A Man Escaped.” The American “Escape From Alcatraz” is a good companion piece.
lead_paragraph: Writing about the hard-edged American filmmaker Don Siegel (“Dirty Harry”), the critic Andrew Sarris once made an offhand observation about Siegel’s 1979 “Escape From Alcatraz,” starring Clint Eastwood. Siegel, he wrote, seemed “to have been inspired by Robert Bresson’s ‘A Man Escaped’ (1956).”

headline: How We Can Get the Next Phase of the Coronavirus Right
abstract: Six ways to survive our pandemic summer.
lead_paragraph: Heading into our pandemic summer, my biggest worry is that in the effort to get Americans to flatten the coronavirus curve, nobody prepared the country for what comes next.

headline: A Caddie’s Most Important Measure of Distance? Now It’s Six Feet
abstract: Professional golf is making plans to resume play even as coronavirus concerns linger, leaving players and caddies to figure out how close is close enough for a consultation.
lead_paragraph: Missy Pederson is eager to get back to work caddying for the two-time major winner Brittany Lincicome on the L.P.G.A. Tour, which is scheduled to resume its season in July, five months after it was suspended because of the coronavirus crisis. “I’m chomping at the bit,” Pederson said on Tuesday in a telephone interview from her home in Minnesota.

headline: Yes, Kids Can Get Migraines. Here Are the Signs.
abstract: The chronic condition, typically thought of as an ‘adult’ problem, can affect up to 3 percent of kids between 3 and 7.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago, long before the novel coronavirus was a threat, my son started calling out to us soon after we tucked him in at night. Sometimes he would ask for an extra kiss, back rub or drink of water. All normal for a 5-year-old. But occasionally, he would report that his room looked funny. “Things that are close look far,” he would say. “And things that are far look close.”

headline: Ralph W. McGehee, Agent Who Exposed the C.I.A., Dies at 92
abstract: A crisis of conscience in Vietnam led him to conclude that the agency was “a malevolent force” and to lay it bare in a memoir, “Deadly Deceits.”
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Post-Quarantine Plans, Leadership and Masks
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we asked teenagers to tell us what they are looking forward to once quarantine ends, describe the qualities they admire in a leader, and detail how their communities are responding to new civic rules in the coronavirus era.

headline: Travis McCready Concert Is Postponed, but Not Happily
abstract: The decision came after Arkansas officials barred the concert, billed as the first since the virus hit, and pulled the venue’s liquor license.
lead_paragraph: The Arkansas authorities Thursday seized the liquor license of a concert hall planning what had been billed as the first major rock concert since the pandemic, forcing the promoters to delay the show, which was originally scheduled for Friday in Fort Smith.

headline: As Virus Ravages Budgets, States Cut and Borrow for Balance
abstract: Balanced-budget laws are on the books in 49 states, and that means hard choices over cuts and borrowing as help from the federal government remains in limbo.
lead_paragraph: In February, Ohio was running a $200 million budget surplus. Then the coronavirus pandemic struck, wiping out the surplus — and then some. Tax revenue plummeted and public health expenses skyrocketed.

headline: The Pandemic Helped Topple Two Retailers. So Did Private Equity.
abstract: At a time when J. Crew and Neiman Marcus needed to be investing money to adjust to changing shopping habits, enormous sums were going to their owners.
lead_paragraph: J. Crew and Neiman Marcus were each facing a host of issues before the coronavirus pandemic forced them to close their stores and eventually file for bankruptcy, including trouble adjusting to the rise of e-commerce and a lack of connection with a new generation of shoppers.

headline: Five: The Accidental Emperor
abstract: How one outsider came to rule the internet — and eventually embody its battle with mainstream culture.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Google Podcasts | Via Spotify

headline: Disney Closes ‘Frozen’ on Broadway, Citing Pandemic
abstract: The show is the first Broadway musical felled by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Even Queen Elsa’s magic is no match for the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: He Saw ‘No Proof’ Closures Would Curb Virus. Now He Has De Blasio’s Trust.
abstract: The head of New York City’s public hospitals pushed to keep the city open in early March. Now the mayor has put him in charge of contact tracing, deepening a rift with the Health Department.
lead_paragraph: As Mayor Bill de Blasio was resisting calls in March to cancel large gatherings and slow the spread of the coronavirus in New York City, he found behind-the-scenes support from a trusted voice: the head of his public hospital system, Dr. Mitchell Katz.

headline: Review: ‘Snowpiercer’ on a New Track
abstract: TNT’s dystopian class-warfare thriller, set on a giant train endlessly circling a frozen earth, runs the sensibility of Bong Joon Ho through the switchyard of basic cable.
lead_paragraph: It took seven years, and some stops and starts, for the 2013 South Korean film “Snowpiercer” to get remade as an American television series. It was just long enough for the film’s director, Bong Joon Ho, to give the show a publicity boost by winning multiple Oscars this year for “Parasite,” his latest violent allegory about the haves and have-nots.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Mumbai outbreak, Rohingya camps, 1MDB: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: There’s a reason Indians call Mumbai “Maximum City.”

headline: Furiosa’s Back: George Miller Discusses the Next ‘Mad Max’ Movie
abstract: The ‘Fury Road’ director is currently casting a prequel, but Furiosa may look a little different this time around.
lead_paragraph: It’s been five years since “Mad Max: Fury Road” came out in theaters, but if the director George Miller has his way, Furiosa will soon ride again.

headline: New Loop, America
abstract: How dystopian and utopian shows like “Westworld” and “Hollywood” can help us map out a better future.
lead_paragraph: In our final episode from our living rooms, we visit the dystopia of “Westworld” and the utopia of “Hollywood” to see if we can glean anything about what might be in store on the other side of this pandemic — and about who we want to be.

headline: Coronavirus May Pose a New Risk to Younger Patients: Strokes
abstract: Doctors have reported a flurry of cases in Covid-19 patients — including a healthy 27-year-old emergency medical technician in Queens. After a month in the hospital, he is learning to walk again.

headline: McDonald’s Details What Dining In Will Look Like
abstract: The fast-food chain distributed a guide to franchise owners with instructions like putting “closed” signs on tables to promote social-distancing and cleaning bathrooms every half-hour.
lead_paragraph: Clean the digital kiosks each time a customer orders. Place “closed” signs on certain tables to promote social-distancing. Scrub the bathrooms every half-hour.

headline: Talking Can Generate Coronavirus Droplets That Linger Up to 14 Minutes
abstract: A new study shows how respiratory droplets produced during normal conversation may be just as important in transmitting disease, especially indoors.
lead_paragraph: Coughs or sneezes may not be the only way people transmit infectious pathogens like the novel coronavirus to one another. Talking can also launch thousands of droplets so small they can remain suspended in the air for eight to 14 minutes, according to a new study.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Catch an offbeat and newly available comedy, as well a lush and devilish new spin on period drama, starring Elle Fanning.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: ‘It Could Happen Anytime’: Scientists Warn of Alaska Tsunami Threat
abstract: A retreating glacier is increasing the risk of a catastrophic landslide and tsunami within a few decades, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Climate change has increased the risk of a huge landslide in an Alaskan fjord that could cause a catastrophic tsunami, scientists said Thursday.

headline: When Can Kids Go Back to Class?
abstract: The economy can’t fully reopen until schools do.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Jobless Claims, Food Supply, Rovers: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Senate Approves Surveillance Bill With Sharper Privacy Safeguards
abstract: The Senate voted to revive three F.B.I. tools for counterintelligence and counterterrorism investigations and amped up a House-passed proposal to bolster outside critics appointed to oppose wiretap requests in court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted on Thursday to reinstate a set of expired F.B.I. tools used to investigate terrorism and espionage that lapsed this spring, adopting modest new privacy protections for Americans swept up in national security cases.

headline: Paralegal for U.S. Attorney Tipped Off Drug Cartel, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Jennifer Loya, 30, helped a drug network in San Antonio stay a step ahead of drug enforcement agents through her access to information as a federal employee, according to court documents.
lead_paragraph: Just before they were raided by federal agents, drug dealers in San Antonio affiliated with a Mexican cartel moved their stockpiles of heroin, methamphetamine and cocaine.  A paralegal in the federal prosecutor’s office tipped them off, the authorities said.

headline: The Virus Killed an Officer. His Town Lined the Streets to Mourn Him.
abstract: Charles Roberts, who died at age 45, was the “poster image” of a police officer, said a colleague in the New Jersey town where he worked for 20 years.
lead_paragraph: GLEN RIDGE, N.J. — For three weeks, a small town in northern New Jersey kept vigil over Officer Charles Roberts.

headline: Behind the Cover: Funeral Homes
abstract: For this issue, a look at how funeral homes are struggling to fulfill their mission to grieving families.

headline: T.S.M.C. Is Set to Build a U.S. Chip Facility, a Win for Trump
abstract: The White House has called for building up U.S. manufacturing and criticized a tech supply chain centered in China.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company has agreed to build an advanced chip factory in the United States, in a response to the Trump administration’s growing concerns about the security of the global electronics supply chain and its competitive tensions with China.

headline: ‘Lives Were Lost’ as Warnings Went Unheeded, Whistle-Blower Tells House
abstract: Dr. Rick Bright testified that he made early appeals that the Trump administration prepare for the coronavirus. President Trump and his health secretary snapped back.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The whistle-blower who was ousted as the head of a federal medical research agency charged on Thursday that top Trump administration officials failed to heed his early warnings to stock up on masks and other supplies to combat the coronavirus, and that Americans died as a result.

headline: Ordinary People Are Leading the Leaders
abstract: America looks better from the bottom up.
lead_paragraph: We have entered the endurance phase of this pandemic. We are slowly mastering this disease, but we have not yet done so. And so we wait — and endure.

headline: Covid-19 Reality Has a Liberal Bias
abstract: Unfortunately, the virus doesn’t care about political spin.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the U.S. government’s top experts warned that Covid-19 was by no means under control, and that premature easing of social distancing could have disastrous consequences. As far as I can tell, their view is shared by almost all epidemiologists.

headline: Biden on Assault Allegation: ‘I Wouldn’t Vote for Me if I Believed Tara Reade’
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Americans should “vote their heart,” but also sharpened his criticism of Ms. Reade’s claim. And he made appearances on Thursday with two women in the running to be his vice president.
lead_paragraph: Capping a day in which he appeared with two Democratic women in the running to be his vice president, Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Thursday night that he did not remember Tara Reade, the woman who has accused him of sexual assault, and said that Americans “probably shouldn’t vote for me” if they believe the accusation, which he has strenuously denied.

headline: Screams in a Park, a Body With a Tattoo and MS-13 Is Now Accused
abstract: New federal charges accuse members of the gang of committing murders in a Queens park, on a subway platform and outside a residential home.
lead_paragraph: The 911 callers said they heard screams coming from the woods near a park in Queens.

headline: Outsider Tapped in Flynn Case Regarded as ‘Straight Arrow’
abstract: John Gleeson, a retired federal judge and former mob prosecutor, will oppose the Justice Department’s move to drop a charge against President Trump’s former national security adviser.
lead_paragraph: The New York mob boss John J. Gotti rose in court one day in 1991 as he was nearing trial and jabbed his finger at the baby-faced Brooklyn prosecutor handling his case.

headline: Navy Reports Describe Encounters With Unexplained Flying Objects
abstract: While some of the encounters have been reported publicly before, the Navy records are an official accounting of the incidents, including descriptions from the pilots of what they saw.
lead_paragraph: Navy fighter pilots reported close encounters with unidentified aerial vehicles, including several dangerously close, in eight incidents between June 27, 2013, and Feb. 13, 2019, according to documents recently released by the Navy.

headline: We Need Tuition-Free College. For Adults.
abstract: Much as the G.I. Bill served to power the postwar American economy, a federal guarantee of education for workers could accelerate an economic recovery now.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan recently announced a plan to make essential pandemic workers in her state eligible for free college. The program will be directed at staff members at hospitals and nursing homes, grocery store clerks, sanitation workers, police officers, delivery people and others working on the front lines to help people in Michigan survive this crisis.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Bid for Virus Protections in Texas Prison
abstract: The case was brought by two older inmates who said their lives were endangered by prison policies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court denied a request on Thursday from two inmates in a Texas geriatric prison to reinstate a trial judge’s order instructing officials to take steps to protect them from the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: In 3 Key States That Elected Trump, Bitter Divisions on Reopening
abstract: With Democratic governors and Republican legislatures, ending stay-at-home orders mixes health guidance and partisan politics.
lead_paragraph: WAUKESHA, Wis. — In Wisconsin, residents woke up to a state of confusion on Thursday after the conservative majority on the State Supreme Court sided with the Republican majority in the Legislature on Wednesday night, overturning a statewide stay-at-home order by Gov. Tony Evers, a Democrat.

headline: U.S. Prison Population Remained Stable as Pandemic Grew
abstract: The number of inmates in federal and state prisons in 44 states declined by 1.6 percent in the first three months of the year, even as prisons became hot spots for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The United States prison population remained stable in the early months of the year, decreasing by just 1.6 percent from January through March even as prisons emerged as incubators for the spread of Covid-19, according to a report released on Thursday.

headline: District of Columbia Is Investigating Trump Nominee to Lead Media Agency
abstract: The announcement was a significant setback in the effort to quickly confirm Michael Pack, a conservative filmmaker President Trump has personally lobbied to install.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The attorney general for the District of Columbia is investigating whether a conservative filmmaker nominated by President Trump to lead the independent agency in charge of state-funded news outlets illegally enriched himself with funds from a nonprofit organization he runs, according to a top Democratic senator.

headline: Trump’s Ad Team Blitzes Biden, Spending Millions to Define Him Early in the Race
abstract: President Trump’s campaign has launched a long-promised barrage of attack ads against Joseph R. Biden Jr., focusing on his age and his past comments on China.
lead_paragraph: The first wave of long-promised negative ads from the Trump campaign began this week in caustic form, flooding Facebook pages and television screens in swing states with harsh messages that make unfounded inferences about Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s mental state and paint the presumptive Democratic nominee as too friendly to the Chinese government.

headline: Your Questions: Voting by Mail, Tara Reade, Congressional Travel
abstract: It’s time to open the mailbag.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Changing Subject Amid a Pandemic, Trump Turns to an Old Ploy: Blame Obama
abstract: After pressure from the president, Senator Lindsey Graham agreed to hold a hearing, but he rebuffed Mr. Trump’s suggestion that his predecessor be called to testify.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has embarked on an aggressive new drive to rewrite the narrative of the Russia investigation by making dark and unsubstantiated accusations that former President Barack Obama masterminded a sinister plot to bring him down.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: A top government scientist and whistle-blower told Congress that the Trump administration failed to heed early warnings about the virus.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Rick Bright, a top government scientist, went before Congress on Thursday and connected some of the dots of the U.S. response to the coronavirus pandemic. They did not add up to a pretty picture.

headline: Trump to Name Brooke Rollins as Domestic Policy Adviser
abstract: As the acting director of the Domestic Policy Council, which oversees the president’s domestic agenda, Ms. Rollins will lead one of the least visible but most crucial bodies during the president’s tenure.
lead_paragraph: President Trump is naming Brooke Rollins, a conservative lawyer and long-serving White House official, as acting domestic policy adviser, according to two senior administration officials.

headline: Giants’ Deandre Baker and Seahawks’ Quinton Dunbar Accused of Robbery
abstract: Baker, a first-round draft pick for the Giants last year, and Dunbar were named in arrest warrants after an armed robbery was reported at a cookout party in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Arrest warrants were issued Thursday for two N.F.L. players who were accused of armed robbery at a cookout they attended near Miami the night before.

headline: Tailgater’s Headgear
abstract: Christopher Adams offers us a crackling Friday puzzle. Yes, you did, Mr. Adams.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Christopher Adams is hard on himself. He says he isn’t, but anyone who can offer us a puzzle this entertaining and then go down the rabbit hole of “all the ways this could have been better” in his constructor notes needs to know that his puzzles really are very good.

headline: Corrections: May 15, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, May 15, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the potential impacts that Manhattan would face if companies decide to let their employees work from home permanently misspelled the name of the owner of Aux Epices restaurant. She is Mei Chau, not Mei Cahu.

headline: Quotation of the Day: After Elmhurst Buckled, State Forced Rare Teamwork Among Hospitals
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 15, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “You knew you weren’t alone in the fight, and that people were listening. That was great for the soul.”

headline: You Have to Let Go to Move On
abstract: She wanted to connect without the cost of connection. Enter the rock climber.
lead_paragraph: My dating profile picture, a blurry, distant figure in a desert landscape, suggested a great deal about my ambivalence: I wanted, and I didn’t want. At 47, divorced for nearly two decades and with my daughters grown, I cherished my solitude, but sometimes when I heard the mice rustling in the attic, I thought of the newspaper story I had read about a man not far from where I lived who had been found dead in his flat, partly eaten by rats.

headline: U.S. and China Trade Coronavirus Accusations, Sparking Fears of a New Cold War
abstract: New evidence of deepening economic crisis came from Germany, China and elsewhere. For the second time in a month, a Brazilian health minister is leaving after clashing with the president.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Barber Shop Chronicles’ and ‘Seberg’
abstract: The National Theater in London is streaming a recent hit. And on Amazon, Kristen Stewart plays the actress Jean Seberg in “Seberg.”
lead_paragraph: BARBER SHOP CHRONICLES Stream on Nationaltheatre.org.uk. Barbershops are portrayed as communal spaces where patrons hang out and talk about politics, relationships and masculinity — and maybe also get their hair cut — in Inua Ellams’s “Barber Shop Chronicles,” a play that was a hit in London in 2017. The story bridges six barbershops in six cities, focusing on conversations in each shop over the course of a day. The fleet-footed script is based on recordings of conversations Ellams made in barbershops in Africa and London. “The men were just laughing whilst talking about really crazy issues,” Ellams said in an interview with The New York Times last year. “I had one rule: If a topic comes up three times in three different countries, then it has to go into the play.” This production, recorded during the show’s run at the National Theater in London, is streaming until late next week as part of a series of free programming being offered during the pandemic.

headline: Australia Is Returning to Normal. What Does That Mean?
abstract: As countries begin lifting restrictions one by one, what does normal look like when life has already unquestionably changed?
lead_paragraph: Recently, as coronavirus restrictions began lifting, I met up with my good friend Sofia for a long walk along Sydney’s coastline. The weather had turned, finally, from a perennial summer to something chillier, but the ocean was full of the usual smattering of surfers and brave swimmers.

headline: Movie Theaters Are on the Brink. Can Wine and Cheese Save Them?

lead_paragraph: When the Spanish-Revival-style Roxy opened on Broadway in 1927, the 5,900-seat movie theater boasted an enormous pipe organ with three keyboards and its own 110-member symphony orchestra. A mechanical orchestra pit rose and receded before screenings. The theater employed a male chorus, a ballet company and a chorus line called the Roxyettes.

headline: Rape, Torture, Murder, Beheadings — All in a Day’s Work for Marilyn Stasio
abstract: This week’s Crime column includes a computer gamer who is handy with a Samurai sword and a 14-year-old girl who solves a murder in an amusement park.
lead_paragraph: The Danish crime writer Jussi Adler-Olsen doesn’t fool around. If he wants to creep you out, he knows exactly how to do it. Take this passage from his latest Department Q novel, VICTIM 2117 (Dutton, 480 pp., $28), in which the villain torments a man named Assad by sending him a message about his abducted wife, Marwa. “It said that he made sure Marwa lost our third child,” Assad discloses, “and that he raped Marwa and my daughters every day, and that every time they gave birth, he immediately killed the child.” Has a certain sadistic ring to it, doesn’t it? That’s how we know we are indeed reading Adler-Olsen, whose style might best be described as literary brutalism.

headline: ‘Killing People in Fiction Was Fun’: Mysteries That Have Stood the Test of Time
abstract: From Agatha Christie to Raymond Chandler to Patricia Highsmith, classic detective stories are given new life in audio form.
lead_paragraph: I am, as we all are, stuck at home these days. Back in mid-March I assumed I would spend much of my time in lockdown reading — still and always my favorite activity, ideal for an indefinite period of mandatory solitude imposed by, say, a pandemic. This has not been the case. I’ve read fewer books over the past few weeks than I have over any comparable stretch that I can remember. Focus has evaporated. The cognitive load of living through the coronavirus has gone straight for my literary jugular.

headline: Finding Solace During This Great Global Pause
abstract: Is it OK to admit that I’m grateful for the isolation of the past few months?
lead_paragraph: Is it OK to admit that I’m grateful for the isolation of the past few months? Because I am. I’m relishing this liminal space, this Great Global Pause.

headline: The Postal Service Is the Most American Thing We’ve Got
abstract: Trump calls it ‘a joke.’ Washington and Lincoln would disagree.
lead_paragraph: It would be difficult to think of a time when we have depended more on the United States Postal Service. With tens of millions of Americans quarantined in their homes, the steady delivery of checks, letters, food and medical supplies is a lifeline.

headline: Watching the Pandemic Steal Intimate Moments From Teenagers
abstract: I’m afraid of holding a tight line of protection and having it snap under the weight of my almost-adult kid’s frustration.
lead_paragraph: On a day when my 17-year-old son can’t seem to summon the strength to wake up, I worry he’s coming down with the coronavirus or that he’s slipped into a deep depression. But he tells me that his partner, who is 19 and uses “they/them” pronouns, is moving into the nursing home where they work. He is listless from the losses of his deli job and the end of his senior year, angry that his partner is in such a compromising situation. Consistently exposed to Covid-19, his partner’s been forced to make the unfathomable choice of isolating in quarantine or exposing their household.

headline: Congress Doesn’t Need to Meet in Person
abstract: Lawmakers are just like the millions of other people who are working from home.
lead_paragraph: This month, in a long overdue change, the Senate finally started holding hybrid hearings, allowing both senators and health experts to appear via videoconferencing as well as in the Senate chamber. This occurred months after other public and private organizations all over the world had already made the transition to remote work. Just last week, the House majority leader introduced rule changes, passed on Friday, allowing the House to follow suit by permitting both remote hearings and remote voting.

headline: She Escaped Sex Work for College. Now the Virus Threatens Her New Life.
abstract: Her dorm closed for the quarantine. In a month she ages out of foster care. What happens when there is no safety net?
lead_paragraph: Last fall, toward the end of her first semester in college, Destiny Moura turned in a paper for an English composition class in which she described her introduction, at the age of 14, to “the life.’’ The “life’’ referred to the exploitation of girls by pimps, traffickers, manipulators.

headline: Miss Your Friends? Try Being a Teenager in Love
abstract: Separated and stuck at home, teen couples are in a star-crossed state.
lead_paragraph: Gabby Rodriguez and Kai Laidhold ask to see each other every day. The answer from their parents is always the same: No.

headline: ‘Everybody Was Sick’: Inside an ICE Detention Center
abstract: Like jails, ICE facilities are faced with tough decisions as to how to keep their dense populations safe.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Makalay Tarawally propped her 2-month-old in front of her phone so that his father could meet him for the first time, virtually. As a blood technician for a Covid-19 hospital unit, Ms. Tarawally knew how careful she needed to be.

headline: DeVos Funnels Coronavirus Relief Funds to Favored Private and Religious Schools
abstract: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos, using discretion written into the coronavirus stabilization law, is using millions of dollars to pursue long-sought policy goals that Congress has blocked.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Education Secretary Betsy DeVos is using the $2 trillion coronavirus stabilization law to throw a lifeline to education sectors she has long championed, directing millions of federal dollars intended primarily for public schools and colleges to private and religious schools.

headline: These Large Carnivorous Lizards Are Right Where They Belong
abstract: Monitor lizards, believed to be invasive species on some Pacific islands, got there long before humans, a new study says.
lead_paragraph: You can’t accuse a monitor lizard of being a picky eater.

headline: Economists Want to Put Stimulus on Autopilot. Congress Has Other Ideas.
abstract: The idea is to link government aid to certain indicators, like the jobless rate, so it shrinks or grows without further action by politicians.
lead_paragraph: When there is an economic crisis, you want a government response that is scaled accordingly. But you don’t know in advance just how long a crisis will last or how severe it will be.

headline: This Summer, Consider Camping in Your Own Backyard
abstract: The great outdoors can be made a little smaller for a close-to-home adventure.
lead_paragraph: Our kids are going to have the weirdest memories of this time, and, ideally, some of them will be beautiful. Or at least comedic. This is where backyard camping comes in. Think s’mores, stars, the air mattress deflating with a cartoony hiss. Picture your children’s faces, fire-lit and, for just another minute, little. It could happen in farmland, suburbia or the Bronx — and it could be lovely. (And if you don’t have access to the outdoors, consider adapting these tips for the middle of your tiny apartment’s living room.)

headline: I Live in Sweden. I’m Not Panicking.
abstract: Time will tell if my country’s coronavirus plan was wise.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — It’s noon here, and from the window of my home office I can see my two daughters playing in the yard at their preschool across the street. I reach for my phone to text my best friend, a nurse who lives in Westport, Conn., to share some family trivia I just discovered. She has been hunkered down in her home with her husband and their two young daughters since March. She’s beginning to wonder what they will lose first — their jobs or their minds.

headline: Young Adults Take Refuge in Parents’ Empty Nests
abstract: Going home to ride out the pandemic can offer security, but with a downside: lost independence and “totally arrested development.”
lead_paragraph: Andrea Yoch loves her adult sons, but would also love to not live with them.

headline: How a Nurse Who Gives Last Rites Spends His Sundays
abstract: Yaakov Shereshevsky has been saying the Viduy, a Jewish prayer, for terminal Covid patients.
lead_paragraph: “No one is meant to see so much death that quickly,” said Yaakov Shereshevsky, an I.C.U. nurse at N.Y.U. Langone Health, where the coronavirus outbreak has taken a heavy toll. For a while, he said, eight floors — 34 beds on each floor — were devoted to Covid-19 patients, and they were at capacity. “At one point, we had 20- and 30-year-olds dying,” he said. “It was a horrible, brutal, helpless feeling. It felt like there was no light. Now it’s getting better.”

headline: Just Because You Can Afford to Leave the City Doesn’t Mean You Should
abstract: It’s a mistake to blame density for the spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The image of cities as caldrons of contagion is a very old one. In the 19th century, rapid urbanization was accompanied by literal squalor and waves of often lethal communicable disease. Life expectancy declined during the Industrial Revolution as cities’ populations surged.

headline: Domestic Violence Calls Mount as Restrictions Linger: ‘No One Can Leave’
abstract: The coronavirus has created new tensions. Staying at home has worsened abusive situations. Shelters worry about the spread of the virus.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The woman dialed the hotline from her car. Her partner was laid off from his job after the coronavirus outbreak hit the United States, she told the counselor, who listened from a basement call center in Chicago. He had become more tense and violent than ever. Please help.

headline: A 92-Year-Old Piano Teacher Won’t Let Students Miss Bach in the Pandemic
abstract: Cornelia Vertenstein, a Holocaust survivor, is still teaching piano lessons over FaceTime from her Denver home.
lead_paragraph: For more than 50 years, Cornelia Vertenstein, 92, has taught piano lessons from her home in Denver. Every week, through all those years, a parade of children came to her door, books in hand.

headline: What Black America Knows About Quarantine
abstract: White people are protesting against being trapped at home. Black people know what it feels like to really be trapped.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 23, a 25-year-old black man named Ahmaud Arbery left his home in Brunswick, Ga., to go for a Sunday afternoon run. As he entered a nearby subdivision, he was followed and later shot dead by a father and son while their neighbor recorded the incident on his phone.

headline: Trump, Biden and the Myth of ‘But 2016’
abstract: There are members of both parties who believe the president has the ability to defy the normal rules of politics. That view ignores electoral trends of recent years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At first glance, there seems little in common between red-hat-wearing admirers of President Trump and Democratic activists still nursing PTSD from Hillary Clinton’s loss. Yet these political opposites share an overriding conviction, one they are apt to invoke any time the president’s re-election prospects are questioned:

headline: Obamagate Is a Fake Scandal. Rick Bright Described a Real One.
abstract: “The darkest winter in modern history” may soon be upon us, while Trumpists are obsessed with a new conspiracy theory.
lead_paragraph: Recently people on the right have started pushing a ludicrous pseudo-scandal they’re calling Obamagate. It holds that investigations by Barack Obama’s administration into Russia’s attack on the 2016 U.S. presidential election were a form of illicit sabotage of Donald Trump and his team. The story doesn’t really make sense, which is why, when asked about Obamagate, President Trump couldn’t describe it. But at the heart of the conspiracy theory is “unmasking,” the routine practice by which national security officials find out the names of Americans who appear on intelligence intercepts of foreign actors. Trumpists have tried to turn this into a sinister and portentous term.

headline: With Go-Slow Approach, Republicans Risk Political Blowback on Pandemic Aid
abstract: With jobless numbers rising, Republicans’ reluctance to negotiate on another round of pandemic relief is proving difficult to sustain.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than eight weeks and almost $2.8 trillion federal dollars into an urgent response to the coronavirus pandemic, congressional Republicans and the Trump administration have made it clear that they are in no rush to engage with Democrats on another round of costly relief measures.

headline: Hospitals Knew How to Make Money. Then Coronavirus Happened.
abstract: Surgeries are canceled. Business models are shifting. Some of the hardest-hit hospitals may close, leaving patients with fewer options for care.
lead_paragraph: When the top-ranked Mayo Clinic stopped all nonemergency medical care in late March, it began to lose millions of dollars a day.

headline: Beach Towns Ask: Will There Be Summer?
abstract: With Memorial Day weekend approaching, areas that rely on tourists say not reopening would be devastating economically, but fear the consequences of opening too soon.
lead_paragraph: In summer resort towns across the United States, livelihoods for the year are built in the 15 weeks between Memorial Day and Labor Day. It is during those 15 weeks that tourists from around the country and the world arrive to bask on the beach and gather for festivals and weddings. And it is during those three months that tour operators, hoteliers, innkeepers, restaurant employees and others earn the bulk of their income.

headline: What to Buy to Create Your Own Backyard Campground
abstract: A trip to Yellowstone or Yosemite may not be the cards yet, but we’ve come up with the gear you need to make camping out in the backyard fun too.
lead_paragraph: Being stuck at home doesn’t mean you can’t have an adventure, especially if you’re fortunate enough to have some outdoor space. Unlike the appeal of a long-distance hiking trip — which relies, of course, on seeing new landscapes — the magic of backyard camping, especially with children, is creating a fantasy in an otherwise familiar environment. It is a theater that we invent for ourselves. And like all good theater, no matter how minimal, the illusion is sustained in the details.

headline: Bringing ‘Normal People’ to Sexy, Soundtracked Life
abstract: Critics at The Times discuss the transfer of Sally Rooney’s novel to TV.
lead_paragraph: Fans of Sally Rooney’s novel “Normal People” are devoted types. They tend to hold the book’s central mismatched-but-also-kind-of-perfect-together couple, Marianne and Connell, close to their hearts. So adapting the book for TV came with risks. “It was a big leap of faith,” Rooney told The Hollywood Reporter earlier this year about casting the show, “that we were going to find people who would just get it, and would know exactly how to communicate that friction between the inner life and the outer world.” Daisy Edgar-Jones and Paul Mescal have received widespread acclaim for their performances in the 12-part series on Hulu. Some of the praise for the show came from James Poniewozik, The Times’s chief television critic, who called it a “gorgeous, melancholy series” starring leads who “have so much chemistry you may need lab goggles.” Poniewozik recently joined The Times’s three book critics — Dwight Garner, Parul Sehgal and Jennifer Szalai — for a discussion I moderated about the show, the novel, the art of adaptation and more. — John Williams, Daily Books Editor

headline: ‘We’re Just Horrified’: Why a Springsteen Sideman Took On Nursing Homes

lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus outbreak was only manifesting itself in horrifying headlines from Italy and China, Nils Lofgren, the guitarist for Bruce Springsteen’s E Street Band, and his wife, Amy, moved her mother into Brookdale Senior Living, a well-regarded long term care facility in Florham Park, N.J.

abstract: And how they came to be staples on Instagram and in our homes.

It neatly covers my kitchen backsplash, and very possibly yours, but do its origins really lie in the subways? Why would that environment be anyone’s inspiration? And why is it so crazily popular now?

headline: America’s Cities Could House Everyone if They Chose To
abstract: Our housing crisis is a symptom of America’s wealth — and its indifference.
lead_paragraph: Tonight, more than half a million Americans will sleep in public places because they lack private spaces. They will huddle in crowded New York City shelters, or pitch tents under highways in Washington, D.C., or curl up in the doorways of San Francisco office towers, or dig holes in the high desert of northern Los Angeles County.

headline: Lobby Heroes of the Lockdown

lead_paragraph: When Genc Rrahmani was growing up in Kosovo, he would fantasize about his future life in New York City. “I was thinking that the U.S. has a lot of money,” Genc said recently. “That I would work hard and start a business, and have a beautiful future with a beautiful family.”

headline: Trump Is Following in Herbert Hoover’s Footsteps
abstract: And we know how that worked out.
lead_paragraph: Additional economic assistance is the only thing that can keep the U.S. economy from falling into a second Great Depression, and with interest rates near zero, the government has all the fiscal capacity it needs to borrow the trillions necessary to relieve the pain. But Congress, or rather congressional Republicans, won’t budge. After backing the $2 trillion CARES Act in March, they believe they’ve done enough for now.

headline: What Home Means to the Homeless
abstract: These are the things they hung on to, when so many things were lost.
lead_paragraph: What makes a home? Is it the materials we use to make the structure or the things we put in it? Is it the people who occupy the space or the memories we accumulate there? The question has vastly different meanings for people who have experienced homelessness, one of the most shameful manifestations of inequality in America.
