headline: Film Club: ‘Are Ice Cream Trucks Essential? In These N.Y.C. Neighborhoods, They Are’
abstract: Who are the people working to make life feel a bit more normal during these difficult times?
lead_paragraph: Note: This is our final Film Club for the 2019-20 school year. Please visit our archive to find dozens of other short films you can use between now and September, when we will resume this feature. You can also sign up for our free weekly newsletter to make sure you don’t miss any of our new films.

headline: When Shoppers Venture Out, What Will Be Left?
abstract: A 16.4 percent sales decline in April may signal the bottom for retailers, but the climb back will be hard, and some companies may not make it.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic dealt another crushing blow to retailers in April. Now the question is what the sector will look like as the economy reopens — and how much permanent damage has been inflicted.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Living alone through the pandemic. A very reliable audiobook narrator. Remembering Little Richard and Jerry Stiller. A pandemic hasn’t stopped this ice cream man. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. Is the world around you reopening? It’s strange to hear a constant hum of traffic out my window, to see people carrying takeaway coffee cups, to see kids at the park. It shouldn’t be strange, people doing what they do, but right now it is. I am trying to be patient with myself as life uncoils itself back out into the world. I hope you are, too, and that whatever you’re doing, you take some time to read some amazing journalism.

headline: ‘The Blacklist’ Draws Up a Novel End to Its Season
abstract: The showrunners for the NBC thriller discuss how and why they hired animators to finish the season after the pandemic brought production to a halt. The finale airs Friday night.
lead_paragraph: In mid-March, when the coronavirus pandemic shut New York City down, television production came to a sudden halt, sabotaging whole seasons for some shows and postponing season finales for others. But NBC’s “The Blacklist,” which follows James Spader’s Raymond “Red” Reddington as he helps the F.B.I. bring down the world’s most nefarious criminals, soldiered on.

headline: One Side Effect of the Virus: Free Credit Reports Each Week
abstract: That’s an improvement over the normal once-a-year limit. While it won’t fix potential credit woes, it can be a helpful tool to stay on top of your finances.
lead_paragraph: The economic turmoil caused by the coronavirus has prompted a helpful — if temporary — change in the window that Americans have into their credit files.

headline: Why So Many Filipino Californians Are on the Front Lines
abstract: Friday: A look at how history has shaped American nursing. Also: Gov. Gavin Newsom unveiled his revised budget proposal.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Why Sofas? These Books Explain the Joys and Mysteries of the Home
abstract: Whether you live in an apartment, house, mansion or cabin, here are books that will help you explore the meaning of where you are right now.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever wondered how forks ended up with four tines, where to store off-season clothes when you live in a small space, or why there’s green felt on pool tables? These books have answers.

headline: Oprah to Class of 2020: ‘What Will Your Essential Service Be?’
abstract: With the usual pomp and circumstance put on hold, Ms. Winfrey and scores of celebrities feted graduates with a virtual celebration on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: Hugging friends? Nope. Class photos? Afraid not. Instead, in place of the usual pomp and circumstance, Oprah Winfrey on Friday asked America’s graduates — the “pandemic class,” she called them — to consider what their “essential service” in this world would be.

headline: U.S. Delivers Another Blow to Huawei With New Tech Restrictions
abstract: The Commerce Department announced rules that threaten to inflict more pain on the company and upset an already rocky U.S.-China relationship.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration issued a new rule Friday that will bar Huawei and its suppliers from using American technology and software, a significant escalation in the White House’s battle with the Chinese telecom giant and one that is likely to inflame tensions with Beijing.

headline: Six Swipes for a Better Night’s Sleep
abstract: Our daily patterns are all off, so our circadian rhythms are too. These tips will help.
lead_paragraph: Our daily patterns are all off, so our circadian rhythms are too. These tips will help.

headline: Within a Week, They Fell in Love
abstract: Clare Goslant and Alex Plum met in Washington, and fell in love right away. But she went back to college, and then he joined the Marine Corps. They managed to marry even so.
lead_paragraph: Clare Goslant was in search of an affordable place to live in Washington, when she took time off between her junior and senior years at Harvard for an internship with the World Wildlife Fund.

headline: In Jerusalem, Ramadan Restrictions Last Seen During the Crusades Return
abstract: A pandemic has transformed how Muslims in Israel and the Palestinian territories are experiencing Ramadan.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The last time Muslim worshipers were kept out of the Aqsa Mosque compound throughout the entire month of Ramadan was when crusaders controlled Jerusalem in the Middle Ages.

headline: Women Face Dilemma in a War Zone: Risk the Blasts or Sexual Assault
abstract: As shelling between Pakistan and India intensifies in Kashmir, some women and girls are staying away from community shelters that have become a stalking ground for sexual predators.
lead_paragraph: NEELUM VALLEY, Kashmir — There is another lockdown underway, forced by falling artillery shells rather than invading viruses. This one also requires frightening choices between bad options.

headline: Paintings that Demolish the Myths of What a Home Should Be
abstract: Naomi Safran-Hon’s textured paintings of abandoned houses hint at our entangled and contradictory relationships to the places we live.
lead_paragraph: Were someone to ask me for an image that clearly represents nostalgia — the definition drawn from Greek of the feeling of ache or pain associated with homecoming — I might point them to the work of the artist Naomi Safran-Hon who makes paintings of (among other things) lost and abandoned homes.

headline: The Mrs. Files
abstract: A woman’s identity in the world is more than a one-dimensional story about honorifics.
lead_paragraph: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific “Mrs.” means to women and their identity.

headline: Trump Vows Vaccine by End of Year, and Mobilizes Military to Help
abstract: The president named Moncef Slaoui, a former pharmaceutical executive, to lead a crash development program that if successful would shatter speed records for vaccine development.
lead_paragraph: President Trump doubled down on Friday on his promise to have a coronavirus vaccine available by the end of this year, betting that he can rally the pharmaceutical industry and the government to have one available to nearly all Americans at a speed never before accomplished.

headline: What Does ‘Wife’ Mean for Queer Women?
abstract: Do married lesbians use the title “Mrs.?” The answer is often “no.” Women also have strong feelings about the word “wife.”
lead_paragraph: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific “Mrs.” means to women and their identity.

headline: Is Marriage a Prize?
abstract: That’s what American social and pop culture taught me.
lead_paragraph: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific “Mrs.” means to women and their identity.

headline: Ray Eames, Out of Her Husband’s Shadow
abstract: The designer let her larger-than-life husband Charles do the talking. But the style symbolized by their shared name was a joint creation.
lead_paragraph: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific “Mrs.” means to women and their identity.

headline: Ms. Monroe
abstract: The poet Helen Mort reflects on the depth of the famous Marilyn.
lead_paragraph: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific “Mrs.” means to women and their identity.

headline: Top Conn. Health Aide Disappears From Virus Briefings, Then Is Fired
abstract: The state’s public health commissioner had been criticized over the response to rising deaths from the outbreak at nursing homes.
lead_paragraph: Several weeks ago, Connecticut’s public health commissioner suddenly stopped appearing with Gov. Ned Lamont at his daily briefings on the state’s response to the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Lady Jordan
abstract: In her poem, Denice Frohman revisits her childhood on the basketball court and how the hoop resembles a wedding band.
lead_paragraph: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific “Mrs.” means to women and their identity.

headline: Mrs.
abstract: A poem explores how society erases a woman’s history, sacrifices and identity when it defines her by her husband’s name.
lead_paragraph: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific “Mrs.” means to women and their identity.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Treat yourself to a Bloody Mary, alcoholic or non, and think of Gabrielle Hamilton’s Prune. Or settle in with some barbecued chicken or lemony orzo.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Gabrielle Hamilton’s back in The Times this week with a lovely essay about community meals that may send you down a summertime memory hole: to small-town fish fries and chicken dinners, spaghetti nights at the firehouse, men grilling venison, jerk pork, brats. “Was it the era or the region” where she grew up, she asks, “that had those suppers commence with a Dixie cup of tomato juice, set down on your plate?” She thought of it as a bracing appetizer, a kind of Communion before dinner.

headline: What Is Beauty Now?
abstract: In a pandemic, we are coming face to face with what lies beneath all that beauty maintenance.
lead_paragraph: — Hannah McCann, a lecturer at the University of Melbourne who specializes in beauty culture

headline: Container
abstract: The agony and anxiety of living in a migrant camp.
lead_paragraph: The agony and anxiety of living in a migrant camp.

headline: Steve Earle’s Week: Pining for New York and Singing With His Son
abstract: With the play featuring his music, “Coal Country,” on hold, the musician is trying to get its message — about miners killed in a disaster — out via his songs.
lead_paragraph: Steve Earle misses New York.

headline: We Are Kids Who Remember Only War
abstract: The agony and anxiety of living in a migrant camp.
lead_paragraph: On a cold afternoon in mid-February, I huddled into a borrowed office on the Greek island of Lesbos with about 12 other volunteers for a workshop with a child psychologist. She had come to teach us about trauma and the human brain. We all worked at the nearby Moria refugee camp. I had been there about three weeks.

headline: A Drug Company Wagers the U.S. Won’t Dare Charge It With Crimes
abstract: Teva, the world’s largest maker of generic drugs, recently pulled out of settlement talks with the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: In the coming days, the Justice Department will make an important decision: whether to file criminal charges against one of the world’s largest pharmaceutical companies for allegedly colluding with rivals to inflate the prices of widely used drugs.

headline: How to Observe Planet Earth, Through Comics and Kafka
abstract: An assignment for all of us to help capture an extraordinary time.
lead_paragraph: An assignment for all of us to help capture an extraordinary time.

headline: Strong Earthquake Hits Western Nevada
abstract: The 6.5-magnitude earthquake in a remote area of the state, felt as far as California and Utah, was the strongest there since the 1950s, an expert said.
lead_paragraph: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck a remote area in western Nevada early on Friday, damaging a major highway and shaking homes as far as Utah and California.

headline: Bob Watson, Baseball’s First Black General Manager, Dies at 74
abstract: A former major leaguer, he shattered a racial barrier in 1994 with the Houston Astros. Two years later, he was the Yankees’ G.M. as New York began a championship run.
lead_paragraph: Bob Watson, the hard-hitting first baseman and outfielder who became the first African-American general manager in major league baseball, with the 1994 Houston Astros, then helped take the 1996 Yankees to the franchise’s first World Series championship in 18 years as their newly hired general manager, died on Thursday in Houston. He was 74.

headline: How Wall Street Is Hampering Some Small Businesses Seeking Aid
abstract: To get government help, some owners who borrowed money from credit funds and bond investors  had to fight their lenders first.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Sullivan borrowed $22 million from a specialist Wall Street lender in 2018 to buy and renovate two Florida hotels, he had no idea how costly that decision would prove to be.

headline: Nick Kotz, Crusading Journalist and Author, Dies at 87
abstract: He won a Pulitzer Prize for exposing unsafe conditions in meatpacking plants. He also wrote about hunger in America and the politics of the B-1 bomber.
lead_paragraph: Nick Kotz, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and author who exposed health hazards in the nation’s slaughterhouses, the gamut of hunger in America and the politics behind the Pentagon’s B-1 bomber, died on April 26 in Broad Run, Va. He was 87.

headline: Aventura’s Stripped-Down Livestream, and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Future, Rico Nasty, Kaitlyn Aurelia Smith and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Your Food Is in the Mail
abstract: The C.E.O.s of Blue Apron and Thrive Market have had to deal with crushing demand with millions of people stuck at home and looking to cook.
lead_paragraph: It started with hoarding. As the coronavirus began to spread across the United States, shoppers stocked up on toilet paper and canned food. Then, as restaurants closed and simply venturing out became a health hazard, people began cooking more meals at home.

headline: ‘A Lot of Bad News Out There’: Parenting in a Pandemic
abstract: A mother balances coverage of tsunamis, plane crashes, bombings and other tragedies with life at home during a coronavirus lockdown.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — I didn’t want to be that parent, the one who talks about how when I was a child I had to walk uphill both ways, in the snow, just to get to school.

headline: Antonio González Pacheco, Accused Policeman in Franco’s Spain, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. González Pacheco was charged with torturing opponents of the Franco dictatorship but never stood trial. Reports said he died of complications of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: From ‘Respect’ to ‘Sick and Twisted’: How Coronavirus Hit U.S.-China Ties
abstract: A sharp escalation of tensions over the handling of the pandemic has raised the specter of a new Cold War.
lead_paragraph: “Evil.” “Lunacy.” “Shameless.” “Sick and twisted.” China has hit back at American criticism over its handling of the coronavirus pandemic with an outpouring of vitriol as acrid as anything seen in decades.

headline: How to Keep Kids Moving (Personal Bounce House Not Required)
abstract: Parents are getting creative to make physical activity fun, yet easy, during lockdown.
lead_paragraph: It feels like a lifetime ago, but it was only March 17 when my daughter learned how to ride her bike without training wheels. It was also my birthday, so it felt like a gift — one with terrific timing, as our home state, Texas, had declared a state of emergency just four days earlier in response to the coronavirus pandemic. Those early days of the new normal were defined by frequent family bike rides, exploring our neighborhood in the welcoming air of an Austin spring.

headline: The Biggest Weekend of Live Sports on TV in a Long Time
abstract: Yes you heard that right. NASCAR, German soccer, U.F.C., horse racing and golf will be live.
lead_paragraph: If it were 2019 or 1998 or 1986 or just about any year since the dawn of cable TV, you would look at the sports schedule for this weekend and say, “Wow, there’s almost nothing on.”

headline: The Hidden Language of Masks
abstract: Even before the world went into lockdown, a team at the Smithsonian was gathering artifacts of a global pandemic for posterity.
lead_paragraph: When, early in the onset of the novel coronavirus pandemic, production shortages of medical grade N95 masks turned obtaining them into a hunt for the grail, D.I.Y. ingenuity kicked into gear.

headline: First Virtual New York Art Fair Brings Low Energy but Solid Prices
abstract: Frieze New York proved surprisingly robust, answering the question, “Can a fair survive online?”
lead_paragraph: There were no air kisses. No celebrity sightings. No champagne flutes in the V.I.P. lounge — in fact, no V.I.P. lounge at all.

headline: Make It Ahead
abstract: Steal a little bit of time during the day to make dinner easier.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. My daughter said something kind of funny the other day at lunch: “Dinner is coming for us, Mama!” She was just narrating the events of the day as she expected them to unfold, using her toddler syntax. But she had divined a feeling I often have these days: Dinner is coming for us! Run!

headline: Using Tech to Teach — Smartly
abstract: Technology — if we keep it in its place — can empower creative teachers to shine.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Will Working From Home Become the Norm?
abstract: Readers discuss the benefits of telecommuting as well as some questions it raises, such as whether employers should share the cost savings with workers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Paralympics Got Postponed. A Retired Champion Got an Idea.
abstract: Rudy Garcia-Tolson competed in four Paralympics and thought he was ready to call it a career — until he realized that an extra year of training could enable his comeback.
lead_paragraph: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year.

headline: How Do You Feel About Returning to Work?
abstract: The New York Times would like to hear from people who are wrestling with what to do as stay-at-home orders ease.
lead_paragraph: America has started to reopen, just weeks after the coronavirus put most of the country on lockdown.

headline: Is the Hand Quicker Than the Zoom Window?
abstract: With theaters and nightclubs closed, magicians have pivoted to remote performance. Can your screen be a place of enchantment?
lead_paragraph: Before my scheduled preview performance of “The Present,” a new show from the Geffen Playhouse (rebranded as Geffen Stayhouse) in Los Angeles, I received — via FedEx, after a failed delivery from the Postal Service and a series of increasingly panicked emails — a letter with strict instructions. I was to download Zoom and join a meeting 15 minutes before showtime. There would be, bold type informed me, “no late seating.”

headline: When Sheltering in Place Puts Your Tax Strategy at Risk
abstract: Advisers say taxpayers facing residency questions because of quarantine orders need to keep detailed records to explain where they lived, for how long and why.
lead_paragraph: Lockdowns have disrupted the lives of millions of Americans since March, when states began issuing shelter-in-place orders. For some people, a key part of their residency for tax purposes — their domicile status — may have shifted in that time for a number of reasons: They are now working from home, they’ve fled a hot spot or they thought they could ride out the pandemic in a vacation house.

headline: Why Are Women-Led Nations Doing Better With Covid-19?
abstract: A new leadership style offers promise for a new era of global threats.
lead_paragraph: Monday was a day of triumph for Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern. Thanks to the efforts of the entire nation, she said, New Zealand had been largely successful in meeting its ambitious goal of eradicating, rather than just controlling, outbreaks of Covid-19. The lockdown she had put in place on March 25 could now end.

headline: To Build Resilience in Isolation, Master the Art of Time Travel
abstract: When the present is unpleasant, it helps to think ahead to the future and back to the past.
lead_paragraph: As isolation day approached, Scott Kelly knew he had to prepare himself mentally. He wouldn’t be able to hug his family and friends. He wouldn’t be able to go outside without protective gear. He’d have a hard time sleeping, because he’d be going to bed in his office and waking up in that same office — on the International Space Station.

headline: Who’s Enforcing Mask Rules? Often Retail Workers, and They’re Getting Hurt
abstract: The risk of a violent reaction now hangs over jobs already fraught with health perils.
lead_paragraph: The exchange was tense between the customer and Jesse, a Trader Joe’s employee sporting a white face mask and a flowery Hawaiian shirt.

headline: ‘Hightown’ Review: Crime on Cape Cod, With a Hint of Elmore Leonard
abstract: The Starz series offers a tough and troubled heroine who chases a murderer through picturesque beach towns and back roads.
lead_paragraph: Jackie Quiñones, the heroine of the new Starz policier “Hightown,” is an off-brand variety of cop, a fisheries agent who boards boats looking for contraband or lobsters that are too young. She’s feisty and contrarian and lives and works in a scenic area with a distinctive local culture, Cape Cod.

headline: Tanglewood, Musical Haven in the Berkshires, Cancels Summer Season
abstract: The shuttering of the Northeast tradition seems to represent the end of live performance in America this summer.
lead_paragraph: Summer after summer, the Boston Symphony Orchestra retreats to its seasonal home: Tanglewood, a bucolic and beloved outdoor destination for music, tucked away in the Berkshires. New England’s vacationers and classical buffs follow by the hundreds of thousands.

headline: One Young Mother and the Homelessness Crisis
abstract: Lauren Sandler talks about “This Is All I Got,” and Sarah Weinman discusses classic mysteries.
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: S. Roger Horchow, Retailer Turned Broadway Producer, Dies at 91
abstract: He built a luxury catalog business, then sold it and used the proceeds to mount the Tony-winning hit musical “Crazy for You.”
lead_paragraph: A boy in Cincinnati wakes up in the night to hear striking piano music — “alive, exciting,” he would describe it decades later — emanating from a gathering his parents are having downstairs. He goes to investigate and sees George Gershwin himself at the piano.

headline: ‘Wuhan Diary’ Offers an Angry and Eerie View From Inside Quarantine
abstract: Fang Fang’s online diary, now a book, made her a nuisance to the powers that be and a national hero to many others in China.
lead_paragraph: The next Chinese New Year will begin on Feb. 12, 2021. It will be the year of the Ox. The first real publishing season since the pandemic started will begin at about the same time. In America and elsewhere, I suspect, it will be the year of the Diary.

headline: U.K. Coronavirus Testers Pay Price for a Day of Triumph
abstract: The British government promised 100,000 daily tests by April 30. It delivered. But the frantic push to hit that deadline has left labs scrabbling for supplies just when they need to expand further.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On May 1, a visibly relieved Matt Hancock announced that the British government had exceeded its target of 100,000 coronavirus tests a day. As health secretary, Mr. Hancock had set the goal after enduring intense criticism for the country’s lagging coronavirus testing program.

headline: Let Vegetables Be the Star of Your Memorial Day
abstract: Finished with creamy burrata and a sweet and tangy agrodolce sauce, this packed platter makes a glorious holiday meal.
lead_paragraph: The sad truth about summer 2020 is that you may not be ushering it in by grilling giant trays of food for a horde of your family and friends.

headline: Dealing With the Dark Side of Low Interest Rates
abstract: When you borrow, low interest rates are fabulous. But if you need to live on your savings, you will be receiving far less income.
lead_paragraph: The extraordinarily low interest rates in place today are a boon when you’re buying a house, refinancing a mortgage, leasing a car or paying off student debt. If you qualify for a loan, low rates can help you spend less and get more.

headline: Is It Safe to Go Out to Eat?
abstract: Dining rooms are reopening in many states, but that doesn’t mean you should go. Before you decide, public health experts advise taking these steps.
lead_paragraph: Restaurants are slowly returning in many states. Just because you can eat out again, though, does not mean that you should. And if you decide to go back before the virus is under control, it will not necessarily be clear which dining rooms are safest.

headline: California’s Warning Signs for Democrats
abstract: The party needs to figure out how to adapt to post-coronavirus politics to hold on to the seats that it flipped in 2018.
lead_paragraph: Before the pandemic, visitors to the Ronald Reagan Library were greeted by a hologram of the 40th president, speaking one day from his ranch and the next from the Oval Office.

headline: What Parents Should Know as States Reopen
abstract: Experts urge caution and continued protective measures for playgrounds, play dates and family travel.
lead_paragraph: After a month or two in virtual confinement, most of us are going downright stir crazy. There’s only so much “Puffin Rock” and “Masha the Bear” we can take. Meanwhile, our kids are crawling up the walls. As most states have begun reopening amid the coronavirus pandemic, people are anxious to know what activities their kids can safely do. Can children have play dates or go to the playground? Can parents hire babysitters?

headline: How the Biden Campaign Aims to Win Battleground States
abstract: The campaign pledged to expand its operation, and expects on-the-ground organizing to take place sometime this year. But when the candidate leaves his home will be determined by public health guidance, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential campaign, which has faced criticism from some Democrats worried about his team’s general election readiness, is planning a substantial expansion of its operation and eyeing an ambitious battleground map even as the question of when Mr. Biden will resume in-person campaigning remains unclear.

headline: As His Pay Shrinks in the Absence of Tennis, His Heart Grows Fonder
abstract: Ron Yu, a racket technician for some of the best players in the world, has lost his primary source of income during the coronavirus pandemic but also remembered how much he loves the sport.
lead_paragraph: People throughout the sports world, from athletes to arena staff members, tell The New York Times how their lives have changed during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Love Letter: Living Alone in a Pandemic
abstract: Plus, proposals are not on pause.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up here to receive Love Letter, a weekly newsletter about relationship highs, lows and woes, in your inbox every Friday.]

headline: She’s 108, Lived Through the Spanish Flu and Just Beat Covid-19
abstract: Sylvia Goldsholl, who lives in a New Jersey nursing home, is one of the country’s oldest survivors of the coronavirus. “She’s very feisty,” her nephew said.
lead_paragraph: Last month, relatives of Sylvia Goldsholl received troubling news from her New Jersey nursing home: She had contracted the coronavirus and was in isolation.

headline: Gil Loescher, 75, Refugees Expert Who Survived Iraq Bombing, Dies
abstract: He lost his legs in a 2003 suicide attack but continued his scholarship and field work on behalf of the world’s displaced.
lead_paragraph: The Iraq war had gone on for six months when Gil Loescher, a scholar and champion of refugees’ rights, arrived in Baghdad in August 2003 as a member of openDemocracy, a London-based human rights organization. On Aug. 19, he and others went to the United Nations headquarters there to discuss the humanitarian costs of the war with Sérgio Vieira de Mello, the U.N. special representative in Iraq.

headline: Looking at Albert Camus’s “The Plague”
abstract: In 1948, Stephen Spender wrote for the Book Review about Albert Camus’s “The Plague,” a novel about an epidemic spreading across the French Algerian city of Oran.
lead_paragraph: In 1948, Stephen Spender wrote for the Book Review about Albert Camus’s “The Plague,” a novel about an epidemic spreading across the French Algerian city of Oran.

headline: Christie’s Gets Creative for 20th-Century Art Auction in July
abstract: The sale, which includes works that were to be sold in New York in May, will be a hybrid: in-person (where allowed) and online in a format tailored for the coronavirus era.
lead_paragraph: Christie’s has a new auction format for a July 10 event that it hopes will revive at least some of the drama — and the prices — of the live evening sales that were held pre-pandemic.

headline: These No-Bake Bars Are the Next Best Thing to a Peanut Butter Cup
abstract: Sweetened peanut butter topped with a simple chocolate shell, you’ll want to keep these treats on hand in the fridge — if they last that long.
lead_paragraph: Despite the fact that I’ve been keeping my family knee-deep in snickerdoodle cake and shortbread, everyone’s been craving peanut butter cups.

headline: An Ex-Steeler’s Recount of a Hard Hit Triggers Bountygate Comparisons
abstract: The former Pittsburgh linebacker James Harrison said in an interview that Steelers Coach Mike Tomlin handed him an envelope after he delivered a helmet-to-helmet hit.
lead_paragraph: The steepest of the four fines the former Steelers linebacker James Harrison incurred in 2010 stemmed from a vicious helmet-to-helmet hit he delivered on Cleveland Browns receiver Mohamed Massaquoi, knocking him out with a concussion. The hit went without penalty on the field, but the N.F.L., intent on meting out stiffer discipline for violations of player safety, docked Harrison $75,000 — at least some of which, Harrison claimed on a podcast Thursday, was offset by his coach, Mike Tomlin.

headline: With Move to Remote Voting, House Alters What It Means for Congress to Meet
abstract: The House’s vote on Friday to allow lawmakers to work from afar will fundamentally change how Congress operates.
lead_paragraph: When the House of Representatives acted on Friday to allow remote voting and virtual hearings, the coronavirus pandemic officially succeeded in doing what Philadelphia’s yellow fever outbreak of 1793, the Spanish influenza of 1918, the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and generations of agitators for institutional change never could: untethering Congress from its mandate to come together physically.

headline: What We Know About Your Chances of Catching the Virus Outdoors
abstract: A stir-crazy nation wonders: Is it safe to stroll on the beach in a deadly pandemic? How about a picnic in the park? Or coffee with a friend at an outdoor table? The risk is in the details.
lead_paragraph: The warmer weather across the country calls to mind carefree summers — picnics in the park, swimming at the beach, fireworks on the Fourth. But nothing feels carefree now.

headline: ‘Geriatric,’ ‘China’s Puppet’: Trump Campaign Unleashes Ads Attacking Biden
abstract: President Trump’s re-election team has launched a long-promised barrage of negative ads against Joseph R. Biden Jr., focusing on his age and his past comments on China.
lead_paragraph: The negative ads attacking Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Facebook pages and television screens are as relentless as they are varied, as if plucked from a vintage Trump rally rant: Some make unfounded inferences about his mental state, saying “geriatric health is no laughing matter.” Others paint the presumptive Democratic nominee as “China’s puppet.”

headline: From Nearly Free to Out-of-Reach: Gasoline’s Crazy Price Swing in Venezuela
abstract: Motorists queue for days to buy subsidized gasoline for next to nothing, but it is increasingly scarce — a reflection of the economic absurdities in the country.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — A dollar could once theoretically buy about 5 billion gallons of gasoline in Venezuela — more than enough to supply the state of Michigan for a year. Now, a dollar gets you half a pint, if you’re lucky.

headline: How to Give Skin a Summer Glow
abstract: With the right application, a little highlighter or bronzer can help create a radiant, sun-kissed look, even if you’ve spent much of spring inside.
lead_paragraph: The widespread closure of nonessential businesses has resulted in a variety of unforeseen beauty challenges — not least among them the need for D.I.Y. hair care — and skin is doubly affected: Not only is professional help off the table but spending less time outside can take a noticeable toll on its vibrancy. “Everyone wants to look like they just had a facial, even in normal circumstances,” says the New York-based makeup artist Gucci Westman. “But particularly during these weeks and weeks of quarantine, when we could all use a confidence boost, I want my skin to be glowing and radiant and exude well-being.” With stay-at-home orders still in effect in many places, a healthy glow may simply seem unattainable, even as summer approaches — but with a little know-how, bronzers, highlighters and blushes can lend a hand. Here, a guide to achieving a subtle sun-kissed look.

headline: Why I’ve Stopped Telling People I’m Not Chinese
abstract: When confronted with racism toward anyone, our instinct should be indignation, not deflection.
lead_paragraph: Mid-February, when the world was starting to go pear-shaped, I had to travel to an area where I’d previously experienced anti-Asian sentiment. So a few days before the trip, I emailed my (white) hairdresser frantically: “I know this sounds crazy but can you can make me blonde? I’m traveling next week and I’m worried about being mistaken for Chinese and blamed for the coronavirus.”

headline: F.D.A. Halts Coronavirus Testing Program Backed by Bill Gates
abstract: The program allows people in the Seattle area to easily take a coronavirus test at home. Researchers say such testing is essential for future monitoring of the virus.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — An innovative coronavirus testing program in the Seattle area — promoted by the billionaire Bill Gates and local public health officials as a way of conducting wider surveillance on the invisible spread of the virus — has been ordered by the federal government to stop its work pending additional reviews.

headline: What Coronavirus Means for Going to the Lake
abstract: Advice to cottage and cabin owners during the pandemic varies by region and can sometimes be contradictory.
lead_paragraph: Like many Canadians in areas where this is a holiday weekend, my wife and I would normally be at our cottage, dragging outdoor furniture and small boats out of their winter dens, assessing the handiwork of mice and squirrels and generally getting set up for a summer of fun.

headline: With Movie Theaters Closed, Marquees Go Viral
abstract: As businesses across the country remain shuttered, movie theater marquees offer jokes and advice to those wandering by.
lead_paragraph: “You’re still here? It’s over. Go home. Go.”

headline: Ty, British Rapper Who Bridged Generations and Genres, Dies at 47
abstract: His sound didn’t fit neatly into any hip-hop archetypes, and he pushed to make room for unconventional voices.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Fed Warns of Financial Risks as Coronavirus Downturn Persists
abstract: The central bank said the financial system “amplified” the shock in March, and warned that vulnerabilities remain heightened.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus outbreak upended markets in March, and the Federal Reserve said on Friday that the financial system had exacerbated that turmoil and warned that highly indebted businesses remained a vulnerability that could hurt the broader economy.

headline: A Short Story Collection Based on Our News-Heavy Times
abstract: The Chronicles of Now tries to make sense of recent headlines with bite-size fiction.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve tried to read a book — or anything longer than 280 characters — lately, you’ve likely pondered the role of, and appetite for, fiction in our attention-fractured times. So, too, has Tyler Cabot, since long before the coronavirus swept in.

headline: Mortgage Relief That Comes With a $4,000 Bill
abstract: Borrowers with privately held mortgages don’t have the same options as those with government-backed loans. Some are being told they can skip payments, if they make them up all at once.
lead_paragraph: As the owner of a small marketing agency in central Florida, Edith Duran quickly found herself in a difficult spot as the coronavirus pandemic crippled the local businesses she counts as clients. She couldn’t draw her full salary in February, and by March, she was seeking relief on her mortgage.

headline: Getting Help With Your Mortgage
abstract: Resources for people in forbearance or struggling to make their payments.
lead_paragraph: If you are having trouble paying your mortgage or have already paused your monthly payments through a forbearance, here are some resources that may help:

headline: U.S. Urges Afghanistan to Stay the Course With Peace Deal as Violence Resurges
abstract: The chief American negotiator is scrambling to keep a tentative peace deal intact as violence inflames tensions between the Taliban and the Afghan government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American officials scrambled on Friday to keep Afghanistan’s tenuous peace process from falling apart, blaming the Islamic State for horrific attacks that have recently killed dozens of people and further inflamed tensions between the Taliban and the government in Kabul.

headline: Two Projects Are Filming Again. Here’s How They’re Doing It.
abstract: In Iceland, a Netflix series relied on testing and color-coded armbands. In Australia, the entire cast and crew of a Stephen King adaptation quarantined together.
lead_paragraph: Baltasar Kormakur, the Icelandic director best known in the United States for “Everest” and “Contraband,” turned to a color-coded armband system to get his Netflix sci-fi series “Katla” back into production in Reykjavik after the coronavirus shut it down in mid-March.

headline: Trump Blames Tests and Obama
abstract: Readers cite the president’s recent claims that testing leads to virus cases, and that his predecessor was guilty of some unspecified crime. Also: The heroes among us; give New York streets over to outdoor dining.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Justice Dept.’s Attempt to Drop the Michael Flynn Case, Explained
abstract: The move is highly unusual and has prompted a judge to appoint an outsider to argue against the department.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Emmet G. Sullivan, who is presiding over the case against President Trump’s former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn, has appointed a former mafia prosecutor and retired federal judge, John Gleeson, to argue against Attorney General William P. Barr’s attempt to drop the case.

headline: Savoring Tea and Toast Through Crisis
abstract: The miracle of tea is that it “somehow comes back to blooming life on your tongue.”
lead_paragraph: When we shared our ode to a buttery, sweet piece of toast, paired with a steaming mug of tea on a recent Friday afternoon, listener responses poured in. Wendy Dorr, who edited the story, on how The Daily team picked this comforting combination, and how to make toast and tea like the experts (though how you’re doing it now is absolutely correct, too):

headline: Learn Guitar with Laura Marling
abstract: The folk singer-songwriter demystifies her various tuning techniques, taking followers step-by-step through some of her most popular songs.
lead_paragraph: Despite performing for more than a decade, and having seven solo albums to her name, the British folk singer-songwriter Laura Marling insists she’s not a natural entertainer. She calls herself the “subtle event” rather than the life of the party.Accordingly, instead of serenading her fans with concerts from her home in London, she has made the most of her lockdown by livestreaming weekly guitar tutorials on Instagram, @lauramarling. Since late March, Ms. Marling has posted more than a dozen 10-to-15-minute videos breaking down some of her most famous songs, garnering tens of thousands of views.

headline: Louis Delsarte, a Muralist of the Black Experience, Dies at 75
abstract: His paintings and murals rendered the Harlem Renaissance, Martin Luther King Jr. and his Brooklyn neighbors in stunning color.
lead_paragraph: Louis Delsarte, a noted artist who celebrated African-American history and culture through dreamlike paintings, drawings, prints and, above all, large-scale public murals, died on May 2 in Atlanta. He was 75.

headline: When Did the Coronavirus Arrive in the U.S.? Here’s a Review of the Evidence.
abstract: Was the virus here in January? In December? Earlier? Here’s a look at the evidence of how the virus emerged from China and landed in the United States.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In a county north of Seattle, two people who came down with respiratory illnesses in December now have antibodies for the coronavirus. In Florida, a public health official who got sick in January believes he had Covid-19.

headline: The Trains Stopped Running. Our Night Was Only Beginning.
abstract: Covering the first planned suspension of overnight subway service in New York required cooperation from reporters and photographers all over the city. And coffee.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Another Health Minister in Brazil Exits Amid Chaotic Coronavirus Response
abstract: The new health minister, Nelson Teich, quit after four weeks, deepening the coronavirus crisis in Brazil, where the death rate is rising and the president wants people to return to work now.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Brazilian government’s chaotic response to the coronavirus pandemic worsened Friday as its latest health minister quit barely a month into the job, with daily deaths from infection climbing and a defiant president exhorting people to get back to work.

headline: ‘There May Not Be Pomp Because of Our Circumstances,’ Oprah Tells Students
abstract: Oprah Winfrey addressed graduates in the Class of 2020. More than 75 other celebrities joined her.
lead_paragraph: Oprah Winfrey addressed graduates in the Class of 2020. More than 75 other celebrities joined her.

headline: The Bundesliga Is Back. So Why Isn’t Your League?
abstract: The return of matches is not so much proof of German soccer’s greed or its smooth running as it is a testament to a broader political reality.
lead_paragraph: Enjoying this newsletter? Tell a friend to sign up at nytimes.com/rory and then you’ll have at least one thing to talk about every Friday.

headline: Tendol Gyalzur, Refugee Who Founded Orphanages in Tibet, Dies
abstract: After losing her parents during the failed 1959 Tibetan uprising, she fled to India, became a nurse in Germany and later worked with the Chinese government to aid needy children in her homeland.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Judge Reinstates Charges Against Engineer in Philadelphia Train Wreck That Killed 8
abstract: The ruling revived the state’s case against Brandon Bostian, a former Amtrak engineer, who has been charged with more than 200 crimes, including eight counts of involuntary manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Thursday reinstated charges against a former Amtrak engineer who was driving a speeding train that derailed in Philadelphia in 2015, killing eight people.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The world is watching Sweden’s high-stakes gamble.
lead_paragraph: Sweden is an outlier with its coronavirus response, forgoing the strict lockdowns of its European neighbors. A new Times analysis looked at how that strategy is playing out.

headline: N.F.L. Owners Will Review Incentives to Boost Racial Diversity
abstract: The league’s owners will meet virtually on Tuesday and vote on measures which would grant competitive advantages to teams that hire nonwhite coaches and general managers.
lead_paragraph: When the N.F.L. owners meet via video conference on Tuesday, they will consider proposals that would give competitive advantages to teams that hire nonwhite candidates for their general manager and top coaching positions, according to several people familiar with the measures who were not authorized to speak publicly about them.

headline: J.C. Penney, 118-Year-Old Department Store, Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The chain’s move came after J. Crew and the Neiman Marcus Group filed, and represented the biggest casualty amid retail closures tied to the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: J.C. Penney, with its budget-friendly clothing for families and reliable home furnishings, was for years a cornerstone of American malls and an undeniable success story. What started as a humble dry goods store in Wyoming in 1902 was a century later a national chain with a household name and more than 1,000 locations.

headline: Amazon Makes No Promises on Bezos Testimony
abstract: The company said it would be happy to send someone to testify. But it never mentions Jeff Bezos.
lead_paragraph: Amazon responded to lawmakers on Friday who demanded that its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, testify as part of a congressional antitrust investigation.

headline: Intelligence Chief Reduces Size of Counterterrorism Office
abstract: The cuts to the National Counterterrorism Center were smaller than some former officials feared. The changes will allow intelligence agencies to shift personnel to other threats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The acting intelligence chief announced a reorganization of the National Counterterrorism Center on Friday, part of an effort to reduce the size of the office overseeing the nation’s spy agencies.

headline: Will Britain’s Pubs Survive the Coronavirus?
abstract: A fundamental pillar of British life is in peril.
lead_paragraph: STROUD, England — A good pub feels a bit like a living room: a familiar, informal space where you can have a pint with friends and strangers. Sometimes there are games, food and a fire, occasionally a dog or cat. There are often pictures of old people on the walls and sports on the television.

headline: Kobe Bryant Helicopter Crash Autopsies Say Pilot Tested Negative for Drugs
abstract: The pilot of the helicopter that crashed in January, killing Mr. Bryant and eight others, didn’t have alcohol or drugs in his system. The victims all died from blunt trauma.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles County coroner’s office on Friday released autopsies for the victims of the helicopter crash in California that killed the basketball star Kobe Bryant, his 13-year-old daughter, Gianna, and all seven other people on board.

headline: A Bit of Relief: Reruns, Rituals and Restaurants
abstract: “Experiencing good or even brilliantly dumb art is a form of self-care.”
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Man Faces Terrorism Charge After Threatening to Kill Michigan’s Governor, Officials Say
abstract: Robert S. Tesh made “credible threats” via social media messages to kill Gov. Gretchen Whitmer and Michigan’s attorney general, Dana Nessel, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A Detroit man has been charged with threatening to kill Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan and the state attorney general, Dana Nessel, prosecutors said on Friday.

headline: House Passes $3 Trillion Aid Bill Over Republican Opposition
abstract: The bill faces a veto threat from President Trump, near-unanimous opposition by Republicans and complaints from Democrats, but leaders called it their opening offer in talks on the next round of pandemic relief.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A divided House narrowly passed a $3 trillion pandemic relief package on Friday to send aid to struggling state and local governments and another round of direct $1,200 payments to taxpayers, advancing a proposal with no chance of becoming law over near-unanimous Republican opposition.

headline: M.L.B.’s Efforts to Return to the Field Could Take the Game Back to 1994
abstract: The potential for labor strife has loomed over plans to put teams on the field this summer, threatening the sport with a potential long-term decline.
lead_paragraph: The best way to sell a product is to convince people that they need it. This concept fuels the overriding fear within Major League Baseball these days. The coronavirus pandemic shut down the league just before the regular season would have started. If baseball remains on hold until 2021, many people will learn to live without it. They will not need the product.

headline: The Masked Versus the Unmasked
abstract: How can Trump opponents take on people who will stop at nothing?
lead_paragraph: Back in the other world, before all was stilled, a neighbor in Colorado would tell me it was time for liberals to “gun up.” The other side was armed, he argued, and would stop at nothing. What would we tell our grandchildren when Ivanka Trump took office as the 46th president of the United States in 2025 and term limits were abolished? That we tried words, all manner of them, he scoffed, but they had the rifles.

headline: A Sitting President, Riling the Nation During a Crisis
abstract: By smearing his opponents, championing conspiracy theories and pursuing vendettas, President Tru​mp has reverted to his darkest political tactics in spite of a pandemic hurting millions of Americans.
lead_paragraph: ​​Even by President Trump’s standards, it was a rampage: He attacked a government whistle-blower who was telling Congress that the coronavirus pandemic had been mismanaged. He criticized the governor of Pennsylvania, who has resisted reopening businesses. He railed against former President Barack Obama, linking him to a conspiracy theory and demanding he answer questions before the Senate about the federal investigation of Michael T. Flynn.

headline: U.S. Is Said to Plan to File Antitrust Charges Against Google
abstract: The case may be joined by state attorneys general in what would be one of the biggest antitrust actions by the United States since the late 1990s.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is planning to file antitrust charges against Google as early as this summer, said two people with knowledge of the situation, in what would be one of the biggest antitrust actions by the United States since the late 1990s.

headline: America’s Obsession With Cheap Meat
abstract: Meat-eating is part of the American identity, a tradition that underlies efforts to keep slaughterhouses open despite coronavirus outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: In the hierarchy of essential things in America, it appears, cheeseburgers rank near the top. The president’s recent declaration that meatpacking plants are “critical infrastructure” and meat is “essential” under the Defense Production Act speaks volumes about this country’s attachment to an abundant supply of beef and pork even amid a pandemic.

headline: In This Election, It’s the Remote Against the Exposed
abstract: Those facing the greatest dangers will decide the outcome.
lead_paragraph: In February 2016 Peggy Noonan wrote a prescient column in The Wall Street Journal, in which she made the distinction between two classes of people: the “protected” — that is, the well-off, the connected, the comfortably insulated — and the “unprotected” — everyone else.

headline: Treasury Eases Terms for Small Businesses to Convert Loans to Grants
abstract: A fact sheet released on Friday said businesses could get forgiveness without rehiring all their employees if the layoffs occurred early on during the lockdowns.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department on Friday made it slightly easier for small-business owners to avoid having to repay government-backed loans they took out under a program designed to keep them from laying off employees and permanently closing.

headline: McConnell’s Rush to Protect Businesses Endangers Everyone Else
abstract: To reopen safely, companies need good, clear and mandatory guidelines, not immunity from liability.
lead_paragraph: There’s a tension at the heart of all of the plans to reopen the country in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic: The economy needs Americans to get back to work, but workplaces need employees and customers to feel that coming back won’t endanger their health or their lives.

headline: Barber Defied Rules and Cut Hair From Home. Now He Has the Virus.
abstract: The barber in Kingston, N.Y., is under investigation for giving haircuts during the shutdown. He lashed out at Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, saying, “Is he going to feed my family?”
lead_paragraph: The complaint came in last month from a resident of Kingston, a city in New York’s Hudson Valley: A local barbershop was still performing haircuts, in violation of New York’s emergency shutdown orders to thwart the coronavirus.

headline: Hefty Barriers to Entry
abstract: Tracy Gray and Jeff Chen make excellent bouncers for their Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We have a really fun, skillful construction today, by Tracy Gray and Jeff Chen, a couple of veteran puzzlemakers who have worked together before, one of whom has his hands on buckets of data and presumably compiles interesting words the way Dr. Frankenstein hoarded body parts. Its seven debuts are mainly on the edges but there are loads of clever bits and pieces everywhere, a few congenial misdirects, and maybe a sticking point or two for the casual Saturday solver. Mainly, I was pleasantly diverted by various cultural references and nostalgia, like this bunch, a very early version of the “entertaining from quarantine” family.

headline: How the Pandemic Hit Bollywood
abstract: The Hindi film industry came together to protect its most vulnerable after the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — “Bollywood” conjures images of ubiquitous stars, but every movie produced in Mumbai is made possible by an army of men and women toiling in the shadows: the extras, the carpenters and caterers, the tailors bent over sewing machines creating glittering costumes, the men putting up movie billboards, the men sitting in the ticket window at the local theater.

headline: Corrections: May 16, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 16, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about threats to the movie theater industry and innovations that might  revive it misstated the expected release date of the film “Jurassic World: Dominion.” It is the summer of 2021, not this summer.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Brazil’s Health Minister Exits Amid Government’s Chaotic Response to Pandemic
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 16, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “My investment advice would be not to run into a burning building.”

headline: Modi’s Popularity Soars as India Weathers the Pandemic
abstract: Recent polls have the prime minister’s approval ratings topping 80 or 90 percent. But the economic devastation from the coronavirus has yet to be reckoned with.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Just before the coronavirus arrived in India, Prime Minister Narendra Modi faced serious challenges, perhaps the biggest of his tenure.

headline: Brazil’s Halting Coronavirus Response Has Made It a Hotspot
abstract: At least 100 babies born into Ukraine’s booming surrogate motherhood business have become marooned in the country, and more are coming. Saudi Arabia’s planned transformation has been thrown off course by the pandemic.
