headline: Trump Removes State Dept. Inspector General
abstract: A top Democrat in Congress described the move as “an outrageous act,” and said that the inspector general, Steve Linick, had opened an investigation into Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump continued his purge of inspectors general late Friday, moving to oust Steve A. Linick, who had served in that post at the State Department since 2013, and replacing him with an ambassador with close ties to Vice President Mike Pence.

headline: Judge Orders Los Angeles to Move Homeless People Away From Freeways
abstract: The order, which takes effect next Friday, will apply to about 6,500 people living under freeways and on their ramps.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday ordered the Los Angeles authorities to move thousands of homeless people away from freeways and their ramps because of the particularly deadly hazards in those areas, including pollutants, passing cars and potential earthquakes.

headline: Suspect in Arbery Shooting Offered to Help Deal With Potential Trespasser
abstract: Two months before Ahmaud Arbery was killed, one of the suspects told the police he could be notified if a nearby homeowner noticed any suspicious activity.
lead_paragraph: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — Two months before Ahmaud Arbery was fatally shot in Glynn County, Ga., a police officer there sent a text to a property owner who was worried about recurring trespassing incidents, a lawyer for the homeowner said on Friday.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Great’ and ‘Graduate Together’
abstract: A historical comedy series streams on Hulu, while Barack Obama joins a virtual graduation ceremony for high school seniors.
lead_paragraph: THE GREAT Stream on Hulu. Before starting this new dramedy, it’s best to leave your historical knowledge at the door. “The Great” refers to Catherine the Great (Elle Fanning), the 18th-century empress who became one of Russia’s most notable leaders after overthrowing her husband, Emperor Peter III (Nicholas Hoult). Created by Tony McNamara, who co-wrote the equally irreverent historical film “The Favourite,” the show favors the comical and absurd over the factual. Writing in The New York Times, Eleanor Stanford said it’s “witty and self-aware, using a charismatic woman from the past as a conduit through which to explore more modern preoccupations.”

headline: A Mogul’s Wife Vanishes. Now Norway Has a National Obsession.
abstract: At first, the disappearance of the wife of one of the country’s richest people seemed to be an abduction. But then suspicion turned on the husband.
lead_paragraph: FJELLHAMAR, Norway — Her last phone call was at 9:14 a.m., around the time that her husband, one of the richest men in Norway, passed under the security cameras at the gates of his energy and property investment company. Not much later that morning more than 18 months ago, Anne-Elisabeth Falkevik Hagen, 68, vanished from her house in suburban Oslo.

headline: The Trout Were Socially Distant, but Not the Family Memories
abstract: Fishing with his adult son for the first time, the author wonders if the pandemic will be remembered as the time we were distancing and yet simultaneously being drawn closer together.
lead_paragraph: ATTLEBORO, Mass. — I distanced myself from my son Patrick, not as a precaution against the virus — though he is an emergency room nurse and in the thick of things — but because a novice fly fisherman poses enough danger.

headline: In Financial Trouble? Track Everything Companies Tell You
abstract: Call centers are short staffed, and employees are scattered. Mistakes are inevitable. Document any changes and offers of relief, just to be safe.
lead_paragraph: Every financial services company has a coronavirus relief page on its website right now, filled with reassuring language about the assistance on offer. Federal laws and regulations are supposed to make it easier to get help.

headline: When the World Unravels, Braid Your Own Hair
abstract: I’ve worn my hair in the same exact style for six years. Learning to style it myself has brought some comfort of normalcy.
lead_paragraph: I’ve worn my hair in the same exact style for six years. Learning to style it myself has brought some comfort of normalcy.

headline: How to Let Your Children Be Upset
abstract: A series of children’s books can help start conversations about deeply uncomfortable subjects.
lead_paragraph: Anastasia Higginbotham’s first book opens with an image of a child holding a glass of milk. The sky outside is partly cloudy, but still blue. A speech bubble floats in from off the page with a parent’s words: “We have something to tell you.”

headline: I'm Usually a Conflict Photographer. Now, I'm Documenting My Family.
abstract: For the first time in my career I decided not to cover a major event. I'm seeing something more timeless and universal.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in my career I decided not to cover a major event. I'm seeing something more timeless and universal.

headline: A Springtime of Death in New Orleans
abstract: The toll of the virus has been grim in New Orleans, taking away lives while also cruelly taking away rituals of loss and mourning.
lead_paragraph: The toll of the virus has been grim in New Orleans, taking away lives while also cruelly taking away rituals of loss and mourning.

headline: I Left My Troubled City Behind. Now I Feel Guilty.
abstract: My adult son, worried about my health, urged me to flee. But New York doesn’t let go easily.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t want to leave the city.

headline: Give a Different Kind of Graduation Gift
abstract: The class of 2020, whether in high school or college, has had a senior year like no other. So give them a fitting present.
lead_paragraph: The class of 2020 is graduating into an off-kilter world. Ceremonies are canceled and it’s not safe to throw an in-person party. But graduates are still celebrating. And gifts are still in order, though in interviews many graduates acknowledged the country’s economic problems, and did not want to create a stress or burden on their families. For many joy and pride are enough.

headline: Summer Is Coming. Don’t Count on N.Y.C.’s Beaches for Relief.
abstract: Nearby beaches will open in time, but for now the pandemic will deprive New Yorkers of that pleasure closer to home.
lead_paragraph: For New Yorkers, a refreshing dip in the ocean at Coney Island has long been a staple of summer and a vital source of relief from the heat.

headline: Michael Jordan: N.B.A. Champ, Marketing Legend and … Toxic Worker?
abstract: Experts say a difficult superstar is rarely worth the cost to workplace morale. Does the Bulls icon prove them wrong?
lead_paragraph: He showed little mercy when berating co-workers. He seized on their setbacks and scoffed at their maladies. He punched at least two in the head.

headline: Can Sports Help Heal a Country? Some Fans Don’t Buy the Emotional Pleas
abstract: The sports world has a clear economic argument for coming back to play. But is the claim that it has a larger purpose out of step with the reality of the pandemic?
lead_paragraph: Few things would make Pedro Urbaez happier than seeing the Mets play again.

headline: Now More Than Ever, Facebook Is a ‘Mark Zuckerberg Production’
abstract: For years, he was an obsessive C.E.O. in some ways, distant in others. Then Facebook’s problems became too acute to leave to anyone else.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On Jan. 27, at a regularly scheduled Monday morning meeting with top executives at Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg turned the agenda to the coronavirus. For weeks, he told his staff, he had been hearing from global health care experts that the virus had the makings of a pandemic, and now Facebook needed to prepare for a worst-case scenario — one in which the company’s ability to combat misinformation, scammers and conspiracy theorists would be tested as never before.

headline: Stacey Abrams Wants More Than the Vice Presidency
abstract: She wants the Democrats to reach a different kind of swing voter — those who otherwise stay home. And she says she can help Joe Biden do it.
lead_paragraph: The clapping hands appeared on the screen — one, two, a flurry of emojis — flashing under the Facebook Live feed of the former minority leader of the Georgia House of Representatives, Stacey Abrams. It was the socially distanced derivative of the applause she has often encountered in the past year or so, since her narrow loss in the race for governor of Georgia in 2018.

headline: Stuck at Home, Men in Japan Learn to Help. Will It Last?
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic is exposing like never before the severe disparities in how Japanese couples divide household work.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Susumu Kataoka was just looking for a diversion from long days sheltering at home with his family during the coronavirus outbreak. He grabbed his drone and took it for a spin around their Tokyo house, snapping some pictures and posting them on Facebook.

headline: Remote and Ready to Fight Coronavirus’s Next Wave
abstract: An island community in Washington State has developed a testing and tracing strategy it hopes will be a model for rural and tribal communities.
lead_paragraph: In mid-March, Dr. Jim Bristow’s wife came down with gastrointestinal issues. Then, she couldn’t stop coughing.

headline: Travels With John Conway, in 258 Septillion Dimensions
abstract: The Princeton mathemagician, who died in April, left an engaging legacy of numerical gamesmanship.
lead_paragraph: When John Horton Conway, the Princeton “mathemagician” who died in April at age 82, first found fame in the late 1960s and early ’70s, he joined the academic equivalent of the jet set. Then at the University of Cambridge, he would fly to Montreal or New York, deliver a lecture on his Conway group — an entity in the realm of mathematical symmetry that inhabits 24 dimensions — and return home all within the space of a day.

headline: Why Bombs Made in America Have Been Killing Civilians in Yemen
abstract: President Trump sees arms deals as jobs generators for firms like Raytheon, which has made billions in sales to the Saudi coalition. The Obama administration initially backed the Saudis too, but later regretted it as thousands died.
lead_paragraph: Year after year, the bombs fell — on wedding tents, funeral halls, fishing boats and a school bus, killing thousands of civilians and helping turn Yemen into the world’s worst humanitarian crisis.

headline: 5 Takeaways on U.S. Involvement in the World’s Worst Humanitarian Crisis
abstract: Thousands of civilians have died in Yemen, and American-made bombs sold to the Saudis have played a key role as the White House has sought to boost the arms industry.
lead_paragraph: Long before the coronavirus caused human suffering and economic chaos on a global scale, the world’s worst humanitarian crisis was unfolding in Yemen, the Arab world’s poorest country and one that has been mired in civil war.

headline: Married but Living Far Apart
abstract: Some couples, driven by their careers, decide to stay put rather than move in with their spouse. Lately, some have changed their minds about that arrangement.
lead_paragraph: Ian Derrer and Daniel James were married in August 2019 in the garden room of a restaurant in Santa Fe, N.M., with each of their 19 guests reading aloud lyrics to the couple’s favorite Stephen Sondheim love songs. After staying in Santa Fe for a weeklong honeymoon, during which they hiked at Bandelier National Monument and enjoyed the opera “La Bohème,” the couple drove to Dallas, where Mr. Derrer, 45, lives. The next day, Mr. James, 33, left for Houston, where he lives.

headline: Germany Criminalizes Burning of E.U. and Other Foreign Flags
abstract: The new ban, relatively rare in the world’s legal codes, was proposed as a response to the burning of an Israeli flag at a demonstration in 2017.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German lawmakers have voted to make the destruction of foreign state flags, including that of the European Union, and the denigration of national anthems punishable by a fine and up to three years in prison, in a relatively rare move by a government to protect the symbols of other nations.

headline: Iran Sentences French-Iranian Academic to 6 Years in Prison
abstract: Fariba Adelkhah has been detained north of Tehran since 2019.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French-Iranian academic who has been detained in Iran for almost a year was sentenced on Saturday to six years in prison on national security charges, according to her lawyer.

headline: Afghan Power-Sharing Deal Would Promote General Accused of Rape
abstract: The case is still open against Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, a strongman from Afghanistan’s civil war. But he would become a marshal in order to help settle a bitter election dispute.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The two sides in the monthslong dispute over Afghanistan’s presidential election are close to signing a power-sharing deal, the terms of which include giving top military honors to a former vice president who is accused of torturing and ordering the rape of a political rival while in office.

headline: Running Down a Dream
abstract: A writer spent a summer living and training with a team of professional runners.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: U.S. Lacks Leadership on Virus, Obama Tells Graduates
abstract: Investigators have uncovered a fraud ring that may have siphoned millions of dollars in unemployment payments. With more than two-thirds of states significantly relaxing restrictions, an uptick in cases is predicted.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live coronavirus pandemic updates.]

headline: Rwandan Genocide Suspect Arrested After 23 Years on the Run
abstract: Félicien Kabuga, 84, had been on the run for 23 years, since he was indicted by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda on multiple charges of genocide.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — He was behind the radio station whose hate-filled invectives turned Rwandan against Rwandan, neighbor against neighbor, even spouse against spouse. He was the man, it was said, who imported the hundreds of thousands of machetes that allowed countless ordinary people to act upon that hatred in one of the last genocides of the past century.

headline: Amazon Reaches Deal With French Unions in Coronavirus Safety Dispute
abstract: The online giant will begin reopening its six warehouses in France following a legal battle over protections for employees.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — ​Amazon has reached an agreement with French unions to reopen its warehouses in France after a lengthy battle over safety measures to protect workers against the coronavirus, capping the most prominent labor showdown the retailer has faced during the pandemic.

headline: Horse Racing Tracks Can Open in New York in June, Cuomo Says
abstract: Some horse racing, as well as some auto racing, will be allowed to go ahead next month as New York State begins reopening nonessential businesses in several regions.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Sunday’s live coverage.]

headline: Grandparents to the Rescue
abstract: Grandkid duty can be ‘wonderful and exhausting’
lead_paragraph: After nearly two months of attempting to do our jobs and also educate and care for our 7- and 3-year-olds full time, the cavalry arrived last week in the form of my parents. They are helping my husband and me with kid care, and when I saw them for the first time after our respective quarantines, I cried from joy and relief. They asked my 7-year-old how distance learning was going, and she said, “It was a mess before you got here.”

headline: Coronavirus Cases Slow in U.S., but the Big Picture Remains Tenuous
abstract: Reports of new cases have declined nationally, and deaths have slowed. But reopening plans leave unanswered questions.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The number of new coronavirus cases confirmed in the United States has steadily declined in recent days. In New York, the figure has dropped over the past month. The numbers have also plunged in hard-hit Massachusetts and Rhode Island, and some states, including Vermont, Hawaii and Alaska, are reporting few new cases at all.

headline: Play-Date Arrangements: Are They Safe or Irresponsible?
abstract: Parents are increasingly concerned that extended isolation may stunt their children’s development. But how much risk is too much?
lead_paragraph: Q: My 3-year-old daughter has been home with us since March, with virtually no social contact beyond her parents. I’m worried about how an extended isolation will affect her development. Another family in our Brooklyn apartment building asked if we would be open to an exclusive play-date arrangement with their child — no other families would be involved outside of ours. What measures could we take to make sure it’s safe? Is that even possible?

headline: A Few Brave Kids Battle a Toxic World
abstract: In Kenneth Oppel’s “Bloom,” three meek teenagers seem poised to inherit the earth. But what kind of earth will it be?
lead_paragraph: If flu-pandemic books make cold sufferers anxious and zombie books make agoraphobics jittery, here’s something to rattle the Zyrtec set.

headline: Jim Obergefell: L.G.B.T.Q. Discrimination Is a ‘Disgrace’
abstract: The named plaintiff in a landmark Supreme Court case on gay marriage discusses current L.G.B.T.Q. cases before the court.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Carnival Performer, Newly Separated; Attachment Issues
abstract: In Lisa Brown’s first long-form graphic novel, “The Phantom Twin,” a formerly conjoined twin touring in a sideshow feels the pang of cut ties.
lead_paragraph: In the tradition of Ransom Riggs’s “Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children” and Katherine Dunn’s “Geek Love,” Lisa Brown’s THE PHANTOM TWIN (First Second, 208 pp., $17.99; ages 12 to 16) explores the behind-the-scenes lives of performers in an old-timey circus sideshow, tapping into our fascination — and on some level identification — with these obvious “outsiders.”

headline: Brazil, Once a Leader, Struggles to Contain Virus Amid Political Turmoil
abstract: The nation’s pioneering responses to past health crises, including AIDS and Zika, won global praise. But the government’s chaotic response to the virus has undercut the country’s ability to cope.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on Brazil’s Coronavirus cases and deaths.]

headline: The Crispiest Oven-Fried Potatoes
abstract: Patatas bravas, leek risotto, and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include oven-fried patatas bravas with two sauces (above); chicken yassa; and leek risotto with sugar snap peas and pancetta. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: ‘I Can’t Turn My Brain Off’: PTSD and Burnout Threaten Medical Workers
abstract: Before Covid-19, health care workers were already vulnerable to depression and suicide. Mental health experts now fear even more will be prone to trauma-related disorders.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus patient, a 75-year-old man, was dying. No family member was allowed in the room with him, only a young nurse.

headline: Saudi Arabia’s Big Dreams and Easy Living Hit a Wall
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic and falling oil prices have yanked the rug out from under Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s development plans and curbed government largess.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia knows about head-spinning change.

headline: Variety: Cascades
abstract: Let’s drift downstream with Eric Berlin’s new variety puzzle.
lead_paragraph: CASCADES — Who says there’s nothing new under the sun? I looked high and low for a precursor to this interesting grid and came up with nothing (and then I asked the constructor, Eric Berlin, who helpfully provided some notes). On first sight, I considered it a variation on “Marching Bands,” since we’re working with two sets of clues, and every letter in the grid appears in two entries. It was a very different solving experience, for me at least; more intuitive and relaxing than “Marching Bands.”

headline: Obama Says U.S. Lacks Leadership on Virus in Commencement Speeches
abstract: The virus has “torn back the curtain on the idea that so many of the folks in charge know what they’re doing,” the former president said. “A lot of them aren’t even pretending to be in charge.”
lead_paragraph: Without the springtime rituals of traditional graduation ceremonies, former President Barack Obama delivered two virtual commencement addresses on Saturday, urging millions of high school and college graduates to fearlessly carve a path and “to seize the initiative” at a time when he says the nation’s leaders have fumbled the response to the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Grieving Shouldn’t Be a Privilege
abstract: Many of us are experiencing loss right now. We need the time and space to process it.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — My friend Moe was back at work a week after her husband, Andrew, hanged himself by the Mississippi River, just a few miles from their home in northeast Minneapolis.

headline: Feds Suspect Vast Fraud Network Is Targeting U.S. Unemployment Systems
abstract: Investigators see evidence of a sophisticated international attack they said could siphon hundreds of millions of dollars that were intended for the unemployed.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A group of international fraudsters appears to have mounted an immense, sophisticated attack on U.S. unemployment systems, creating a network that has already siphoned millions of dollars in payments that were intended to avert an economic collapse, according to federal authorities.

headline: Sorry, Abe Lincoln Is Not on the Ballot
abstract: But the 16th president is showing up quite a bit in the 2020 race. He remains uncommitted.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Lincoln may have died 155 years ago, but everyone still wants his endorsement.

headline: At the Drive-In: Thrills, Chills, Popcorn and Hand Sanitizer
abstract: Cabin fever and movies drew carloads of people to the drive-in theater in Warwick, N.Y., on Friday as it opened for business again.
lead_paragraph: WARWICK, N.Y. — In the end, it was the rain, not the virus, that drove some moviegoers to leave the drive-in theater here Friday as a storm interrupted the season’s first shows.

headline: How Washington Learned to Embrace the Budget Deficit
abstract: Many economists who once warned of mounting debt are now urging lawmakers to spend more to combat economic pain from coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This month, the federal government said it would borrow a record-breaking $3 trillion from April to June to help businesses and workers get through the coronavirus-induced recession. In April alone, the United States recorded a larger budget deficit in a single month than it did for all of the 2017 fiscal year, a total of $738 billion.

headline: Doctor to Congress and Supreme Court Toils to Sidestep Politics Amid Pandemic
abstract: Dr. Brian P. Monahan has found himself in the middle of politicized debates over how quickly to reopen the country and who should be testing for Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Senator John Barrasso, Republican of Wyoming, sought guidance on how to protect his family, including his 94-year-old father-in-law, when he returned home from the nation’s capital amid the coronavirus pandemic, a doctor offered him some blunt advice.

headline: Peter Brancazio, Who Explored the Physics of Sports, Dies at 81
abstract: He used science to demystify the myths of rising fastballs and Michael Jordan’s seemingly long hang time. He died of complications of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: 100 Babies Stranded in Ukraine After Surrogate Births
abstract: Travel bans have prevented the babies’ parents from entering the country. One official says as many as 1,000 babies will be born before restrictions are lifted.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The babies lie in cribs, sleeping, crying or smiling at nurses, swaddled in clean linens and apparently well cared for, but separated from their parents as an unintended consequence of coronavirus travel bans.

headline: Burying My Bubby During the Pandemic
abstract: The coronavirus is a deep, dark life lesson in how to experience something awful while quietly leaning over to your neighbor and whispering, “Can you believe these schmucks?”
lead_paragraph: One Sunday afternoon a month ago, my mother put me on a conference call with a nurse who explained exactly how we were going to say goodbye to my grandmother, Bubby. She was dying of the coronavirus.

headline: David Carter, a Historian of Stonewall, Is Dead at 67
abstract: His research into the 1969 uprising that was a turning point in the gay rights movement helped get the site of that uprising recognized as a landmark.
lead_paragraph: David Carter, whose careful research into the Stonewall Inn uprising of 1969, a pivotal event in gay rights history, culminated in an authoritative book on the subject and helped win the area in Greenwich Village where the episode occurred a listing in the National Register of Historic Places, died on May 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.

headline: Justin Amash Abandons Third-Party Presidential Bid
abstract: The Michigan conservative said the “extraordinary challenges” of campaigning in the current environment had discouraged him from challenging President Trump and Joe Biden.
lead_paragraph: Representative Justin Amash of Michigan announced on Saturday that he would not pursue the Libertarian Party’s nomination for president, bringing an end to his extended flirtation with a third-party candidacy that could have introduced a new element of uncertainty into the race between President Trump and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Read the Full Transcript of Obama’s H.B.C.U. Commencement Speech
abstract: Former President Barack Obama addressed a ceremony for graduates of historically black colleges and universities. Here is what he had to say.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama gave the virtual commencement address at a ceremony for graduates of historically black colleges and universities on Saturday. The two-hour event, “Show Me Your Walk H.B.C.U. Edition,” celebrated more than 27,000 students from 78 schools.

headline: Exotic Lizards Creep Into Georgia. Don’t Expect Southern Hospitality.
abstract: State wildlife officials have warned residents to be on the lookout for the Argentine black and white tegu, an invasive lizard species that is threatening native creatures.
lead_paragraph: Add it to the list of terrors of the natural world — including murder hornets and feral hogs — that have been disrupting life these days: The Argentine black and white tegu, an invasive lizard species from South America, has taken root in Georgia, where it poses a threat to native wildlife, according to state officials.

headline: Trump Ousted State Dept. Watchdog at Pompeo’s Urging; Democrats Open Inquiry
abstract: The lawmakers said Steve Linick, the State Department’s inspector general, had opened an investigation into Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s conduct.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged President Trump to fire the official responsible for fighting waste and fraud in his department, a White House official said Saturday, a recommendation certain to come under scrutiny after congressional Democrats opened an investigation into what they said “may be an act of illegal retaliation.”

headline: Fred Willard, Who Played Characters ‘Gloriously Out of Their Depth,’ Dies at 86
abstract: He was nominated for Emmys for his roles on “Modern Family” and “Everybody Loves Raymond,” and was a frequent collaborator with the director Christopher Guest.
lead_paragraph: Fred Willard, the Emmy Award-nominated comic actor best known for his scene-stealing roles in Christopher Guest’s improvised ensemble film comedies like “Best in Show” and “Waiting for Guffman” and on sitcoms like “Modern Family” and “Everybody Loves Raymond,” died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 86.

headline: Astrid Kirchherr, Who Helped Create the Beatles’ Image, Dies at 81
abstract: The stark black-and-white photographs she took of the group in Hamburg, Germany, before the musicians were famous captured both their toughness and their sensitivity.
lead_paragraph: Astrid Kirchherr, the German photographer whose portraits of the Beatles when the musicians were a scruffy British bar band playing in Hamburg’s red-light district captured not only their toughness but also the sensitivity beneath their leather-clad exteriors, died on Tuesday in Hamburg, Germany. She was 81.

headline: Cody Latimer of Washington Redskins Faces Assault and Weapons Charges
abstract: Deputies went to an apartment complex in Colorado early Saturday morning after receiving a report of gunfire inside a unit, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Cody Latimer, the Washington Redskins wide receiver formerly of the New York Giants, was arrested early on Saturday in Colorado on assault and weapons charges, local officials said.

headline: Donald Trump Jr. Smears Biden With Baseless Instagram Post
abstract: Signaling the increasingly dark tactics of the Trump campaign, the president’s oldest son falsely accused Mr. Biden of preying on children.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s eldest son on Saturday posted a social media message suggesting Joseph R. Biden Jr. was a pedophile, an incendiary and baseless charge that illustrates the tactics the president is turning to as he attempts to erase Mr. Biden’s early advantage in key state polls.

headline: F.D.A. Clears Another Coronavirus Testing Kit for Use at Home
abstract: The agency granted emergency clearance for a testing kit that allows a consumer to take a nasal sample at home and send it to a laboratory for the diagnosis.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Saturday granted emergency clearance for a coronavirus testing kit that will enable individuals to take a nasal sample at home and send it to a laboratory for diagnostic testing, the second such approval it has made.

headline: Wide-Open Spaces
abstract: Byron Walden slows our roll with a tough Sunday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We are fast approaching Byron Walden’s 100th puzzle for The Times, and he’s prolific elsewhere (including the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament). I think today’s construction is an escalation in the unthemed Sunday crossword monster construction race, as it has only 122 entries, tied with a beast from last year by Frank Longo (fewer answers make puzzles tougher to solve and absolute bears to build, as a rule). As its title intimates, this grid also has 177 “open squares,” which are empty squares that don’t touch any black block, even diagonally, third only to a 218 Patrick Berry Sunday puzzle and the aforementioned Longo puzzle. Joel Fagliano has made a 124-answer Sunday puzzle in the last year as well; all of these have been unthemed. Perhaps one day we’ll get a collaboration between all of these constructors with 42 spans and no black squares at all, and someone will still drop a “too easy!” in the comments.

headline: Lynn Shelton, Director of Intimate Comic Dramas, Dies at 54
abstract: She got a late start on her filmmaking career but won acclaim for a freewheeling style that made room for contributions from actors like Marc Maron, who survives her.
lead_paragraph: Lynn Shelton, the acclaimed director of “Humpday,” “Sword of Trust” and numerous other independent films, died on Friday at a hospital in Los Angeles. She was 54.

headline: Lynn Shelton Movie Moments
abstract: A look back at the writer and director’s films, and where to watch them.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Lynn Shelton, who in the last decade emerged as a strong voice in contemporary American independent film, has died at the age of 54. Her films often captured regular people facing irregular or extraordinary, scenarios that forced them to view their lives differently. Here is a look at highlights from her filmography, including review excerpts and information on where you can stream the movies.

headline: Phyllis George, Trailblazing Sportscaster, Is Dead at 70
abstract: Four years after being crowned Miss America, she became a celebrity, and drew criticism, as a co-host of the CBS show “The NFL Today.”
lead_paragraph: Phyllis George, who achieved one level of fame as Miss America 1971 and another one four years later, when CBS hired her to join the otherwise all-male cast of “The NFL Today,” died on Thursday in Lexington, Ky. She was 70.

headline: Glitches in Online A.P. Tests Add to Students’ Anxieties
abstract: Technical problems with the digital versions of the Advanced Placement exams caused angst for high school students and parents at an already stressful time.
lead_paragraph: Julia Rock-Torcivia had everything in place for her Advanced Placement chemistry test.

headline: Read the Full Transcript of Obama’s High School Commencement Speech
abstract: Former President Barack Obama gave a commencement address to the nation’s high school seniors. Here is what he had to say.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama spoke Saturday at “Graduate Together: High School Class of 2020 Commencement,” an event organized by XQ Institute, a think tank that works with schools, in partnership with LeBron James’s foundation and the Entertainment Industry Foundation.

headline: Corrections: May 17, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 17, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 13 about the TNT series “Snowpiercer” misstates the class status of Andre Layton, the character played by Daveed Diggs. Layton is a member of the bottom class, known as tailies, not the third class, which is higher.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘I Can’t Turn My Brain Off’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 17, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “The virus scares the hell out of our guys. And now, when they go home to decompress, instead they and their spouses are home-schooling. The spouse has lost a job, and is at wit’s end. The kids are screaming. Let me tell you: The tension level in the crews is through the roof.”

headline: Where New Yorkers Moved to Escape Coronavirus
abstract: As some of New York's wealthiest neighborhoods emptied out, mail-forwarding requests show us where they went.
lead_paragraph: As some of New York's wealthiest neighborhoods emptied out, mail-forwarding requests show us where they went.

headline: Ahmaud Arbery’s Final Minutes: What Videos and 911 Calls Show
abstract: Using security footage, cellphone video, 911 calls and police reports, The Times has reconstructed the 12 minutes before Ahmaud Arbery was shot dead in Georgia on Feb. 23.
lead_paragraph: Using security footage, cellphone video, 911 calls and police reports, The Times has reconstructed the 12 minutes before Ahmaud Arbery was shot dead in Georgia on Feb. 23.

headline: Where Ahmaud Arbery Ran, Neighbors Cast Wary Eyes
abstract: He took his final jog across a stretch of South Georgia marked by increasingly blurred racial boundary lines.
lead_paragraph: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — For many residents of Satilla Shores, a subdivision in coastal Georgia, their waterfront neighborhood is paradise without pretension.

headline: At Least 12 Firefighters Injured After Explosion in Downtown Los Angeles
abstract: Two firefighters were in critical condition after a blaze at a building that houses smoking and vaping products, officials said.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The firefighters realized something was wrong inside the building in downtown Los Angeles on Saturday night.

headline: Kathy Su, Eric Schultz
abstract: The couple met in 2017 through OkCupid and had their first date at a whiskey bar in New York.
lead_paragraph: Kathy Su and Eric Paul Schultz were married May 16 in Mesa, Ariz. Wade R. Swanson, a cousin of the groom and a Universal Life minister, officiated in the backyard of his home.

headline: Ayelet Bentley, Samuel Tbeile
abstract: They met in college and became a couple about a year later while on a Birthright Israel trip.
lead_paragraph: Ayelet Meryl Bentley and Samuel Joshua Tbeile are to be married May 17. Rabbi Meyer Laniado is to officiate at the Wadsworth Mansion in Middletown, Conn.

abstract: China has quarantined thousands of people after a resurgence of cases in the Northeast. The leaders of Italy and Britain warned that a vaccine may be a long time coming.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow live global updates on the coronavirus here.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Snowpiercer’ and Taylor Swift
abstract: An adaptation of Bong Joon Ho’s action movie debuts on TNT, and a Taylor Swift concert airs on ABC.
lead_paragraph: SNOWPIERCER 9 p.m. on TNT. Jennifer Connelly and Daveed Diggs star in this postapocalyptic drama series, based on the action flick of the same name by the director Bong Joon Ho (“Parasite”) and its source material, the French graphic novel series “Le Transperceneige.” The title refers to the show’s setting: a 1,001-car train that continuously circles the Earth after the planet has frozen and become unlivable. Yet worldly evils remain, namely class divides, social injustice and greed. Tensions reach a fever pitch when someone is killed in first class and Melanie Cavill (Connelly), the head of hospitality, seeks the help of Andre Layton (Diggs), a rebellious third-class passenger and the only surviving homicide detective on the planet. The series has been five years in the making, buts its debut comes two weeks earlier than planned. And TNT has already ordered a second season.

headline: ‘I Must Present a Compelling Case for Keeping the Item in Question’
abstract: A couple’s deal on what passes for trash, a first kiss in Brooklyn and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: How France Lost the Weapons to Fight a Pandemic
abstract: The French once thought of medical gear, like fighter jets, as a national security asset that had to be made at home. But cuts and outsourcing have left them scrambling for masks, tests and even pain pills.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When President Emmanuel Macron repeatedly declared “war” on the coronavirus in March, he solemnly promised that France would support “front-line” health workers with “the means, the protection.”

headline: Seeking: Big Democratic Ideas That Make Everything Better
abstract: By the end of primary season, the Democratic Party had all but settled on a conventional center-left agenda. But the pandemic is forcing the Biden campaign and other leaders to redraw plans for 2021.
lead_paragraph: More than 36 million Americans are suddenly unemployed. Congress has allocated $2.2 trillion in aid, with more likely to be on the way as a fight looms over government debt. Millions more people are losing their health insurance and struggling to take care of their children and aging relatives. And nearly 90,000 are dead in a continuing public health catastrophe.

headline: Chinese Ambassador Is Found Dead at Home in Israel
abstract: An embassy worker found the body of Du Wei, 57, in his bed in a coastal suburb north of Tel Aviv, Israeli officials said. The Chinese government in preliminary findings attributed his death to unspecified health problems.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — China’s ambassador to Israel, who took up his post in February, was found dead at his home on Sunday morning in a coastal suburb north of Tel Aviv, officials said.

headline: Wandering a Grand Hotel Emptied by Coronavirus, and Checking 1,400 Taps
abstract: A luxury hotel in Barcelona plans to welcome guests again once Spain’s lockdown ends. Until then, its sole occupant lives in a room with enviable views and preps it for a post-pandemic world.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Every five days, Daniel Ordoñez opens 1,400 pipe taps in a waterfront hotel here in Barcelona that locals call “The Sail” because of its shape.

headline: Without Fans, Some College Football Games Won’t Make Financial Sense
abstract: There are nearly 30 games scheduled for neutral sites in the coming season. Financially, they become somewhat untenable if the coronavirus forces them to go without fans.
lead_paragraph: When Alabama and Southern California agreed to kick off the season on Sept. 5 in Arlington, Texas, the one certain winner seemed to be the host — the Dallas Cowboys’ owner, Jerry Jones, whose Labor Day weekend game has become a college football staple.

headline: Will Cirque du Soleil Rise Again?
abstract: The coronavirus has pulverized the famed circus, forcing it to shut down dozens of shows and grounding its small army of circus artists.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Until the coronavirus pandemic hit, the Mongolian contortionist Uranbileg Angarag wowed spectators nightly at Cirque du Soleil shows on a cruise ship, contorting her body into a ball and balancing on a vertical stick held in her mouth.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Oil Prices Are Coming Back as Demand Rises
abstract: The U.S. benchmark reached $32 a barrel, a month after briefly falling below zero, but it’s still far from where it was before the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Driving in the United States and Europe is picking up a little. Refineries in China are buying more oil as that country’s economy reopens. Saudi Arabia and Russia ended their price war and slashed production, and American oil companies are decommissioning rigs and shutting wells.

headline: One More Relationship Tested by the Pandemic: Siblings
abstract: For many brothers and sisters, the coronavirus and its limits on relationships outside the home have upended their dynamics.
lead_paragraph: The isolation and close quarters of self-quarantine have shifted the balance in relationships between spouses and partners, employees and bosses, children and parents, students and teachers.

headline: In the Shadows of America’s Smokestacks, Virus Is One More Deadly Risk
abstract: Nationwide, poor communities  are exposed to much more air pollution than wealthier ones. Scientists are racing to understand what role this may play in  Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This isn’t the first time Vicki Dobbins’s town has been forced to shelter in place.

headline: State of the Virus, Barack Obama, Baseball: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Illinois Shooting Suspect Found Dead After Standoff at Super 8 Motel
abstract: One person was killed and two others wounded in the northern city of Rockford before a barricaded suspect died by what appeared to be a “self-inflicted” gunshot wound, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A burst of violence on Sunday morning at a Super 8 motel in Northern Illinois ended with one person killed, two others wounded and a suspect who was barricaded for hours inside the building dead of what appeared to be a “self-inflicted” gunshot wound, the authorities said.

headline: The Week in Business: Ready or Not, Here Comes the Reopening
abstract: Businesses start coming back to life, but will it lead to a resurgence of virus cases?
lead_paragraph: What letter will the economic recovery resemble? Everyone wants it to be a “V” — after a precipitous fall, straight up from here. But more realistic forecasters warn that it’ll likely be a long, wide “U,” taking years to rebuild. Scarier yet, some health officials say that we could see a “W” if the country reopens too early and there’s a resurgence of cases. Here’s the rest of the business news you need to know for the week ahead.

headline: As Cable TV Fades, Fearing ‘the End of Comedy Central’
abstract: The network that made the careers of Dave Chappelle, Stephen Colbert and Amy Schumer has laid off top executives while looking to make shows that are cheaper to produce.
lead_paragraph: Last year there were signs of hope for Comedy Central. Trevor Noah, the host of “The Daily Show” since 2015, had found his footing. New series like “The Other Two” and “South Side” got strong reviews. Awkwafina, the breakout star of “Crazy Rich Asians” and “The Farewell,” came aboard for a new show.

headline: Afghan Rivals Sign Power-Sharing Deal as Political Crisis Subsides
abstract: President Ashraf Ghani gave Abdullah Abdullah the leading role in seeking peace with the Taliban and the ability to name half the cabinet.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s monthslong election dispute, which resulted in the bizarre reality of two men taking the oath of office as president, reached a resolution on Sunday when President Ashraf Ghani gave his chief rival, Abdullah Abdullah, the leading role in the country’s peace process with the Taliban and the right to appoint half the cabinet.

headline: I’ll Take Biden’s Confusion Over Trump’s Corruption
abstract: Let’s not repeat the false equivalence of 2016.
lead_paragraph: Please tell me why I should care whether Joe Biden is declining mentally when Donald Trump bottomed out morally long ago.

headline: Illinois Threatens to Fine Defiant Businesses as Reopening Tensions Rise Nationally
abstract: Fed chair warns full economic recovery may await vaccine, while Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York has a public nasal swab to encourage testing.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Cuomo Urges More New Yorkers to Get Tested for Coronavirus
abstract: In New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio warned residents to avoid crowding on city beaches, saying they could be shut down completely if necessary.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Monday’s live coverage.]

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Letters of Recommendation’
abstract: Our worlds are smaller now. So for today, expand yours by peering through the views offered by a writer’s window, a grandmother’s diary and a believer’s superstition.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Arthur, the First Named Storm of the Hurricane Season, Forms
abstract: A tropical storm warning was issued for North Carolina’s Outer Banks, the National Hurricane Center said.
lead_paragraph: The first named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season  formed off the coast of Florida over the weekend and approached North Carolina, making this the sixth consecutive year that a system formed before the official June 1 start of the season, the National Hurricane Center said.

headline: The Museum Is Closed, but Its Tomato Man Soldiers On
abstract: Although the Guggenheim’s “Countryside” show was shuttered by the pandemic, its crop of cherry tomatoes is still growing, and feeding New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: The halls of the Guggenheim Museum are pretty quiet these days, with mostly just its ghosts and some security guards as company for the art.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: This might be the perfect time for Mark Bittman’s ribollita, paired with garlic bread, or a big salad with grains.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There was a great moment the other day as I was driving down to the market for supplies, a rare traffic jam on a stretch of road that’s generally barren, cars backed up in both directions so that a family of Canada geese could waddle across the road, moving from a pond on one side to the bay on the other. The mother goose had her neck stretched low to the pavement, guiding the goslings along, and if Michael the police officer wasn’t there with his whistle to help, it was still reminiscent of Robert McCloskey’s “Make Way for Ducklings,” and I knew every driver in line was smiling behind her mask.

headline: Ending Crisis, Israel Swears in Netanyahu-Led Government to Rescue Economy
abstract: A unity government with Benny Gantz, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s former rival, will brace for a second wave of the coronavirus while restoring “jobs, jobs, jobs,” Mr. Netanyahu promises.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Ending a 510-day political crisis that three elections had failed to resolve, Israel on Sunday swore in a new government charged with responding to the coronavirus pandemic, extending Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s record-setting tenure just a week before his corruption trial is set to begin.

headline: Covid-19 Outbreak in Nigeria Is Just One of Africa’s Alarming Hot Spots
abstract: Dozens of doctors are infected and gravediggers are overwhelmed in Kano, Nigeria’s second-largest city, where inaction led to an unchecked outbreak. Across Africa, other hot spots are emerging.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — In the northern Nigerian city of Kano, some people say they now get four or five death notices on their phones each day: A colleague has died. A friend’s aunt. A former classmate.

headline: How Democrats Win in My Red State (and They Do Win)
abstract: For the shrewd Montana Democrat, good government and good politics are often indistinguishable.
lead_paragraph: BOZEMAN, Mont. — The only reason to be a Democrat running for statewide office in Montana is that, alas, you are one. Just keep in mind that there will be none of that heady, audacity-of-hope-type jazz. In this cold, conservative state, your mission is to persuade the skeptics east of the Rocky Mountain Front that you are a levelheaded, friendly, capitalist adult who won’t be levitating the Pentagon — a task that has gotten considerably easier since the Republican establishment lost interest in basic empiricism.

headline: The Silver Lining of Being Quarantined During Ramadan
abstract: Being at home with family has made observing Islam’s holiest month a richer and deeper spiritual experience.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York announced that lockdown would be extended through May 15, I wondered how this would affect Ramadan. After all, dinner parties and communal prayers have long been integral to this month, which began on April 24. But rather unexpectedly, quarantine has enhanced my Ramadan experience. Being at home has made it easier to observe our holiest month and made it a richer and deeper spiritual affair.

headline: What’s Behind the Nursing Home Horror
abstract: After decades of mistreatment, older Americans are bearing the worst of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: We knew it from the beginning. A nursing home in Washington State was the center of the first known coronavirus outbreak in the United States. We knew that institutions caring for the elderly and disabled in close quarters would be particularly vulnerable during the pandemic.

headline: How Many Covid Deaths? Don’t Ask President Trump
abstract: The president has expressed skepticism about the fatality figures reported to him by his own experts.
lead_paragraph: The fatality numbers are, to be sure, heartbreaking: more than 85,000 Americans dead and more than 1.4 million infected. But many public health experts, including some within the Trump administration, have been stressing that, if anything, Covid-19 deaths and cases are being undercounted.

headline: Fathers, Sons, Forgiveness and Regrets
abstract: Readers respond to a Sunday Review essay with their own experiences, personal and professional.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: To the Class of 2020
abstract: A high school senior reflects on shared experiences and a changed world. Also: A young teenager yearns for his real life.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Autoworkers Are Returning as Carmakers Gradually Crank Up Factories
abstract: After being idle for nearly two months, G.M., Ford and Fiat Chrysler will restart assembly plants on Monday with masks, gloves and curtains.
lead_paragraph: After sheltering at home for nearly two months, tens of thousands of autoworkers have started streaming back into car and truck plants across the South and Midwest, a critical step toward bringing the nation’s largest manufacturing industry back to life.

headline: Fed Chair Says Economic Recovery May ‘Stretch’ Through End of 2021
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, who heads the central bank, predicted a slow economic recovery and reiterated that policymakers may need to do more.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said that the United States would have a slow recovery from what he called the “biggest shock that the economy’s had in living memory,” suggesting that a full rebound from virus-induced lockdowns could take until the end of 2021.

headline: Black Deliveryman Says He Was Blocked and Interrogated by White Driver
abstract: Travis Miller Sr. said he was trying to leave a gated neighborhood in Oklahoma after a delivery when a vehicle blocked his path.
lead_paragraph: Travis Miller Sr., an appliance and furniture deliveryman, had just completed his eighth and last delivery of the day last Monday and was attempting to leave a gated community with a co-worker when a white car blocked his path to the neighborhood’s only exit.

headline: Immigration Agency That Issues Visas, Green Cards Struggles to Stay Afloat
abstract: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services has asked Congress for a lifeline amid the coronavirus pandemic, which has caused applications to plummet and brought it to the brink of insolvency.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A precipitous drop in applications for green cards, citizenship and other programs has threatened the solvency of the federal agency that administers the country’s lawful immigration system, prompting it to seek a $1.2 billion cash infusion from Congress as well as fee hikes to stay afloat.

headline: Moses Sumney and Perfume Genius: Complex Voices of Desire
abstract: Two new albums by musicians who have taken on a spectrum of love and longing explore more ambitious sonic possibilities.
lead_paragraph: Sexual desire is always complicated. It’s a profoundly individual tangle of physical and psychological actions and responses, and it’s inseparable from flesh and circumstance, from instinct and memory and culture. It grows even more complex when those desires are seen as abnormal, outside the mainstream, unacceptable or even immoral — attitudes that an adolescent can internalize and an adult can struggle to outgrow.

headline: A (Barely) Controlled Explosion, and 330 M.P.H. Before You Can Blink
abstract: An inside look at the engines that propel the funny cars of drag racing from zero to you-can’t-be-serious in four seconds.
lead_paragraph: At the head of a straight ribbon of pavement, a swarm of technicians and worker bees is attending to an odd contraption — a seeming cross between a car and the Batmobile. A brief, explosive show is about to thrill thousands watching from the grandstands.

headline: A Generation Gap in Car Wax
abstract: Younger car owners are more likely to see their vehicle as utilitarian, and they’re trickier for product makers to market to.
lead_paragraph: Millennials don’t love their cars the way their elders did, and if you make car wax, that’s a problem.

headline: My Cancer Doesn’t Care About the Coronavirus
abstract: I’ve seen a new layer of anxiety, and heroism, during my lonely treatment visits.
lead_paragraph: There is a checkpoint as you enter the Kimmel Cancer Center at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, where I am being treated for cancer of the prostate and lymph nodes. With all but two sets of doors to the building locked shut, patients are corralled into an area roped off from the rest of the first-floor lobby. You are required to show your orange Hopkins patient identification card and proof that you have an appointment.

headline: China Virus Cluster, Yemen, Cirque du Soleil: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Straight-Up Fire’ in His Veins: Teen Battles New Covid Syndrome
abstract: Jack McMorrow, 14, awoke in agony, with heart failure. His case may help doctors understand a frightening new affliction in children linked to the coronavirus.

headline: Why Driving in New York City Now Feels ‘Post-Apocalyptic’
abstract: Fifth Avenue moves like a country road. The F.D.R. Drive is smooth sailing. The coronavirus pandemic has made steering a car through the city an eerily normal activity.
lead_paragraph: A late morning drive down Fifth Avenue, starting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where the lanes are normally choked with inching traffic, now passes by almost impossibly quickly. Glance down at the speedometer, and you might miss Rockefeller Center.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 18, 2020
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Note: This is our final photograph for the 2019-20 school year. Please visit our archive to find hundreds of other images you can use between now and September, when we will resume this feature. You can also sign up for our free weekly newsletter to make sure you don’t miss any of our new images.

headline: S. David Freeman, 94, Tireless Advocate for Clean Energy, Dies
abstract: A folksy but forceful “Green Cowboy,” he helped shape energy policy in the White House and at local utilities for seven decades.
lead_paragraph: S. David Freeman, a folksy but driven “green cowboy” who worked in energy policy under three presidents, ran some of the nation’s largest public utilities and pushed for renewable energy, died on Tuesday in Reston, Va. He was 94.

headline: Shell Game
abstract: Christina Iverson continues our streak of playful crosswords.
lead_paragraph: WORDPLAY, THE CROSSWORD COLUMN

headline: Farewell, Office. You Were the Last Boundary Between Work and Home.
abstract: Your workplace shaped your identity in ways you never knew.
lead_paragraph: The office, for the foreseeable future, is dead. Google and Facebook are telling employees they can work remotely until 2021. Twitter is allowing employees to work from home “forever.” A number of big banks are contemplating never fully refilling their office towers in Manhattan. Last week, my colleague Matthew Haag wrote a thoroughly depressing story in which the chief executive of Halstead Real Estate asked him point blank: “Looking forward, are people going to want to crowd into offices?”

headline: Trump Looks Forward to the Return of Sports With Crowds
abstract: The president called in to the broadcast of the golf tour’s first live TV event since the coronavirus pandemic shuttered tournaments.
lead_paragraph: In a telephone appearance during a televised charity golf exhibition on Sunday, President Trump enthusiastically supported the return of live sports events during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: As States Reopen, Governors Balance Existing Risks With New Ones
abstract: The costs of the coronavirus shutdown, economic and otherwise, have driven many people to the breaking point. But governors are increasingly worried about the costs of reopening, too.
lead_paragraph: The pain of the coronavirus shutdown, in terms of wrecked economies and shattered lives, has been unmistakable. Now, governors across the country are contemplating the risks of reopening, particularly if it produces a surge of new cases and deaths.

headline: Forty Years Later, Lessons for the Pandemic From Mount St. Helens
abstract: The tensions we now face between science, politics and economics also arose before the country’s most destructive volcanic eruption.
lead_paragraph: When I met David A. Johnston, it was on a spring evening, about a month before he would be erased from existence by a gigantic cloud of volcanic ash boiling over him at 300 miles per hour. He was coming through the door of a makeshift command center in Vancouver, Wash., the closest city to the graceful snow-capped dome of Mount St. Helens, a volcano that had been dormant for 123 years. This was April 1980, and Mr. Johnston, a 30-year-old geologist, was one of the first scientists summoned to monitor new warning signs from the mountain — shallow earthquakes and periodic bursts of ash and steam.

headline: Canadian Military Jet Crashes During Flyover for Coronavirus Workers, Killing One
abstract: Another member of the military was injured, the authorities said. The jet crashed into a house in Kamloops, British Columbia.
lead_paragraph: A Canadian Air Force jet crashed, killing one of the military personnel on board, in Kamloops, British Columbia, on Sunday during a flyover that was intended as a tribute to Canadians, especially those on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic, the authorities said.

headline: 2 Kansas City Officers Charged With Assaulting Transgender Woman
abstract: Prosecutors said the officers slammed Breona Hill to the sidewalk and kneed her in the face, torso and ribs in an episode that a passer-by captured on video.
lead_paragraph: Two Kansas City, Mo., police officers have been indicted on assault charges a year after they were caught on video using excessive force to arrest a transgender woman, prosecutors said.

headline: Obama Lives in Trump’s Head
abstract: The president feels the need to shower lies and blame upon his predecessor.
lead_paragraph: No one irritates Donald Trump quite like Barack Obama.

headline: Inspector General’s Firing Puts Pompeo’s Use of Taxpayer Funds Under Scrutiny
abstract: Accusations of improperly using government resources have trailed the secretary of state, but President Trump’s move to fire the State Department inspector general has handed Democrats a new weapon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo swatted away questions about his use of government resources again and again last year.

headline: Is Ronan Farrow Too Good to Be True?
abstract: He has delivered revelatory reporting on some of the defining stories of our time. But a close examination reveals the weaknesses in what may be called an era of resistance journalism.
lead_paragraph: It was a breathtaking story, written by The New Yorker’s marquee reporter and published with an attention-grabbing headline: “Missing Files Motivated the Leak of Michael Cohen’s Financial Records.”

headline: Japan Falls Into Recession, and Worse Lies Ahead
abstract: Despite signs of success in fighting the coronavirus, the world’s third-largest economy will struggle for months to come as it tries to reopen for business.
lead_paragraph: Japan fell into a recession for the first time since 2015, as its already weakened economy was dragged down by the coronavirus’s impact on businesses at home and abroad.

headline: Fire Consumes Storefront in Harlem
abstract: The fire started at 7:30 p.m. in a furniture store on 125th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard.
lead_paragraph: New York firefighters battled a three-alarm blaze on Sunday night that started in a furniture store across the street from the Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Office Building in Harlem, the authorities said.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 5, Episode 3 Recap: Subjugate and Conquer
abstract: Axe teaches his son a valuable lesson in economics. Chuck offers a lesson in family values, but not really.
lead_paragraph: “Billions” is a show that seems to appreciate pro wrestling, as seen in the fandom of its dudebro character Mafee and the recent cameo by Becky Lynch. So I hope it’s not too indulgent to quote one of the great heel wrestlers, Ted DiBiase, better known as the Million Dollar Man, as a kind of epigraph for this episode: “Everybody’s got a price.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: Stuck Inside With Siblings, With Time to Bicker and Bond
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 18, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Ezekiel, he is more than a handful. He is a school bus’s worth of handfuls.”

headline: No Corrections: May 18, 2020
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 18, 2020.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 18, 2020.

headline: SoftBank in Crisis Amid Record Losses
abstract: Its flagship tech fund is underwater, annual losses are huge and a key board member departed, as the firm faces the coronavirus and a tech slump.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — His flagship tech fund is losing money. His company just posted billions in losses. And a key ally, the Chinese technology mogul Jack Ma, stepped aside.

headline: Germany and France Propose $545 Billion Coronavirus Fund for Europe
abstract: The U.S. sharply criticized the World Health Organization, while China pledged $2 billion to fight the pandemic. President Trump said he has been taking hydroxychloroquine, an unproven drug against Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: Faced with economic calamity and the threat of the coronavirus further fracturing the European Union, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Monday broke with decades of German economic orthodoxy and agreed to back the idea of collective European debt to help those countries that have been hit hardest by the pandemic.

headline: 14 Ways We’re Finding Joy (in Spite of Everything)
abstract: These times are terrible. Why not read about a few things that aren't?
lead_paragraph: These times are terrible. Why not read about a few things that aren't?

headline: The Joy of Caring for Others
abstract: It started with a mask.
lead_paragraph: A month or so back, at the beginning of mask wearing out here in Bloomington, Ind., I was taking a walk and a friend pulled up in her little Toyota pickup truck. We chatted a bit from a distance (we usually hug, so many friends, so many beloveds we no longer touch, that touching being one of the ways we know each other, a sensorium bereft, and let us figure out how to mourn this properly), and then she told me she was on her way to drop off some masks she’d made for her nephew, who’s about my age, at the jail.

headline: The Joy of Perfecting the Sexy Selfie
abstract: Some people are raising little sourdough bread children. I am learning photography. Learning is learning.
lead_paragraph: In a memorable episode of “30 Rock,” Tracy Jordan says: “I’m just going through the classic stages of grief: fear, denial, horniness, wisdom, sleepiness and now depression.” My therapist really had done his very best to explain to me that the collective loss of normalcy we were all experiencing was rooted in grief, but nothing — absolutely nothing — prepared me for the horniness.

headline: The Joy of Looking at the Lives of Strangers
abstract: Scrolling through my Instagram search page is hope for the future, an opportunity to step outside of my isolation, or at least outside the house.
lead_paragraph: I’m in Dakar, Senegal. I haven’t left the house since Feb. 27. The airport isn’t expected to reopen until May 31. Not that I’ll know where to go once it does, and if I’ll have to remain inside for two weeks once I get there.

headline: The Joy of Imaginary Homesteading in Los Angeles
abstract: Sure, my prairie is a driveway, but the mind must travel.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, my husband found a large baby bird in our yard. It was the size of a cantaloupe and had gray wings with tendrils of yellow fuzz sticking out of them. Someone online said we should keep it hydrated, so I went outside with a dropper and a jar of water, expecting it to be afraid of me.

headline: The Joy of Consuming an Obscene Number of Calories Before Noon
abstract: Some might call it breakfast.
lead_paragraph: I’m not, traditionally, a breakfast person. I can house a fry-up, but only when the occasion calls for it — say, hypothetically, an extra drink or six the night before — and, sure, I’ll dip into the pastry basket at a free hotel breakfast buffet, but generally less for nutrition than for the more sustaining satisfaction of maximizing the value of my hotel room.

headline: The Joy of a Junky Old Nintendo
abstract: Why Super Mario Bros. brought me to tears.
lead_paragraph: One evening, a few weeks ago, at 8 p.m., my husband and I put our young daughter to bed as usual. At 8:01 p.m., I was scheduled to begin the crying hour, in which I burst into tears from the stress and headlines and death toll stats of the day.

headline: The Joy of Deleting My Many Mediocre Photos
abstract: Like Frankenstein’s creature, they trail us across time and terra. Let’s set ourselves free.
lead_paragraph: “I wear the chain I forged in life,” the ghost of Jacob Marley once complained to a former co-worker. “I made it link by link, and yard by yard.” I know exactly what he was talking about — I have several thousand mediocre to wretched photos saved on my smartphone, and I carry them with me at all times.

headline: The Joy of Regrowing My Scallions — Yes, Regrowing My Scallions
abstract: You’ll have to trust me. It’s more thrilling than it sounds.
lead_paragraph: One night, after making this terrifically simple Melissa Clark ginger-scallion chicken dish for dinner, I eyed the leftover hairy scallion butts, laying discarded near the cutting board. On a whim, I arranged them roots-down in a jelly jar with a little bit of water. By the next morning, they were happily back on their way, a tender, alive thing, stretching toward the light.

headline: The Joy of Getting Lost and Finding Your Way
abstract: Sure, the journey is the destination and all that. But to me, it’s more about the gamble.
lead_paragraph: I’m not so unusual: I have Google calendar to remind me where I’m supposed to be at any given hour of any given day, Google maps to tell me how to get there, and Google notifications to pester me, so I don’t show up late.

headline: The Joy of Jogging Very, Very Slowly
abstract: It’s a great day for the race. The human race. At an infinitesimal pace.
lead_paragraph: We were knee-deep in quarantine and the television was on. “Andrew Cuomo is talking about running!” I shrieked excitedly to my husband.

headline: The Joy of Having Plans Cancel Themselves
abstract: No longer do I have to make creative excuses for the things I don’t want to do. Science and nature have done that for me.
lead_paragraph: We isolated as a family a full 10 days before others; one of my sons has asthma, and it was clear we weren’t getting good information — Sure! Masks won’t help prevent a respiratory illness! Sure! We became like Pompeii, frozen in place in a house in the suburbs that I’d longed to leave until all of this happened. Now, we’re left to find the smaller things that give us joy, and I’m not finding much. Also, my 9-year-old? He hums all the time, it turns out. All. The. Time.

headline: The Joy of the Hate-Watch
abstract: I knew I would hate ‘The Princess Bride.’ What a delight to confirm not just my hunch, but that I know myself so well.
lead_paragraph: “The Princess Bride” debuted on my 18th birthday — Sept. 25, 1987 — but did not find its way onto my radar until 10 years later, when suddenly everyone was running around saying, “I am Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die.”

headline: The Joy of Circling the Block
abstract: It’s a rediscovery of aimless ambling, but also a late-breaking innovation of movement in lives suddenly devoid of trips or errands.

headline: Coronavirus Clusters, Latin America, Sweden: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Joy of Picking a Fight With Friends
abstract: In isolation, I’ve begun to recognize the entertainment value in making the biggest deal over the smallest thing.
lead_paragraph: “Anyone for Zoom Uno?” I suggested to a group chat. “Maybe Friday night?”

headline: Stocks Surge as Oil Prices Rally
abstract: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Many of the world’s economies have begun to loosen restrictions on commerce, the Federal Reserve chair on Sunday signaled that the central bank has more firepower to lend to recovery efforts, and a drugmaker reported positive developments in an early trial of a coronavirus vaccine.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Big Flower Fight’ and ‘Dead Still’
abstract: A botanical-sculpture competition show drops on Netflix. And a Victorian crime series set in Dublin debuts on Acorn TV.
lead_paragraph: BIG FLOWER FIGHT Stream on Netflix. The title says it all. In this new series, 10 pairs of amateur floral designers fight it out to see who can come up with the most beautiful and behemoth botanical sculptures. As in similar shows, the contestants receive challenges that test their skills, ingenuity and ability to work under pressure. Winners are awarded the “best in bloom” honor while losers are plucked away like weeds. The creations — which need to combine architectural integrity, horticultural acumen and visual appeal — are judged by Kristen Griffith-VanderYacht, a floral designer to the stars, and guest experts. The comedian Vic Reeves and the actress Natasia Demetriou host the proceedings.

headline: Germany Is Reopening. And Learning a Tough Lesson.
abstract: The way out of a lockdown is much harder than the way in.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In its handling of the coronavirus, Germany has been something of a model, alternately admired and envied across the world.

headline: The Joy of Working on a Project About Joy
abstract: Things are so bad right now, what better time to read about the things that aren’t?
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Hong Kong Legislators Brawl Amid Fears Over Widening Chinese Control
abstract: The scuffles erupted as lawmakers debated the leadership of a committee that would consider legislation that would make it illegal to insult the Chinese national anthem.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Scuffles erupted Monday between lawmakers in Hong Kong as they debated the leadership of a committee that is to consider legislation that pro-democracy politicians fear would tighten China’s control over the semiautonomous territory.

headline: Word + Quiz: corpus
abstract: This word has appeared in 71 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: This Is What Watching Sports Looks Like Now
abstract: In Germany, soccer returned with games in empty arenas, forcing a nation of fans to cheer their clubs from afar. Can we learn to love this new reality, at least for a while?
lead_paragraph: As soon as you leave Dortmund’s central station, you see the black and yellow. Decked out in the team’s luminous colors, Borussia Dortmund’s club shop draws the eye from across the square.

headline: Did the Coronavirus Kill Ideology in Australia?
abstract: How a government both sectarian and divisive learned (briefly) to become inclusive.
lead_paragraph: HOBART, Australia — Until four months ago few leaders seemed more influenced — even inspired — by President Trump’s worldview than Australia’s prime minister, Scott Morrison.

headline: Passed By for Decades, Clarence Thomas Is a New Symbol of the Trump Era
abstract: He isn’t yet the pop culture star that Ruth Bader Ginsburg — “Notorious R.B.G.” to many — is. But his fans think he could be.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: ‘I Feel Like a Hero’: A Day in the Life of a Grocery Delivery Man
abstract: Gerald Timothee walks miles every day to make deliveries, taking stringent precautions against the coronavirus. He rarely sees his customers anymore.
lead_paragraph: When he heard the news about the coronavirus pandemic and the citywide shutdown, Gerald Timothee called his family back home in Port-au-Prince, Haiti.

headline: ‘License to Kill’: Inside Rio’s Record Year of Police Killings
abstract: A Times analysis found officers shoot without restraint, protected by their bosses and by politicians, certain that illegal killings will not be held against them.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Rodrigo dos Santos, 16, was speeding downhill on a motorcycle in Rio de Janeiro, a knapsack packed with marijuana, cocaine and pellets of crack on his back, when two police officers raised their rifles at him.

headline: Where Chronic Health Conditions and Coronavirus Could Collide
abstract: The outbreak may spread to new areas with high rates of diabetes, obesity and other illnesses that can worsen coronavirus symptoms. See where your county falls among those with the highest health risk factors.
lead_paragraph: The outbreak may spread to new areas with high rates of diabetes, obesity and other illnesses that can worsen coronavirus symptoms. See where your county falls among those with the highest health risk factors.

headline: You Can Be Homesick at Home
abstract: The lockdown revealed an uncanny and alienating version of my surroundings
lead_paragraph: The lockdown revealed an uncanny and alienating version of my surroundings

headline: We Can’t Comprehend This Much Sorrow
abstract: History’s first draft is almost always wrong — but we still have to try and write it.
lead_paragraph: History’s first draft is almost always wrong — but we still have to try and write it.

headline: Idlib Was Their Last Refuge. They Couldn’t Hide From the Bombs.
abstract: Millions of Syrians have fled to Idlib Province seeking safety. During a rare reporting trip, The Times found that President Bashar al-Assad and his Russian allies are still bombing them.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Syrians have fled to Idlib Province seeking safety. During a rare reporting trip, The Times found that President Bashar al-Assad and his Russian allies are still bombing them.

headline: How to Host Your Family’s Own Personal Summer Camp
abstract: Expand your ideas about summer fun and give your kids (and yourself) a little room to grow.
lead_paragraph: The summer of 2020 is approaching, and with it the waiting game on whether summer camps will open in your town. If you were expecting to send your kids off either every morning or for actual months on end, you might be panicking. But whether camp has already been canceled for your children, or you’re concerned about sending them even if it’s open, keep in mind there may be something not-so-terrible about a summer spent at home.

headline: Emotional Eating in Quarantined Kids
abstract: Boredom and stress are two big contributors to emotional eating, and children have a lot of both right now.
lead_paragraph: As parents stay home with their children, in a situation of anxiety and uncertainty, the recurring rituals of daily life — eating and sleeping and occupying your time — can be opportunities for comfort and family bonding or fraught expressions of stress, and sometimes both in rapid succession.

headline: Freed by Court Ruling, Republicans Step Up Effort to Patrol Voting
abstract: Officials seek to recruit 50,000 poll watchers and spend millions to fight voter fraud. Democrats say the real goal is to stop them from voting.
