headline: ‘The Equivalents,’ by Maggie Doherty: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “The Equivalents,” by Maggie Doherty
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 1960, the prestigious women’s college Radcliffe, the sister school of Harvard, had announced an unprecedented fellowship program, one that targeted a ubiquitous and yet marginalized class of Americans: mothers. In the words of its founder, the Radcliffe president and microbiologist Mary Ingraham Bunting, the Radcliffe Institute for Independent Study was designed to combat the “climate of unexpectation” facing women in mid-century America. As she saw it, too many accomplished female undergraduates were giving up their dreams of becoming scholars or artists because they couldn’t see how they could do research or write a book while also managing a family and keeping house. The new program proposed to get these “intellectually displaced women” back on track.

headline: ‘Drifts,’ by Kate Zambreno: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “Drifts,” by Kate Zambreno
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2015, I was supposed to be at work on Drifts, a book I had been under contract for almost as long as I had lived in this city, renting the first floor of a shabby Victorian house in a tree-lined neighborhood so remote it was almost a suburb. The title of the book came from a feeling, and I wanted to write through this feeling. What I really wanted to write was my present tense, which seemed impossible. How can a paragraph be a day, or a day a paragraph? But I couldn’t often exist in the room, or even in this paragraph, now. I found myself always distracted.

lead_paragraph: Reading Suzanne Collins’s “Hunger Games” trilogy, which concluded a decade ago, was a feverish, disturbing, exhilarating, all-consuming experience. Its premise was horrible: that in the dystopian world of Panem, built on the ruins of what was once North America, young people who were selected each year by lottery would fight to the death, gladiator-style, while an enthralled nation followed along on TV.

Its timeliness, however, is undeniable: With the investigations into the deaths of Breonna Taylor and Ahmaud Arbery currently making news, this awkward hybrid of horror and social consciousness plucks at one of our country’s rawest nerves.

headline: U.S. Is Using Taiwan as a Pressure Point in Tech Fight With China

lead_paragraph: The Trump administration has for years sparred with China over tariff threats, technology and the terms of their trade deal. abstract: In the midst of a pandemic, faith-based wellness programs have been grounding for some religious followers.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the streaming fitness class looks like any other: blue yoga mats against a neutral background, with ambient music and candles to set the mood. Two athleisure-clad instructors, flanked by hand weights, introduce themselves.

headline: Raids Reveal Massive Fentanyl Production in Myanmar
abstract: China’s crackdown on makers of the drug, which has fueled the U.S. opioid crisis, may have simply created opportunities for crime syndicates elsewhere.

headline: The 10 Tools You Need for Basic Home Repair
abstract: Our homes are getting a lot more use while we shelter in place. Here are the tools you’ll need to handle most projects.
lead_paragraph: Now that you’re spending nearly all your time at home, you may be noticing little things around the place that require your attention — a door that won’t close right, or a loose handrail. If you can’t wait until quarantine ends to take on these projects (or if a wobbly hinge is driving you nuts), you can tackle most home repairs with a set of basic tools.

headline: EasyJet Says Cyberattack Stole Data of 9 Million Customers
abstract: The low-cost airline said that email addresses and itineraries were hacked, and that the credit card details of 2,200 travelers were revealed.
lead_paragraph: EasyJet, the low-cost airline based in England, said on Tuesday that it was the target of a “highly sophisticated” cyberattack that exposed the email addresses and personal travel plans of about nine million customers, and that some had their credit card details stolen.

headline: Clinic Bombed as Afghan Forces Fend Off Taliban Attack on Kunduz
abstract: Airstrikes destroyed much of a health center after the militants again attacked the northern city, which they have repeatedly overrun.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a day of intensifying violence across Afghanistan, the country’s security forces bombed a clinic in the northern province of Kunduz on Tuesday in their efforts to thwart another coordinated assault by the Taliban on the provincial capital that the militants have twice overrun and continue to besiege.

headline: Too Big to Fail: The Entire Private Sector

lead_paragraph: During the 2008 financial crisis, Wall Street banks and other big financial institutions were deemed “too big to fail.” The crisis unleashed by the pandemic has broadened that elite status to a significant swath of the American private sector.

headline: Amid Pandemic, Finding Normalcy in the Abnormal

headline: Mother Sea Turtles Might Be Sneakier Than They Look
abstract: The large reptiles make decoy nests to distract predators during an oft-ignored behavior following their egg laying, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: The birth process of sea turtles provides some of the most endearing images in nature. Mother turtles trudge up on to the beach at night, dig a nest and lay their eggs, then haul themselves back into the ocean. Weeks later, dozens of adorable little hatchlings, tiny flippers churning through sand, scamper into the sea for the first time.

headline: Five Artists to Follow on Instagram Now
abstract: Rahima Gambo’s wanderings, Yoriyas’s Moroccan photo scenes, Amos Paul Kennedy Jr.’s “Pile of Bricks,” Slavs and Tatars’ archival gems, Vanessa Bell’s Buenos Aires.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I recommended Instagram feeds of artists mostly based in New York City. We were just getting accustomed to the new state of affairs, and it felt invigorating, in the suddenly compacted experience of lockdown, to take in multiple perspectives on local reality.

headline: Woods Became David Berman’s Band. Then They Picked Up the Pieces.

lead_paragraph: Jeremy Earl had been a father for two weeks when one of his favorite songwriters — David Berman, of the Silver Jews — emailed him with a plea: Help me make my first record in a decade.

headline: Coronavirus Shutdowns Weigh on Book Sales
abstract: Total U.S. sales in March were down 8.4 percent to $667 million, a sign of how the early days of the pandemic hurt booksellers and publishers.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus spread across the United States this spring, most of the entertainment industry went into hibernation, as movie theaters, concert halls, museums, Broadway and film production sets shut down. Publishing, however, seemed more resilient: Books remained available online and stand apart as an art form that can be easily produced and consumed in isolation.

headline: Why Did Mike Pompeo Want His Watchdog Fired?
abstract: His vague explanations for asking President Trump to dismiss the State Department’s inspector general don’t add up.
lead_paragraph: Three years in, President Trump’s vow to “drain the swamp” stands as one of his more ludicrous campaign promises. That said, his spring cleaning of inspectors general has exposed a patch of grime that threatens to make life awkward for one of his staunchest allies, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.

headline: Right to Privacy Extends to Foreign Internet Users, German Court Rules
abstract: The intelligence services cannot randomly search the digital data of citizens of other countries living abroad, judges said, in a decision welcomed by civil rights activists.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Privacy rights enshrined in Germany’s Constitution extend to foreigners living abroad and cover their online data, the country’s highest court ruled on Tuesday, ordering Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government to overhaul a law governing the foreign intelligence agency.

headline: Will Mandatory Face Masks End the Burqa Bans?
abstract: As face coverings become the rule in public spaces, attitudes about head scarves may change.
lead_paragraph: While face coverings are fast becoming the norm to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus, visible on city streets and public transportation everywhere, the global politics that surround them are more complicated than ever — a reflection not just of this current crisis, but also of broader values and stereotypes.

headline: Private and Public Schools: Equity Issues in a Pandemic
abstract: Readers discuss Betsy DeVos’s plan to share relief funds with private schools and how teachers’ unions influence remote learning.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A New Spot for Basque Dishes to Go Opens in SoHo
abstract: Haizea pivots to a new approach, and takeout and delivery from spots offering Ethiopian favorites, pizza and tiki cocktails.
lead_paragraph: What does it take to open a restaurant in the midst of a pandemic? Mikel de Luis, the chef and the owner of a tiny, contemporary Basque-style spot whose opening was postponed by two months, will now test the waters, going takeout-only. “It’s been frustrating not to open,” he said, adding, “It’s time to try; people want something new.” Most of his dishes were to be small plates, but for his takeout menu, he is serving some larger dishes like roast suckling pig, duck and mushroom fideos (thin noodles), fisherman’s rice with chicken and seafood, and a substantial sandwich of Iberico ham with Roncal cheese. A mentee of Martin Berasategui, for whom he cooked at the Ritz-Carlton in the Canary Islands, Mr. De Luis is a native of Bilbao, in the Basque region of Spain. (The restaurant’s name means “wave” in Basque.) He has worked in Barcelona; Homer, Alaska; and, more recently, at Nana in Dallas, with the chef Anthony Bombaci. When it can fully open, Haizea will seat only around 10 instead of about 20 to facilitate social distancing. (Opens Wednesday)

headline: Trump on Hydroxychloroquine
abstract: Readers criticize the president’s announcement that he is taking a drug viewed as ineffective and risky.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Search of Time Lost and Newly Found
abstract: Our critic Parul Sehgal examines how the notion of time — and how we describe it — has changed during the quarantine.
lead_paragraph: Almost as soon as it appeared, Covid-19 seeded a peculiar and deep dread of the literature it might someday inspire. “Novel coronavirus” — in the literary sense — already conjures contempt and exhaustion, but why? What do we fear? Limp attempts at parody? Schematic sci-fi? Autofictional accounts of quarantine in Brooklyn in which the pandemic serves as backdrop to the personal epiphany of an alienated protagonist who discovers the virtues of the simpler life, via much massaging of dough and theoretical jargon? (Yes.)

headline: America’s Immigration Paradox
abstract: Two new books, Jia Lynn Yang’s “One Mighty and Irresistible Tide” and Adam Goodman’s “The Deportation Machine,” take very different approaches to the immigration question.
lead_paragraph: ONE MIGHTY AND IRRESISTIBLE TIDEThe Epic Struggle Over American Immigration, 1924-1965By Jia Lynn Yang

headline: DanceAfrica, Dormeshia and Contact Improvisation (for One)
abstract: In this guide to the best virtual dance this week, a festival goes digital, and classes at Movement Research illuminate the body-mind connection.
lead_paragraph: The DanceAfrica experience has always been about more than just the performances gracing the stage of the Brooklyn Academy. It’s about the surrounding magic, too: the food, the street fashion (it doesn’t get better than this, anywhere) and even — don’t judge — the shopping. The DanceAfrica Bazaar, with its heady array of fabric and jewelry, is like parting the curtain to summer.

headline: A Little E-Commerce Has Big Ripples
abstract: Online shopping has changed our behavior, reordered the nature of work and challenged our cities.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Marie Pino, Navajo Teacher Who Educated Generations, Dies at 67
abstract: A well-known teacher, she was mourning the loss of her son to the virus when she tested positive. Then she died as well, adding to the Navajo Nation’s toll.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Life Is More Like a Simulation. On These Shows, So Is Death.
abstract: As viewers shelter with screens from the pandemic, more and more TV wrestles with mortality within digital reproductions.
lead_paragraph: “Are we living in a simulation?”

headline: The Military’s Travel Ban Leaves Some Families in a Financial Crunch
abstract: In March, the Pentagon announced restrictions on movements for service members and their families because of the coronavirus, upending plans for some in the middle of relocating.
lead_paragraph: Maureen Elias expected her family’s final move with the military to come as a relief. She and her husband, Dustin, purchased a house in Oakton, Va., where the Army was transferring them from California for Dustin’s final assignment as he neared the end of his 20-year career. They expected to be on the East Coast by April 1, just in time to close on their dream home.

headline: Five Delicious Reasons to Always Have Gnocchi in Your Pantry
abstract: Crisp on the outside, chewy on the inside, these little shelf-stable dumplings are easily dressed up or down.
lead_paragraph: Shelf-stable gnocchi doesn’t exactly recall its delicate homemade ricotta or potato cousins. And that’s a good thing. Pleasantly chewy like an udon noodle or, sure, a Gummi Bear, they’re a blank slate for speedy meals and keep for months. And, it’s worth mentioning, they’re also just fun to eat.

headline: For Boris Johnson, Parliament Is Becoming a House of Horrors
abstract: In a mostly empty chamber, the blustery prime minister is sorely missing the usual whoops and catcalls as he is picked apart by the lawyerly new opposition leader, Keir Starmer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, debating in Parliament used to be a raucous affair, as backbenchers from his Conservative Party hollered and whooped, booing his rivals and cheering him on like a classmate in a schoolyard brawl. These days, to his evident chagrin, it is more like a legal deposition.

headline: Yu Lihua, 90, Dies; Writer Spoke to ‘Rootless’ Chinese Émigrés
abstract: In her fiction she depicted “the struggle of Chinese immigrants in American society” — not the “Oriental exoticism” preferred by many publishers in the ’60s.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: An Audience Comes Out of Lockdown for Schubert and Mahler
abstract: Observing social distancing, a German theater cautiously restarted live concerts.
lead_paragraph: WIESBADEN, Germany — Normally, when a performer peers beyond bright stage lights into a darkened theater and sees every fourth seat occupied, it’s not a good sign.

headline: U.S. Arms Sales and the Yemen War
abstract: A foreign policy expert discusses the fiction of arms sales as jobs creator. Also: The future of Christianity.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Newly Minted Artists, Facing a Precarious Future, Take Action
abstract: How do you get discovered in a teetering art world? Graduating students organize shows with peers, team up with dealers — and lobby for relief funds. Will they bring change?
lead_paragraph: For art students finishing B.F.A. and M.F.A. programs this spring, the big debut was supposed to have been the thesis exhibition. The culmination of years of work, these shows represent a shot at getting discovered by curators, dealers, collectors and critics who make the rounds at top schools.

headline: Twitter Could End the Office as We Know It
abstract: This is the company’s most disruptive move yet.
lead_paragraph: Twitter is out of the office. Last week, the social media company’s chief executive, Jack Dorsey, informed employees that many of them would be allowed to work from home permanently, even after the Covid-19 pandemic subsides. Other tech giants, including Google and Facebook, have not gone quite so far but have also said that they plan to continue working remotely at least through the end of 2020.

headline: I Accept Death. I Hope Doctors and Nurses Will, Too.
abstract: A lesson from hospice care might help.
lead_paragraph: Nurses crying. That’s what I hear from the front lines treating Covid-19 patients. A nurse will begin the shift crying and end it crying. Crying. And we are not a profession that cries easily.

headline: The Risks of Trump’s Hydroxychloroquine Hype
abstract: The evolving story of this drug represents one failure after another among government officials, physicians and the media.
lead_paragraph: President Trump revealed on Monday that despite warnings from the Food and Drug Administration, he said he has been taking hydroxychloroquine for about a week and a half as a preventive measure.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Why Obsess Over Expectations?’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Barbecue. Introduction, joke, smile. Friend request, message sent. First date: loud restaurant, easy conversation. Second date: “Sushi?” Who cares if I’ve never eaten it; I’ll try it for you. Third date: meeting your friends. I’m not too social, but for you I’ll try to be. “This isn’t serious,” I say. “This isn’t serious,” we say. One, two, three, four, five years pass. “This still isn’t serious.” Who wants to be serious? Still don’t know what to expect, but why obsess over expectations? I will still try everything new for you. Because I love you. — Aleks Fedoriw

headline: Tesla Owners Try to Make Sense of Elon Musk’s ‘Red Pill’ Moment
abstract: A liberal status symbol now has a founder who is moving to the right.
lead_paragraph: Owning a Tesla, the luxurious electric car, is a major liberal status symbol. It signals nothing more than good taste — the perfect balance of wealth with care for fossil fuels. But the man behind the brand is crafting a very different persona online that may now prove to be a challenge for his fans.

headline: Michael McCaskey, Bears’ Boss in Their Glory Years, Dies at 76
abstract: He was a business professor when he took the reins from his grandfather George Halas, then led the team as it flourished in the 1980s, winning a Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Michael B. McCaskey, who took over running the Chicago Bears from his grandfather George S. Halas and led the team during its 1980s heyday, when it won its only Super Bowl championship, died on Saturday. He was 76.

headline: The Hot New Thing in Clubby Silicon Valley? An App Called Clubhouse
abstract: For all the high-minded talk among techies, their new favorite app is an invite-only (so far) social network for mingling with one another.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Marc Andreessen, a Silicon Valley investor, published a rallying cry last month that quickly ricocheted around the tech industry. In it, he placed the blame for America’s dismal response to the coronavirus on “smug complacency, this satisfaction with the status quo and the unwillingness to build.”

abstract: Being an astronaut’s wife thrust her into the spotlight, but a stutter left her struggling for words until she found help.

abstract: At 60, she moved to New York to care for her dying son. Instead of returning home, she dedicated herself to AIDS patients during the worst of the epidemic.

headline: Mnuchin and Powell Warn of Economic Scarring, and Offer Divergent Solutions
abstract: The Treasury secretary and Fed chair said economic damage could last. One prescribed rapid reopening, the other robust policy action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States economy faces irreparable damage from the coronavirus, the nation’s top economic policymakers warned on Tuesday, although they offered differing solutions on how to ease the blow to business that has thrown more than 20 million people out of work.

headline: At Fox News, Mixed Message on Malaria Drug: ‘Very Safe’ vs. ‘It Will Kill You’
abstract: For two days running, Neil Cavuto has warned that a drug taken by President Trump, hydroxychloroquine, carries risks. Some of his colleagues disagree.
lead_paragraph: The stress of the coronavirus pandemic is testing even the closest relationships.

headline: N.F.L. Team Owners Enhance Rooney Rule, but Stop Short of Incentives
abstract: Tuesday’s vote will prevent teams from blocking assistant coaches and executives who plan to interview for new jobs. But team owners tabled a measure to upgrade the draft status of franchises that hire nonwhite candidates for leadership positions.
lead_paragraph: After years of criticism about the lack of minorities in top coaching and player personnel positions, the N.F.L.’s 32 owners on Tuesday took steps to increase racial diversity in the league’s leadership ranks but stopped short of adopting the most aggressive measure under consideration, which would have tied hiring to draft slots.

headline: Johnson & Johnson to End Talc-Based Baby Powder Sales in North America
abstract: The company has faced thousands of lawsuits from cancer patients who claim that its talc was contaminated with asbestos, a known carcinogen, and that the company knew of the risks.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson is discontinuing North American sales of its talc-based baby powder, a product that once defined the company’s wholesome image and that it has defended for decades even as it faced thousands of lawsuits filed by patients who say it caused cancer.

headline: How SoulCycle Got Stuck Spinning Its Wheels
abstract: It was the gold standard of indoor-cycling classes. Then everybody went home.
lead_paragraph: It could have been the battle of the bikes.

headline: When Is California Reopening?
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the state’s plan to reopen for business during the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: California was the first state to order all residents to stay home to slow the spread of the coronavirus. On May 18, Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that state health officials would relax their criteria for counties that wanted to reopen their economies faster, provided that they met public health guidelines.

headline: Authorities Seek Forfeiture of Ancient Gilgamesh Tablet From Hobby Lobby
abstract: The “Gilgamesh Dream Tablet” was displayed at the Museum of the Bible in Washington until the authorities seized it in 2019.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors moved on Monday to formally confiscate a rare cuneiform tablet that bears part of the Epic of Gilgamesh, one of the world’s oldest works of literature, from a Bible-themed museum founded in part by the president of the crafts retailer Hobby Lobby.

headline: Cécile Rol-Tanguy, French Resistance Fighter, Dies at 101
abstract: Passing through Nazi checkpoints in disguise, she carried machine guns and hand grenades to members of the underground.
lead_paragraph: Cécile Rol-Tanguy, a heroine of the French Resistance who helped lead a popular uprising against the German occupation of Paris, died on May 8 at her home in Monteaux, about 130 miles from Paris. She was 101.

headline: The ‘Call Her Daddy’ Feud: What Happened?
abstract: The podcast built a loyal audience. So did its hosts.
lead_paragraph: In just two years, “Call Her Daddy,” a raunchy podcast about sex, dating, culture and life in New York, became a cult sensation. This week, it descended into a fireball of chaos and internet drama.

headline: Emulating Democrats, G.O.P. Ties House Hopes to Diverse Recruits
abstract: “We need candidates other than boring old white people”: House Republicans are betting on a group of diverse candidates with compelling biographies to help them reclaim lost seats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Representative Mike Garcia of California was sworn in as a member of Congress on Tuesday, it marked more than just the addition of another Republican to the ranks of the minority party in the House.

headline: Election Watchdog, Dormant for Months, Can Finally Move Into Action
abstract: With the confirmation of James E. Trainor III, the Federal Election Commission can function again. But warring ideologies among its members raise questions about what it can accomplish.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even before the coronavirus pandemic hit the United States and forced millions of Americans to stay at home, the top floor of the Federal Election Commission was quiet. Three of the six commissioners’ offices sat empty. Stacks of green paper accumulated, detailing hundreds of enforcement matters on which the agency was powerless to act.

headline: Leonard Levitt, Reporter Who Riled N.Y.P.D. Brass, Dies at 79
abstract: His newspaper column, books and blog sought to hold the police accountable, and his reporting reopened a murder case against a Kennedy cousin in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Levitt, a journalist and author whose investigative and gossipy revelations of wrongdoing by the New York City police made him a must-read as the self-anointed conscience of Police Headquarters, died on Monday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 79.

headline: One Crisis Too Many: How the Coronavirus Pushed Germany to Shift Course
abstract: Some may not like it back home, but in the twilight of her career, Angela Merkel joined with France to try to save the European Union.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — In her time as chancellor of Germany, Angela Merkel has seen the European Union put to the test by Brexit, a wave of migration, the Greek debt crisis and populism, and still she held to a largely steadfast course.

headline: CBS Courts Advertisers Virtually, With a Zinger From Stephen Colbert
abstract: Instead of celebrities and sizzle reels at Carnegie Hall, the network presents its wares in videos sent to ad buyers.
lead_paragraph: Every spring CBS parades its stars and executives across the Carnegie Hall stage to try to persuade advertisers to buy commercial time during an event filled with scripted banter and sizzle reels. This year, ad buyers working from home clicked on a link that led them to a cartoon of Stephen Colbert interviewing a dog.

headline: Why Clean Shirts Become the Stuff of Dirty Laundry
abstract: Government watchdogs say skirting the rules against subordinates doing chores hints at a broader disregard for ethics restrictions.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to airing dirty laundry in Washington, dry-cleaning abuse has to be near the top of the list.

abstract: They could take a long time to recover — and may look very different when they do.

headline: Susan Pompeo Draws Scrutiny in Inquiry Over Dry Cleaning and Dog Walking
abstract: The wife of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is at the center of an investigation into whether a State Department employee was assigned to do household tasks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Susan Pompeo, the wife of America’s top diplomat, said in an interview last year that she could handle the criticism that came with taking a high-profile role at the State Department.

headline: Pompeo Declined Interview Request From Inspector General About Saudi Arms Sales
abstract: The secretary of state instead offered written answers. He was aware of the inquiry and the specific lines of questioning about his decision to resume the sales.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo declined an interview request for the State Department inspector general’s inquiry into whether the Trump administration acted illegally in declaring an “emergency” to bypass a congressional freeze on arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, according to three people with knowledge of his actions.

headline: Trump Is Playing the China Card. Who Believes Him?
abstract: He attacks Joe Biden to deflect blame for his terrible handling of Covid-19 and record of appeasing Beijing.
lead_paragraph: There is a long history of American presidential candidates using China as a campaign cudgel — from Bill Clinton blasting President George H.W. Bush in 1992 for dealing with a Chinese premier known as the “Butcher of Beijing” to Donald Trump’s 2016 attack that the Obama administration had allowed China to “rape” the United States while Hillary Clinton was secretary of state. This election year, China-bashing will reach a new level, as Mr. Trump seeks to capitalize on high voter disapproval of China, Beijing’s failure to contain the coronavirus and persistent bilateral tensions between our countries.

headline: Is Trump Challenging Mother Nature to a Duel?
abstract: He can’t beat her coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: On Easter, as the coronavirus was rapidly spreading, NPR’s “Weekend All Things Considered” carried excerpts from sermons from across the country. I was particularly touched by the way Presiding Bishop Michael Curry ended his talk at Washington National Cathedral, singing, “He’s got the whole world in his hands, he’s got the whole world in his hands. …”

headline: Biden Calls Out ‘Anti-Semitism’ on the Left and Criticizes Israeli Policies
abstract: “Criticism of Israel’s policy is not anti-Semitism,” the former vice president told donors. “But too often that criticism from the left morphs into anti-Semitism.”
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told donors on a call on Tuesday that it was important to condemn criticism of Israel that drifts toward anti-Semitism, including on the political left, even as he acknowledged that he had “gotten in trouble” for such calls in the past.

headline: Iran Quietly Lowers the Temperature With U.S.
abstract: Despite the heated rhetoric on both sides, Iran has toned down its approach to the West on several fronts, and the U.S. has reciprocated.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — After years of increasing tensions that nearly led to war, Iran has moderated its approach to the West, shifting from a policy of provocation to one of limited cooperation. The change reflects an effort to avoid direct confrontation with the United States that the Iranians say could benefit President Trump in the November election.

headline: Cambridge University Will Hold Its Lectures Online Next Year
abstract: Colleges and universities around the world, confronting the coronavirus pandemic, are studying whether and how to move forward with classes next year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Cambridge on Tuesday became the first British university to move all student lectures online for the coming academic year, underscoring the far-reaching changes the coronavirus is forcing on higher education institutions around the world.

headline: W.H.O. Members Reject Trump’s Demands but Agree to Study Its Virus Response
abstract: The outcome left the United States isolated as officials from China, Russia and the European Union chided Mr. Trump over his heated threats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s angry demands for punitive action against the World Health Organization were rebuffed on Tuesday by the organization’s other member nations, which decided instead to conduct an “impartial, independent” examination of the W.H.O.’s response to the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Amid Hydroxychloroquine Uproar, Real Studies of Drug Are Suffering
abstract: The political fights around a malaria drug that President Trump says he takes daily have impeded studies into whether it works to prevent coronavirus infection or treat Covid-19 early.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s enthusiastic embrace of a malaria drug that he now says he takes daily — and the resulting uproar in the news media — appears to be interfering with legitimate scientific research into whether the medicine might work to prevent coronavirus infection or treat the disease in its early stages.

headline: When Barbra Streisand and Ryan O’Neal Went Screwball
abstract: Our critics and readers packed up their plaid valises and fled the doldrums of the present for the loony-tune streets of San Francisco circa 1972 and “What’s Up, Doc?”
lead_paragraph: In 1971, while watching a rough cut of Peter Bogdanovich’s “The Last Picture Show,” Barbra Streisand turned to a studio executive and said: “I want him.” What Babs wants, Babs apparently gets, which is how Bogdanovich ended up directing “What’s Up, Doc?” and we ended up laughing through it for our latest Weekend Watch Party.

headline: Former U.S. Nazi Hunter Seeks I.R.S. Sanctions Against Whitney Museum
abstract: Neal Sher, a former federal prosecutor, filed a complaint saying the museum had mishandled protests that led to the resignation of a trustee.
lead_paragraph: Many anticipated some fallout for the Whitney Museum of American Art when a veteran board member, Warren B. Kanders, felt compelled to resign last year after protesters targeted him in regular demonstrations at the museum.

headline: Roe v. Wade Plaintiff Was Paid to Switch Sides, Documentary Says
abstract: Before dying in 2017, Norma McCorvey said she had supported anti-abortion groups only for the money.
lead_paragraph: Norma McCorvey, the anonymous plaintiff in Roe v. Wade, the landmark 1973 U.S. Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion throughout the United States, said she had later spoken out on behalf of the anti-abortion movement only because she was paid to do so, according to a new documentary.

headline: New Conspiracy Theory, Familiar Path
abstract: President Trump’s baseless “Obamagate” charge illustrates how disinformation bubbles from the internet.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.

headline: Corrections: May 20, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, May 20, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about a possible connection between air pollution and Covid-19 referred incorrectly to Chevron’s air-monitoring efforts around the Richmond refinery. According to Braden Reddall, a company spokesman, Chevron monitors 10 chemical compounds at three fence-line locations at the refinery and tracks additional compounds at three other locations in the community. It does not monitor five chemical compounds at three locations.

headline: Abbas Says Security Cooperation Will End, Raising Stakes for Israeli Annexation
abstract: The Palestinian leader has made such assertions before, but this may not be a mere threat. The agreements have protected Israelis and preserved the Palestinian Authority’s political hold over the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Raising the stakes over Israel’s drive to annex land the Palestinians have long claimed, President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Tuesday angrily declared it free of its commitments under the Oslo peace process, including security understandings that have protected Israelis and preserved the authority’s political hold over the occupied West Bank.

headline: Israel Hack of Iran Port Is Latest Salvo in Exchange of Cyberattacks
abstract: Israel was behind a cyberattack that disrupted a major port in Iran, done in response to an attempt by the Revolutionary Guards to infiltrate an Israeli water facility.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Israel was behind a cyberattack on May 9 that disrupted operations at a major port in Iran, according to high-ranking intelligence officials and experts in the Middle East who are kept informed of covert Israeli actions in the region.

headline: College Calendars in the Pandemic: No Fall Break and Home by Thanksgiving
abstract: As universities announce plans to bring back students, a pattern is emerging: shorter semesters to avoid late-fall infections.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — As colleges make plans to bring students back to campus, alongside discussions of mask requirements and half-empty classrooms, one common strategy is emerging: Forgoing fall break and getting students home before Thanksgiving.

headline: French Cheese Tasting
abstract: The J.A.S.A. class, ably assisted by Natan Last and Andrew Kravis, shows us how to look at things differently.

headline: 2 Dams Fail in Michigan, Forcing Thousands to Evacuate
abstract: The failure of the dams was expected to bring record-setting flooding, with the response complicated by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Severe flooding struck central Michigan on Wednesday after two dams were breached by rain-swollen waters, forcing the evacuation of thousands of residents and prompting officials to warn of life-threatening danger.

headline: A City Locks Down to Fight Coronavirus, but Robots Come and Go
abstract: Like many other places, a community 50 miles outside London went into quarantine. A fleet of delivery robots has been helping with the groceries.
lead_paragraph: If any place was prepared for quarantine, it was Milton Keynes. Two years before the pandemic, a start-up called Starship Technologies deployed a fleet of rolling delivery robots in the small city about 50 miles northwest of London.

headline: Xi Jinping Uses Pandemic to Strengthen His Rule in China
abstract: The Chinese leader hopes to rally national pride as his People’s Congress begins. Mexican officials will investigate why the official death toll is far smaller than the figures compiled in the capital.

headline: After Cyclone Hits India and Bangladesh, the Waiting Begins
abstract: The authorities acted quickly to move people from the cyclone’s path, but worried they might be putting them into the path of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This live briefing has ended. The day after the cyclone struck, the death toll rose in Bangladesh and India.

headline: Fed Minutes Show Concern About Long-Term Economic Damage

headline: Coronavirus Inquiry, E.U. Fund, Cyclone Amphan: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.

headline: Burundi Turns Out to Replace President of 15 Years, Pandemic or No
abstract: The campaign has been marred by violence against the political opposition and a disregard of measures to protect the public from the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Standing shoulder to shoulder without masks or gloves, throngs of voters in Burundi waited in long lines on Wednesday to mark their ballots to replace the country’s long-reigning, autocratic president.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: Ben Platt Live and ‘At Home With Amy Sedaris’
abstract: “Ben Platt Live From Radio City Music Hall” hits Netflix. And a new season of Amy Sedaris’s sendup of TV home shows debuts on TruTV.
lead_paragraph: BEN PLATT LIVE FROM RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL Stream on Netflix. Last month, audiences were given a chance to see a mustachioed Ben Platt perform via webcam as part of a virtual tribute to Stephen Sondheim. See Platt perform on a real stage — and with fuller facial hair — in this concert movie, which was recorded last year at Radio City Music Hall in New York. The set includes music from Platt’s solo album, “Sing to Me Instead,” and covers of songs originally performed by Brandi Carlile, Elton John and Stevie Wonder.

headline: I Expected War. I Didn’t Expect Trump’s Impeachment or a Pandemic.
abstract: Ukraine’s president looks back at what got him through his first year in office.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Last year on May 20, I was surrounded by crowds of people shaking hands, high-fiving and leaning in for selfies as they gathered to watch my inauguration. Ukrainians had elected me with 73 percent of the vote, pinning their hopes on me to clean up a corrupt government and bring stability.

headline: Is It OK to Snack? Our Health Writers on Staying Fit During the Pandemic
abstract: In a group call with readers, Tara Parker-Pope, the founding editor of the Well section, and Jane Brody, the personal health columnist, shared wellness strategies.
lead_paragraph: In these times, staying healthy — physically, mentally, emotionally — can be a daily challenge. Every Monday, as part of the new “Live at Home” event series, Tara Parker-Pope, the founding editor of Well, The Times’s consumer health section, hosts experts and takes questions from readers.

headline: Word + Quiz: agitprop
abstract: This word has appeared in 21 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Calls Trump a ‘Hydroxymoron’
abstract: After President Trump told the press he was taking hydroxychloroquine, Kimmel looked up the side effects and decided it must be true.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Songs of Hope
abstract: Which song would you choose to celebrate a milestone or resilience through a difficult period?
lead_paragraph: Staff members at hospitals in the New York metropolitan area have been playing songs like “Don’t Stop Believin’,” the “Rocky” theme and “Every Breath You Take” to celebrate the release of patients who had been hospitalized because of the coronavirus.

headline: Virus Raged at City Jails, Leaving 1,259 Guards Infected and 6 Dead
abstract: Correction officers in New York City live in fear of bringing the virus home to families. They say the city has not protected them.
lead_paragraph: For one Rikers Island correction officer, the low point came when he and his wife were both extremely sick with the coronavirus. She could hardly breathe and begged him to make sure she was not buried in a mass grave, he recalled. He was sure he had contracted the disease working in the jailhouse, where supervisors had discouraged him from wearing a mask.

headline: How a Queens Pastor Tends to His Flock From Six Feet Away
abstract: After recovering from the coronavirus, the Rev. Peter Purpura found a way to bring the church directly to his people.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Peter Purpura walked slowly down the middle of a street lined with brick rowhouses in Middle Village, Queens. He wore a black cassock, white vestments and a light blue surgical mask as he led a procession.

headline: Is a Pandemic the Right Time to Start a Business? It Just Might Be
abstract: Previous financial crises gave rise to high-profile American companies. The spread of the coronavirus challenges entrepreneurs to meet new needs.
lead_paragraph: In March, as small businesses across the country were shutting down amid the spreading coronavirus pandemic, Shanel Fields was about to open one up.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘How Pandemics End’
abstract: In this lesson, students will research and learn about how historical pandemics ended medically and socially.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “How Pandemics End” by Gina Kolata

headline: John Maynard Keynes Died in 1946. An Outstanding New Biography Shows Him Relevant Still.
abstract: In “The Price of Peace,” Zachary D. Carter situates the development of Keynes’s economic thought in relation to his social milieu.
lead_paragraph: Do you hear that? It’s the sound of the money printer whirring — trillions of dollars getting pumped into a collapsing economy, making the bailouts following the 2008 financial crisis look like small change.

headline: ‘I Have to Make Use of What Is at My Disposal.’
abstract: What Zanele Muholi, Titus Kaphar, Kara Walker and other artists are creating during quarantine.
lead_paragraph: What Zanele Muholi, Titus Kaphar, Kara Walker and other artists are creating during quarantine.

headline: Inequality Has Been Laid Bare by the Outbreak. Now What?
abstract: We're seeing how what we have compares with what others have, and the differences can matter a lot.
lead_paragraph: We're seeing how what we have compares with what others have, and the differences can matter a lot.

headline: How a Game With My Daughter Helped Us Cope With Quarantine and the Past
abstract: Playing hours of pretend with my 5-year-old showed me how coronavirus was re-activating old medical traumas in our family.
lead_paragraph: Playing hours of pretend with my 5-year-old showed me how coronavirus was re-activating old medical traumas in our family.

headline: When Can I See My Grandkids?
abstract: The pandemic has separated many grandparents from their grandchildren. Here’s advice for safely reuniting your family’s oldest and youngest generations.
lead_paragraph: Grandparents have had enough. They want to see their grandchildren.

headline: This Is No Time to Read Alone
abstract: In lockdown and through our screens, we’re reminded of all that’s special and strange about group reading: a solitary, private act made public.
lead_paragraph: My silent reading party begins the same way every week, promptly at 6 p.m., with the now very familiar initiation of a Zoom call. A piano player’s hands appear in close-up among the gallery of boxes on my screen. His set list, a mix of Eric Satie and Radiohead instrumentals, will be the only sound. Like the windows of a New York City apartment building at night, other boxes soon come to life. People are in their homes, on their couches or in bed, all with a book. A hundred, then two hundred, absorbed in their reading, muted.

headline: To My Patients’ Family Members, My Apologies
abstract: I hope I held the iPad still enough so that it didn’t shake while you were saying the things you would regret not saying.
lead_paragraph: I wish I could tell you that I’m sorry.

headline: What Is All of That Screen Time Doing to Your Skin?
abstract: We checked in with experts to learn about the risks of indoor light and how we can protect ourselves.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably heard more about the perils of blue light lately because our lives are more likely to be lived indoors and online. Our laptops, phones, tablets, TVs and even LED light bulbs are all sources of blue light. And now that we’re tethered to those devices, are we getting drenched? Should we be more worried about damage to our skin?

headline: They Beat the Virus. Now They Feel Like Outcasts.
abstract: Some people who have survived the coronavirus describe being shunned by relatives and friends, rather than being celebrated.
lead_paragraph: On the day Elizabeth Martucci and her 11-year-old son were deemed to have recovered from the coronavirus, they emerged from their home on the Jersey Shore with some sidewalk chalk to sketch a message in the driveway.

headline: ‘I Believed That I Would See Her Again’
abstract: A Christian theologian recounts how her mother’s death affirmed her faith and belief in the afterlife.
lead_paragraph: This month’s conversation in our series exploring religion and death is with Karen Teel, who has been a member of the department of theology and religious studies at the University of San Diego since 2007. Her research and teaching focus on the essential beliefs of Christianity and the theological engagement with the problems of racism and white supremacy. She is the author of “Racism and the Image of God.” — George Yancy

headline: Returning to Exercise After Recovery From Coronavirus
abstract: Two new expert consensus statements urge caution for athletes with coronavirus who are returning to serious training.
lead_paragraph: Is it OK to resume athletic training, even if you have gotten through a bout of Covid-19 or tested positive for coronavirus or suspect you might have been infected? Two new expert-consensus statements from pulmonologists and cardiologists, published separately in The Lancet and JAMA Cardiology, urge caution.

headline: Trump Judges or Federalist Society Judges? Try Both
abstract: The group says it doesn’t endorse nominees for public office. Say what?
lead_paragraph: When the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, called the chamber back into session two weeks ago, he did not do it to debate legislation regarding Covid-19 or other essential, time-sensitive business. Rather, as usual, he seemed mostly interested in having the Judiciary Committee consider confirming judges — this time most significantly Justin Walker, Mr. McConnell’s protégé, to the powerful U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

headline: Sheltering With My Boyfriend and No Booze
abstract: Eliminating alcohol for a month drastically changed this New Yorker’s dating life, and ultimately her relationship.
lead_paragraph: Just before shelter in place went into effect in New York on March 20, I unofficially moved in with my boyfriend Will Gorfein, 32. I grabbed some essentials from my Manhattan apartment — including half-empty bottles of hand sanitizer, nonperishable food and comfortable clothes — to prepare for the uncertain weeks ahead. I purposely left behind alcohol.

headline: Summer Reading Suggestions, Handpicked for Your Taste
abstract: If you know what you’ve liked in the past, here are some books that might work for you now.
lead_paragraph: There’s no question that this summer reading season will be different from any we can remember. But despite the state of the world, a number of absorbing books are on their way. So we’ve taken a look back at some very popular books of summers past with an eye toward what their fans might enjoy among the titles being published in the coming few months.JOHN WILLIAMS

headline: Don’t Bail Out the States
abstract: Instead of propping up failed state bureaucracies, the federal government should support American workers.
lead_paragraph: Over 30 million Americans have filed for unemployment over the past six weeks. That is roughly 20 percent of the labor force. And that number is likely to grow larger as most states are ill equipped to handle the onslaught of the newly unemployed.

headline: Art Is a Different Kind of Cosmic Order
abstract: Its patterns help us access the inner truths that science can’t articulate.
lead_paragraph: This is the essay is part of The Big Ideas, a special section of The Times’s philosophy series, The Stone, in which more than a dozen artists, writers and thinkers answer the question, “Why does art matter?”

headline: What Elvis, Michael Jackson and Trump Have in Common
abstract: They were all nightmare celebrity patients.
lead_paragraph: Well, well. The president says he’s spent the last week and a half enjoying his hydroxychloroquine, presumably neat. It’s impossible to say whether it’s true; as doctors on Twitter were quick to note, Sean Conley, the White House physician, said in a memo that he discussed the drug with Trump, not prescribed it, though together he and the president concluded it was worth the risk.

headline: Say Hello to That New Spin Studio and Goodbye to Your Child Care
abstract: We’ve long failed to fund the child care sector like the public good that it is. Now it’s on the brink of collapse.
lead_paragraph: As Covid-19 continues to wreak havoc on businesses, among the hardest hit are in industries that rely on the ability of customers to safely show up day after day — and to pay for the privilege. They range from the $32.3 billion fitness industry to the $47.2 billion child care sector. Hopefully, your neighborhood spin studio will survive. Unfortunately, your day care probably won’t.

headline: A Sudden Coronavirus Surge Brought Out Singapore’s Dark Side
abstract: The pandemic seemed to pass over the city-state. Then the government was blindsided by an outbreak among poor migrant workers in packed dormitories.
lead_paragraph: I remember that time when we’d beaten the pandemic. That’s what we thought, anyway, for a few weeks in late winter: That Singapore had conquered the novel coronavirus without lockdowns or widespread mask use, without even closing the schools.

headline: Why Is Mitch McConnell Protecting Nursing Homes?
abstract: My mother and countless other residents have died. But Mitch McConnell cares only about protecting corporations from lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: CONSHOHOCKEN, Pa. — Just three weeks ago, family and friends did their best to comfort my six siblings and me via videoconference as we mourned my mother, Sylvia. Our grief was compounded by the circumstances of her death: She died at 82 after contracting the coronavirus at her assisted living facility, one of the victims of an outbreak that killed 20 patients and sickened dozens of other residents and staff members.

headline: When the Mask You’re Wearing ‘Tastes Like Socialism’
abstract: The partisan divide over how to respond to the coronavirus pandemic has deepened over the past few weeks.
lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 pandemic has divided Americans into two camps. To no one’s surprise, lockdown politics have joined the legion of issues that pit Democrats against Republicans.

headline: Salvage Firm Can Cut Into Titanic to Recover Telegraph, Judge Says
abstract: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration opposes the operation to salvage the Marconi device and contends that the wreckage should not be disturbed.
lead_paragraph: An underwater salvage company was granted approval this week to cut into the wreckage of the Titanic to try to recover a Marconi telegraph, rekindling a complex debate over access to the ship and maritime law.

headline: In a World ‘So Upside Down,’ the Virus Is Taking a Toll on Young People’s Mental Health
abstract: The shuttering of the American education system has cut off young people from school staff members who helped them navigate the pressures of adolescence and cope with trauma.
lead_paragraph: The email, written by an eighth grader and with the subject line “Wellness Check,” landed in her school counselor’s inbox nearly three weeks after schools had closed in Libby, Mont., a remote town of 2,700 cradled by snow-topped mountains.

headline: The Worst Is Yet to Come
abstract: The coronavirus and our disastrous national response to it has smashed optimists like me in the head.
lead_paragraph: For as long as I can remember, I have identified as an optimist. Like a seedling reaching toward the golden sun, I’m innately tuned to seek out the bright side.

headline: From Chaos to ‘Scary Silence’: Elmhurst Hospital After the Coronavirus Surge
abstract: Elmhurst Hospital in Queens had been inundated by patients. The Times went back to see how the staff was recovering, and planning for the possibility of another wave.
lead_paragraph: Elmhurst Hospital in Queens had been inundated by patients. The Times went back to see how the staff was recovering, and planning for the possibility of another wave.

headline: Gymnasts Push for Lasting Change After a Coach Is Suspended for Abuse
abstract: When Maggie Haney, the prominent coach of an Olympian, was barred for eight years after being accused of emotional abuse, gymnasts saw an opening to press for other cases to go forward and to demand broader change.
lead_paragraph: The suspension of a top coach last month for emotional and verbal abuse has galvanized gymnasts to share similar stories of misconduct, both privately and publicly, in a way that could signal a turning point in a sport desperate for a change in culture after the Lawrence G. Nassar molestation scandal.

headline: Bill T. Jones Knows Life Will Change, and His Art Too
abstract: The choreographer, whose life and work were affected by the devastation of AIDS, wonders, “How does my art find the new normal?”
lead_paragraph: It’s not a shock that the choreographer Bill T. Jones would be thinking about AIDS right about now.

headline: 10 Years Old, Tearful and Confused After a Sudden Deportation
abstract: Since the coronavirus broke out, the Trump administration has deported hundreds of migrant children alone — in some cases, without notifying their families.
lead_paragraph: The last time Sandra Rodríguez saw her son Gerson, she bent down to look him in the eye. “Be good,” she said, instructing him to behave when he encountered Border Patrol agents on the other side of the river in the United States, and when he was reunited with his uncle in Houston.

headline: Elephants Really Can’t Hold Their Liquor
abstract: Humans and other species have a gene mutation that lets them digest alcohol. In other species, it’s missing.
lead_paragraph: Humans are not the only animals that get drunk. Birds that gorge on fermented berries and sap are known to fall out of trees and crash into windows. Elk that overdo it with rotting apples get stuck in trees. Moose wasted on overripe crab apples get tangled in swing sets, hammocks and even Christmas lights.

headline: What Do the Paparazzi Do When the Stars Are Quarantined?
abstract: More FaceTime means less face time, but the celebrity photographers are still shooting away.
lead_paragraph: “Can I call you back in, like, 10 minutes?” asked Giles Harrison, a longtime celebrity photographer and owner of London Entertainment Group, a paparazzi collective. He was driving around the Venice Beach area of Los Angeles in his Ford Expedition when he spotted a star: Tim Robbins, on his bike, wearing a mask. Mr. Harrison politely hung up and got his shots.

headline: Poor Americans Face Hurdles in Getting Promised Internet
abstract: Broadband companies like Charter and Comcast vowed to help low-income people during the pandemic. But taking them up on the offer hasn’t always been easy.
lead_paragraph: The people behind a nonprofit that helps workers at the famed Churchill Downs racetrack in Louisville, Ky., had spotted a great opportunity.

headline: The Garage Saves the Day
abstract: Where to turn when you need a spot for an ice rink, a swimming pool, an exercise studio, a romantic cafe or even a satellite food bank.
lead_paragraph: Amélie Kretz was in Australia in March, training for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics alongside her Canadian triathlon teammates, when Covid-19 sent her entire team back to Canada. Within weeks, the Olympics had been postponed to 2021, the 2020 racing season was delayed until at least June, and the gyms, pools and hiking trails near her Montreal home had all closed.

headline: The Many Masks of Nancy Pelosi
abstract: The speaker of the House has relentlessly, and strategically, made masks a part of her platform.
lead_paragraph: Late last week, as she was leading the charge to push the Democrats’ $3 trillion pandemic relief package through the House, Speaker Nancy Pelosi strode the floor of the Capitol in a fuchsia pantsuit, red pumps, white shell — and a coordinated red, white and green cherry-print face mask.

headline: No More ‘Kneecap to Kneecap’ Talks: Coronavirus Hinders Military Recruiting
abstract: There is no substitute for face-to-face conversations when trying to get Americans to sign up to be service members. Boot camp outbreaks slow the pipeline, too.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Army is in constant need of new soldiers, and Sgt. Austin West knows precisely where to find them and reel them in: high school auditoriums, local fairs and even Walmart. At the store, he casually questions workers to “see how they are doing there, how they like their job, to see if we can tailor their hopes” to fit with the Army’s need for thousands of new recruits each year.

headline: How the ‘Plandemic’ Movie and Its Falsehoods Spread Widely Online
abstract: Conspiracy theories about the pandemic have gained more traction than mainstream online events. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: There have been plenty of jaw-dropping digital moments during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: A Visual Dispatch From One of the World’s Most Remote Islands
abstract: The inhabitants of Tristan da Cunha, which sits in the remote waters of the South Atlantic, are insulated from the coronavirus by an immense moat.
lead_paragraph: With travel restrictions in place worldwide, we’ve launched a new series, The World Through a Lens, in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Andy Isaacson shares a collection of photographs from the remote island of Tristan da Cunha.

headline: Hospitals Move Into Next Phase as New York Passes Viral Peak
abstract: A sharp drop in coronavirus patients was “like someone turned off the hose,” one doctor said. But the city’s health system faces challenges ahead.
lead_paragraph: Across New York City, hospitals have moved into a new phase in their battle against the coronavirus.

headline: Brooklyn, Before It Was a Global Brand: Walk Its History
abstract: A few hundred years in the borough, from the brownstones to the shipyards. Our critic chats with a fourth-generation Brooklynite and historian.
lead_paragraph: Officially incorporated in 1834, Brooklyn was already the third largest city in America by the Civil War. Just over a century later it was in shambles, hemorrhaging jobs. Now it’s a global brand, a glorious, complex megalopolis of thriving streets, gentrification and poverty, its booming neighborhoods illuminated by a million twee Edison bulbs, its enduring emblems a parachute jump and an old, beloved roller coaster.

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
abstract: The state would allow visitors at 16 hospitals, nine of them in New York City, as part of a pilot program.

headline: Lockdown Delays Led to at Least 36,000 More Deaths, Models Find
abstract: All 50 states have begun to reopen to some degree, but rules vary. Scientists say they see progress on the path to developing a vaccine by next year.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Sleepless and Going Broke: Riding Out Coronavirus Alone
abstract: Najee Wilson is a 32-year-old artist’s muse who is quarantining alone in Crown Heights. Unable to work or see his friends, his video diary documents what it means to find a new virtual community while organizing a rent strike.
lead_paragraph: Najee Wilson is a 32-year-old artist’s muse who is quarantining alone in Crown Heights. Unable to work or see his friends, his video diary documents what it means to find a new virtual community while organizing a rent strike.

headline: Who Made My Puzzle?
abstract: This month’s constructor spotlight shines on Jonathan Kaye.
lead_paragraph: In Washington, D.C., with my wife, our 11-year-old son and our dog, a rescue hound mix. For the last 15 years I’ve served as Senior Counsel to the American Red Cross at its D.C. headquarters.

headline: Why Is the Pandemic Killing So Many Black Americans?
abstract: Racial disparities in the death rate contradict the claim that the novel coronavirus is “the great equalizer.”
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: What Went Wrong With My Vegetables and Flowers?
abstract: Three of the most common questions gardeners have at this time of year — and some answers.
lead_paragraph: The moment just before the official start of summer is a good time to take stock of how spring went in the garden. Before I forget, I make notes on what worked and what didn’t — how there weren’t enough of that Primula over there, and too much of that Pulmonaria in another spot, or which patch of some overly enthusiastic ground cover I’m going to reduce or eliminate next.

headline: A Struggling Stimulus Program
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: There have clearly been problems with the business loan programs in the federal government’s coronavirus stimulus.

headline: On Politics: The Economy’s Biggest Threat Is …
abstract: Financial warnings and reopener’s remorse: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin’s testimony before a virtual hearing of the Senate Banking Committee was shown on televisions in the Capitol.

headline: Policymakers and the Pandemic: Now What?
abstract: The Fed and Treasury chiefs both described the economy in gloomy terms at a congressional hearing. But they differed about how to fix it.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: Conn. Reopens, and Some Worship to Resume in N.Y.
abstract: Malls, stores and restaurants in Connecticut are open with restrictions, and religious services with up to 10 people in New York can resume on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Thursday’s live coverage.]

headline: He Was Thriving in New York’s Art Scene. The Virus Changed Everything.
abstract: Najee Wilson, an artist and muse living in Brooklyn, ponders the future of his New York dream, now derailed by Covid-19.

headline: Do You Believe in Ghosts?
abstract: Reports of paranormal activity have increased during the coronavirus pandemic. Have you ever experienced strange, unexplained sights or sounds? Do you have a personal ghost story?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever heard strange noises in the middle of the night? Have you seen household objects mysteriously move or be suddenly gone? How about free-floating, full-torso vaporous apparitions, in the famous words of “Ghostbusters”?

headline: Mom-Shaming Ourselves
abstract: To compare is human, even during a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The other day I watched a mother make crackers from scratch in an Instagram story. I had already had it up to here with surprisingly unharried parents spending days making perfectly plated, elaborate meals, but the crackers were some next-level nonsense. These crackers took days to make, and are a foodstuff found in delicious abundance at every grocery store! It broke my brain.

headline: Iran Extends Temporary Release of British-Iranian Woman
abstract: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, 41, was sentenced to five years in prison in 2016 after she was accused of plotting to overthrow the government in Tehran. She has vigorously denied the charges.
lead_paragraph: A British-Iranian woman who was granted temporary release from prison in Iran in March amid the coronavirus pandemic has had her furlough extended indefinitely, her family said on Wednesday, raising hopes that she could be granted clemency and return to Britain.

headline: The Law of Supply and Demand Isn’t Fair
abstract: In a crisis, consumers think it is outrageous to jack up prices of essential items, yet that social norm predictably leads to shortages.
lead_paragraph: For an economist, one of the most jarring sights during the early weeks of the coronavirus crisis in the United States was the spectacle of bare shelves in sections of the supermarket.

headline: Janelle Monáe Touches Down in ‘Homecoming’
abstract: The intergalactically attuned pop singer and star of films like “Moonlight” and “Hidden Figures” continues to expand her horizons as an actor, playing the lead in the new season of the Amazon thriller.
lead_paragraph: If there is any silver lining to the weeks that Janelle Monáe has spent sheltering in place, it is the opportunity it has afforded her to refocus on the fundamentals of performance and shed some of the excess of what she calls her “p.c.” — that is, “pre-corona” — days.

headline: What You Get for $400,000
abstract: A 1917 house in Shreveport, La.; an 18th-century building complex in Brookfield, N.H.; and a Craftsman home in Tacoma, Wash.
lead_paragraph: A 1917 house in Shreveport, La.; an 18th-century building complex in Brookfield, N.H.; and a Craftsman home in Tacoma, Wash.

headline: $400,000 Homes in Louisiana, New Hampshire and Washington
abstract: A 1917 house in Shreveport, an 18th-century building complex in Brookfield and a Craftsman home in Tacoma.
lead_paragraph: Designed by a builder as his own residence, this home has original features in excellent condition, including pine flooring, mahogany trim, pocket doors and double-hung sash windows throughout. A remodel about 20 years ago introduced mechanical systems upgrades and a new kitchen and bathrooms.

headline: Why Expanded Covid-19 Testing in California Won’t Fix Everything
abstract: Wednesday: Officials in Los Angeles cautioned against changing behavior based on test results. Also: The Department of Justice warns Gov. Gavin Newsom.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Volkswagen Settles Emissions Charges Against 2 Managers
abstract: The carmaker will pay a relatively modest fine to resolve criminal cases involving the chairman and chief executive. They were accused of not warning shareholders about a scandal.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen has agreed to pay a fine of 9 million euros ($10 million) to settle criminal charges against its two highest-ranking executives, who were accused by German prosecutors of failing to warn shareholders about an emissions cheating scandal, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Design Meets Nature in Slovenia
abstract: This three-bedroom contemporary house with walls of windows and brilliant views in Slovenia is on the market for $908,000.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom contemporary house with walls of windows and brilliant views in Slovenia is on the market for $908,000.

headline: House Hunting in Slovenia: Tucked Into the Trees for $908,000
abstract: In and around the Slovenian capital of Ljubljana, real estate professionals are ready to get their market growing again.
lead_paragraph: This two-story, 2,350-square-foot house is tucked into a grassy hillside in Topol pri Medvodah, a quiet village just outside Ljubljana, the capital city of Slovenia.

headline: Does Knowing What You’re Hearing Matter?
abstract: Yuja Wang caused a small sensation at Carnegie Hall by throwing her program’s order to the winds.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall was packed, including extra seats on the stage, for a recital by the pianist Yuja Wang. Her program offered 13 wildly contrasting works spanning three centuries, from Bach and Galuppi through Chopin and Brahms to Ravel, Scriabin, Berg and Federico Mompou.

headline: Steve Coogan Reaches the End of ‘The Trip’
abstract: He plays a version of himself in the movie series, which is ending with “The Trip to Greece.” In reality “I’m not quite as precious as I come across. But there’s certainly a lot of truth in it.”
lead_paragraph: As fans of “The Trip” movies know well by now, Steve Coogan has a shelf full of Baftas, the British equivalent of the Oscars. It’s a feat turned running gag throughout the films as he flaunts it at virtually every opportunity.

headline: With No Fans in the Seats, Do Sports Remain Must-Watch TV?
abstract: The White Sox and Orioles played in front of empty stands in 2015. It was a one-off that showed how hard it could be to captivate viewers without fans in attendance.
lead_paragraph: From the press box, I covered the Baltimore Orioles’ hosting the Chicago White Sox in an empty stadium on April 29, 2015, an afternoon of eerie quiet and desolation at Camden Yards.

headline: Zoom Fatigue: How to Politely Decline a Call During Quarantine
abstract: The normal boundaries that once dictated social etiquette have essentially dissolved. So how do you disconnect?
lead_paragraph: Much of the United States is still on lockdown, so your loved ones are aware that you, like them, are probably sprawled on the couch in elastic waistband pants Googling how to create a sourdough starter, making it hard to find guilt-free excuses for declining a FaceTime call or virtual happy hour invite.

headline: Trump Steps Up Attacks on Mail Vote, Making False Claims About Fraud
abstract: President Trump initially said he might withhold federal funding for Michigan and Nevada if the states moved forward in expanding vote by mail, though he later backed off that threat.

headline: The Galaxy That Grew Up Too Fast

What returned was an image of space littered with what the astronomer Alan Dressler of the Carnegie Observatories called “train wrecks”: irregular, fragmented clouds of stars known as protogalaxies, flecks of starlight scattered like orphan jigsaw puzzle pieces across the primordial heavens.

But then comes Breland, wiry and enthusiastic, shoving him out of the frame to take over the singing, providing an object lesson in genre and racial expectations. “My Truck,” one of the year’s most beguiling singles, is a fluent amalgam of country verbiage and vocal texture with hip-hop bluster and cadence. “Wood-grain dash with the matte-black finish,” Breland sing-raps, “and it match my shawty with the big ol’ butt.”

headline: Paper Dolls for Your Crafting Pleasure
abstract: By turns escapist and timely, eclectic outfits from artists, illustrators, designers and one set of architects.
lead_paragraph: Eighteenth-century iterations of paper dolls — hand-painted figures marketed to wealthy Europeans — were nearly as rarefied as the real-life versions of the towering headdresses and ruffled gowns they wore. By the next century, advancements in printing technologies allowed for paper dolls to go mainstream as toys for children. And while these toys reinforced often limited notions of what a person (usually a woman) ought to be, they also acknowledged the multiplicity of selves that live within us all, and provided an affordable way for children to use fashion to experiment and escape (paper dolls were especially popular during the Great Depression). Today, too, fantasies of slipping into a new self or world are deeply appealing. There may not be much cause to shop or dress up yourself, but who knows where a doll might need to go, or who they might need to see.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: Leonard Bernstein’s ‘Mass’ and ‘Trial by Fire’

lead_paragraph: GREAT PERFORMANCES: LEONARD BERNSTEIN MASS Stream on PBS.org. Classical music, musical theater, rock and blues (and don’t forget the marching band) all factor into Leonard Bernstein’s “Mass,” a sonic hodgepodge that first premiered in 1971. The piece mixes lyrics by the “Godspell” creator Stephen Schwartz with passages of the Latin mass liturgy. It was applauded by some and criticized by others when it debuted — and has been argued over ever since. This recorded production with the baritone Paulo Szot and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra under the baton of Marin Alsop offers a chance for listeners to make up their own minds on whether the piece is innovative or abrasive (or both).
