When they talk about having to relinquish their American identities and empathize with “ordinary people” of other cultures, it obliges with swelling, inspirational music.

headline: ‘Kate Nash: Underestimate the Girl’ Review: A Star Who Fell to Earth
abstract: A new documentary, about the British singer-songwriter’s struggle to reassemble her pop career, is a frank depiction of the life of a workaday musician.
lead_paragraph: The music business takes center stage in “Kate Nash: Underestimate the Girl,” the appealingly candid documentary that finds the director Amy Goldstein working with her subject to show the financial realities of a career in pop.

headline: ‘The Painter and the Thief’ Review: An Unexpected Friendship
abstract: In this Norwegian documentary, the artist Barbora Kysilkova finds her muse in the man who stole her paintings.
lead_paragraph: In a real-life occurrence so serendipitous that it feels almost scripted, the perpetrator and the victim of an art crime become unexpected friends. In 2015, the Czech artist Barbora Kysilkova learned that two of her most prized paintings had been stolen from a gallery in Oslo, where she lives. Surveillance footage led to arrests and a trial. In court, Kysilkova asked the ringleader, Karl-Bertil Nordland, to sit for a portrait; he agreed.

headline: How the Pandemic Splintered the Appalachian Trail
abstract: The coronavirus scuttled plans and forced officials to ask people to get out of the woods. Of the thousands who hoped to hike the trail this year, only a few hundred remain.
lead_paragraph: When Kelsey Foster started hiking the Appalachian Trail in early March, she had left her whole life behind — her job, her apartment, her family.

headline: On Politics: Putting a Stamp (or Not) on Vote-by-Mail
abstract: President Trump makes false claims, and Mike Pompeo faces scrutiny: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: President Trump at a coronavirus meeting with Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas and Gov. Laura Kelly of Kansas at the White House on Wednesday.

headline: Are You Ready to Go Back to the Office?
abstract: A long stretch of remote working has led companies to rethink their office space — namely, whether they need as much of it after the pandemic subsides.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: Nearly 1 in 4 New Yorkers Needs Food as Pandemic Persists
abstract: With about two million city residents thought to have inadequate food amid the coronavirus outbreak, the city will soon distribute 1.5 million meals a day.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Friday’s live coverage.]

headline: ‘Lucky Grandma’ Review: Mean Streets of Chinatown
abstract: In Sasie Sealy’s darkly funny mafia thriller, the veteran actress Tsai Chin exudes cool.
lead_paragraph: Cantankerous and fiercely independent, the 80-year-old Grandma Wong (Tsai Chin) wants to live by herself in her Chinatown apartment in New York. Her son, Howard (Eddie Yu), wants her to move in with his family to save on rent. Encouraged by a fortune teller’s promise of imminent luck, she takes all her savings to a casino only to find herself — after some hilariously absurd twists — with a bagful of a dead man’s cash and a pair of gangsters on her tail.

headline: ‘Survive the Night’ Review: Droning Through a Home Invasion
abstract: As bored as Bruce Willis has looked in recent movies, you can’t expect him to muster much interest in this home invasion thriller.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Willis was doing his part for video on demand even before the pandemic made it the norm for watching movies. In recent years, he has cultivated a side gig droning through supporting roles in uninspired thrillers that barely surface in theaters. The latest obscurity is “Survive the Night,” a flabby hunk of meat that the director, Matt Eskandari, hasn’t bothered to season.

headline: ‘Inheritance’ Review: A Rich Kid’s Estate Surprise
abstract: Lily Collins stars in this peculiar cat-and-mouse thriller.
lead_paragraph: After her tycoon father dies under frantic, fast-cutting circumstances (so much so that this movie’s opening minutes look like a trailer, or a parody of one), Lauren (Lily Collins) gets the short end of the stick, money wise, and something worse. She’s made the ward of a man, played by Simon Pegg, whom her father has held captive in a bunker on the family’s property for untold years.

headline: ‘Villain’ Review: Brothers in Harm
abstract: An aging ex-con is forced into old ways in this superior crime thriller.
lead_paragraph: Any movie containing the line “You need to grab that hacksaw and start on his legs” is already halfway to winning me over, and Philip Barantini’s “Villain” does not disappoint. Populated by men with fists like shovels and faces like bruised fruit, this British crime drama has, for all its grime and gutter maneuvering, an unusual, mournful dignity.

headline: ‘Nothing Fancy’ Review: Mexican Food Through British Eyes
abstract: This documentary is an admiring visit with Diana Kennedy, who has devoted her life to researching and cooking traditional Mexican food.
lead_paragraph: No seasoning wimps need show up in the enviable kitchen of Diana Kennedy, the famed cook and British expat who has devoted most of her life to chronicling and conquering Mexican cuisine. And in Elizabeth Carroll’s debut documentary, “Diana Kennedy: Nothing Fancy,” a group of eager acolytes try not to flinch beneath her gimlet gaze and salt-seeking palate. Kennedy may be pushing her centenary, but her words are as sharp as her flavor profiles.

headline: ‘Smash,’ NBC’s Short-Lived Musical Drama, Eyes the Stage
abstract: Steven Spielberg and other original producers are adapting the backstage TV series, which theater fans continued to embrace after its brief run.
lead_paragraph: The NBC drama “Smash,” though both loved and abhorred when it premiered in 2012, has since grown into a cult favorite among theater buffs. There were flashy musical numbers! Christian Borle sitting at a piano! The high stakes of putting on a show! (Critics were less thrilled.)

headline: ‘Joan of Arc’ Review: The Saint Is Revisited in Song
abstract: Bruno Dumont’s movie features a young actress as the saint in her later years — along with the French pop singer Christophe.
lead_paragraph: The French director Bruno Dumont returns to the subject of his galvanic 2018 “Jeanette: The Childhood of Joan of Arc” in this not-quite-sequel.

headline: These Labs Rushed to Test for Coronavirus. They Had Few Takers.
abstract: The fragmented U.S. health care system has hampered efforts to expand coronavirus testing, by making it difficult for hospitals to switch to new labs with ample capacity.
lead_paragraph: When a stay-at-home order in March all but closed the revered labs of the gene-editing pioneer Jennifer Doudna, her team at the University of California, Berkeley dropped everything and started testing for the coronavirus.

headline: Many Jobs May Vanish Forever as Layoffs Mount
abstract: With over 38 million U.S. unemployment claims in nine weeks, one economist says the situation is “grimmer than we thought.”
lead_paragraph: Even as states begin to reopen for business, a further 2.4 million workers joined the nation’s unemployment rolls last week, and there is growing concern among economists that many of the lost jobs are gone for good.

headline: Talking California With Our Newest Correspondent
abstract: Thursday: Meet Shawn Hubler, a longtime California journalist who’s based in Sacramento. Also: The reopening of the state picks up speed.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘Surreal’: What It’s Like to Ride a Motorcycle Through New York Right Now
abstract: Cruising down Broadway without crowds sounds like a total joy ride. Until you remember why it’s like this.
lead_paragraph: When Giorgio Milella, a graphic designer, started working from home in mid-March, he figured out how to break up the tedium: by leaving his Harlem apartment and hitting the newly empty streets on his motorcycle.

headline: Can the ‘Melting Pot of Humanity’ Survive This?
abstract: A dismal season is predicted for Coney Island. If there is one at all.
lead_paragraph: This summer was supposed to be big for Coney Island.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Woven leather accessories, provocative paintings — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: How to Go on a First Date During Quarantine
abstract: Being alone is tough. Here are some ways to go on a first date in isolation.
lead_paragraph: If you want to go on a first date, take advantage of what you can uniquely do in this moment. For starters, you can now see into other people’s houses without the expectation of hooking up. You can see so much of their actual lives before meeting up.

headline: Lori Loughlin to Plead Guilty in College Admissions Scandal
abstract: The actress Lori Loughlin has agreed to plead guilty and to serve two months in prison. Her husband, Mossimo Giannulli, a fashion designer, is expected to serve five months.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — At first, being the face of a national scandal seemed to slide off Lori Loughlin’s glamorous back.

headline: Shooting at Texas Base Was ‘Terrorism Related,’ F.B.I. Says
abstract: The gunman was killed, and a member of the base’s security force was injured in the attack at an entrance to Naval Air Station Corpus Christi, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: An attack by a gunman who opened fire early Thursday at a gate of Naval Air Station Corpus Christi in Texas was related to terrorism, the F.B.I. said on Thursday.

headline: The Most Popular Properties of April
abstract: The most popular real estate listings of April are a mixed bag of commercial and residential properties.
lead_paragraph: The ongoing coronavirus pandemic has wreaked havoc on the real estate industry, reducing the number of available listings and altering priorities for both buyers and sellers. We can see the impact as we look at the five most-viewed listings in April on The New York Times’s Find a Home site — a collection of residential and business spaces.

headline: Tony Hawk’s 900 Spin Was Amazing. An 11-Year-Old Skateboarder Stuck a 1080.
abstract: That’s three full spins before landing back on the halfpipe for Gui Khury.
lead_paragraph: Gui Khury owned a skateboard before he was even born, thanks to his father, Ricardo.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘What We Know About Your Chances of Catching the Virus Outdoors’
abstract: All 50 states have begun to reopen to some degree. In this lesson, students will learn about the risks in going outdoors again — and precautions they can take to minimize them.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “What We Know About Your Chances of Catching the Virus Outdoors” by Michael Levenson, Tara Parker-Pope and James Gorman

headline: Trump Will Withdraw From Open Skies Arms Control Treaty
abstract: The president held out the possibility of negotiations with the Russians that could save American participation in the accord. But even some of his own aides said success for that seemed unlikely.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has decided to withdraw from another major arms control accord, he and other officials said Thursday, and will inform Russia that the United States is pulling out of the Open Skies Treaty, negotiated three decades ago to allow nations to fly over each other’s territory with elaborate sensor equipment to assure that they are not preparing for military action.

headline: 3 Injured in Mall Shooting in Arizona, Officials Say
abstract: The gunfire erupted at the Westgate Entertainment District, an outdoor shopping center that had recently reopened, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A gunman opened fire on Wednesday night at a recently reopened shopping mall near Phoenix, leaving one person in critical condition and two others with injuries that were not life-threatening, the authorities said.

headline: Five Art Books to Read This Summer
abstract: As the art world mulls whether a return to “normalcy” should be its goal, publishers mine the archives of artists who found their own counterpaths.
lead_paragraph: For much of the culture industry, as with society at large, a single pressing issue looms over all others: Join the rush to reopen? Or remain anxiously hunkered down, lest — like the fake ending of so many horror movies — the seemingly defeated killer suddenly re-emerges from his hiding spot.

headline: A Season to Celebrate Asian-American Theater Is Lost to Pandemic
abstract: Briefly this spring New York theaters featured a stunning array of plays by writers of Asian descent. The scripts showed diversity and adventurous experimentation.
lead_paragraph: The cast and crew of “Wolf Play” were on their third day of tech rehearsals at Soho Rep in Manhattan in mid-March. “We were doing this complicated boxing scene, and we had the smog machine and the costumes, and it looked awesome,” said Hansol Jung, who wrote the play.

headline: China Moves to Tighten Its Control of Hong Kong
abstract: New security laws would allow Beijing to take aim at the protests that have roiled the semiautonomous city and posed a direct challenge to the Communist Party and its leader, Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China signaled on Thursday it would move forward with laws that would take aim at antigovernment protests and other dissent in Hong Kong. It is the clearest message yet that the Communist Party is moving to undermine the civil liberties the semiautonomous territory has known since the 1997 British handoff.

headline: How to Protect Kids’ Ears From Constant Headphone Use
abstract: Volume is not the only measure to consider. Duration also contributes to damage to our kids’ ears.
lead_paragraph: Children glued to their headphones. It’s a familiar scene these days.

headline: Charlie Brooker Saw All This Coming
abstract: The “Black Mirror” creator, who knows something about dystopias, discusses the cognitive dissonance of this “boring apocalypse” and the continued importance of satire.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Charlie Brooker may have been more prepared than most for the coronavirus and the subsequent global lockdown.

headline: Will Hot Weather Kill the Coronavirus Where You Live?
abstract: Trump says warm weather “kills this kind of virus.” Is he right?
lead_paragraph: Trump says warm weather “kills this kind of virus.” Is he right?

headline: ‘I’m Teaching Into a Vacuum’: 14 Educators on Quarantine Learning
abstract: An illustrated look at how teachers across the country are reaching students during the pandemic.

headline: Susan Rothenberg, Acclaimed Figurative Painter, Dies at 75
abstract: Her raw renditions of horses and other figures breathed new life into painting when the genre was under siege in 1970s SoHo.
lead_paragraph: Susan Rothenberg, whose flayed, lushly foreboding paintings radiated a Paleolithic grandeur and helped usher figuration back into an art world that had declared it extinct in the 1970s, died on Monday at her home in Galisteo, N.M. She was 75.

headline: Scientists Predict ‘Busy’ Atlantic Hurricane Season Amid Virus Crisis
abstract: This year’s season is complicated by the coronavirus pandemic, which makes relief strategies like group shelters risky.
lead_paragraph: The coming Atlantic hurricane season is “expected to be a busy one,” with the likelihood of as many as 19 named storms, including as many as six major hurricanes, a federal weather scientist said Thursday. That worrisome forecast could be further complicated by the coronavirus pandemic, which is hobbling relief agencies and could turn evacuation shelters into disease hot spots.

headline: Livestreams to Watch: John Legend Performance and Memorial Day Events
abstract: Appointment viewing is back. Find out what online events to look for in coming days, and when to tune in.
lead_paragraph: Here are a few of the best events happening Thursday through Wednesday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern).

headline: Why Yo-Yo Ma Would Invite Socrates to Dinner
abstract: “For once, I’d like to ask the questions.”
lead_paragraph: “For once, I’d like to ask the questions,” says the renowned cellist, whose new ensemble album is “Not Our First Goat Rodeo.”

headline: 6 Things to Do This Memorial Day Weekend
abstract: Our writers offer suggestions for what to watch or listen to while we’re housebound.
lead_paragraph: As the curtain rises in Stephen Adly Guirgis’s “Our Lady of 121st Street,” a pantless man exclaims, “What kinda [expletive] world is this?” That sensational line established Guirgis as one of the most exciting voices of his generation when the play opened in 2002, and in 2020 it’s a question we might find ourselves repeating on a daily basis.

headline: ‘Horrified’ and ‘Ashamed’: Volkswagen Apologizes for Ad
abstract: The German car company withdrew an online ad that attracted criticism for its racist images.
lead_paragraph: In the brief video, a dark-skinned man is pushed off a city street and onto a sidewalk by a giant white hand. Then another giant hand takes him by the head and pushes him toward a doorway, before he is summarily flicked inside.

headline: What Is New York Without New York Bars?
abstract: I miss the promise the night offers. Liquor bottles standing sentry behind the bartender. The endless possibility in conversations overheard, lives intersecting.
lead_paragraph: I miss bars.

headline: How to Make a Great To-Do List
abstract: You’re stuck at home with a lot on your plate, but it’s easy to get distracted. A proper to-do list will keep you on track.
lead_paragraph: You’re stuck at home with a lot on your plate, but it’s easy to get distracted. A proper to-do list will keep you on track.

headline: Robots! (Don’t Get Too Excited.)
abstract: Robots are cool. But we should be skeptical of emerging technology.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Justice Dept. Unit That Prosecuted Roger Stone Is Reorganized
abstract: The overhaul of a division of the U.S. attorney’s office in Washington came at the end of a brief tenure by a longtime adviser to Attorney General William P. Barr.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on Roger Stone’s sentence being commuted by President Trump.]

headline: Senate Approves John Ratcliffe for Top Intelligence Job in Sharply Split Vote
abstract: The congressman from Texas was confirmed by a divided Senate to take over an office at the center of the Trump administration’s investigations of Obama administration officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A divided Senate voted on Thursday to confirm Representative John Ratcliffe of Texas, a fierce conservative ally of President Trump’s with relatively little intelligence experience, to lead the nation’s spy agencies.

headline: 10 Great Bottles of Italian White Wine Under $25
abstract: Though noted primarily for red wine, Italy actually makes more white. These are diverse, delicious, great values and not a pinot grigio among them.
lead_paragraph: Regardless of the ubiquity of pinot grigio and Prosecco, the antiquated notion of Italy as solely a red wine culture retains its tenacious grip on the imagination. It was not true 20 years ago, and it’s not true today.

headline: Boris Johnson Avoids Criminal Inquiry Into His Dealings as London’s Mayor
abstract: A police watchdog did find evidence, however, that Mr. Johnson and an American businesswoman may have had an “intimate relationship” and that the relationship helped her secure money and networking opportunities.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British police watchdog agency said on Thursday that it would not conduct a criminal investigation into Prime Minister Boris Johnson over claims that as mayor of London he had done official favors for an American businesswoman whose apartment he sometimes visited during working hours.

headline: Pulling Out Your Hair? This Might Be the Cause
abstract: Hair-pulling in an age of anxiety.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny Friday last month, 10 days into Australia’s coronavirus lockdown, Jayde Beaumont put her toddler daughter down for a nap, closed her bathroom door and started to shave her head.

headline: Harold Blake, Loyal to Robert Moses Until the End, Dies at 91
abstract: He was executive assistant to that imperious urban planner when Mr. Moses headed the 1964-65 World’s Fair in New York. He was later an executive with the city’s bridge and tunnel authority.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Our Best Memorial Day Recipes
abstract: Here’s what to cook for the unofficial start of summer.
lead_paragraph: Summer may officially begin on the solstice, the longest day of the year, but the unofficial start to the season is the long Memorial Day weekend, when many home cooks dust off their grills and declare that cookout season begun. Here are our best Memorial Day recipes, from side dishes to desserts and everything in between.

headline: New Threat to New York City: Commercial Rent Payments Plummet
abstract: One landlord reported that 80 percent of retail tenants missed rent at the start of the month. The drop in commercial rent payments could imperil property tax collections that pay for city services.
lead_paragraph: In Brooklyn, a nightclub has been closed for two months. In Manhattan, a travel agency says it is unlikely to ever reopen. Both have not paid rent since the coronavirus shutdowns began.

headline: Bard College Music Student Sues School, Citing Instructor’s Conduct
abstract: The teacher was fired, but the suit says he should not have been on staff because of prior complaints by other students.
lead_paragraph: A music instructor at Bard College was fired this year after a Title IX investigation determined he had sexually harassed a young percussion student. Now, the student is asserting in a lawsuit against the college that the instructor should not have been on staff because of prior harassment complaints that the school knew about.

headline: As Trump Rails Against Voting by Mail, States Open the Door for It
abstract: Despite the president’s opposition, states are increasingly reducing barriers to what many see as the safest way to vote amid the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By threatening on Wednesday to withhold federal grants to Michigan and Nevada if those states send absentee ballots or applications to voters, President Trump has taken his latest stand against what is increasingly viewed as a necessary option for voting amid a pandemic.

headline: As Saudi Official Hid Abroad, His Family Became a Target at Home
abstract: Saad Aljabri knows “where the bodies are buried.” Now Saudi authorities are arresting his relatives to force him to return to the kingdom, his son says.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For years, he was one of Saudi Arabia’s top intelligence officers, an expert in artificial intelligence who played key roles in the kingdom’s fight against Al Qaeda and in its security coordination with the United States.

headline: Women in Charge: Success Against the Coronavirus
abstract: Readers discuss leadership styles and stereotypes as they speculate about why countries headed by women are seeing fewer deaths.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The 1975: Self-Aware, Self-Indulgent and, Yes, Sincere
abstract: The British band’s new album, “Notes on a Conditional Form,” is a more downcast take on the challenges of living in the internet age.
lead_paragraph: The 1975 is a British pop band, not a graduate seminar’s sparsely attended lecture series, though the titles of its most recent albums certainly invite that clarification. The bold, eclectic “A Brief Inquiry Into Online Relationships” from 2018 found the verbose, self-aware frontman Matty Healy moving deftly between arena-sized anthems and confessional ballads, serving up cheeky Twitter-era bons mots on the pitfalls of fame, mortality and contemporary life. (“Danny says we’re living in a simulation,” he sang, “but he works in a petrol station.”) Now, a year and a half later, comes the 200-level curriculum: “Notes on a Conditional Form.”

headline: Russia Flouts Another Treaty. So We’re Leaving It.
abstract: The agreement undermines security instead of promoting it.
lead_paragraph: Arms control treaties can be a powerful national security tool. But too often arms control proponents — those who seek to control weapons by agreement — get confused: Is arms control a means to a national security end or the end itself?

headline: How to Refresh Your Home With Minimal Fuss
abstract: From reconsidering your lighting to upgrading your bedding, suggestions for making the space you’re isolating in feel new again.
lead_paragraph: If you’re lucky enough to be healthy but bored, having already reorganized your spice rack and closet, you might be in need of another project to fill some of the remaining hours of self-isolation. Perhaps, like many of us, you’re also feeling overly familiar with every contour and corner of your home, and are longing for a not-too-daunting, not-too-costly way to refresh it. Here are a few simple home-décor projects you can accomplish without the need for outside help. While none is a huge undertaking — no power tools or wall removal required — each can have an outsize effect, turning a room you’re all too used to into a space that feels at least somewhat new.

headline: A Case for Cooperation Between Machines and Humans
abstract: A computer scientist argues that the quest for fully automated robots is misguided, perhaps even dangerous. His decades of warnings are gaining more attention.
lead_paragraph: The Tesla chief Elon Musk and other big-name Silicon Valley executives have long promised a car that can do all the driving without human assistance.

headline: University of California Will End Use of SAT and ACT in Admissions
abstract: The change is expected to accelerate the momentum of American colleges away from the tests, amid concern that they are unfair to poor, black and Hispanic students.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — The University of California on Thursday voted to phase out the SAT and ACT as requirements to apply to its system of 10 schools, which include some of the nation’s most popular campuses, in a decision with major implications for the use of standardized tests in college admissions.

headline: Fed Chair Warns This Is a ‘Downturn Without Modern Precedent’
abstract: It’s impossible to guess what the trajectory for the economy will look like, a series of central bankers warned. That makes nimbleness key.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, and other top central bank officials warned on Thursday that the United States was experiencing an exceptional shock in the coronavirus pandemic, and that it was wildly unclear when and how low unemployment and widespread prosperity would return.

headline: Trump’s Inaccurate Claims on Hydroxychloroquine
abstract: The president falsely described scientific research around the malaria drug, falsely denied the existence of a federal warning against it and argued, with no evidence, that large numbers of health care workers were taking it.
lead_paragraph: As President Trump has promoted hydroxychloroquine as a treatment for the coronavirus and claimed to be taking it himself, he has continued to make inaccurate or incomplete statements about the drug. Here is a fact check of his recent claims.

headline: Lucky Peterson, a Bluesman Since He Was a Boy, Dies at 55
abstract: He cut a record at 5 and went on to a steady if somewhat under-the-radar career as a backing musician and solo artist.
lead_paragraph: In his recent concerts the bluesman Lucky Peterson, who died on Sunday in Dallas, had been celebrating his 50th anniversary in show business. That was striking considering that Mr. Peterson, at his death, was only 55.

headline: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: I spent a lot of hours in the town library as a kid — my mother volunteered there, before she earned her graduate degree and became a school librarian a few towns over — and one result of all that happy browsing is that I developed a taste for the unexpected juxtaposition, the serendipity of shelving that might lead you from a book about gardening to a book about horses to a book about extrasensory perception. It wasn’t a big library; it wasn’t a big town. But it contained the world.

headline: What Comes After a 2-Month Quarantine Date?
abstract: Sheltering at home means we’ve basically been on a date for 60 days. How will we go back to living apart?
lead_paragraph: My guy and I have been seeing each other since August, and our relationship is going great. For the past two months, we’ve been sheltering in place together at his home (which is 90 minutes away from mine). We’ve been having lots of fun: great conversations, making art, listening to music and still getting our work done. My question: How do we address the transition when the pandemic ends, and we inevitably go back to our normal lives (and homes)? Essentially, we’ve gone on 62 dates in 62 days!

headline: How to Be Alone
abstract: I was struggling with quarantine — until I found the polar explorers.
lead_paragraph: I was struggling with quarantine — until I found the polar explorers.

headline: How to Be Alone When You’re Really Bad at It
abstract: I was struggling with quarantine — until I found the polar explorers.
lead_paragraph: My friend Kelsey doesn’t recommend getting dumped on your birthday. Valentine’s Day, I’ve heard, is also unideal. And while I can’t endorse breaking up on vacation in Hawaii with your entire family either, that ex and I do remain close friends, so perhaps there are worse ways to go than crying about irreconcilable differences over piña coladas.

headline: Sally Rowley, Jewelry Maker and Freedom Rider, Dies at 88
abstract: She fought for civil rights, learned to fly and sold her art on the streets of San Francisco. She died of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: A New Site to Help Rescue New York Restaurants
abstract: The city gets its own spot on SaveTheEats, a website that highlights deals, classes and special dinners provided by kitchens navigating the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: An initiative called SaveTheEats is working to consolidate support for many restaurants that have closed or are struggling to remain open during the coronavirus pandemic. On Tuesday, New York City joined the growing list of participating cities on its website, including Philadelphia (where #SavePHILLYEats started on March 31), Washington, Minneapolis-St. Paul, Baltimore, Los Angeles and Austin, Texas.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Hong Kong, Cyclone Amphan, Spike Lee: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: A proposal for new national security laws would give the Communist Party more control over the semiautonomous territory, and threatens to erode the freedoms that distinguish the global, commercial city from the rest of the country.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Online Test Proctoring, Favorite Books and Driving Tests
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we asked teenagers to decide if students should be monitored during online tests, to share what books assigned by teachers became their favorites, and to weigh in on whether or not teenagers should be allowed to drive without passing a road test.

headline: Abdullah al-Hamid, Saudi Dissident, Dies in Detention at 69
abstract: A tireless advocate for human rights and a thorn in the side of the monarchy, he spoke out for democratic reforms and was imprisoned seven times.
lead_paragraph: Abdullah al-Hamid, an intellectual and human-rights activist whose calls for reforming Saudi Arabia’s monarchy made him one of the kingdom’s most prominent and persistent dissidents and led to frequent prison terms, died on April 24 in detention. He was 69.

headline: Six: Impasse
abstract: An interview with PewDiePie, as he comes to grips with his influence.

headline: Getting on a Plane? Please Take the Food Out of Your Bag
abstract: New security and health policies at airports and on planes will make traveling this summer a bit stranger and, officials hope, safer.
lead_paragraph: Airports this Memorial Day weekend are likely to be far emptier than usual, but people who plan to travel can expect to encounter lots of changes and new inconveniences.

Eleven years ago, it was a notorious hellhole where Mr. Seymour, then a crack addict, dealer and pimp, shooed away do-gooders from the local church because, as he put it, “I’m selling dope here and you’re disturbing my business.”

headline: I’ve Been Sounding Taps Since My Ship Was Attacked in 1945
abstract: I played Taps for my fallen brothers-in-arms after a kamikaze pilot attacked our ship during World War II. I now play it every year on Memorial Day.
lead_paragraph: This account is from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series from The Times that documents lesser-known stories from the war. In the spring of 1945, the U.S.S. Terror, a minelayer, was anchored at Kerama Retto, off the southwest coast of Okinawa Island, where it was receiving casualties from nearby ships. On the morning of May 1, George Sherwood, a 17-year-old signalman, stood watch on the bridge as it was attacked by a kamikaze aircraft; 48 servicemen were killed or went missing, and more than a hundred others were wounded.

The woman, played by Janelle Monáe and introduced to viewers as Jackie, has amnesia. How she got in the boat is a mystery (as is everything else about her). So she sets out to investigate, in a search that comes to involve a fictional wellness company with a dark side. Her story’s connection to the previous season of the show — which starred Julia Roberts as a therapist with her own murky past — is a surprise. “We didn’t want to repeat the same tricks of Season 1,” Micah Bloomberg, one of the series’s creators and showrunners, said in a recent interview with The New York Times. “We wanted each season to come to a satisfying conclusion and then leave a trap door into the next one.”

On Monday, speaking jointly onscreen from their respective capitals, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Emmanuel Macron of France emerged from what Ms. Merkel described as “the most serious crisis of the E.U.’s history” and announced that they had found a solution.

headline: Children May Be At Higher Risk of Drowning This Summer
abstract: The pandemic poses new safety challenges around water. Parents should be ready.
lead_paragraph: The summer of 2020 is shaping up to be anything but normal. Will camps be open? What about day care? What will kids stuck at home do all day long? With so many families sheltering in place and parents juggling work and child-care responsibilities, drowning is probably low on the list of concerns. But it’s this exact scenario that can lead to kids being unsupervised around water — even momentarily — with tragic results.

headline: Learning How to Love From Afar
abstract: I am trying to survive this season of fear as I did another one, the summer of 1951, when I contracted polio. But how long can you live on the knife edge of unknowing?
lead_paragraph: One afternoon in early February, a gazillion memories ago, I put a few things on the curb the day before trash pickup, in accord with my neighborhood’s ongoing swap meet. By the next morning the mail carrier had carted off the fireplace irons; someone else took the French coffee press. But my old kitchen wall clock went unclaimed. I propped it against a tree, a forlorn Dali melting into the rough winter earth. Its hands had been stuck at 7:00 for years.

headline: Looking at War Across 2,500 Years
abstract: Thomas E. Ricks considers books from ancient China down to the war in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: In few areas of human activity is there such a discrepancy between perception and reality as there is with war. There tends to be a huge difference between what people think war is and what it really is, a thought that returned to me repeatedly as I read a stack of new books.

headline: The Public Has Been Forgiving. But Hospitals Got Some Things Wrong.
abstract: Mistakes are inevitable. But we can try to do better.
lead_paragraph: The mean arterial pressure was well over 100 and the patient’s heart rate was racing. In an emergency room hastily converted into an I.C.U., abnormal vital signs were not unusual. Intubated coronavirus patients lined the unit, ventilators and IV pumps crammed in between their beds. The patients needed fluids, sedatives, paralytics, antibiotics. Some needed heparin (a blood thinner) for the raging blood clots that Covid-19 incited. Others whose blood pressure had plummeted were being given vasopressors.

headline: Brazil’s First Indigenous Curator: ‘We’re Not Afraid Anymore’
abstract: Sandra Benites, of the Guaraní Ñandeva people, is using art to bring new visions and voices to the museum world.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Sandra Benites’s work is all about finding common ground. As Brazil’s first Indigenous art curator, the 45-year-old educator, who grew up with the Guaraní Ñandeva people in the village of Porto Lindo, wants to use art to bridge the gap between Indigenous Brazilians and those from other backgrounds.

headline: First They Fled the City. Now They’re Building $75,000 In-Ground Pools.
abstract: When the going gets tough, the rich buy oases.
lead_paragraph: When the visual history of the pandemic is winnowed down to its defining images, we’ll be struck again by the glare of disparity — the pictures of mobile morgues and long lines at food banks next to those of people who seem to be riding out the crisis on a wave of rhubarb cocktail infusions and early evening beach walks. On the one side, the pervasive physical and economic toll; on the other, the chic home gyms of Instagram, the velvety spring lawns of Amagansett, the casting of lockdown life as an image from Slim Aarons.

headline: How Quarantine Saved the Hot Dog
abstract: Facing a summer with no baseball and no picnics, the makers of the original Coney Island red hot feared the worst. But even with an empty boardwalk, business is booming.
lead_paragraph: In 1867 Charles Feltman, a German immigrant, opened the first hot-dog stand in Coney Island. He called his signature frankfurter the Coney Island red hot, and it was served with mustard, sauerkraut and diced raw onions.

headline: Art Is How We Justify Our Existence
abstract: Our technologies are tools. But our creative works carry the wisdom of the world.
lead_paragraph: This is the essay is part of The Big Ideas, a special section of The Times’s philosophy series, The Stone, in which more than a dozen artists, writers and thinkers answer the question, “Why does art matter?” The entire series can be found here.

headline: ‘Working People Want Real Change’: A Union Chief Sounds Off on the Crisis
abstract: Mary Kay Henry of the Service Employees International Union leads nearly two million workers, many of them on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Growing up as the oldest girl among 10 siblings in a large Catholic family in Detroit, Mary Kay Henry learned the power of collective action at an early age. Sometimes, she and her older brother would have to get all their siblings ready for school, packing lunches, getting kids dressed and shepherding everyone on to the bus.

headline: Beyond Rotten Apples: The Colombian Military Intelligence Needs to Be Reformed

headline: Can Anyone Save New York’s Bars and Restaurants?
abstract: Even when businesses like mine can open up for real, it will be very hard to keep them going in a socially distanced world.
lead_paragraph: On March 13, as New York City schools let out for what turned out to be their last official day and offices were telling their employees to work from home, I came down with an ominous fever and chills, and my business partner and I closed our two Brooklyn bar-restaurants. By the next week I would be diagnosed with Covid-19, and the week after that I would develop pneumonia. I spent four weeks bedridden, isolated from my family, at times immobilized with terror that I wouldn’t survive the night. When the virus released its grip and I could finally sit up in bed, my first impulse was to email my staff: We’re back in business!

headline: They Both Found Their Jukebox Hero

abstract: One essential job wasn’t enough, so Kevin Bradford, a partner of Harlem Hops, took on a second one.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Bradford is a seventh-grade math teacher in Westchester County at Isaac E. Young Middle School in New Rochelle. With stay-at-home-orders, his commute from Manhattan has certainly gotten easier, but he can’t say the same about remote learning (and he’s been in education for 26 years). “The students, they are constantly forgetting the password,” he said.

headline: Why a ‘Strange and Nerdy’ Book About Eels Is Making Waves
abstract: Patrik Svensson mixed natural history with memoir for his debut, which has become a surprise best seller and award winner in his native Sweden.
lead_paragraph: MALMO, Sweden — In the 1980s, American scientists devised an experiment that they were convinced would solve the mystery of how eels reproduce.

headline: Two Very Different Democrats: What a Biden-Warren Ticket Might Be Like
abstract: If Joe Biden selects Elizabeth Warren as his running mate, the ticket would be a marriage of contrasting policy ideas and governing philosophies unlike any in decades.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. speaks with Elizabeth Warren about once a week. They review the latest developments on the Covid-19 crisis and the collapsing economy. They trade ideas about how a Democratic president, like Mr. Biden, might rescue the country. They exchange tales about their lives sheltered in place, he in Wilmington, Del., and she in Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Sexual Abuse Case in Global Soccer Puts FIFA Under Scrutiny Again
abstract: A year after similar accusations led to the ouster of a top soccer official in Afghanistan, global soccer faces calls to do more to protect athletes after another case in Haiti.
lead_paragraph: A year after the ouster of the head of soccer in Afghanistan over accusations that he sexually abused female players, global soccer is facing another serious case that is raising questions over its commitment to protecting vulnerable athletes.

headline: Beach Towns Have a Message for New York City Residents: Go Away
abstract: Annoyed by the city’s decision to keep its shoreline closed, officials in nearby areas are limiting beach access to keep outsiders at bay.
lead_paragraph: In the Hamptons, the locals have put up barricades to limit parking and deployed enforcement officers to ticket outsiders. Jersey Shore towns have banned short-term leases and Airbnb rentals. The Suffolk County executive’s office taunted Mayor Bill de Blasio: “Do your job. Figure out a plan to safely reopen your beaches.”

headline: Turning Your Backyard Into a Vacation Spot
abstract: With summer camps shut down and beach vacations seeming risky, homeowners are investing in ways to create a summer retreat at home.
lead_paragraph: Savannah Shyne has big plans for the summer, and none of them involve leaving her backyard in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

headline: What Happened to the Great American Logistics Machine?
abstract: Nobody could make supply chains sing like the United States. And now maybe nobody can, period.
lead_paragraph: It started with silence, or something close to silence, or perhaps it was simply the absence of a low-level hum that nobody knew was humming until it stopped. In the quiet we realized that, until the pandemic arrived, we had lived in a vast, elaborate, whirring contraption that delivered culture and commerce at spectacular speeds, with astonishing efficiency.

headline: How to See, in Four Minutes
abstract: An assignment for all of us to help capture an extraordinary time.

headline: The Country Enters a Memorial Day Weekend to Remember (or Forget)
abstract: Communities are finding creative ways to celebrate the traditional start of summer in the midst of social distancing and coronavirus alarm.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A sailboat race from Cape Cod to the island of Nantucket has marked the unofficial beginning of summer for the last 49 years. But the Figawi regatta, which raises money for veterans over Memorial Day weekend, will not involve any actual boats this year. Instead, organizers will host a virtual cocktail party from a boathouse, among other online events.

headline: The Circus Came to Town, Then It Couldn’t Leave
abstract: One of Italy’s famed family-owned circuses has been sitting out the coronavirus pandemic in a field outside Rome.
lead_paragraph: CORCOLLE, Italy — At the end of Italy’s coronavirus lockdown, one of the camels broke free.

headline: Pick a Card and Be Transported: 7 Board Games From Around the World
abstract: Design the Sagrada Família in Barcelona or wander through Edo-era Japan. These games are about learning and exploring, not winning.
lead_paragraph: Like good books, travel-themed board games take your eyes off your screen and your mind far away. They’re about more than winning. They’re departure points, capturing a bit of the beauty, history and spirit of the places in which they’re set, provoking questions and talk of future trips.

headline: Can You Gather With God Over Zoom?
abstract: Quakerism goes virtual, offering an intimate window into silent worship.
lead_paragraph: For the past 27 years, Ted Ehrhardt has awoken on Sunday morning and headed to worship at the Brooklyn Quaker Meetinghouse. “I wait all week to get there,” he said. “I know every board in the room, every crack in the plaster.”

headline: First Inklings of Fame
abstract: The class of 2020 has no idea what the future holds — and neither do we. Here’s a look back at some icons starting on their paths to renown.
lead_paragraph: It is graduation season, and luminaries like Tina Fey, Oprah, Tom Hanks and Barack Obama are giving advice to graduates about starting their next chapter.

headline: Treating Mild Coronavirus Cases Could Help Save Everyone
abstract: Acting before or very soon after an infection is the best way to handle most acute viral diseases. Why aren’t we focusing on that with Covid-19?
lead_paragraph: President Trump said this week that he was taking the antimalarial drug hydroxychloroquine as a measure against Covid-19, the illness caused by SARS-CoV-2. This, even though he is not known to have tested positive for the virus or to have any symptoms of the disease — and even though scientific evidence is growing that the drug offers no benefit to Covid-19 patients and could be dangerous to some people.

headline: Jane Roe’s Pro-Life Conversion Was a Con
abstract: Norma McCorvey makes a shocking deathbed confession.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, I went to Jackson, Miss., to report on the weeklong siege of the state’s last abortion clinic by the anti-abortion group Operation Save America. Flip Benham, then the group’s leader, had T-shirts made up, black with white lettering, saying, “Homosexuality Is Sin! Islam Is a Lie! Abortion Is Murder! Some Issues Are Just Black and White!”

headline: No One Knows What’s Going to Happen
abstract: Stop asking pundits to predict the future after the coronavirus. It doesn’t exist.
lead_paragraph: The best prophet, Thomas Hobbes once wrote, is the best guesser. That would seem to be the last word on our capacity to predict the future: We can’t.

headline: As Death Toll Nears 100,000, Some in White House Question the Math
abstract: President Trump ordered states to reopen places of worship, but several governors said that decision would be their call. Persistently high case levels in Los Angeles, Chicago and Washington have medical experts concerned.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the global coronavirus pandemic

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
abstract: With about two million city residents thought to have inadequate food amid the virus pandemic, the city will soon distribute 1.5 million meals a day.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: China Doesn’t Just Want to Control Hong Kong
abstract: The special governance system set up to protect the city’s freedoms was really only ever designed to stifle them.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Beijing says it wants to safeguard “one country, two systems,” the principle that supposedly guarantees Hong Kong’s semiautonomy from the mainland. In reality it is weaponizing the policy to crush the city’s freedoms.

headline: Welcome to Our Surprise Zwedding
abstract: Plans for a wedding in Bolivia are called off, but a ceremony in Central Park, disguised as a Zoom happy hour, brought their families together.
lead_paragraph: Brian Clarke was exhausted the first time he met Mariana Ranz in 2015. By the time they were married on May 11, he had cause to feel frazzled again.

headline: Love on the Mountain Bike Trail
abstract: The couple met on a bicycle outing, had their first date on another, and fell in love on a biking road trip. But for the wedding? They hiked.
lead_paragraph: On Friday afternoons in the small Adirondack town of Wilmington, N.Y., local mountain bike enthusiasts gather for “Hardy hour” at the Hardy Road trailhead.

headline: A Big Sur Elopement for Two Olivias
abstract: Olivia Hall and Olivia Reaney were married in an outdoor ceremony on the California coast in Big Sur as family members watched on Zoom.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Olivia Hall received a surprise during a psychiatry lecture at N.Y.U. when she took a peek at her phone and noticed a message in her Bumble account from another Olivia — Olivia Reaney.

headline: A Driveway Wedding and Flowers by Trader Joe’s
abstract: “Despite the craziness, we were still able to zero in on what’s really important to us, and that’s being together,” said Laurie Moise about her wedding to Horton Sears.
lead_paragraph: Laurie Moise made an impression on Horton Sears the first time he saw her, in the fall of 2009, at an orientation for new students at Providence College, in Providence, R.I.

headline: 9 Miles, 7 Locations and a 3-Hour Ceremony
abstract: “By deconstructing a traditional wedding, we performed one wedding ritual at each station, drawn from either the German or Chinese traditions,” said Dr. Huchuan Xia of his wedding to Erik Lorenz.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Huchuan Xia and his partner, Erik Lorenz, put their makeshift nuptials into another gear.

headline: A More Idyllic Setting Was Found
abstract: The bride’s mother drew the line at a marriage in the county jail.
lead_paragraph: The bride’s mother drew the line at seeing her daughter, Hope Wolf, married at the booking window of the Caswell County detention center in Yanceyville, N.C.

headline: Genie Chance and the Great Alaska Earthquake
abstract: This is the story of the biggest earthquake ever recorded in North America — and the voice that told Anchorage’s story in the aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: The ‘Cradle Catholic’ Promoting Family Planning in Ghana
abstract: Dr. Leticia Adelaide Appiah is determined to slow her conservative country’s birthrate by any means, including contraception. Not everyone is pleased.
lead_paragraph: ACCRA, Ghana — On the last Sunday before Lent, Dr. Leticia Adelaide Appiah was up early and the first to be ready for Mass in her home, a government bungalow in the affluent Cantonments neighborhood of Accra, the capital of Ghana.

headline: Biden-Warren: Really?
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: There is a long history of bad feelings between Joe Biden’s inner circle and Elizabeth Warren.

headline: Khashoggi’s Son Says Family Pardons His Father’s Killers
abstract: The pardon effectively ends the prospect that any of the men who killed Jamal Khashoggi will be executed.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A son of the slain Saudi writer Jamal Khashoggi said on Friday that he and his siblings had forgiven the men who killed their father, effectively extinguishing the prospect that the killers will be executed for the crime.

headline: Celebratory Flight Ends in Tragedy as Plane Crashes in Pakistan, Killing Scores
abstract: The plane, an Airbus A320, crashed in a residential area near the Karachi airport. At least 80 are dead, but the toll may climb.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — The Friday afternoon flight was supposed to be a happy sign that Pakistan was moving past the coronavirus and inching toward normalcy, with families set to reunite after two months in lockdown to spend the Eid al-Fitr holiday together.

headline: How the Trump Effect Could Lift Democratic Senate Candidates
abstract: Republican incumbents in swing states have struggled to disentangle themselves from President Trump, whose voters are loyal but represent a minority of the electorate.
lead_paragraph: A driving theme of Republican Party politics circa 2020 is consolidation.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘When Cadaver Dogs Pick Up a Scent, Archaeologists Find Where to Dig’
abstract: In this lesson, students learn about how dogs’ noses are uniquely suited for supporting archaeologists conducting ancient excavations.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “When Cadaver Dogs Pick Up a Scent, Archaeologists Find Where to Dig” by Cat Warren

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Rethinks the Office
abstract: Facebook said that half of its employees could work remotely within a decade, the latest company to suggest that virtual working will become the norm.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: The U.S. Is Getting Shorter, as Mapmakers Race to Keep Up
abstract: Scientists are hard at work recalibrating where and how the nation physically sits on the planet. It’s not shrinkage — it’s “height modernization.”
lead_paragraph: Height is height, right? Look at a Manhattan skyscraper, or the Washington Monument, or a mountain peak in California, and you imagine that it will be the same height tomorrow as it is today.

headline: Do You Prefer to Dwell in the Past, Live in the Present or Dream of the Future?
abstract: A psychologist writes that when the present is unpleasant, it helps to think ahead to the future and back to the past. Is this good advice?
lead_paragraph: How do you cope with the uncertainty and upheaval in your own life and in the world? What strategies and tools have you used to maintain your sanity during the coronavirus pandemic?

headline: New Jersey Allows Gatherings and Opens Campgrounds
abstract: Social distancing would still be required at outdoor get-togethers, which can have up to 25 people. Face coverings are not required outside, but state officials recommend them.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Saturday’s live coverage.]

headline: Islands Created for Quarantines
abstract: Immigrants arriving in New York in the 1870s who were suspected of carrying diseases were isolated and treated on two man-made islands.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has looked askance at a coughing neighbor or a maskless jogger in recent weeks understands how anxiety and suspicion can take hold when a virulent infectious disease assaults a crowded city.

headline: Summer Activities for the Family, At Home
abstract: We want to hear what creative family activities you’ve come up with to replace summer vacations and camps.
lead_paragraph: Family vacation trips and camps for the kids may not happen this year, but you can still enjoy summer activities at or near your home. We want to hear about the creative and safe ways you and your family are having fun this summer that don’t involve a lot of travel or money. Are you camping in your backyard? Building a makeshift water park out of sprinklers? Let us know what fun summer activities you’ve done or plan to do with the family (the more creative, the better!).

headline: Behind the Cover: Quarantine Journal
abstract: For this issue, a look at the lessons we’ve learned from our time in isolation.

headline: Like ‘Learning to Swim’: How It Feels to Go Out
abstract: Friday: Readers share how they felt visiting businesses in reopening communities. Also: The University of California moves to phase out the SAT; and Memorial Day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Interest Rate on Federal College Loans Is About to Hit a Record Low
abstract: It will drop to 2.75 percent for new loans for undergraduates. That’s a “silver lining” of the current economic turmoil, an advocate said.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus may be upending the way colleges operate, but at least students and their families will get a break if they borrow money from the government for an education.

headline: China’s Tighter Grip on Hong Kong Shakes City’s Business World
abstract: The territory’s stock market plunged amid expectations that money would soon be leaving the Asian financial hub, which faces tough new measures from Beijing and retaliation from the United States.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s desire to take a stronger hand in running Hong Kong has imperiled its status as Asia’s financial capital, sending its stock market into its sharpest plunge in five years and spurring predictions that money and business could soon leave the former British colony.

headline: Pandemic Has Increased Money Anxiety. Therapists Hope to Cure That.
abstract: Interest in financial therapy rose after the 2008 recession, as Americans confronted their fears about money. The field has become relevant again, professionals say.
lead_paragraph: Dale Mackey closed her event space in Knoxville, Tenn., a week before the state issued its orders to end large gatherings. She did not think about the economic ramifications of shuttering her business, the Central Collective; she said it was the right thing to do to reduce the spread of the virus.

headline: Creating an Exhibition of Britain’s Lockdown Dreams
abstract: The artist Grayson Perry talks about his latest TV series, “Grayson’s Art Club,” which showcases art made by a British public trapped at home.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If any British artist has reached the status of a national treasure, it’s Grayson Perry, who is adored both by art critics and by those who rarely step into a gallery.

headline: Video Shows Moment of Jet Crash in Pakistan, and Aftermath
abstract: At least 99 people were aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane when it crashed into a residential neighborhood near the airport in Karachi.
lead_paragraph: At least 99 people were aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane when it crashed into a residential neighborhood near the airport in Karachi.

headline: The Pandemic Ad Salutes You
abstract: In coronavirus-themed commercials, consumption is reframed as a public service performed by heroes, for heroes.
lead_paragraph: There’s something about the coronavirus that has alienated us from the visual cues of disaster. Locked inside under stay-at-home orders, a pandemic appears oddly routine. It looks like the inside of the refrigerator and the menu of the Roku. Bingeing some reality show from my couch, I begin to forget why I’m stuck here, watching it night after night. Until the commercial break arrives.

headline: Issa Rae and Kumail Nanjiani on the Real Challenge of ‘The Lovebirds’
abstract: The actors say their new Netflix movie, which starts where most rom-coms end, needed to acknowledge their characters were people of color.
lead_paragraph: “The Lovebirds” begins as a romantic comedy, then steers a hard left into comic murder mystery territory. The movie’s road to release has taken a turn or two as well.

headline: U.S. Museums Are Reopening: To See Monet, Don a Mask
abstract: As museums around the country prepare to reopen, the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, is going first with safety protocols in place.
lead_paragraph: You won’t be able to use the drinking fountains, check your coat or eat in the cafe. You will have to wear a mask, submit to a temperature check and agree to leave if you show signs of illness. These are the requirements set by the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, when it reopens on Saturday, the first major arts institution in the country to welcome the public back since the outbreak of the pandemic.

headline: Virus Crisis Exposes Cascading Weaknesses in U.S. Disaster Response
abstract: Nonprofits are sending fewer volunteers. Local emergency managers risk being overwhelmed. FEMA is trying “virtual” assistance. And hurricane season starts June 1.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades, the backbone of the nation’s disaster response system — and a hallmark of American generosity — has been its army of volunteers who race toward danger to help shelter, feed and counsel victims of hurricanes, wildfires and other calamities.

headline: How to Have a Safer Pandemic Memorial Day
abstract: You shouldn’t gather in groups this weekend, but we know you probably will. So here’s some guidance from the biology professor whose advice for lowering coronavirus risk has reached millions.
lead_paragraph: Memorial Day weekend is usually a time to come together and honor those who gave their lives defending the nation. But sometime this weekend, we also will pass the milestone of 100,000 American lives lost to Covid-19.

headline: When Coral’s Colorful Show Is a Sign That It’s Sick
abstract: Under stress, certain coral species put on displays to try to re-attract symbiotic algae they need to survive.
lead_paragraph: Breaking up is hard to do, and the measures some take to get their partners back can be colorful at times. Coral reefs are that way, too, but for them, it’s a matter of life and death.

headline: Amazon Angles to Grab Back Customers
abstract: After losing some online shoppers to rivals during the pandemic, the retail giant is turning back to faster shipping times and big sales.
lead_paragraph: As millions more Americans turned to online shopping during the pandemic, Amazon struggled to keep up with the demand, and its rivals pounced. Target’s online sales shot up 141 percent last quarter, while Walmart’s rose 74 percent. Etsy’s were up almost 80 percent in April.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Make memories out of the dishes you’re making now, whether that’s a macaroni salad, baby back ribs or a potato chip omelet.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. We’ll get to recipes soon enough, but I woke up thinking about slice pizza. I thought about waiting for two plain while crammed into the space between the counter and the dining room at New Park on Cross Bay Boulevard in Howard Beach, Queens, drinking grape drink from a paper cup in a crowd of people doing the same.

headline: As Coronavirus Keeps the West at Bay, China Moves to Tame Hong Kong
abstract: An emboldened China and its leader, Xi Jinping, assert themselves on national security, in line with Mr. Xi’s vision for a “great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation.”
lead_paragraph: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, has made one of his boldest political gambits yet, wagering that he can tame Hong Kong through national security legislation, despite the risk of fresh upheavals there and a new flash point with the United States.

headline: A No. 1 Hit Vanished From Poland’s Charts. It’s Not Going Quietly.
abstract: In a furor over censorship, prominent broadcasters resigned and artists asked for the state-run radio station at the center of the controversy to stop playing their music.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Last Friday, Kazik Staszewski, a rock legend in Poland, achieved a stunningly short-lived success in the country’s oldest music chart.

headline: Biden Apologizes for Saying Black Voters ‘Ain’t Black’ if They’re Considering Trump
abstract: The former vice president ignited controversy in a testy exchange during a radio interview with Charlamagne Tha God on “The Breakfast Club.”
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, apologized Friday afternoon for telling a radio host that black voters torn between voting for him and President Trump “ain’t black,” remarks that ignited a firestorm online.

headline: How to Have a Better Argument
abstract: Couples who air their differences productively give their relationship “real staying power.” Here’s how to argue better.
lead_paragraph: Couples who air their differences productively give their relationship “real staying power.” Here’s how to argue better.

headline: Joel M. Reed, 86, Director of Horror Movies, Dies
abstract: He made the exploitation-splatter film “Blood Sucking Freaks,” which was widely reviled but achieved cult status. He died of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Polio and Measles Could Surge After Disruption of Vaccine Programs
abstract: A new study of 129 countries found that the interruption of inoculation efforts could put 80 million babies at risk of getting deadly, preventable diseases.
lead_paragraph: The widespread interruption of routine immunization programs around the world during the coronavirus pandemic is putting 80 million children under 1 year old at risk of contracting deadly, vaccine-preventable diseases, according to a report Friday by the World Health Organization, UNICEF and Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance.

headline: The Sun-Starved Prepare to Storm Beaches. Locals Are Worried.
abstract: As beaches open, out-of-towners will bring business, but also behavior that could threaten public health.
lead_paragraph: Beaches across the United States have been closed to visitors for months. But that hasn’t stopped out-of-towners from trying to use them, sometimes running afoul of the law to do so.

headline: Lori Loughlin Pleads Guilty via Zoom in College Admissions Case
abstract: As part of an agreement with prosecutors, Ms. Loughlin, the Hollywood actress, is expected to receive a two-month prison sentence.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — She frowned at times, and other times nodded ruefully. When it was all over — after she had uttered the word “guilty” — she closed her eyes and sighed.

headline: Grandmother’s Refusal to Remove Photos From Facebook Tests Privacy Law
abstract: A Dutch court ruled a woman violated Europe’s General Data Protection Regulation after refusing to take down photos of her grandchildren from social media.
lead_paragraph: Handling pictures of children and grandchildren is usually a private affair.

headline: ‘Lionhearted’ Girl Bikes Dad Across India, Inspiring a Nation
abstract: A 15-year-old migrant girl pedaled hundreds of miles to bring her injured father back to their home village. India’s cycling federation has taken notice.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — She was a 15-year-old with a simple mission: bring papa home.Jyoti Kumari and her dad had nearly no money, no transport, and their village was halfway across India.And her dad, an out-of-work migrant laborer, was injured and could barely walk.So Jyoti told her dad: Let me take you home. He thought the idea was crazy but went along with it. She then jumped on a $20 purple bike bought with the last of their savings. With her dad perched on the rear, she pedaled from the outskirts of New Delhi to their home village, 700 miles away."Don’t worry, mummy,” she reassured her mother along the way, using borrowed cellphones. “I will get Papa home good.”

headline: Another Casualty of the Coronavirus: Summer Internships
abstract: Like so much else, summer internships have been upended by the pandemic, with hundreds of companies canceling their programs and rescinding offers.
lead_paragraph: When she found out in mid-March that she had landed an internship with an education nonprofit in Washington, Lydia Burns, a senior at the University of Louisville, called her mother to celebrate. The whole world was falling apart, but here, finally, was good news.

headline: Why the Call to Prayer Made Me Cry This Ramadan
abstract: Abdi Latif Dahir, a New York Times reporter based in Nairobi, reflects on how the pandemic’s “gift of loneliness” reshaped the holy month.
lead_paragraph: Abdi Latif Dahir is a Kenyan who was appointed the East Africa correspondent for The New York Times last year. He has fasted every day of Ramadan since he was 9 years old.

headline: Interracial Romance, With Black Women as the Stars
abstract: In “Insecure,” “Love Is Blind” and “The Lovebirds,” these leading ladies are pushing back against dating bias in the real world.
lead_paragraph: In a recent episode of HBO’s “Insecure,” Molly (Yvonne Orji), home for Thanksgiving and chatting about her dating life, shares a picture of her new beau, Andrew, from her phone. With slight glee in her eyes, Molly’s mother probes, “Oh, is he Korean?” Then her brother, asks, “Is he ‘Crazy and Rich’?,” referring to the hit movie from 2018.

headline: Carly Rae Jepsen’s Summery Throwback, and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Phoebe Bridgers, Polo G, Neil Young and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: This Gymnast Hasn’t Turned Off Her Olympic Countdown
abstract: Sunisa Lee, 17, had stellar showings at the national and world championships, and her sights on making the U.S. women’s Olympic team. Those plans are now up in the air.
lead_paragraph: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year.

headline: Vulnerable in the Coronavirus Hot Spots
abstract: Officials discuss how nursing homes, jails and hospitals are coping with the crisis.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Putting the Risk of Covid-19 in Perspective
abstract: Is the risk of dying from Covid-19 comparable to driving to work every day, skydiving or being a soldier in a war?
lead_paragraph: How dangerous is it to live in New York City during this pandemic? How much safer is it in other places? Is the risk of dying from Covid-19 comparable to driving to work every day, skydiving or being a soldier in a war?

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Summer reading. One teenager’s fight against the new Covid syndrome. Running while black. Annie Glenn dies. Suze Orman. Spike Lee. Ronan Farrow. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. It’s the unofficial start of summer in the U.S., though we will toast it without the usual barbecues and get-togethers. Many beaches are open, so we can enjoy the salt and sea once again. Whatever you are doing, I hope that the sun reaches you and that you take a moment to read some amazing journalism.

headline: Coronavirus Cases Fall in Europe’s Capitals, but Fears Over Reopening Linger
abstract: Although declines in the numbers of new infections and deaths have brought relief in Europe’s major cities, there is uncertainty about how much people can now relax.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — During a week of bluebird skies and Mediterranean temperatures, when sunbathers thronged parks and cars poured back onto streets, one sound has been notably absent in London: the wail of ambulance sirens.

headline: Regan Smith: No Swimming, No Olympics, No Graduation. No Complaints.
abstract: Smith, 18, set two world records last summer and seemed primed for the Tokyo Games. When they were postponed, she focused on what she could do rather than what she couldn’t.
lead_paragraph: People throughout the sports world, from athletes to arena staff members, tell The New York Times how their lives have changed during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: How to Improve and Protect Nursing Homes From Outbreaks
abstract: More than a third of America’s Covid-19 deaths can be traced back to these facilities. Experts suggest several ways to make them safer.
lead_paragraph: The doctors, researchers and advocates who have been paying close attention for years are appalled at the way the coronavirus has devastated the nation’s nursing homes — but they’re not shocked.

headline: Lloyd Porter, Cafe Owner Who Found Joy in Everyone, Dies at 49
abstract: An actor transplanted from California, he and his wife opened Bread Stuy, a bakery and cafe that became a local gathering spot.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Parents Really Need a Break. But Is Summer Camp Too Risky?
abstract: Some programs are planning on testing, disinfecting and social distancing to protect children from the virus. Others say camp can’t be safe this year.
lead_paragraph: Surprise Lake Camp, one of the country’s oldest Jewish summer camps, told families on Monday that it would not be opening this year because of worries over the coronavirus.

headline: Jerry Sloan, Hall of Fame N.B.A. Guard and Coach, Dies at 78
abstract: An All-Star with the Bulls, he became an immensely successful coach, turning the Utah Jazz into a powerhouse and a postseason perennial.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Sloan, who entered the National Basketball Association as an unlikely prospect for a Hall of Fame career but carved out one nevertheless, as an All-Star guard with the Chicago Bulls and one of the winningest coaches in league history, died on Friday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 78.

headline: Hungary Moves to Close Border Camps After E.U. Court Ruling
abstract: Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s government has shifted more than 300 asylum applicants out of detention in fenced “transit zones.”
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — The government of Hungary has moved nearly 300 asylum seekers and begun closing detention sites along its southern border after the European Union’s highest court ruled that it was holding migrants unlawfully.

headline: Top U.S. Officials Threaten Action on China Over Hong Kong Security Law
abstract: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and the White House economic adviser, Kevin Hassett, signaled the Trump administration would punish China.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Friday that a broad new security measure proposed by China would amount to a “death knell” for Hong Kong’s political freedoms, as Trump administration officials warned of punishments — possibly including revoking the territory’s special economic and trading status.

headline: Malaria Drug Taken by Trump Is Tied to Increased Risk of Heart Problems and Death in New Study
abstract: The drugs did not help coronavirus patients, and should not be used outside clinical trials, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: The malaria drugs hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine did not help coronavirus patients and may have done harm, according to a new study based on the records of nearly 15,000 patients who received the drugs and 81,000 who did not.

headline: So Much Flavor
abstract: These recipes don’t need many ingredients to deliver a lot of taste.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. One of the glories of life in New York before Covid-19 was the vast variety of flavors you could take in over the course of a week without even entering your own kitchen. Tomatillos and Thai basil, Sichuan peppercorns and smoked salmon: It was a luxury to be able to eat them all, day to day, meal to meal.

headline: You Can’t Beat a Savory Babka
abstract: This cheesy garlic-scented, herb-speckled version may just outshine the chocolate kind.
lead_paragraph: If you feel the desire for a multiday bread-baking project, but chocolate babkas are too sweet, and crusty sourdoughs, too needy, I’ve got a loaf for you. It’s a savory, ricotta-filled babka that’s absorbing and meditative, but not at all fussy. Simply tearing the warm, garlic-scented bread with your hands will make procuring the yeast and flour well worth the search. And slices make for the best grilled cheese sandwiches, ever.

headline: Rock-Bottom Interest Rates May Be Here to Stay
abstract: Once the labor market begins to recover, the Federal Reserve’s experience in the pre-pandemic, record-long economic expansion is likely to influence when its raises rates.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials were running a huge experiment with America’s job market before coronavirus lockdowns gripped the American economy, one that could inform how officials think about unemployment — and the path for interest rates — in the pandemic’s aftermath.

headline: Detroit Police Arrest Man in Connection With Nursing Home Assault
abstract: Both the 20-year-old man who was arrested and the 75-year-old victim were patients of the facility, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit police on Thursday arrested a 20-year-old man in connection with a viral video that showed an assault on a patient at a nursing home, the authorities said.

headline: Judge Is Ordered to Explain Handling of Flynn Case as F.B.I. Announces Review
abstract: In the latest twists in a highly politicized case, Michael Flynn’s lawyers are trying to force a judge to end the case immediately, and the F.B.I. will weigh whether it committed misconduct.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court panel has ordered a trial judge to explain why he is hesitating to grant the Justice Department’s request that he dismiss the criminal case against President Trump’s former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn.

headline: Biden’s Online Campaign Is Still Loading
abstract: As Trump hogs the cameras, the homebound presumptive nominee’s video presence is a limbo of “virtual rallies,” glitches and … birds.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has an opportunity and a challenge: He is the presumptive nominee for president taking on an incumbent weighed down by a public-health disaster and a resulting deep recession.

headline: Why All the Shouting About Google?
abstract: Here’s the one question that matters: Does Google rig the system to squash its rivals and hurt us?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: He Says Trumps Cost Him $2 Million, but Hotelier Now Cheers Federal Assist
abstract: Plans to launch a brand of Trump hotels in Mississippi fizzled when the president’s family business walked away. Now a former partner has received  coronavirus relief loans as he completes the project.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump was campaigning in 2016, his company announced a new line of bespoke hotels that would be built with partners across the country.
