But two years into his presidency, the Trump Organization shelved the brand and dropped the only partner, a Mississippi family business that one member says lost about $2 million in the collaboration.

headline: How to Share Food Safely During the Pandemic
abstract: It’s totally possible. But here are some tips from a food safety expert.
lead_paragraph: Maybe your big sister just had a baby, and you want to take her a home-cooked meal. Or you’d love to swap some sourdough starter for your neighbor’s famous beef stew. Or maybe you baked a birthday cake for your immunocompromised neighbor.

headline: A Philip Glass Score Was Lost. 50 Years Later, Here It Is.
abstract: “Music in Eight Parts” has finally been reconstructed and recorded.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1970s, Philip Glass was already writing masterpieces and performing them with his ensemble in lofts, galleries and museums. But he wasn’t quite making a living as a composer yet.

headline: 9 Splashy Masks to Try On
abstract: Sure, you could make your own. But if you’re in the mood to buy, most of these also include a charitable element.
lead_paragraph: Retail as a whole has declined rapidly over the last two months, but one segment of the struggling industry has defied the trend: face masks. In early April, the Centers for Disease Control began encouraging Americans to wear face masks outside their homes. By then, a crop of do-it-yourself solutions had already emerged, intended to abate shortages of medical-grade personal protective equipment among those on the front lines of the fight against the coronavirus. More than a month later, it’s apparent that social distancing — and thus, mask-wearing — will continue to be necessary throughout the summer. (Of course, in some parts of the world, face masks are already worn daily.)

headline: 8 Cannes Film Festival Prizewinners We Love (and 3 We Don’t)
abstract: About now the festival jury would be weighing its choices. So our critics singled out highlights from more than 70 years of festival glory, as well as a few less-than-stellar prizewinners.
lead_paragraph: At the end of every Cannes Film Festival, juries of cinematic eminences deliver verdicts on the films in competition. The name of the top prize has changed over time — from Palme d’Or to Grand Prix and back again — but the winners include a roster of modern classics.

headline: Is Crying a Sign of Weakness? Tell That to Churchill
abstract: How Churchill showed caring in the dark days of World War II. Also: A condolence note in your own hand; robot fun.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Love Letter: Must Love Dogs
abstract: Plus, how to date now.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up here to receive Love Letter, a weekly newsletter about relationship highs, lows and woes, in your inbox every Friday.]

headline: SpaceX Gets Go-Ahead for NASA Astronaut Launch Next Week
abstract: The agency confirmed its mission was proceeding smoothly, but made the announcement amid the puzzling departure of a top NASA official.
lead_paragraph: [When to watch SpaceX’s next NASA launch of astronauts.]

headline: This One-Bowl Cake Is Worthy of Its Own Celebration
abstract: Whether it’s for a birthday, or just the long weekend, this classic recipe doesn’t need much to shine.
lead_paragraph: This holiday weekend may be a lot more subdued than my usual Memorial Day revelries (lake house, potato cannon, punch), but there will still be cake. Lots of it, smothered in strawberries and cream.

headline: A Bright, Comforting One-Pot Stew With West African Roots
abstract: This brothy version of asaro is packed with yams, plantains and hearty greens.
lead_paragraph: When I returned from Nigeria at the end of February, it was at the tail end of the Harmattan, a season when the winds from the north deposit the finest sand from the Sahara onto Lagos’s every surface. The city was hot and dry, and the markets were bursting with life.

headline: Trump Suggests Virus Death Count Is Inflated. Most Experts Doubt It
abstract: Senior White House and health officials have sought new ways to find the extent of infections and deaths, questioning whether official counts are inflating the toll of the virus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, eager to reopen the economy, has begun questioning the official coronavirus death toll, suggesting the numbers, which have hobbled his approval ratings and harmed his re-election prospects, are inflated.

headline: Walter Dallas, ‘Heartbeat’ of Philadelphia Theater, Dies at 73
abstract: A man of many talents, he led Freedom Theater, one of the nation’s top African-American companies, for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: Walter Dallas, a powerful force in African-American theater, chiefly as a director but also as a playwright, musician and teacher, died on May 3 at his home in Atlanta. He was 73.

headline: Britain Orders a 14-Day Quarantine on Arriving Travelers
abstract: Officials say it will prevent a “devastating resurgence” of the coronavirus. Critics say it should have been imposed three months ago.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain on Friday moved ahead with a 14-day mandatory quarantine on arriving travelers, and heavy fines for those who break the rules, outlining strict new travel restrictions as other European nations are thinking about easing theirs.

headline: Plant-Based ‘Meats’ Catch On in the Pandemic
abstract: As the meat industry struggles to respond to the outbreak, makers of vegan substitutes are ramping up production to meet new interest from shoppers.
lead_paragraph: The news for the American meat industry over the last month has not been good. Slaughterhouses closed as the coronavirus sickened and killed workers. Even after President Trump declared meat processing plants “critical infrastructure,” hundreds of Wendy’s restaurants ran out of hamburgers. As meat-processing plants have shut down, farmers have had to kill hundreds of thousands of pigs.

headline: The Best Films of 2020 (So Far), and They’re All Streaming
abstract: Yes, it’s been a weird year for movies, but our chief critics have still found plenty of gems. Here are their top picks.
lead_paragraph: Theaters closed in March because of the pandemic, and studios delayed the release of several much-anticipated films till the fall or even 2021. So you’d think there might not be much to recommend so far this year. But our chief critics, Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, are having none of that: they are championing several movies that hit theaters before the shutdown or were released online afterward. If you’re looking for new movies that will challenge you, here are their picks.

headline: How to Make a Frozen Margarita
abstract: You’ll need some blanco tequila, lime juice, triple sec, simple syrup, ice and a blender. A summer weekend refreshment is a few easy steps away.
lead_paragraph: You’ll need some blanco tequila, lime juice, triple sec, simple syrup, ice and a blender. A summer weekend refreshment is a few easy steps away.

headline: My 14-Year-Old Isn’t Socially Distancing. What Should I Do?
abstract: Covid-19 offers parents and teenagers a limited number of unsatisfying options, but partial solutions may be better than no solution at all.
lead_paragraph: Our Adolescence columnist, the psychologist Lisa Damour, responds to a reader’s question. The question has been edited and is being published with the consent of the person who submitted it.

headline: With Museums Closed, Coffee-Table Books Bring the Art to You
abstract: The catalogs meant to accompany the spring’s biggest exhibitions are now the exhibitions themselves.
lead_paragraph: GERHARD RICHTERPainting After All By Sheena Wagstaff and Benjamin H. D. BuchlohIllustrated. 269 pp. Metropolitan Museum of Art/Yale University. $50.

headline: Coronavirus Vaccine Shows Promising Early Results in China
abstract: A trial with 108 participants suggests the vaccine is safe and may be moderately effective. But experts noted that the approach has failed in the past.
lead_paragraph: A vaccine developed in China appears to be safe and may protect people from the new coronavirus, researchers reported on Friday.

headline: Reduced Demand for Electricity Leads to Power Giveaways
abstract: The pandemic is turning energy markets upside-down. Some consumers will get paid for using electricity.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has played havoc with energy markets. Last month, the price of benchmark American crude oil fell below zero as the economy shut down and demand plunged.

headline: Argentina Tries to Escape Default as It Misses Bond Payment
abstract: Despite the missed payment, its creditors have agreed to extend negotiations on restructuring $66 billion in foreign debt.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina missed a bond payment on Friday and inched closer to another crushing default, which would plunge it into a new period of economic isolation and deepen a recession that has been exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The Kindness of Strangers
abstract: The story of our show about a restaurant owner grappling with reopening.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday’s episode about Jasmine Lombrage, a restaurant owner in Baton Rouge, La., struggling with the decision of whether to reopen, struck a chord with many of you. There was an outpouring of feedback.

headline: Moving Forward
abstract: At a time of year long associated with graduation and with students moving on to new adventures, members of the first class of New York Times fellows also prepare for their next steps. Here they reflect on the journeys that brought them together and on some of the lessons they've learned.
lead_paragraph: At a time of year long associated with graduation and with students moving on to new adventures, members of the first class of New York Times fellows also prepare for their next steps. Here they reflect on the journeys that brought them together and on some of the lessons they've learned.

headline: Phil May, British Rocker of Unbridled Energy, Is Dead at 75
abstract: Mr. May’s snarling vocals and rebellious persona helped make his band, the Pretty Things, an influential part of the 1960s British scene.
lead_paragraph: Phil May, the lead singer of the Pretty Things, a 1960s British rock band whose members played faster, louder and with more unbridled energy than their contemporaries, died on May 15 in Norfolk, England. He was 75.

headline: Germany’s Lessons for China and America
abstract: Better to love your country with a broken heart than love it blind.
lead_paragraph: “The nation-state alone does not have a future,” Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, said this week. It was a direct challenge to President Trump’s “America First,” the slogan whose poison keeps on giving. His United States has become the most unserious of nations.

headline: Immigration Reform, Past and Present
abstract: Jia Lynn Yang talks about “One Mighty and Irresistible Tide,” and Judith Newman discusses books that help simplify life.
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Surfaces Are ‘Not the Main Way’ Coronavirus Spreads, C.D.C. Says
abstract: If you’re worried about wiping down grocery bags or disinfecting mailed packages, this C.D.C. guidance might bring some relief. It’s not new information; the agency has been saying this for months.
lead_paragraph: Guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention making the rounds this month on the internet are clarifying what we know about the transmission of the coronavirus.

headline: After 3 Children Die, a Race to Investigate a Baffling Virus Syndrome
abstract: At least 161 children in New York have gotten sick, making the state’s caseload one of the largest publicly reported anywhere.
lead_paragraph: Blood will be collected from dozens of children in New York to determine whether they share any genetic variations that might make them susceptible to a mysterious syndrome linked to the coronavirus.

headline: What Role Should Employers Play in Testing Workers?
abstract: Amazon and other companies are planning to test workers for the coronavirus. But there is little federal guidance, and some fear it could lead to a false sense of security.
lead_paragraph: As the country reopens, employers are looking into how to safely bring back their workers. One recurring question: Should they be tested for the new coronavirus?

headline: As Virus Spreads in Russia’s Caucasus, Rumors Swirl Over Strongman’s Health
abstract: Official numbers are still low, but signs are emerging by the day that the toll across the region is growing. And the Chechen leader, Ramzan Kadyrov, was reported hospitalized.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The strongman leader of Chechnya, a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin, is hospitalized with possible symptoms of the coronavirus, state-run news agencies say. A spokesman suggests he is just keeping a low profile because he is “thinking.”

headline: Trump Takes Aim at a Watergate Reform: The Independent Inspector General
abstract: The idea after the Watergate scandals was to keep government honest. President Trump’s goal seems to be to ensure its loyalty.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress had a clear idea of the role it expected inspectors general to play when it created them in 1978 after the Watergate scandals. They were to be dispersed in the agencies and departments of the federal government not as compliant team members but in-house referees, charged with rooting out corruption, waste, malfeasance and illegality.

headline: Churches, China, Memorial Day: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Marcel Ospel, Architect of the Swiss Bank UBS, Is Dead at 70
abstract: He built a global colossus that nearly toppled during the financial crisis of 2008, a plunge that required a bailout and led to his resignation.
lead_paragraph: Marcel Ospel, who fashioned the Swiss bank UBS into a global banking power but then saw it come close to unraveling during the financial crisis of 2008, died on April 26 at his home in Wollerau, Switzerland, near Zurich. He was 70.

headline: Being More Like Athletic Bilbao
abstract: By only recruiting local players, the Basque club has not only forged a unique identity, it has generated a mind-set among its fans. It may now be a helpful path for others to tread.
lead_paragraph: If you are enjoying this newsletter every Friday, please pass it on to a friend (or four) and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.

headline: Investigators Say Man Who Filmed Arbery’s Killing Was More Than a Witness
abstract: The video captured by William Bryan brought the world’s attention to the case. Authorities said he participated in the deadly confrontation.
lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ga. — From the beginning, William Bryan has portrayed himself as a concerned citizen, one drawn by commotion when he pulled out his phone and filmed the fatal encounter between two of his white neighbors and Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old black man who was running in their neighborhood.

headline: What’s Lost and Gained When We Put In 9-to-5 From Home?
abstract: Shopify, Canada’s most valuable corporation, has decided that its employees will now permanently remain out of the office. A leading Canadian expert discusses the implications.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Tobi Lütke, the founder and chief executive of Ottawa-based Shopify, announced on Twitter that most of his company’s 5,000 employees had permanently become stay-at-home workers.

headline: C.D.C. Test Counting Error Leaves Epidemiologists ‘Really Baffled’
abstract: The Centers for Disease Control has been lumping together tests for active coronavirus with tests for recovered patients, boosting testing totals but muddying the pandemic’s course.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As it tracks the coronavirus’s spread, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is combining tests that detect active infection with those that detect recovery from Covid-19 — a system that muddies the picture of the pandemic but raises the percentage of Americans tested as President Trump boasts about testing.

headline: Coronavirus Poems to the Editor: ‘Death Too Wears a Mask’
abstract: Many people are finding comfort in reading and writing poetry during these difficult times. Here are some reflections on life amid Covid-19 submitted by readers.
lead_paragraph: In the Time of Plague

headline: Mass Firing on Zoom Is Latest Sign of Weight Watchers Unrest
abstract: The company, which has broadened its focus to wellness and is now known as WW, let go of a large number of workers during simultaneous video conferences.
lead_paragraph: On the afternoon of May 14, Joanne Patten sat down at her computer in her home in Houston and logged in to a Zoom call with her employer, WW International, the company formerly known as Weight Watchers.

headline: John Driscoll, Scholar, Art Dealer and Collector, Dies at 70
abstract: He purchased and expanded Babcock Galleries, New York’s oldest art seller, while building a renowned pottery collection. He died of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: With Unemployment Expected to Reach 20%, Senators Take a Vacation
abstract: Facing a calamity on par with the Great Depression, they left without a new relief package in place.
lead_paragraph: After three weeks in session, the United States Senate emptied out again on Friday, as lawmakers fled Washington for the Memorial Day recess. They left without even pretending to tackle the next round of coronavirus relief.

headline: Trump’s Press Secretary Displays One of His Checks in a Little Too Much Detail
abstract: The $100,000 check was made out to a government agency. This time his account and routing numbers were clearly visible.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s a feel-good story that President Trump’s press secretaries have relished over the years: the quarterly announcement of which government agency Mr. Trump has selected to be the lucky recipient of his salary, an easy way to show the president sticking to his 2016 campaign pledge to forgo his $400,000 salary and donate it.

headline: Firing a Salvo in Culture Wars, Trump Pushes for Churches to Reopen
abstract: President Trump threatened to overrule states that refuse to open places of worship. The White House could not explain how he has that power, and legal experts said he did not have such authority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump may not consider church essential to his personal life, but it may be to his political future. And so he waded into the culture wars on Friday by demanding that states allow places of worship to reopen “right away” and threatening to overrule any that defy him.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The pandemic doesn’t have to spoil your holiday plans, as long as you take some precautions.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. is about to kick off its first major holiday weekend since the pandemic began — and it’s going to be unlike any other, with most of the traditional activities off limits or significantly restricted.

headline: Patrick Ewing Says He Has Covid-19
abstract: Ewing, the Knicks great, revealed on Friday evening that he had tested positive for the coronavirus. “This virus is serious and should not be taken lightly,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Ewing, the Knicks great who is now coaching the Georgetown University men’s basketball team, announced on Friday evening that he had Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.

headline: Virus Lockdown Forces Iran Into Its First Virtual Quds Day
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei openly acknowledged, apparently for the first time, Iran’s support for armed Palestinian groups fighting Israel.
lead_paragraph: For the past four decades, on the last Friday of Ramadan, supporters of Iran’s government have marched to denounce Israel. They burn Israel’s flag. They mock effigies of the leaders of Israel and of its patron, the United States. They chant pledges to liberate Jerusalem, or Quds, as the city is known in Arabic.

headline: White House Worries About Kelly Loeffler’s Senate Prospects in Georgia
abstract: President Trump, concerned about his own outlook in the state, plans to stay on the sideline in a race where he favored a different choice for senator.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s advisers are increasingly concerned about Senator Kelly Loeffler’s campaign in Georgia, a newly competitive state where the president’s own poll numbers have tightened against former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., according to people briefed on the discussions.

headline: Uncertain Results in Study of Convalescent Serum for Covid-19
abstract: Do antibodies from patients who have recovered actually help those struggling with the disease?
lead_paragraph: A small study of patients who were severely ill from the coronavirus hints that treatment with antibodies from recovered patients may modestly help recovery and survival, scientists reported on Friday.

headline: Michael Flynn and the Presumption of Guilt
abstract: A distrust of prosecutorial power should not be abandoned.
lead_paragraph: Of all the low moments in the 2016 Republican presidential convention — there were many — Michael Flynn’s speech ranks high.

headline: Prosecutors to Drop Charges Against Boyfriend of Breonna Taylor
abstract: The announcement came one day after the Federal Bureau of Investigation said it had opened an investigation into the fatal shooting of Ms. Taylor by three police officers in Louisville, Ky.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors on Friday said they were dropping charges against the boyfriend of Breonna Taylor, a black woman who was fatally shot by three white police officers in Louisville, Ky., in March.

headline: Airlines Given Tentative OK to Halt Service at Dozens of U.S. Cities
abstract: The destinations are mostly in secondary markets that have had little demand for flights or could be served by nearby airports, airlines said.
lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department said late Friday that it would tentatively allow 15 airlines to stop flights to about 60 mostly small and midsize cities, though none of the destinations stand to lose service entirely.

headline: Completely
abstract: Wyna Liu and Erik Agard turn up with a whole lotta puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This pair of constructors, Wyna Liu and Erik Agard, are proving to be a dynamic Saturday duo with their second Saturday grid this spring. This one is measurably harder, in my eyes at least, and required a revisit after a night’s sleep to finish (I am always amazed when that works, it’s like taking the crayon out of your frontal lobe).

headline: Hertz, Car Rental Pioneer, Files for Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: The company, which had amassed a large debt, has been devastated by the sharp drop in travel during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Hertz, which started with a fleet of a dozen Ford Model T’s a century ago and became one of the world’s largest car rental companies, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday after falling victim to its mountain of debt.

headline: Corrections: May 23, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 23, 2020.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a grant given to the drug company AstraZeneca misstated the partial results announced by the biotech company Moderna from a first-phase trial of a vaccine it is developing. The vaccine candidate produced an immune response in the first 45 study participants, the company said, not just in 8.

headline: Quotation of the Day: This Year’s Official Start to Summer Comes With Alarm and Face Masks
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 22, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody’s tired of being quarantined. They are stunned that they couldn’t watch their children graduate from high school. They are afraid that the whole world is going to get canceled.”

headline: Pandemic Swells in South America, as the U.S. Nears 100,000 Deaths
abstract: Gaza reports its first coronavirus death. New York is allowing gatherings of up to 10.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the global coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Akim Aliu’s Account of Racism Pushes Hockey to Search Its Soul
abstract: After an article by the former N.H.L. player was published, various hockey players, fans and other stakeholders committed to reckoning with a culture they say cannot be fixed from the top down.
lead_paragraph: Akim Aliu, a former National Hockey League player, gave a harrowing account this week in The Players’ Tribune about his experiences with racism in the sport. Aliu’s unusually frank post — in which he challenged the culture of the sport and named his tormentor — intensified a debate within the hockey community about efforts to diversify.

headline: Jacinda Ardern Sold a Drastic Lockdown With Straight Talk and Mom Jokes
abstract: Leading New Zealand from isolation, Ms. Ardern coaxed her “team of five million” into accepting extreme restrictions. But the lessons of her success go beyond personality or charm.
lead_paragraph: Halfway into a Facebook Live video last week, updating the world on New Zealand’s plan to reopen restaurants, schools and even movie theaters, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern noticed a concern cropping up among the commenters: They thought she looked tired.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Premature’ and ‘The Painter and the Thief’
abstract: A nuanced romantic drama arrives on Hulu, along with a documentary about an unlikely friendship.
lead_paragraph: PREMATURE (2020) Stream on Hulu. Two people meet, form an undeniable connection and fall in love. But the timing just isn’t right. It’s a familiar story, yet there are more layers to this romantic drama by the filmmaker Rashaad Ernesto Green. Seventeen-year-old Ayanna (Zora Howard), an aspiring poet, is enjoying summer at home in Harlem with her friends before going off to college. Enter Isaiah, (Joshua Boone), an older music producer who instantly catches her eye. They bond over their artistic ambitions and embark on a dreamy summer romance, but reality strikes when discussions about the future crop up. Jeannette Catsoulis named “Premature” a Critic’s Pick, and in her review for The New York Times wrote that “the poetry of the writing and the vibrancy of the filmmaking” lift the movie above its narrative clichés.

headline: A Comics-Obsessed Cinderella Down on the Farm
abstract: In Lucy Knisley’s “Stepping Stones,” a city girl faces her fears about farming, family life and evil stepsisters.
lead_paragraph: After skimming only a few pages of Lucy Knisley’s STEPPING STONES (Random House Graphic, 224 pp., $20.99; ages 8 to 12), even the least jaded of readers might guess the story’s arc: A mother moves her daughter, a true city kid, to the country, where the child will be surprised to find, over time, that she thrives on the pleasures of hard work, fresh milk and the natural world.

headline: Going Places: An Anonymous Gossip Cartoonist With Buzz
abstract: In Remy Lai’s “Fly on the Wall,” an overprotected boy who feels invisible at school creates an eavesdropping alter ego.
lead_paragraph: I remember 12 as a particularly stressful age. My family had recently moved to England, and for a time I was the center of attention, asked to repeat things in my “funny accent” and regale everyone with what was happening in American television. I simultaneously loved it and desperately wanted it to stop — one wrong move and they could all turn on me. It was a relief when they got used to my pronunciation of “aluminum” and I could quit performing.

headline: The New Training Facilities: Backyard Gym, Hallway Track
abstract: With restrictions imposed in their countries to slow the spread of Covid-19, athletes from the canoeist Mallory Franklin to the runner Valeria Nazarova have found ways to train at home.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it’s a new adage: If you build a backyard gym, the quarantined athletes will come.

headline: The Coronavirus Patient Had a Question: Don’t You Lead a Soccer Team?
abstract: The president of Sporting Clube de Portugal, Frederico Varandas, is a former military doctor who returned to duty to assist in the nation’s battle against the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: He swapped his blazer and tie for the uncomfortable fit of personal protective equipment and left the boardroom for the emergency room at Lisbon’s military hospital.

headline: European Defense and ‘Strategic Autonomy’ Are Also Coronavirus Victims
abstract: With governments under intense spending pressure to cope with the coronavirus, European ambitions for a more independent defense are facing the chop.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The coronavirus has upended the best-laid plans and priorities of many, including the European Union. But one of the biggest casualties may be European efforts to build a more credible and independent European military.

headline: Going Outside This Weekend? Don’t Freak Out
abstract: Crowded parks, beaches and hiking trails can bring out our anxieties. A bit of preparation can help.
lead_paragraph: After being holed up indoors for an extended period of time, perhaps you’re feeling the itch to peer outside: to explore the world beyond the radius of your home, grocery and takeout spot. But is it recommended? Will others adhere to social distancing? What fresh horrors await?

headline: Is the Wedding Off? (For Now?) Here’s What to Do Next.
abstract: The coronavirus has forced couples to reschedule or plan quarantine-approved celebrations. Experts share some how-to tips for navigating alternative plans.
lead_paragraph: Organizing a wedding under normal circumstances can be stressful — now throw in a global pandemic and it’s near maddening. As couples look to safely solidify their union, some are planning intimate ceremonies at home, while others are pushing back their original wedding dates to the following year. Here are a few tips from wedding experts to help you tackle some of the issues that may arise while trying to get your celebration back on track.

headline: Should You Renew Your Lease if You’ve Lost Your Job?
abstract: For renters with expiring leases, the next steps will depend largely on whether the home is rent-stabilized or market-rate.
lead_paragraph: Q: I have been furloughed from my job, and the lease on my Brooklyn apartment is up in June. My landlord sent me a renewal, but I am worried about committing to a year lease when I am living on savings and unemployment insurance. I asked if I could stay on as a month-to-month tenant, or sign at a lower rent, but I’ve gotten no response. What can I do?

headline: This Neighborhood Stifled Gangs and Guns. Then a New Killer Moved In.
abstract: Shootings had dropped sharply in South Jamaica, Queens, after local leaders engineered a cease-fire. But there is no negotiating with a virus.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, the main public health threat facing people living in and around the Baisley Park Houses complex in South Jamaica, Queens, was one that had taken too many young lives: gangs armed with guns.

headline: Investigators Say One Man Shot Ahmaud Arbery. Why Are Three Charged With Murder?
abstract: The authorities said Travis McMichael fired the fatal shots, yet his father and a neighbor also are charged with murder in connection with Mr. Arbery’s death.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Three shots were fired in the confrontation that killed Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old black man who was chased by white men as he ran through their southeastern Georgia neighborhood. The authorities said Travis McMichael, who with his father and a neighbor pursued Mr. Arbery, pulled the trigger.

headline: The Drones Were Ready for This Moment
abstract: While humans hunker below, aerial robots are taking over as cops, street cleaners, medical assistants, delivery workers and soon — friends?
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers strolling along the East River early last month glanced up to see an unsettling sight: a mysterious drone claiming to represent something called the “Anti-Covid-19 Volunteer Drone Task Force” barking orders to pedestrians below to maintain social distancing.

headline: Biden’s ‘Breakfast Club’ Controversy Shows What His Rivals Already Knew
abstract: The syndicated radio show with Charlamagne Tha God, Angela Yee and DJ Envy has serious political power.
lead_paragraph: A few months after former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. entered the 2020 race for president, the executive producer of the popular nationally syndicated radio show “The Breakfast Club” said that he and the hosts were in discussions with the Biden campaign about an appearance.

headline: Why Is the SAT Falling Out of Favor?
abstract: The University of California will no longer use SAT and ACT scores in admissions decisions. Critics say the tests put less wealthy students at a disadvantage.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — The University of California’s decision this past week to stop requiring the SAT and ACT tests for admissions renewed a debate that could be a prompt on a college application: Are the tests that were first deployed to diversify the Ivy League beyond rich prep schoolers a worthwhile yardstick, or are they, as one U.C. regent put it, “a proxy for privilege”?

headline: China Deploys Propaganda Machine to Defend Move Against Hong Kong
abstract: State-run news media depicted the proposed national security laws as necessary to protect the rule of the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: China’s propaganda machine went into full gear as the government sought to defend new laws aimed at limiting dissent and protest in Hong Kong.

headline: What a Week’s Disasters Tell Us About Climate and the Pandemic
abstract: Extreme weather presents an even bigger threat when economies are crashing and ordinary people are stretched to their limits.
lead_paragraph: The hits came this week in rapid succession: A cyclone slammed into the Indian megacity of Kolkata, pounding rains breached two dams in the Midwestern United States, and on Thursday came warning that the Atlantic hurricane season could be severe.

headline: Long Limbs Helped Propel T. Rex Up the Dinosaur Food Chain
abstract: The apex predator wasn’t a quick runner because of its heft, but its lanky limbs ensured it could amble efficiently for hours.
lead_paragraph: Surviving in the Cretaceous wasn’t a sprint, it was a marathon. And Tyrannosaurus rex was built to amble for hours, new research reveals. That attribute might have helped propel the carnivore to the top of the food chain, researchers suggest.

headline: Will the Coronavirus Kill What’s Left of Americans’ Faith in Washington?
abstract: In 2019, just 17 percent of Americans said they trusted the federal government to do the right thing. The pandemic appears to be eroding their faith even more.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Millner, a nurse in Hershey, Pa., was born the year Dwight D. Eisenhower was re-elected. The economy was booming, and trust was high: When national pollsters began asking the question two years later, about three-quarters of Americans said they trusted the federal government to do the right thing.

headline: As Sports Begin Reopening, Athletes Weigh the Health Risks
abstract: Some must consider their own underlying health conditions that make them particularly susceptible to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Baker, 23, a gold medal-winning Olympic swimmer, began wearing masks on airplanes long before the coronavirus outbreak began to avoid contracting illnesses that are especially hard for her to shake off because she has Crohn’s disease, which causes inflammation in the digestive system.

headline: A Feud in Wolf-Kink Erotica Raises a Deep Legal Question
abstract: What do copyright and authorship mean in the crowdsourced realm known as the Omegaverse?
lead_paragraph: Addison Cain was living in Kyoto, volunteering at a shrine and studying indigenous Japanese religion. She was supposed to be working on a scholarly book about her research, but started writing intensely erotic Batman fan fiction instead.

headline: ‘I Am Just Hong Kong’: A City’s Fate in China’s Hands
abstract: This hybrid of East and West may have reached the limits of its middle ground.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong was born at the crossroad of empires, a hybrid of British and Chinese parentage. It may fade there, too.

headline: The Artisans Behind Italian Fashion Tremble at Their Future
abstract: The industry has returned to work, but it’s far from business as usual for small suppliers to luxury brands and retailers.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, some of the most intricately embroidered fabrics in the world, like those found in garments designed by Giorgio Armani, Valentino, Etro and Prada, have come out of a duplex apartment complex in Milan, the home of a small business called Pino Grasso Ricami.

headline: Pakistan Plane Crash Leaves Grim Task: Identifying Victims From DNA
abstract: Officials were using samples from relatives to identify many of the remains pulled from the rubble and smoldering wreckage after the flight went down in a congested neighborhood of Karachi.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — The bodies were pulled one by one from the ruins of damaged buildings and the smoldering wreckage of the Pakistan International Airlines plane that had crashed a day earlier into a crowded neighborhood of Karachi: 97 of them by Saturday.

headline: N.Y. Reports Fewer Than 100 Virus Deaths for First Time Since March
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said that the Mid-Hudson region of New York would most likely start to reopen on Tuesday, and that Long Island may do so on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Sunday’s live coverage.]

headline: Can a Coach Save You From Divorce?
abstract: The blogger motivating men to care about emotional labor.
lead_paragraph: In a newsletter last year, I (cheekily) suggested that one way to get partners to do their fair share of emotional labor is to become physically incapacitated for several months, like I was when I was pregnant with my younger daughter. This week, Jancee Dunn offers a more viable solution to a mental load imbalance: Hire a coach.

headline: Together, Alone: The Car as Shelter in the Pandemic
abstract: The fears of infection from the coronavirus have created a new role in society for the automobile, where birthdays, weddings and other events are being celebrated.
lead_paragraph: The role of the automobile has been reinvented in the coronavirus era. Once just a way of getting from one place to another, the car has been turned into a mini-shelter on wheels, safe from contamination, a cocoon that allows its occupants to be inside and outside at the same time.

headline: Outrage Grows Over Boris Johnson Aide’s 260-Mile Trip During Lockdown
abstract: Dominic Cummings, the British prime minister’s top adviser, said he behaved “reasonably and legally” in driving for child care needs while coming down with the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced a torrent of calls on Saturday to dismiss his most influential adviser, Dominic Cummings, after reports that Mr. Cummings had visited relatives in northern England while he was ill with the coronavirus — a violation of Britain’s lockdown rules.

headline: This Bloody Mary Is Just as Good Without Alcohol
abstract: Gabrielle Hamilton’s recipe for the drink, Yewande Komolafe’s baked tofu, and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include Gabrielle Hamilton’s recipe for Bloody Mary mix (above), Yewande Komolafe’s baked tofu with peanut sauce and coconut-lime rice, and Dawn Perry’s berry buttermilk cake. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: How Upbeat Vaccine News Fueled a Stock Surge, and an Uproar
abstract: The desperate hunt for treatments and vaccines has changed how researchers, regulators, drug companies like Moderna, investors and journalists do their jobs.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine.]

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon keep a low profile, but they run the show.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — This is a classic Team Cox-Rathvon acrostic where a topic makes itself evident in the clues as well as in the grid, as you tease the whole thing apart — familiar territory, but still satisfying. The passage is from an 1899 book (with a gorgeous gilded Art Nouveau cover) by Mabel Wagnalls, called “Stars of the Opera,” that lionizes everyone, including the lead sopranos and the occupants of the orchestra pit. I love it when professionals who operate in the background receive proper attention, and I find that the statements made about the opera’s orchestra apply to great support staff everywhere.

headline: Are Cars Protecting Los Angeles?
abstract: The city is reviled for its sprawl-and-crawl culture, but a pandemic can change things.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — I was born in New York and spent my formative years there, so waiting makes me crazy. I’m a jaywalker and I push elevator buttons more than once. I find the shortest line to anything. I walk fast and can drive like a competitor in a video game race. I attribute these qualities to years spent trying to survive in New York’s hustle culture, and not to innate personal flaws.

headline: Contact Tracing Is Harder Than It Sounds
abstract: An elite cadre of 20th-century syphilis hunters can teach us a lot about what it takes to stop infections.
lead_paragraph: How likely are you to answer an unknown number popping up on your caller ID? And if you were to pick up, how likely is it that you would disclose personal information about yourself and your family, friends and colleagues to the stranger on the other end of the line?

headline: What if We All Vacationed at Home Again?
abstract: The past few decades have seen an explosion of international travel. But maybe a summer trapped together within our own borders is just what we need.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For us, it was supposed to be France — a big house in a soporific Breton village, with 16 members of my partner’s family. Her bon vivant father, who recently completed chemotherapy, had paid for the rental to celebrate with two weeks surrounded by grandkids and half-empty bottles of Beaujolais. Everyone had been looking forward to it all year. It is only in the past two weeks, after France announced an 18 billion euro (about $20 billion) “Marshall Plan” to place its vital tourist sector on life support, that I finally conceded that the trip isn’t going to happen.

headline: In Mexico, ‘Roma’ Lit a Fire for Workers’ Rights
abstract: A role in Alfonso Cuarón’s film showed me how art can provide a voice for the disenfranchised.
lead_paragraph: This  essay is part of The Big Ideas, a special section of The Times’s philosophy series, The Stone, in which more than a dozen artists, writers and thinkers answer the question, “Why does art matter?” The entire series can be found here.

headline: U.N. Documents Abductions and Torture Of Iraqi Protesters
abstract: Protesters have long said threats and abductions by militias were routine. United Nations investigators have begun to substantiate the claims.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Hundreds of people were killed and thousands wounded in the antigovernment protests in Iraq last fall and winter that halted political life and immobilized cities from Baghdad to Basra.

headline: Simple Stretches to Combat All That Sitting
abstract: Done correctly, these restorative stretches, working on muscles from your eyes to your toes, really do make you feel better.
lead_paragraph: Whether you are hunched over a laptop in a makeshift work space or slouched on the couch binge-watching TV, you know — and can feel — that sitting for long periods can sabotage your health. From head to toe, these simple exercises can provide relief, restore muscle function and improve posture.

headline: N.B.A. in Talks to Resume Season at Walt Disney World Resort
abstract: The league is in discussions with its players’ union and the Walt Disney Company about restarting its season — suspended since March 11 — at the Orlando-based resort in late July.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. is in the early stages of discussions with the Walt Disney Company to restart its suspended season in late July at the Walt Disney World Resort in Florida, a league spokesman said Saturday.

headline: John Macurdy, Stalwart Bass in Roles Large and Small, Dies at 91
abstract: During a 38-year career with the Metropolitan Opera, he sang 1,001 performances, drawing notice for his performances in Wagner, Verdi and Mozart.
lead_paragraph: John Macurdy, an American bass who belonged to a select group of solo singers who have tallied more than 1,000 performances at the Metropolitan Opera, died on May 7 in Stamford, Conn. He was 91.

headline: Hawaii Primary Election Results 2020
abstract: Detailed results from the Hawaii presidential primary election.
lead_paragraph: Detailed results from the Hawaii presidential primary election.

headline: Covid Dreams, Trump Nightmares
abstract: Of masks, unmasking and dropping our professional masks for our medical ones.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — My corona dreams are so crazy and vibrant, with star turns by politicians, celebrities, zombies and my late mother, that sometimes as I wake, I groggily think the virus that devoured the globe has to be a dystopian vision.

headline: Crumbs for the Hungry but Windfalls for the Rich
abstract: Billions are going to zillionaires under the guise of pandemic relief.
lead_paragraph: While President Trump and his allies in Congress seek to tighten access to food stamps, they are showing compassion for one group: zillionaires. Their economic rescue package quietly allocated $135 billion — yes, that’s “billion” with a “b” — for the likes of wealthy real estate developers.

headline: Why Does the U.S. Military Celebrate White Supremacy?
abstract: It is time to rename bases for American heroes — not racist traitors.
lead_paragraph: The white supremacist who murdered nine black churchgoers in Charleston, S.C., five years ago dispensed with the fiction that the Confederate battle flag was an innocuous symbol of “Southern pride.” A murderer’s manifesto describing the killings as the start of a race war — combined with photos of the killer brandishing a pistol and a rebel flag — made it impossible to ignore the connection between Confederate ideology and a blood-drenched tradition of racial terrorism that dates back to the mid-19th century in the American South.

headline: The End of the New World Order
abstract: The coronavirus is provoking anti-globalist paranoia, but the real globalism is disintegrating.
lead_paragraph: It’s a mistake to believe most conspiracy theories, but it’s also a mistake to assume that they bear no relation to reality. Some are just insane emanations or deliberate misinformation. But others exaggerate and misread important trends rather than denying them, or offer implausible explanations for mysteries that nonetheless linger unexplained.

headline: It’s My 100th Birthday. It’s Been Quite a Century.
abstract: I grew up in the Great Depression and served in World War II. Trust me when I say America will survive this crisis, too.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like reaching the age of 100 to make a person want to get a grip on life, to start looking for that elusive way forward, especially when it comes during a pandemic propelled by a devilish virus that is everywhere and nowhere.

headline: How Cubans Lost Faith in Revolution
abstract: In this election year, the key for American politicians to understanding Cuba’s politics is understanding its people and the promises of a better life that were not kept.
lead_paragraph: GUANABACOA, Cuba — There was nothing Caridad Limonta would not do for her dear mother, even if it meant fulfilling her strange wish to be buried with two pairs of socks.

headline: A Hidden Origin Story of the CBD Craze
abstract: The cure-all debate over the cannabis compound has distracted from the serious — and seriously odd — back story of how cannabidiol conquered the country.
lead_paragraph: Long before CBD had become a trendy wellness elixir found in juice and moisturizer and ice cream and dog treats; before corporate chains like Walgreens and Sephora had decided to sell it; and way before Kim Kardashian West had thrown a CBD-themed baby shower, a ragtag crew of activists, doctors, writers and marijuana farmers met up on an early winter evening in 2011. They sat in a circle at a house in the hills a few hours north of San Francisco — where wine country becomes weed country — to discuss the therapeutic potential of CBD, and how to get people to take it seriously.

headline: Federal Scientists Finally Publish Remdesivir Data
abstract: A clinical trial led to the authorization of the only drug shown to work in Covid-19 patients. But until now, few experts had seen the numbers.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a month after federal scientists claimed that an experimental drug had helped patients severely ill with the coronavirus, the research has been published.

headline: Fire at San Francisco’s Pier 45 Destroys a Quarter of Its Warehouses
abstract: One firefighter was injured in the four-alarm blaze at Fisherman’s Wharf early on Saturday morning, officials said.
lead_paragraph: About 150 firefighters battled a four-alarm blaze that destroyed a quarter of the structures on Pier 45 in San Francisco early on Saturday morning, the authorities said.

headline: Rattled by a Pandemic, People Turn to Leaders — Any Leaders
abstract: Placing faith in a leader with little control over a virus may seem irrational, but it fills a very human need.
lead_paragraph: As world leaders grapple with when and how to safely reopen their countries, many are also facing a political problem: how to maintain support as they oversee tanking economies, stifling restrictions and staggering death tolls.

headline: Less Is More as an Art Museum Reopens
abstract: With timed tickets and limited entry, each visitor to the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston had a studio apartment’s worth of space to themselves.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — They waited patiently in line in 80-degree heat, standing on large blue stickers placed six feet apart, to enter the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston — the first major American art museum to reopen since the country went into lockdown in March.

headline: How to Make an Envelope From Newspaper
abstract: Dress up your letters in all the news that’s fit to print.
lead_paragraph: You may not be able to embrace your friends and family for a while, but letter writing is a great (and screenless) way of letting them know you care from afar. And why not give your penpals a real treat by dressing up your letter in all the news that’s fit to print? You’ll need some folding skills and a roll of either clear or decorative tape.

headline: Is It Time to Stop Clapping for Health Care Workers? An Organizer Thinks So
abstract: “To maintain the positive impact that it’s had so far, it’s best to stop at its peak,” said Annemarie Plas, who started #ClapForOurCarers.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday nights, Britons bang pots and pans and let out hearty cheers of support for doctors and nurses who care for coronavirus patients and for other essential workers amid the pandemic.

headline: The Mystery of McGuffin Manor
abstract: Andrew Chaikin’s Sunday puzzle shines bright.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s grid is a surprise and a delight, the type that makes me want to grab any poor solver I see on the street and explain every loving dimension. Andrew Chaikin, who also goes by Kid Beyond, is a San Francisco-based musician and game inventor, a constructor of pleasurable mind-benders for us and elsewhere (please read his notes and check out Puzzle Bouquet as well; he’s also philanthropic).

headline: Black Coronavirus Patients Land in Hospitals More Often, Study Finds
abstract: Compared to white or Hispanic patients, black patients seeking care have more advanced cases of Covid-19, researchers reported.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus spread across the United States, sweeping through low-income, densely populated communities, black and Hispanic patients have been dying at higher rates than white patients.

headline: The Project Behind a Front Page Full of Names
abstract: A presentation of obituaries and death notices from newspapers around the country tries to frame incalculable loss.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Rafael Leonardo Black, Solitary and Self-Trained Artist, Dies at 71
abstract: After laboring for years in his small Brooklyn apartment, he had his first New York gallery show when he was 64. He died from complications of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: In Joe Flacco, Jets Get a Credible Backup for Sam Darnold
abstract: For a pittance, the Jets address a major need by adding Flacco, the Super Bowl 47 most valuable player.
lead_paragraph: The Jets are hoping that their most prominent addition this off-season — a former most valuable player of the Super Bowl — never takes a snap for them. Such is the plight of a backup quarterback, and that is the new role for the veteran Joe Flacco, who agreed to a one-year deal on Friday as he recovers from neck surgery.

headline: Elizabeth Warren to Hold Big-Dollar Fund-Raiser for Joe Biden
abstract: Ms. Warren, in the mix for the Democratic vice-presidential nomination, had made opposition to fund-raising events with big donors a central part of her own presidential bid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Elizabeth Warren, whose full-throated opposition to high-dollar fund-raising events was a central tenet of her presidential campaign, has agreed to host such a gathering of donors for Joseph R. Biden Jr., the presumptive Democratic nominee, who is considering her to be his running mate.

headline: Trump Bans Travel From Brazil, Citing Pandemic
abstract: As the United States marked the Memorial Day weekend, President Trump golfed, some Americans flocked to beaches and the death toll neared 100,000. And in Britain, the prime minister said he would not fire an aide for driving across the country while infected.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow live updates on the coronavirus here.

headline: Afghan Sides Agree to Rare Cease-Fire During Eid al-Fitr
abstract: President Ashraf Ghani welcomed the Taliban’s announcement of a three-day cessation of violence after months of intensifying attacks.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban and the Afghan government announced a cease-fire for the three days of the Islamic festival Eid al-Fitr, which starts on Sunday in Afghanistan, offering the war-torn nation a rare respite from violence that has been intensifying.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Lance’ and ‘Underestimate the Girl’
abstract: Watch a celebrity profile or two: A portrait of Lance Armstrong airs on ESPN, while a documentary about Kate Nash is available to rent.
lead_paragraph: 30 FOR 30: LANCE 9 p.m. on ESPN. Nearly eight years after an investigation by the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency found that Lance Armstrong had been using performance-enhancing drugs throughout his career — making him a pariah essentially overnight — the disgraced athlete has resurfaced to reflect on his misdeeds. This two-part documentary by the director Marina Zenovich (“Robin Williams: Come Inside My Mind”), airing as part of ESPN’s “30 for 30” series, gives him ample opportunity to do so. (Although if you’ve already made up your mind on Armstrong, the former superstar cyclist, this movie might not change it.) The film packs plenty of back story, chronicling his early days as a cyclist, his battle with testicular cancer and the demise of his reputation after he admitted to doping in 2013. Zenovich doesn’t shy away from tough questions, and by interviewing Armstrong’s family, friends, rivals and others, she manages to create an objective portrait of a shunned star. The second half of the film airs May 31.

headline: Corrections: May 24, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 24, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 5 about the choreographer Bill T. Jones misstated the name of his company. It is the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Company, not the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In the Fight to Be ‘Just Hong Kong,’ a Daunting New Salvo
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 24, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “At the end of the day, we have to accept that we answer to one country. And that country is more and more powerful.”

headline: Kim Jong-un Moves to Increase North Korea’s Nuclear Strength
abstract: After another weekslong absence from public view, Mr. Kim convened his top military body to promote top aides specializing in nuclear and missile forces.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — After another weekslong absence from public view, North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, has convened the country’s top military-governing body, outlining “new policies for further increasing” its nuclear capabilities and promoting top weapons officials, the North’s state-run media said on Sunday.

headline: ‘I Was a Little Nervous as I Finished and Dropped Back Onto the Sidewalk’
abstract: Exercising in public, a Valentine’s treat and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Hong Kong Police Fire Tear Gas as Protesters Resist China’s Grip
abstract: Marchers defied social distancing rules and a water cannon to demonstrate against Beijing’s plan for new security legislation in the territory.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Thousands of protesters swarmed some of Hong Kong’s busiest neighborhoods on Sunday, singing, chanting and erecting roadblocks of torn-up bricks and debris, as the police repeatedly fired tear gas, pepper spray and a water cannon during the city’s largest street mobilization in months.

headline: Remembering the 100,000 Lives Lost to Coronavirus in America
abstract: As the U.S. reached a grim milestone in the outbreak, The New York Times gathered names of the dead and memories of their lives from obituaries across the country.
lead_paragraph: As the U.S. reached a grim milestone in the outbreak, The New York Times gathered names of the dead and memories of their lives from obituaries across the country.

headline: Trump Sows Doubt on Voting. It Keeps Some People Up at Night.
abstract: A group of worst-case scenario planners — mostly Democrats, but also some anti-Trump Republicans — have been gaming out how to respond to various doomsday options for the 2020 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In October, President Trump declares a state of emergency in major cities in battleground states, like Milwaukee and Detroit, banning polling places from opening.

headline: Too Many Memorial Days
abstract: For one veteran who’s also a Times journalist, there are too many fallen friends, and unending wars mean there will most likely be more.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: What Happens if a Hurricane Hits During the Pandemic?
abstract: Florida is trying to figure out the daunting prospect of asking residents to evacuate for their safety during a storm after asking them to stay at home for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It’s deep into the summer and a massive hurricane looms off the Florida coast, threatening enormous destruction and widespread power blackouts. In normal times, in such a scenario, the orders would come down for millions of coastal residents: Evacuate.

headline: Pay Cuts Become a Tool for Some Companies to Avoid Layoffs
abstract: “Shared sacrifice” in the white-collar ranks aims to avoid the cost of staffing up again. With no end to the crisis in sight, it is a leap of faith.
lead_paragraph: It was late and Martin A. Kits van Heyningen feared he was letting the team down at the company he co-founded, KVH Industries. Rather than lay off workers in response to the coronavirus pandemic, he had decided to cut salaries, and when he emailed a video explaining his decision at 3 a.m. last month, he was prepared for a barrage of complaints.

headline: Summer in Lockdown: 5 Families Mull a Spoiled Season
abstract: New York City’s 1.1 million schoolchildren and their families are steeling themselves for an unusual summer.
lead_paragraph: Dolly and Amaya Diaz were hoping to spend July and August in the sun, playing softball. Nael Genao was planning a big trip out of the country. Amy Tsai’s five children were supposed to be in math programs or day camp, finally leaving her time and space to catch up on work.

headline: For Some Italians, the Future of Work Looks Like the Past
abstract: As the coronavirus drastically reorders society and economies, more Italians are returning to the agricultural jobs of their grandparents.
lead_paragraph: CORCOLLE, Italy — On a small farm outside Rome, workers crouched in the corridors of a cornfield and tended to stalks for the coming harvest. The ones from Morocco, Romania and Nigeria knew exactly what to do. It was the new Italian hires who needed help.

headline: After 17 Years Underground, Cicadas Stage a 2020 Southern Invasion
abstract: The big and noisy insects have started to emerge and are looking to mate in Virginia, West Virginia and North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: They break through the ground, like the undead emerging from graves.

headline: Memorial Day, Testing, Hong Kong: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: The End of the Office as We Know It
abstract: The economy is reopening, but office buildings remain empty — and may stay that way, permanently.
lead_paragraph: Holiday weekends seem a little strange when Saturdays feel the same as Tuesdays and you can’t really go anywhere, but have a good Memorial Day all the same! Here’s what you need to know in business and tech for the short week ahead.

headline: Netanyahu Corruption Trial Begins, Taking Israel Into Uncharted Territory
abstract: The prime minister’s trial is expected to last a year or more, with the first witnesses not expected to testify for months. He has long maintained his innocence.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Three electoral challenges by a popular former army chief could not unseat Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. A clear majority of Israeli lawmakers could not set aside their differences long enough to oust him.

headline: Why China’s Move to Rein In Hong Kong Is Just the Start
abstract: Xi Jinping’s China, emboldened by its handling of the coronavirus pandemic, no longer seems constrained by the threat of international rebuke.
lead_paragraph: China’s move to strip away another layer of Hong Kong’s autonomy was not a rash impulse. It was a deliberate act, months in the making. It took into account the risks of international umbrage and reached the reasonable assumption that there would not be a significant geopolitical price to pay.

headline: New York Prepares for Two More Regions to Open
abstract: With the Mid-Hudson and Long Island regions set to reopen this week, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced new safety measures for public transit in those areas.
lead_paragraph: With the Mid-Hudson and Long Island regions poised to start reopening this week, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced new public transit safety measures on Sunday in an effort to ensure public health as those areas emerge from lockdown.

headline: They Survived the Worst Battles of World War II. And Died of the Virus.
abstract: Inside the Holyoke Soldiers’ Home was a man who had served as a jailer to Hitler’s top aide. A man who had rescued Japanese kamikaze pilots from the sea. A man who carried memories of a concentration camp.
lead_paragraph: HOLYOKE, Mass. — In 1945, James Leach Miller returned from the war and said nothing.

headline: Push to Reopen Houses of Worship in Europe and Mideast Brings Perils and Tensions
abstract: In Germany, 40 new cases were confirmed among the faithful in Frankfurt. France restarted church services this weekend. And protesters in the West Bank demanded that mosques reopen for the Eid holiday.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As nations weigh the calculus of reopening parts of society after locking down because of the coronavirus, Germany has plunged ahead after bringing its outbreak under control, reopening houses of worship and allowing the faithful to gather again in larger numbers.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Make Momofuku’s bo ssam, or take the Memorial Day holiday to bake an Earl Grey tea cake, peanut butter brownies, or an easy rhubarb trifle.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s funny, the things that bring happiness in these weird, unsettled times. I thrill to routine: the morning bike ride to see the sun rise; the hurried lunch alongside my children in the kitchen; Kai Ryssdal on the radio in the evenings, as I chop and steam, slice and fry. Weekends unmoor me. Anything could happen. Nothing might. So I shower a pork butt with salt and sugar and let it cure on Saturday, and Sunday it spends in the oven: my weekly bo ssam (above), David Chang and Peter Meehan’s gift to the world. At least I’ve got that.

headline: You’re Getting Used to Masks. Will You Wear a Face Shield?
abstract: The clear plastic guards may be easier to wear, disinfect and reuse than cloth or surgical face coverings, although they don’t entirely replace the need for masks.
lead_paragraph: The debate over whether Americans should wear face masks to control coronavirus transmission has been settled. Governments and businesses now require or at least recommend them in many public settings. But as parts of the country reopen, some doctors want you to consider another layer of personal protective equipment in your daily life: clear plastic face shields.

headline: The Unexpected Joys of Lockdown
abstract: Despite the tug of our digital realm, life’s true pleasures remain in the analog world.
lead_paragraph: “Arithmetic,” wrote Carl Sandburg in a famous poem, “is where numbers fly like pigeons in and out of your head.”

headline: The Most Patriotic Thing You Can Do Right Now
abstract: Our nation is rising, however imperfectly, to meet the challenge posed by the coronavirus pandemic. That needs to be said more often.
lead_paragraph: Thank you, Americans.

headline: My Futile Struggle for Stillness
abstract: I am isolating in a Mexican village, alternating between being impressed by my capacity for serenity and wanting to strangle myself for descending into triteness of Eat, Pray, Love proportions.
lead_paragraph: ZIPOLITE, Mexico — When in mid-March “Quedate En Casa,” or “stay at home,” became the coronavirus rallying cry for the Spanish-speaking world, I had just arrived from El Salvador to the village of Zipolite on the coast of southeastern Oaxaca State in Mexico.

headline: The Fall of Autumn: Live Performance Producers Are Giving Up on 2020
abstract: Uncertainty about the coronavirus and the challenge of protecting audiences and artists is prompting many prominent presenters to wait till next year.
lead_paragraph: In the world of performing arts, the coronavirus pandemic has already sunk summer. Now it is felling fall.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: 100,000: The Names Behind a Grim Toll
abstract: Readers express their appreciation for what one calls a “heartbreaking, breathtaking memorial.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New Vaccine Team Leader
abstract: “Who would be more qualified to head a fast-track effort to develop a coronavirus vaccine than someone who had run a major pharmaceutical company?” Also: The Democratic convention; Denmark.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: June Willenz, Champion of Women in the Military, Dies at 95
abstract: She didn’t serve in the military herself. But she saw the armed services denying equal benefits to female veterans, and she crusaded to make a difference.
lead_paragraph: June A. Willenz, a longtime human rights activist and champion of women in the military, died on May 3 in Bethesda, Md. She was 95.

headline: College Students Colonize the Divided Romania of ‘Mad Forest’
abstract: In a livestream production of Caryl Churchill’s 1990 tale of riot-torn Bucharest, quarantined Bard acting students grapple with revolution.
lead_paragraph: Revolution has come to Bucharest, and a society has exploded into shards. A multitude of writhing, flailing, falling bodies fills the screen during the climax of the second act of Ashley Tata’s fervently inventive new streaming version of Caryl Churchill’s “Mad Forest,” a coproduction of Theater for a New Audience and the Fisher Center at Bard College.

headline: Sal Capozucca, Rock Drummer with a Real Estate Gig, Dies at 65
abstract: He had a day job as a broker specializing in townhouses, but his heart belonged with his rock ’n’ roll drum set and his local band. He died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: World TeamTennis Plans to Play Its Entire Season in West Virginia
abstract: The league is planning to have a three-week season featuring nine teams from July 12 to Aug. 1 at the Greenbrier resort in White Sulphur Springs.
lead_paragraph: World TeamTennis, the coed professional tennis league that has operated in summers after Wimbledon since the 1970s, has chosen a site in West Virginia to conduct its entire 2020 season, according to several people familiar with the league’s plans.

headline: Trump Promotes Posts From Racist and Sexist Twitter Feed
abstract: On a somber Memorial Day weekend, the president did not mention the mounting coronavirus toll and instead retweeted personal attacks on his political rivals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a weekend when the nation was bracing for the approaching toll of 100,000 lives lost to the coronavirus and honoring the many more people who have died in wars, President Trump amplified a series of demeaning personal attacks from a supporter with a history of racist and sexist online commentary.

headline: Gallery Sues Landlord, Claiming Covid-19 Shutdown Voids Lease
abstract: The lawsuit contends that since the Venus Over Manhattan gallery is closed by government orders during the pandemic, the lease should be terminated.
lead_paragraph: In early March, the Venus Over Manhattan gallery on the Upper East Side mounted an exhibition of paintings, drawings and wall reliefs by the artist Roy De Forest, the biggest presentation of his work in New York City since 1975.

headline: There Are No Flag-Draped Coffins
abstract: As the number of deaths in the ranks of veterans continues to rise, we need to revisit our enduring commitment to their care.
lead_paragraph: I had loaned my body to America. That’s what the Navy doctor said, as he poked and prodded me in his office during my separation physical. After eight years in the Marines and two wars, I was in remarkably good shape, so I didn’t expect to receive any disability from the Department of Veterans Affairs. However, my doctor wasn’t entirely convinced. When he asked whether I suffered chronic pain from the grenade shrapnel in my back, I said no. When he asked whether I suffered blackouts or short-term memory loss after a handful of head-ringing encounters with improvised explosive devices, I again said no. Still, he recommended me for disability. The reason: hearing loss. I had passed my audiogram but, according to the doctor, that didn’t matter. Someday, I’d likely need hearing aids, he said, and the government had to budget for that. “You loaned society your body,” he said. “It’s our obligation to return it to you with interest.”

headline: Pixar Short Film ‘Out’ Features Studio’s First Gay Main Character
abstract: The animated film follows a gay man’s journey into acceptance as he prepares to move into a city with his boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: The man nervously practices in front of his dog how he is going to tell his parents he is gay.

headline: Mory Kante, Million-Selling African Singer and Bandleader, Dies at 70
abstract: Incorporating electric instruments and elements of Western pop, he gave many Western listeners an accessible introduction to African music.
lead_paragraph: Mory Kante, a Guinean singer, kora player and bandleader who built a worldwide audience for music rooted in West Africa, died on Friday in Conakry, Guinea. He was 70.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Hong Kong protests, Afghan cease-fire, Jacinda Ardern: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of demonstrators streamed into some of Hong Kong’s busiest neighborhoods on Sunday in the city’s largest street mobilization in months. The police responded with tear gas, pepper spray and water cannons.

headline: Michael Halkias, Who Promised Wish Fulfillment at Banquet Hall, Dies at 82
abstract: His Grand Prospect Hall in Brooklyn hosted four decades’ worth of events, and he and his wife, Alice, made the hall’s commercials a late-night TV staple.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Boris Johnson Backs Top Aide Accused of Flouting Lockdown Rules
abstract: Despite the appearance of a double standard, the British leader defended Dominic Cummings’s travel, even as the aide was falling ill.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson, defying a storm of criticism, said on Sunday that he would not dismiss his most influential adviser, Dominic Cummings, for breaching Britain’s lockdown rules by driving across the country to visit relatives, even when he was falling ill with the coronavirus.

headline: Hana Kimura, Japanese Wrestler and Star of Netflix Series, Dies at 22
abstract: She was featured on the reality series “Terrace House: Tokyo.’’
lead_paragraph: Hana Kimura, a Japanese professional wrestler who starred in the Netflix reality series “Terrace House: Tokyo,” has died. She was 22.

headline: The Virus Has Wrecked Some Families. It Has Brought Others Closer.
abstract: With little else to do, many people are savoring the time they have for simple pleasures like eating and dancing with the ones they love.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has smothered New York City’s economy and sealed off its museums and concert halls like crime scenes. Many people have filled the void with something that has always been there, close at hand but often crowded out of reach: their families.

headline: Suriname’s President Shrugs Off Murder Sentence in Re-election Bid
abstract: If President Desi Bouterse can hang on to immunity, past crimes could become just another chapter in his four-decade battle to stay in power.
lead_paragraph: Suriname’s president looked straight at the judge as she read his sentence for crimes committed during the 1982 political purge that cemented his grip on the small South American nation.

headline: What Just Happened?
abstract: You might think twice about Andrea Carla Michaels and Victor Barocas’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — First, I wish you all a contemplative and peaceful Memorial Day. It’s not the same during the pandemic, I know, but I hope that in lieu of the picnics and vacations, we can turn our attention to the men and women who have given their lives while serving in the United States military.

headline: As Trump Pushes for Reopenings, Congregations Choose Safety Over Haste
abstract: Houses of worship are balancing the desire to reopen and worship together against the health consequences of moving too fast.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — For the first time in weeks, Jason Dees looked out as he preached on Sunday and saw faces, instead of just a camera lens. The group of Christ Covenant Church worshipers was considerably smaller than before the coronavirus pandemic — 40 people this week, wearing masks as they sang and prayed, a small fraction of the congregation’s 500 members — but they were there.

headline: Camp Is Canceled. Three More Months of Family Time. Help.
abstract: We’re homemakers, stay-at-home parents and paid workers. All at the same time.
lead_paragraph: Summer is upon us, and many summer camps across the Northeast — and other parts of the country — have been canceled. We all know what this means: three more months of family togetherness! 270 more meals! 540 if you have teenagers! All without the nominal structure of online school! Who’s excited?

headline: Florida Law Restricting Felon Voting Is Unconstitutional, Judge Rules
abstract: A federal judge said the law would result in discrimination against felons who cannot afford to pay court fines and fees.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A Florida law requiring people with serious criminal convictions to pay court fines and fees before they can register to vote is unconstitutional, a federal judge ruled on Sunday, declaring that such a requirement would amount to a poll tax and discriminate against felons who cannot afford to pay.

headline: Trump Tweets and Golfs, but Makes No Mention of Virus’s Toll
abstract: Coronavirus deaths in the United States approached a staggering 100,000, a number the president once predicted would never be reached.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Trump’s motorcade pulled into his golf club in Virginia on an overcast Sunday, a small group of protesters waited outside the entrance. One held up a sign.

headline: C.D.C. Warns of ‘Aggressive’ Rats Searching for Food During Shutdowns
abstract: “They’re simply turning on each other” after being deprived of food and waste generated by restaurants that have closed during the pandemic, an expert said.
lead_paragraph: Humans are not the only ones who miss dining out.

headline: The New Model Media Star Is Famous Only to You
abstract: With short videos and paid newsletters, everyone from superstars to half-forgotten former athletes and even journalists can, as one tech figure put it, “monetize individuality.”
lead_paragraph: Back in March, I was trying to persuade my dad to stop taking the subway to work in Manhattan and join me upstate. So I paid $75 to Leonard Marshall, a retired New York Giants defensive lineman we both loved in the 1980s, to send the message.

headline: Biden Can Beat Trump … if He Doesn’t Blow It
abstract: Joe being stuck at home during an election year may turn out to be a good thing.
lead_paragraph: As the United States’ death toll raced toward 100,000, Donald Trump went golfing.

headline: He Died at War. The Pandemic Gave Me Time to Grieve.
abstract: My partner, Diego Pongo, was killed in Iraq in March. More than two months later, the pandemic has paused everything, including his funeral.
