lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A senior Department of Interior official violated federal ethics rules by using his position to try to get a family member a job at the Environmental Protection Agency, the Interior Department’s internal watchdog said in a report published Friday.

headline: Economic Giants Are Restarting. Here’s What It Means for Climate Change.
abstract: Want to know whether the world can avert catastrophe? Watch the recovery plans coming out now in Europe, China and the United States.
lead_paragraph: As countries begin rolling out plans to restart their economies after the brutal shock inflicted by the coronavirus pandemic, the three biggest producers of planet-warming gases — the European Union, the United States and China — are writing scripts that push humanity in very different directions.

headline: Renault Is Slashing Its Work Force. Other Carmakers May Follow.
abstract: The French carmaker said it would close assembly lines and abandon China as sales plunge. Other carmakers are expected to take similarly harsh measures.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — About eight million people around the world earn their living making cars and trucks. It’s becoming clearer that not all of them will come out of the pandemic with jobs.

headline: Charges Recommended Against 3 Officers Involved in Violent N.Y. Arrest
abstract: The departmental charges would be in connection with a May 2 incident in the East Village during which an officer sat on a man’s neck.
lead_paragraph: Investigators with the New York Police Department have recommended misconduct charges against three police officers, including one who sat and knelt on the neck and upper torso of a man he was arresting, a maneuver similar to the one used in the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis, two people familiar with the matter said.

headline: If You’ve Got Lemons, Make Limoncello
abstract: You’ll also need alcohol, sugar and, most of all, patience.
lead_paragraph: Limoncello is a vibrantly colored digestif that goes down easy on a hot summer’s day. Although the sweet liqueur is most often served, chilled, in a shot glass, it is meant to be sipped slowly after your meal.

headline: Inside an Extraordinary G.O.P. Event: ‘Pressing Flesh and Kissing Babies’ Again
abstract: At the South Carolina event, attended by Senators Lindsey Graham and Tim Scott, there were few masks and no social distancing — and that was the point.
lead_paragraph: CONWAY, S.C. — The first mention of the coronavirus pandemic was a joke.

headline: Emma Amos, Painter Who Challenged Racism and Sexism, Dies at 83
abstract: Early in her career she created brightly colored scenes of black middle-class domestic life. Her later work was increasingly personal and experimental.
lead_paragraph: Emma Amos, an acclaimed figurative artist whose high-color paintings of women flying or falling through space were charged with racial and feminist politics, died on May 20 at her home in Bedford, N.H. She was 83.

headline: Alberto Rottura, Stylist to Boldface Names, Dies at 77
abstract: A teenage immigrant from Italy, he opened salons in Manhattan and cut the hair of Mayor Bloomberg of New York and other prominent people.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Taiwan Court Strikes Down Law Criminalizing Adultery
abstract: The decision was hailed by rights activists who said the law had disproportionately targeted women.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Taiwan’s constitutional court on Friday struck down an 85-year-old law that made adultery a crime punishable by up to a year in prison, a decision hailed by activists as a major step forward for women’s rights on the island.

headline: Rebuking China, Trump Curtails Ties to Hong Kong and Severs Them With W.H.O.
abstract: Critics say the actions would do little to blunt China’s influence and could ultimately hurt the U.S. and others.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said Friday that his administration would “begin the process” of ending the American government’s special relationship with Hong Kong, including on trade and law enforcement, and that he was withdrawing from the World Health Organization, as part of a broad effort to retaliate against China.

headline: The Country Is Reopening. My Patients Are Still Suffering.
abstract: Nursing home residents. Cabdrivers. Immigrants. Covid-19 has become a disease of the vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: I stood at my patient’s bedside as she picked at the sheets, eyes roving, seemingly unaware of my presence. When I placed my stethoscope on her chest, she started to moan. It was a sad sound, high-pitched and pleading. I set down the stethoscope and touched her hair with a gloved hand. “It’s OK,” I said through my N95, hoping that she could understand the meaning if not the words. “You’re safe. We’re taking care of you.”

headline: It’s Not Whether You Were Exposed to the Virus. It’s How Much.
abstract: The pathogen is proving a familiar adage: The dose makes the poison.
lead_paragraph: When experts recommend wearing masks, staying at least six feet away from others, washing your hands frequently and avoiding crowded spaces, what they’re really saying is: Try to minimize the amount of virus you encounter.

headline: What Birds Do for Us and What We Can Do for Them
abstract: We want to return to our lives and livelihoods without sacrificing the natural world that supports us in body and in spirit.
lead_paragraph: This spring, the dawn chorus sounds different. In the dark hours before sunrise, my yard whistles, chips, hoots, and trills with deafening birdsong. The birds caroling at my home in Virginia — robins, mockingbirds, warblers, cardinals, titmice, finches — sound more numerous, boisterous and energetic than in past years, all singing raucously at the same time, like a poetry slam where everyone’s reading at once.

headline: N.H.L. Awards Offer Closure to Disrupted Season
abstract: The league doled out honors on Thursday as it prepared to begin an abnormal postseason.
lead_paragraph: The National Hockey League announced the recipients of four of its annual awards Thursday, two months after the regular season was abruptly halted, then canceled.

headline: What Trump, Biden and Obama Said About the Death of George Floyd
abstract: Both President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. have called for justice for Mr. Floyd. Mr. Trump has also called protesters “thugs,” and Mr. Biden has blamed him for “incendiary tweets.”
lead_paragraph: The death of George Floyd, which set off huge and sometimes violent protests in Minneapolis, drew responses on Friday from President Trump, his predecessor and the man who hopes to succeed him.

headline: An Artist Who Delights in the Minor Key
abstract: Moyra Davey’s work moves freely between photography, video and writing but is united in its unwavering attention to the objects and accidents of everyday life.
lead_paragraph: In “I Confess,” the final essay in Moyra Davey’s new collection of prose pieces, “Index Cards” (2020), she recalls losing, as a child at school, a pencil given to her by her mother. Thinking it was stolen, she began to sob. Her teacher asked her: “Pourquoi as-tu tant de peine pour un crayon?” (Why so much grief over a pencil?) That question has remained with Davey, the New York-based artist, for 50 years. The anecdote — the triviality of the pencil, the pinprick of a particular line — is emblematic of her art, in which tension comes from small traumas and everyday talismans. Moving between video, photography and prose, Davey’s work is bound by idiosyncratic references and quasi-dreamed connections. An acute chronicler of quotidian life, she is both the narrator and protagonist of her work. She paces her apartment hallways in her videos; she photographs the dust under her bed; she reads and writes restlessly, hoping to find what Walter Benjamin called the “tiny spark of accident” that will set off stray thoughts and images. “Index Cards,” which she wrote between 2003 to 2019, reads like a serial novel and distills Davey’s methodology: Her art is rooted in finding a way to practice and is a record of its own creation.

headline: Rules, Rescheduled Games and a Covenant Worth Preserving
abstract: The Premier League has finally resisted the temptation to pretend the 2019-20 season never happened. Doing so would have ruptured the bond between fans and the sport, perhaps forever.
lead_paragraph: If you are enjoying this newsletter every Friday, please pass it on to a friend (or four) and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.

headline: We Work in an Amazon Warehouse. We Didn’t Sign Up to Be Heroes.
abstract: Thanks for the flattering commercials, but we’re about to lose our hazard pay.
lead_paragraph: Thanks for the flattering commercials, but we’re about to lose our hazard pay.

headline: We Work in an Amazon Warehouse. We Didn’t Sign Up to Be Heroes.
abstract: Thanks for the flattering commercials, but we’re about to lose our hazard pay.
lead_paragraph: While Amazon may glorify its workers with sentimental commercials, thanking them for their heroic bravery, it has also rolled back some policies designed to keep those very workers safe during this pandemic. And on June 1, it’s getting rid of hazard pay too, even though its facilities continue to see outbreaks of the coronavirus.

headline: Trump, Twitter and the First Amendment
abstract: Readers discuss the president’s attempted crackdown on Twitter. Also: Cate Blanchett and feminism; remembering Larry Kramer; leaving the city in the pandemic; Groucho on college football.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hire a D.J. and Turn the Music Up
abstract: Everyone loves to groove. Even in their own apartment.
lead_paragraph: At any party, there’s a moment of awkwardness, when the dance floor is still empty and guests are arriving. But then, something clicks. Maybe the lights dim. Maybe the D.J. plays That Song and the room becomes a hydra, moving together to the beat. The party has truly started.

headline: Bobby Digital Dies at 59; His Reggae Rhythms Spread Worldwide
abstract: The producer born Robert Dixon was responsible for hits like the Shabba Ranks song “Dem Bow,” which became a staple of global pop.
lead_paragraph: Robert Dixon, who as Bobby Digital became one of Jamaica’s most influential producers, and whose production of the Shabba Ranks song “Dem Bow” became a cornerstone of reggaeton and 21st-century pop, died on May 21 in Kingston. He was 59.

headline: She Accused a Coach of Abuse. Then More Than 30 Gymnasts Backed Her Up.
abstract: A gymnastics coach in New York City was suspended after Sara Allan, who trained at a gym there, wrote about her experience on Facebook. She received an outpouring of similar complaints from other gymnasts.
lead_paragraph: For two years, Sara Allan, a former gymnast who grew up in New York City, had wanted to file a complaint.

headline: President Trump Is a Doughnut
abstract: Will he concede if beaten by Joe Biden in November?
lead_paragraph: In a much-loved children’s story, “The Doughnuts” by Robert McCloskey, a boy, Homer Price, is left alone in his Uncle Ulysses’ luncheonette, where a newfangled doughnut machine has been installed. As he puts the final touches to it, Homer sets the machine in motion and finds he cannot stop doughnuts “comin’, an’ a comin’, an’ a comin’.”

headline: Black Journalists Are Exhausted
abstract: But we keep on keeping on.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, when I first pitched this essay about the unique stressors that many black journalists experience while covering the coronavirus pandemic, I pointed to the glaring racial disparities in deaths, the over-policing of black New Yorkers and Chicagoans, and the killings of Breonna Taylor, Douglas C. Lewis and Ahmaud Arbery.

headline: While Twitter Confronts Trump, Zuckerberg Keeps Facebook Out of It
abstract: The companies have similar policies on the limits of what they allow users to post. But Facebook is more permissive when the user is President Trump.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Earlier this week, as Twitter executives waded into a confrontation with President Trump, Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive of Facebook, took a very different tack: He kept his head down.

headline: Aid Swelled Incomes, but Spending Still Saw a ‘Wild’ Drop
abstract: Government assistance, mainly stimulus checks, provided an overall boost in April. With little immediate outlet, savings soared.
lead_paragraph: Even as emergency government aid gave incomes a boost in April, coronavirus lockdowns caused Americans to shut their wallets, prompting the biggest monthly drop in consumer spending on record.

headline: The Voice That Steadied Alaska
abstract: Why we told the story of Genie Chance and the Great Alaska Earthquake.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday’s episode told the story of Genie Chance, a radio reporter whose voice held together the state of Alaska in the panicked hours after an earthquake in Anchorage in 1964.

headline: Army Withdraws Nomination for Officer Involved in Deadly Niger Ambush
abstract: The decision comes amid criticism that the American military is harsher in dispensing punishment to African-American officers than to their white counterparts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Army is withdrawing the promotion of a senior Special Forces officer involved in the fatal Oct. 4, 2017, ambush in Niger, Defense Department officials said Friday. The attack resulted in the deaths of four Americans and exposed the United States military’s shortcomings in western Africa.

headline: What Tracee Ellis Ross Worried About in ‘High Note’ (It Wasn’t Her Mom)
abstract: Her character, a glamorous singer, might remind others of Diana Ross, but that’s not what the star was thinking. Really.
lead_paragraph: Tracee Ellis Ross can’t dance — at least, not the kind of dancing that requires following choreography in three-inch heels while belting disco-pop into a microphone. She learned this the hard way, preparing for “The High Note,” a new comedy out Friday on video on demand. She plays Grace Davis, a superstar singer looking for a refresh; enter her striving personal assistant (Dakota Johnson) who dreams of being a producer.

headline: Fund for Jeffrey Epstein’s Accusers Gets Attorney General’s Approval
abstract: The Virgin Islands attorney general said Mr. Epstein’s estate had agreed to what she considered sufficient protections for victims’ rights.
lead_paragraph: A plan by the estate of Jeffrey Epstein to establish a compensation fund for dozens of women who say they were sexually abused by the financier as teenagers is on the verge of becoming a reality.

headline: Bugs Bunny Is Back, and So Is the ‘Looney Tunes’ Mayhem
abstract: A new collection of shorts on HBO Max, “Looney Tunes Cartoons,” captures the look and feel of the originals.
lead_paragraph: In “Dynamite Dance,” Elmer Fudd comes at Bugs Bunny with a scythe, prompting the hare to jam a stick of lit dynamite in Elmer’s mouth.

headline: Here’s the Lady. Where’s the Gaga?
abstract: On “Chromatica,” Lady Gaga strives to bring introspection to the dance-pop that made her a star. But hallmarks like her audaciousness and sense of adventure are in shorter supply.
lead_paragraph: CARYN GANZ Lady Gaga isn’t built to go halfway. She plays sweeping statements as virtuosically as her grand piano, and shameless statements as shamelessly as her keytar. This passion has brought her one of the most fervent fandoms in pop. It’s also set up tensions between Lady Gaga the performer and Stefani Germanotta the person, which Gaga has said grew to the point that they emotionally and physically sickened her over the last decade. Her sixth album, “Chromatica,” she told Zane Lowe, is an attempt to reclaim a sound she loved from her past while retaining the humanity that was stripped from her as she was objectified and jettisoned to the realm of the hyperfamous.

headline: Their Minneapolis Restaurant Burned, but They Back the Protest
abstract: Though a Bangladeshi family lost their business in the uproar over the death of George Floyd, they support demonstrators and helped medics treat them.
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, as dawn broke through the smoke hanging over Minneapolis, the Gandhi Mahal Restaurant was severely damaged by fire. Hafsa Islam, whose father owns the Bangladeshi-Indian restaurant with members of his family, woke at 6 a.m. to hear the news.

headline: In Brazil, a President Under Fire Lashes Out at Investigators
abstract: President Jair Bolsonaro and his allies have taken an increasingly belligerent stance toward the array of criminal and legislative investigations engulfing his office.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The embattled president of Brazil stood outside his mansion on Thursday, indignant and angry, wearing a necktie patterned with assault rifles.

headline: Pressure Mounts Over Calls for Guantánamo’s Most Isolated Prisoners
abstract: Amid the coronavirus pandemic, two judges have ordered the government to arrange classified calls between some detainees and their lawyers, or explain why not.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

headline: Minneapolis, Hong Kong, Lady Gaga: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Harold and Marion Wernig, Together Until the End, Die at 87 and 85
abstract: The Wernigs, married for 67 years, shared a “fierce” love. They died on the same day of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: New York City, Battered by Outbreak, Finally Moves Toward Reopening
abstract: As many as 400,000 people could return to work starting June 8, the possible first stage of the city’s recovery after two months of isolation and economic woes.
lead_paragraph: New York City, long the epicenter of the global coronavirus crisis, is poised to start reopening in slightly more than a week, setting the stage for a slow and tentative recovery after two months of suffering, social isolation and economic hardship.

headline: Blaming China for Pandemic, Trump Says U.S. Will Leave the W.H.O.
abstract: America’s decades-long relationship with the organization has been instrumental in improving health around the world.
lead_paragraph: After spending weeks accusing the World Health Organization of helping the Chinese government cover up the early days of the coronavirus epidemic in China, President Trump said on Friday that the United States would terminate its relationship with the agency.

headline: Over Veterans’ Protests, Trump Vetoes Measure to Block Student Loan Rules
abstract: President Trump sided with Education Secretary Betsy DeVos over veterans’ groups, vetoing a measure that would have blocked new regulations that tighten access to student loan forgiveness.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump vetoed a bipartisan resolution on Friday to overturn new regulations that significantly tighten access to federal student loan forgiveness, siding with Education Secretary Betsy DeVos over veterans’ organizations that say her rules will harm veterans bilked by unscrupulous for-profit colleges.

headline: When Going to Work Means Taking a Calculated Risk
abstract: The coronavirus hasn’t gone away. But an increasing number of Canadians are heading back to workplaces that may increase their risk of infection.
lead_paragraph: Last week I spoke with one of Canada’s leading experts about the effects of working from home. But the coronavirus shutdown has also created a class of people who still go to their regular workplaces but may not want to be there.

headline: ‘The Pain Is Too Intense’: Biden Challenges White Americans
abstract: In his first formal remarks on the death of a black Minneapolis man, Joseph Biden spoke in stark terms about the everyday indignities African-Americans still suffer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., addressing a nation on edge, challenged white Americans on Friday to fully confront the enduring inequities faced by black Americans because, he said, “the pain is too intense for one community to bear alone.”

headline: Congress Plans Hearings on Racial Violence and Use of Force by the Police
abstract: A top Democrat said the House would likely weigh a federal chokehold ban as leaders in the House and Senate announced hearings on race and policing.
lead_paragraph: Top lawmakers in both parties, spurred to action by the death of a black Minnesota man in the custody of white police officers, said on Friday that they would hold hearings in the coming weeks on the use of excessive force by law enforcement and on racial violence.

headline: A Justice Dept. Skeptical of Police Abuse Cases Vows to Investigate Floyd Death
abstract: Critics pointed to the president’s and the attorney general’s full-throated support for the police and the department’s inaction on systemic policing issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr on Friday labeled the images of the death of George Floyd, a black man in Minneapolis whom a white police officer knelt on for nearly nine minutes, as “harrowing” and “deeply disturbing” and vowed that the federal investigation into his death would proceed quickly.

headline: What Happened in the Chaotic Moments Before George Floyd Died
abstract: The episode began with a report of a $20 counterfeit bill. It ended in a fatal encounter with the police, which the authorities have described in detail for the first time.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — One was a veteran of the Minneapolis Police Department who moonlighted as a security guard. The other provided security at a Salvation Army store, and spent some of his evenings at local clubs, working as a bouncer.

headline: Ex-Officer Charged in Death of George Floyd in Minneapolis
abstract: City officials on Friday were urging calm the day after protests turned violent and a police precinct went up in flames.
lead_paragraph: A white former Minneapolis police officer was charged with third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter on Friday after a shocking video of him kneeling for nearly nine minutes on the neck of a black man set off a wave of protests across the country.

headline: A Continent Reopens
abstract: Patrick Kingsley, an international correspondent, and Laetitia Vancon, a photojournalist, are driving 3,700 miles to explore the reopening of the European continent after coronavirus lockdowns.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The C.D.C. recommended big changes to the way office spaces are laid out.
lead_paragraph: Corporate workers may barely recognize the offices they return to. Instead of open-floor layouts optimized for space, they are likely to see desks six feet apart, plastic barriers and common areas without seating.

headline: China and the Rhineland Moment
abstract: America and its allies must not simply accept Beijing’s aggression.
lead_paragraph: Great struggles between great powers tend to have a tipping point. It’s the moment when the irreconcilability of differences becomes obvious to nearly everyone.

headline: Why Derek Chauvin Was Charged With Third-Degree Murder
abstract: A document by prosecutors details how Mr. Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, interacted with George Floyd before his death. Third-degree murder does not require an intent to kill.
lead_paragraph: The former Minneapolis police officer charged in the death of George Floyd held his knee to Mr. Floyd’s neck for nearly nine minutes, including for two minutes and 53 seconds after Mr. Floyd became unresponsive, according to a document released by prosecutors on Friday.

headline: How the Supreme Court Lets Cops Get Away With Murder
abstract: The courts protected police abuses for years before George Floyd’s death. It’s time to rethink “qualified immunity.”
lead_paragraph: A Minneapolis police officer, who was filmed kneeling on George Floyd’s neck for nearly nine minutes until the life left his body, has been fired, arrested and charged with third-degree murder and manslaughter. That is a step toward justice. Those who take a life should face a jury of their peers. But the rarity of the arrest, the fact that police officers who brutalize or even kill other people while wearing a badge so seldom end up facing any consequences is an ugly reminder of how unjust America’s legal system can be.

headline: Flynn Discussed Sanctions at Length With Russian Diplomat, Transcripts Show
abstract: The former national security adviser now says he does not remember those discussions as he fights a criminal charge he had previously pleaded guilty to.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn discussed sanctions at length with a Russian diplomat in late 2016, according to transcripts declassified on Friday that appear to bolster earlier assertions that Mr. Flynn misled Vice President Mike Pence and F.B.I. agents about those conversations.

headline: America Is a Tinderbox
abstract: Scenes from a country in free fall.
lead_paragraph: The last two and a half months in America have felt like the opening montage in a dystopian film about a nation come undone. First the pandemic hit and hospitals in New York City were overwhelmed. The national economy froze and unemployment soared; one in four American workers has applied for unemployment benefits since March. Lines of cars stretched for miles at food banks. Heavily armed lockdown protesters demonstrated across the country; in Michigan, they forced the Capitol to close and legislators to cancel their session. Nationwide, at least 100,000 people died of a disease almost no one had heard of last year.

headline: Special Episode: The Latest From Minneapolis
abstract: In the wake of George Floyd’s death, a city is ablaze in a longstanding demand for justice.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Confrontational
abstract: Brian Thomas brings us an action-packed Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Brian Thomas is a regular contributor who almost always works with a theme; this is his second Saturday grid. It’s classic-feeling and smooth, with interesting cluing and fun entries — nothing super flashy, but sometimes that’s the point!

headline: ‘Facing the Darkest Hour’: Hong Kong’s Protest Movement in Crisis
abstract: As the Chinese government’s grip tightens, protesters are debating how and why to keep fighting, or whether resistance is even possible.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Protesters have deleted their social media accounts, afraid that their messages could be used against them under China’s new national security laws. Young parents have scoured the internet for instructions on emigration. Organizers have planned rallies, only to cancel them at the last minute in the face of impenetrable police blockades.

headline: Leaving the W.H.O. Shows Poor Leadership
abstract: America should be demanding answers, not retreating.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s recent decision to terminate America’s role in the World Health Organization will have devastating effects on global health, and it will benefit the Chinese Communist Party. Throughout the Covid-19 crisis, the C.C.P. has pursued an aggressive messaging and disinformation campaign with twin goals: to restore its own image after a botched response to the pandemic and to sow discord among European nations about American commitment abroad. Moreover, leaving the W.H.O. sends the message that the world cannot count on the United States.

headline: Atlanta Protesters Clash With Police as Mayor Warns ‘You Are Disgracing Our City’
abstract: Protesters broke windows and set fire to cars after the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Protests emerged in many U.S. cities.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Hundreds of demonstrators poured into the streets near Atlanta’s Centennial Olympic Park on Friday night, smashing windows and clashing with police officers in a protest that grew so tense that the city’s mayor forcefully told people to go home.

headline: Trump Postpones June G7 Summit
abstract: The German chancellor had announced earlier Saturday that she would not travel to the U.S. for the G7. Businesses are starting up again, but workers commuting by public transportation face dilemmas.
lead_paragraph: This live briefing has ended. Click here for the latest global updates.

headline: Corrections: May 30, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 30, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the activation of the National Guard amid protests in Minneapolis referred incorrectly to Kirsten Delegard’s employer. She works for the Mapping Prejudice project at the University of Minnesota, but she is not a professor there or at Augsburg University.

headline: Protests Flare in Brooklyn Over Floyd Death as de Blasio Appeals for Calm
abstract: Demonstrators stormed the perimeter of Barclays Center, hurling bottles and debris at police officers. The police responded with pepper spray and arrested more than 200 people.
lead_paragraph: [The latest: Protests Over George Floyd Death Reach Trump Tower and Across N.Y.C.]

headline: Supreme Court, in 5-4 Decision, Rejects Church’s Challenge to Shutdown Order
abstract: A California church argued that restrictions on public gatherings treated houses of worship worse than many businesses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday turned away a request from a church in California to block enforcement of state restrictions on attendance at religious services.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Ramy’ and ‘The High Note’
abstract: Ramy Youssef’s faith-focused dramedy is back for a second season, and a comedy about the music industry arrives on digital platforms.
lead_paragraph: RAMY Stream on Hulu. This dramedy series made a splash when it debuted last year for putting the experiences of American Muslims front and center. Created by the comedian Ramy Youssef, who also stars as the title character, the show follows an Egyptian-American millennial in New Jersey torn by hedonistic pleasures and his desire to reconnect with his faith. Existential questions are still swirling through Ramy’s mind in Season 2, but he’s now unpacking them with help of a spiritual mentor (newcomer Mahershala Ali). We learn more about Ramy’s family and watch as he navigates sticky situations that test his faith. In an interview with Entertainment Weekly, Youssef suggested that this season may spark “uncomfortable conversations” among critical viewers — for one, the trailer reveals a scene featuring a former adult film star — but it also offers a more intimate look at his character’s spiritual motivations.

headline: How to Get Your Money to Those Who Need It More Than You
abstract: Your instinct may be to help right now, in cash. These services bridge the gap between Venmoing someone from Twitter and a check to a big charity that could steer that money anywhere.
lead_paragraph: As unemployment claims pass 40 million and the anxious people who file them grow more desperate, an altruistic instinct has emerged among those who are more financially secure.

headline: Wealthy Fliers Worried About Coronavirus Turn to Private Jet Service
abstract: As business executives curtail their travel, jet service providers are shifting to meet the demand from people concerned about getting on a commercial flight.
lead_paragraph: Commercial air travel has plummeted in the pandemic, but interest in private jet service is surging, particularly among people who have not paid to fly privately before.

headline: In Hong Kong, Anxiety and Defiance Over Trump’s Move to Cut Ties
abstract: The reactions to President Trump’s decision fell along familiar political fault lines in a city wracked by nearly a year of protests.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong officials reacted with a mix of anxiety, resignation and defiance to President Trump’s announcement that the United States would end its special relationship with the city, reflecting the semiautonomous territory’s deep political divide over its relationship with mainland China.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Now, the Sommelier Lifts His Mask to Sniff the Wine
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 30, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Of course, there were many delivery companies, but it’s not the same, sitting on your sofa and having this ugly pizza.”

headline: ‘Wow, Everything’s Gone’: The Covid Class of 2020
abstract: Born in the wake of 9/11, they entered adulthood in the middle of a global pandemic. Meet a generation bookended by tragedy.
lead_paragraph: Born in the wake of 9/11, they entered adulthood in the middle of a global pandemic. Meet a generation bookended by tragedy.

headline: How to Organize Your Closet
abstract: You’re just a few steps away from a happier wardrobe.
lead_paragraph: Cameron Silver, the owner of Decades, a Los Angeles vintage haven known for high-end consignment, has years of experience organizing and preserving garments. Here, he shares advice for how to do it yourself.

headline: Is Pickleball the Perfect Pandemic Pastime?
abstract: Ellen DeGeneres recently declared herself among the intergenerational sport’s ardent enthusiasts.
lead_paragraph: When social distancing mandates struck Daytona Beach, Fla., in April, residents of Latitude Margaritaville (one of several “55 and better” communities inspired by the Jimmy Buffett song) quickly gathered the essentials.

headline: Past Presidents Faced Police Brutality and Protests. They Handled It Differently.
abstract: President Trump’s predecessors took different approaches when responding — or not responding — to police killings or assaults of black men. But they never threatened violence against protesters.
lead_paragraph: It is a bleak reality of American history that each of the past four presidents faced the same crisis President Trump is facing now: The police just killed or seriously injured a black man, and the city where it happened is reeling with grief and rage.

headline: The White Dog Walker and #LivingWhileBlack in New York City
abstract: The confrontation between a black bird watcher and a white woman walking her dog reminded many black residents that a diverse city can also be hostile.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Roberts, a professor at Columbia University, remembered being stopped by the police as he walked his Rottweiler along Morningside Drive after someone reported that a black man was robbing people with a dog in tow.

headline: A Mile-Long Line for Free Food in Geneva, One of World’s Richest Cities
abstract: The Swiss city is best known for bankers, watchmakers and U.N. officials. But the virus has forced thousands from Geneva’s underclass to line up for hours for food aid.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Kingsley, an international correspondent, and Laetitia Vancon, a photojournalist, are driving more than 3,700 miles to explore the reopening of the European continent after coronavirus lockdowns. Read all their dispatches.

headline: Kris Kobach Is Back, and a Kansas Senate Seat May Be Up for Grabs
abstract: Mr. Kobach’s polarizing presence in a race in a reliably Republican stronghold has party leaders worried that Kansas will become a high-stakes battleground for control of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: LEAWOOD, Kan. — It has been 88 years since Kansas last sent a Democrat to the United States Senate — one of only three Democrats ever to represent the state in the upper chamber.

headline: Twitter Had Been Drawing a Line for Months When Trump Crossed It
abstract: Inside the company, one faction wanted Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief, to take a hard line against the president’s tweets while another urged him to remain hands-off.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Jack Dorsey was up late Thursday at his home in San Francisco talking online with his executives when their conversation was interrupted: President Trump had just posted another inflammatory message on Twitter.

headline: In Lockdown, a Neighborhood Opens Up
abstract: Grab a hyperlocal bakery loaf and a copy of the kids’ newspaper, and we can discuss over stoop cocktails.
lead_paragraph: The residents of Bernal Heights, a dense little neighborhood built around a grassy hill in the south of San Francisco, have been under lockdown a long time — since March 17, to be exact, when the city became among the first in the United States to shut down.

headline: Coronavirus Slams Broken, Embattled Yemen
abstract: Lacking equipment, expertise and authority, a divided, war-torn country bobbles a response to a surging pandemic.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In northern Yemen, more and more people are falling ill and dying after having trouble breathing, yet the Iran-backed group that controls the region, the Houthis, has acknowledged only a few coronavirus deaths.

headline: In Some Nations, Coronavirus Is Only One of Many Outbreaks
abstract: In countries like Honduras, the virus has diverted resources from efforts to fight other serious diseases, straining weak public health systems, draining supplies and unraveling hard-won gains.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A dengue epidemic ravaged Honduras last year, sickening over 100,000 people and leaving 180 dead. As this year began, officials braced for another surge in cases of the mosquito-borne disease and wondered how they would manage with their frail public health system and shortage of trained personnel.

headline: Appeals for Calm as Sprawling Protests Threaten to Spiral Out of Control
abstract: Escalating violence and destruction raised questions about whether a diverse, broadly decentralized protest movement was veering off track.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The nation was rocked again on Saturday as demonstrators clashed with police from outside the White House gates to the streets of more than three dozen besieged cities, as outrage over the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis traversed a razor’s edge between protest and civic meltdown.

headline: Rabbis to Return to German Military Amid Growing Anti-Semitism
abstract: The Army will welcome rabbis into its chaplaincy this year to provide spiritual support to Jewish soldiers as anti-Semitism surges in the country.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany will allow rabbis to return to the chaplaincy of its military for the first time since they were kicked out under the Nazis in the 1930s, as officials struggle to curb a rise in anti-Semitic attacks in society as a whole.

headline: Protesters Confront Police at Minneapolis Precinct
abstract: On the fourth night of unrest in Minneapolis, protesters expressed outrage at the police at the Fifth Precinct as the surrounding area turned into a smoky battleground.
lead_paragraph: On the fourth night of unrest in Minneapolis, protesters expressed outrage at the police at the Fifth Precinct as the surrounding area turned into a smoky battleground.

headline: Cuomo Focuses on Quelling Virus Hot Spots in N.Y.C. Before Reopening
abstract: As New York City looks to enter Phase 1 of reopening on June 8, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said officials were preparing hospitals for a potential uptick in coronavirus cases.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Sunday’s live coverage.]

headline: World Leaders, Pop Stars and Drag Queens to Headline Livestream for Gay Pride
abstract: Global Pride, a online event scheduled for June 27, will feature remarks by prime ministers and royalty as well as performances by international musical acts, according to organizers.
lead_paragraph: World leaders, human rights activists, international musical acts and drag queens will participate in a 24-hour online celebration of gay pride organized after the coronavirus pandemic forced the cancellation or postponement of hundreds of L.G.B.T.Q. pride events around the world, organizers announced on Saturday.

headline: Are Virtual Tours Really Enough Before Renting a New Home?
abstract: Video tours have quickly become the standard way to see available apartments and houses. But not all videos are created equal.
lead_paragraph: Q: I need to move by July 1 and am looking for a rental in Manhattan, but I can only view apartments virtually. How can I get a sense of what an apartment really looks like from just videos and photographs? How does anyone move into an apartment without ever visiting it?

headline: What Is Your Most Significant Relationship? Here Are 10 Answers
abstract: As they deal with the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, people across the United States reflect on their most treasured personal relationships with family, friends, partners and pets.
lead_paragraph: In times of celebration, growth and uncertainty, the most significant people in our lives extend companionship and support. Sometimes by chance, important bonds are forged instantly over an unplanned event. In other instances, ties develop gradually throughout years of shared experiences. Here’s what 10 people had to say about their connections with their family, friends, partners and even pets.

headline: Do Runners Need to Wear Masks?
abstract: Some people have taken to yelling (online and off) at people exercising without masks. But does it really matter?
lead_paragraph: Jane Rosen began yelling sometime in April. By May, it had become routine. The incidents usually occur near her minivan, which she parks alongside Central Park in New York City.

headline: Fiery Clashes Erupt Between Police and Protesters Over George Floyd Death
abstract: As standoffs intensified across the country on Saturday, officials in Minneapolis vowed to take a harder line against unrest in the streets.
lead_paragraph: This live briefing has ended. Click here for the latest updates.

headline: SpaceX Launch: Highlights From NASA Astronauts’ Trip to Orbit
abstract: Look back at the day when a NASA crew headed to the space station from the United States for the first time since the space shuttles were retired in 2011.
lead_paragraph: The United States opened a new era of human space travel on Saturday as a private company for the first time launched astronauts into orbit, nearly a decade after the government retired the storied space shuttle program in the aftermath of national tragedy.

headline: For Fans of Ivan, the Answer to ‘What About Bob?’
abstract: In Katherine Applegate’s “The One and Only Bob,” Ivan’s best buddy strikes out on his own.
lead_paragraph: Outsider stories resonate strongly with children: Even the luckiest of us start life in a land of giants where doorknobs and cookie jars hover beyond reach and adults call most of the shots. Katherine Applegate has made a specialty of mining this emotional territory in novels that blend elements of fantasy and realism while tracking the changing fortunes of resilient outsiders — like a homeless fifth grader (“Crenshaw”) and a Sudanese refugee (“Home of the Brave”), or, most memorably to date, a silverback gorilla living in captivity as the star attraction of a squalid shopping-mall tourist destination (“The One and Only Ivan”).

headline: A Tale of Twinned Cities
abstract: In William Shivering’s “Thieves of Weirdwood,” a mirror city’s buildings and streets physically reflect the hopes and fears of a “normal,” grim, Dickensian city’s residents.
lead_paragraph: The most important thing to know about William Shivering’s THIEVES OF WEIRDWOOD (Holt, 338 pp., $16.99; ages 8 to 12) is that it will delight and satiate those besotted with Harry Potter, Percy Jackson, Artemis Fowl, Miss Peregrine, the Spiderwicks. It boasts a familiar but enticing list of ingredients — an orphaned hero, plucky sidekicks, shape-shifting monsters, hidden worlds, magical peacekeepers, foul deeds, fateful destinies — whisked into a story that is fast-paced, funny and sometimes surprising. It comes to a satisfying conclusion, though with just enough loose ends, and an appended cliffhanger, to propel readers forward to the next installment, since being the first book in a series is arguably the single most essential part of the recipe, like sugar in a cookie.

headline: Make the Zestiest Macaroni Salad
abstract: Macaroni salad with lemon and herbs, blueberry cobbler, and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include macaroni salad with lemon and herbs (above), blueberry cobbler, and one-pot chicken and rice with ginger and cumin. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Andrew J. Ries brings some order to this mixed-up, crazy world, or vice versa.
lead_paragraph: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Not bragging, but explaining the last few puzzles by Andrew J. Reis has taught me a lot, and I am finding myself increasingly prepared for his new puzzles. There are a few stumpers today, but if you’re getting to the point where you know your containers from your charades and your homophones, you might feel the same way about a clever little jewel box like this P and A. If not, then grab a guide and keep reading for hints — you’ll get there soon!

headline: In Case of Emergency, Make Art
abstract: Hand a kid colored pencils and the trepidation and confusion of the coronavirus pandemic transmutes into striped penguins.
lead_paragraph: I was a firefighter for many years. But because it was more than a decade ago, it often seems like another person wore those turnout boots, cinched that ax belt and ran into burning buildings. Yet when the Covid-19 pandemic hit a few months ago, my old first-responder instincts rose up.

headline: The Rich Love India’s Lockdown. For the Poor It’s Another Story.
abstract: Estimates show the lockdown is pushing tens of millions of Indians below the poverty line.
lead_paragraph: I landed in Delhi on a work trip in mid-March and just over a week later, Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced what was soon recognized as the world’s strictest lockdown. He warned Indians to imagine “a sacrosanct line” around their homes, not to be breached for work or travel of any kind, not even a walk outdoors. Evoking the 18-day war described in the Mahabharata, an ancient Indian epic, Mr. Modi said it would take 21 days to win the war on the coronavirus.

headline: Where Dance and Fashion Collide
abstract: A conversation between the designer Iris van Herpen and the choreographer Damien Jalet on the creative process.
lead_paragraph: This conversation is part of The Big Ideas, a special section of The Times’s philosophy series, The Stone, in which more than a dozen artists, writers and thinkers answer the question, “Why does art matter?” The entire series can be found here.

headline: What Top Conservatives Are Saying About George Floyd and Police Brutality
abstract: For those on the right whose usual instinct is to stand up for law enforcement, the stark video showing Mr. Floyd being fatally pinned by a police officer raises conflicting feelings about the incident.
lead_paragraph: In her typical appearances on Fox News, Jeanine Pirro, a former Republican district attorney, reserves her highest dudgeon for castigating liberals and lamenting the demise of law and order.

headline: No More Money for the Police
abstract: Redirect it to emergency response programs that don’t kill black people.
lead_paragraph: The only way we’re going to stop these endless cycles of police violence is by creating alternatives to policing. Because even in a pandemic where black people have been disproportionately killed by the coronavirus, the police are still murdering us.

headline: Sam Johnson, Congressman and Former P.O.W., Is Dead at 89
abstract: A much-decorated pilot held by the North Vietnamese for years, he would later criticize his fellow Republican Donald Trump for disparaging John McCain.
lead_paragraph: Sam Johnson, a former military pilot who suffered torture as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam for nearly seven years, part of that time alongside John McCain, then came home to Texas to serve for 28 years in Congress, died on Wednesday in Plano, Texas. He was 89.

headline: To Disinfect a Police Car in a Pandemic, Software Cranks Up the Heat
abstract: The N.Y.P.D. and other departments were concerned about the spread of the coronavirus in vehicles. Ford’s answer is software to raise the temperature.
lead_paragraph: Over the last two months, law-enforcement agencies around the country have increasingly found themselves transporting people infected with the coronavirus, and facing the challenge of how to quickly and effectively sanitize their vehicles.

headline: The Problem With Military Base Names
abstract: Readers say those named for Confederate Army officers should be changed; another points to the overriding fact that the U.S. military was a pioneer in achieving racial equality.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Lessons for the Future From Online Learning
abstract: Should schools incorporate more virtual learning when they reopen? Students and educators respond to one student’s enthusiasm for it.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Days of Discord, a President Fans the Flames
abstract: Mr. Trump has presented himself as someone who seeks conflict, not conciliation, a fighter, not a peacemaker. And he has lived up to his self-image at a perilous time.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a nation on edge, ravaged by disease, hammered by economic collapse, divided over lockdowns and even face masks and now convulsed once again by race, President Trump’s first instinct has been to look for someone to fight.

headline: Trump Threatens White House Protesters With ‘Vicious Dogs’ and ‘Ominous Weapons’
abstract: The president, before traveling to Florida to watch a rocket launch, also said that his base “loves the black people.” Hours later, intense protests erupted near the White House for a second night.
lead_paragraph: A day after claiming he didn’t mean to suggest that law enforcement officials should shoot people who were part of the unrest in Minnesota, President Trump said on Saturday that the Secret Service had been prepared to sic the “most vicious dogs” on protesters outside the White House gates on Friday night.

headline: How We Broke the World
abstract: Greed and globalization set us up for disaster.
lead_paragraph: If recent weeks have shown us anything, it’s that the world is not just flat. It’s fragile.

headline: Think Outside the Box, Jack
abstract: Trump, Twitter and the society-crushing pursuit of monetized rage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — C’mon, @Jack. You can do it.

headline: Annexing the West Bank Is a Brazen Violation of International Law
abstract: It would also render the territory into a patchwork of simmering, unstable Palestinian areas, forever threatening a new intifada.
lead_paragraph: For his next act, after surviving a yearlong political struggle that he needed three national elections and a health crisis to overcome, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has announced that on July 1 he will start the process to annex Jewish settlements and the Jordan Valley in the West Bank, as he pledged to do in his campaign.

headline: Why Have One Pandemic Hobby When You Can Have 1,000 of Them?
abstract: My quest to try everything and master nothing.
lead_paragraph: Over the past 60 days, I have not touched my stack of presidential biographies or baked a single loaf of sourdough bread. Nor have I acquired new muscle definition, signed up for a 12-week Russian course or embarked on the slow but fulfilling process of practicing a new hobby.

headline: The Case Against Riots
abstract: What nonviolent protest gains, violent protest unravels.
lead_paragraph: In the origin myth of post-1960s liberalism, all the defeats that the Democratic Party suffered in the years of Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan were owed to the party’s heroic support for civil rights, which rectified a great injustice but opened the way for the Republicans to build majorities on racial backlash.

headline: The Top U.S. Coronavirus Hot Spots Are All Indian Lands
abstract: Living conditions make it difficult to contain the virus's spread.
lead_paragraph: CHINLE, Ariz. — The Navajo Nation is a vast, awe-inspiring land of desert crags and canyons, the largest reservation in the country, but today it reverberates with grief and fear.

headline: Thousands of Complaints Do Little to Change Police Ways
abstract: Efforts to hold problem officers accountable face resistance from unions, and juries are reluctant to second-guess.
lead_paragraph: In nearly two decades with the Minneapolis Police Department, Derek Chauvin faced at least 17 misconduct complaints, none of which derailed his career.

headline: Remember, No One Is Coming to Save Us
abstract: Eventually doctors will find a coronavirus vaccine, but black people will continue to wait for a cure for racism.
lead_paragraph: After Donald Trump maligned the developing world in 2018, with the dismissive phrase “shithole countries,” I wrote that no one was coming to save us from the president. Now, in the midst of a pandemic, we see exactly what that means.

headline: SpaceX Lifts NASA Astronauts to Orbit, Launching New Era of Spaceflight
abstract: The trip to the space station was the first from American soil since 2011 when the space shuttles were retired.
lead_paragraph: [When to watch SpaceX’s next NASA launch of astronauts.]

headline: What Goes UpMust Come Down
abstract: Lewis Rothlein and Jeff Chen raise us high and drop us low.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — After a couple of trippy weeks we have a classic today, a grid that finds a wild little feature in the language, one we’ve all seen before but might not have noticed, and expands on it to make a polished Sunday puzzle. Jeff Chen is involved, and Lewis Rothlein makes his Sunday debut after a run of five Thursdays, so we know we have some theme veterans at work (Will Shortz’s introduction says the two constructors exchanged over 100 emails on the theme alone).

headline: China and India Brawl at 14,000 Feet Along the Border
abstract: As China projects its power across Asia, and along the disputed India-China border in the Himalayas, India is feeling surrounded. Both sides insist they don’t want a war, but thousands of troops have been sent.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — High in the Himalayas, an enormous fistfight erupted in early May between the soldiers of China and India. Brawls at 14,000 feet along their inhospitable and disputed frontier are not terribly unusual, but what happened next was.

headline: John Loengard, Life Photographer and Chronicler, Dies at 85
abstract: He shot compelling portraits of the Beatles, Georgia O’Keeffe and many others and celebrated photography, and Life magazine, in books.
lead_paragraph: When Life magazine sent John Loengard to Miami to photograph the Beatles in February 1964, he had a quirky idea: Pose them in a swimming pool, as a Fab Four of bobbing heads. But on a very chilly day, he could find only an unheated pool.

headline: What to Know About Breonna Taylor’s Death
abstract: Fury over the killing of Ms. Taylor by the police has fueled tense demonstrations in Louisville, Ky., and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The death of Breonna Taylor, a Black medical worker who was shot and killed by Louisville police officers in March during a botched raid on her apartment, led to wide-scale demonstrations in the spring and summer as the case drew more attention.

headline: Thousands Protest in N.Y.C., Clashing With Police Across All 5 Boroughs
abstract: By early Sunday, 345 protesters had been arrested and 47 police cars had been damaged or destroyed, as demonstrators angry over the death of George Floyd clashed with officers and looted stores.
lead_paragraph: [The latest: Protests flared for a fourth night on Sunday.]

headline: ‘They’re Just Doing Whatever They Want’: Few Masks Are Seen as Beach Town Reopens
abstract: As businesses in the Maryland town of Ocean City try to enforce mask wearing, they are finding some visitors unwilling to comply.
lead_paragraph: OCEAN CITY, Md. — Dave Heyburn and Nevada Kaler viewed their weekend on this seaside boardwalk as an escape from the coronavirus “red zone” where they live, in Elverson, Pa. Neither wore masks, which are not required to be worn outdoors here.

headline: George Floyd Protests: A Timeline
abstract: At least six people have been killed in violence connected to the protests that started after Mr. Floyd died in police custody.
lead_paragraph: After the death of George Floyd on May 25, protests and unrest have rocked Minneapolis and other cities.

headline: Draw a Self-Portrait
abstract: Our template provides guidelines on spacing, now you just have to really look. And don’t move!
lead_paragraph: There is truly no time like the present to give drawing a shot, and a self-portrait is an excellent place to start. The template  provided here can help you figure out how to draw a human face — how much space there is between all of its parts and what goes where.  Some of the best portraits in the world don’t follow these rules and you don’t always have to either, but it’s helpful to know them.

headline: Photos From the George Floyd Protests, City by City
abstract: Scenes from the protests over racism and police violence that have erupted across the country.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the protests over racism and police violence that have erupted across the country.

headline: Trump Hopes for His Own Booster Shot From SpaceX Rocket Launch
abstract: The president, beleaguered by a pandemic, economic troubles and racial unrest, viewed the liftoff as a welcome moment of triumph that he celebrated with a campaign rally-style speech.
lead_paragraph: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — For President Trump, the launch of the sleek SpaceX rocket with two NASA astronauts on Saturday not only propelled America back into the heavens but, he hoped, gave a booster shot to his own beleaguered presidency after months of misery afflicting the country.

headline: A Reporter’s Cry on Live TV: ‘I’m Getting Shot! I’m Getting Shot!’
abstract: From a television crew assaulted by protesters to a photographer struck in the eye, journalists have found themselves targeted on the streets of America.
lead_paragraph: Linda Tirado, a freelance photographer, activist and author, was shot in the left eye Friday while covering the street protests in Minneapolis.

headline: Trump Postpones G7 Summit and Calls for Russia to Attend
abstract: The president said he also planned to invite South Korea, Australia and India to the meeting of world leaders in order to discuss China’s future.
lead_paragraph: President Trump said on Saturday that he planned to postpone the annual Group of 7 summit of world leaders until September and that he wanted to invite Russia to rejoin as part of an alliance to discuss the future of China.

headline: U.S. Sends Two Million Doses of Hydroxychloroquine to Brazil
abstract: The two countries are studying whether the drug is safe and effective for the prevention and early treatment of Covid-19. Nicaragua has become a place of midnight burials.
lead_paragraph: The United States has delivered two million doses of a malaria drug to Brazil for use in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic, and the two countries are embarking on a joint research effort to study whether the drug is safe and effective for the prevention and early treatment of Covid-19, the White House announced Sunday.

abstract: When the pandemic collided with the spring migration, the sounds of the city changed overnight.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic collided with the spring migration, the sounds of the city changed overnight.

lead_paragraph: [When to watch SpaceX’s next NASA launch of astronauts.]

headline: Protests in Los Angeles Over Police Violence
abstract: Demonstrations broke out across the country in response to the death of George Floyd. In Los Angeles, protesters shut down freeways and faced off with police officers.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrations broke out across the country in response to the death of George Floyd. In Los Angeles, protesters shut down freeways and faced off with police officers.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Quiz’ and ‘The Vast of Night’
abstract: A new AMC series dramatizes a very real English scandal, while a sci-fi thriller streams on Amazon.
lead_paragraph: QUIZ 10 p.m. on AMC. By sheer coincidence, the British director Stephen Frears, more recently known for “A Very English Scandal,” is back with another series that easily could have borrowed that title. “Quiz,” a three-part drama, revisits a case that took Britain by storm in 2001. After Charles Ingram (played by Matthew Macfadyen of “Succession”), a former British Army major, won the grand prize on the ratings juggernaut “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?,” he, his wife, Diana (Sian Clifford of “Fleabag”), and Tecwen Whittock (Michael Jibson), an accomplice, were found guilty of cheating. Diana and Tecwen, who had been seated in the audience, were said to have hinted at the correct answers by coughing. The couple were vilified in the British media, yet they still claim innocence. This show leaves it up to viewers to decide whether the Ingrams should have walked away millionaires. The season finale of KILLING EVE leads in at 9 p.m.

headline: Sing Duets Over the Internet
abstract: Even if you’re not a pro, you can still record your duets together from afar.
lead_paragraph: People love singing together at the best of times, and perhaps even more at the worst of times. For example, currently gaining traction on Instagram are the trans-Atlantic Lockdown Duets videos that pair Broadway and West End performers. The series was hatched by Alistair Brammer, who played the G.I. Chris in the recent revival of “Miss Saigon.”

headline: In Hong Kong, China Threatens Businesses and Workers
abstract: Beijing is using fear and pressure to drum up support for its increasingly hard-line stance in the Asian financial capital, threatening its status as a global business center.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China and its allies are using threats and pressure to get business to back Beijing’s increasingly hard-line stance toward Hong Kong, leading companies to muzzle or intimidate workers who speak out in protest.

headline: Corrections: May 31, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 31, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 12 about the Netflix series “The Baby-Sitters Club” refers imprecisely to Lucia Aniello’s role. She is one of several executive producers; she is not its sole executive producer. It also misstated when Aniello and Rachel Shukert met. They met during the development of “The Baby-Sitters Club,” not while working together on the wrestling comedy “GLOW.”

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 31, 2020.

headline: Western Countries Leave Children of ISIS in Syrian Camps
abstract: The children are living in squalid detention camps lacking schools, health care and clean water, and where disease and jihadist ideology are rampant.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As about 900 children languish in fetid, disease-ridden detainment camps in northeastern Syria, the Western states their parents hail from have insisted they cannot take them back.

headline: Why Major Sports Might Risk Comebacks During the Pandemic
abstract: After months of pessimism, the biggest sports leagues have made a flurry of announcements about plans to return. What changed?
lead_paragraph: Once more, the pronouncements arrived in a torrent, though this time they were about rebirth rather than cancellation.

headline: Mexico’s President Says Most Domestic Violence Calls Are ‘Fake’
abstract: The leader compared the requests for help to prank calls, the latest controversy over his government’s response to record levels of violence against women.
lead_paragraph: The numbers were startling: In March, Mexico’s government said, the country’s emergency call centers were flooded with more than 26,000 reports of violence against women, the highest since the hotline was created.

headline: Alicia Silverstone Wants Us to Eat Our Fruits and Vegetables
abstract: From ’90s “It” girl to animal-rights advocate and food activist — with a dash of controversy.
lead_paragraph: “There were people in my life at one time that really did say you couldn’t really do the activism thing if you wanted to be an actor,” said Alicia Silverstone, 43, who after Aerosmith’s “Cryin’” video and her role as Cher Horowitz, the spoiled and charming teenager in the 1995 coming-of-age hit “Clueless,” became a Hollywood “It” girl.

headline: How PETA Won Its Messy Fight and Took a Seat at the Table
abstract: Turns out if you throw enough red paint, eventually they’ll listen.
lead_paragraph: The alpaca’s scream sounded like a high-pitched electric pencil sharpener, more machine than mammal. It was awful, and that was the point. The group behind the video, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, has been publicizing graphic scenes like this long enough to know which sights and sounds make people feel the most miserable.

headline: Watching Lots of TV? Welcome to My World
abstract: The pandemic hasn’t dramatically changed the job of a Times television critic. Yet.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Two Crises Convulse a Nation: A Pandemic and Police Violence
abstract: Emotions were already raw over the toll of a pandemic that has killed more than 100,000 people across the country and cost millions of jobs.
lead_paragraph: They are parallel plagues ravaging America: The coronavirus. And police killings of black men and women.

headline: Tenants Largely Stay Current on Rent, for Now
abstract: Collections have been surprisingly strong through the pandemic, but there are troubling signs — for landlords and tenants alike.
lead_paragraph: Since April, landlords have looked to the first of the month fearing that tenants will stop paying their rent. For the most part, that has not happened. Despite a 14.7 percent unemployment rate and millions of new jobless claims each week, collections at many buildings are only slightly below where they were last year, when the economy was booming.

lead_paragraph: Patrick Kingsley, an international correspondent, and Laetitia Vancon, a photojournalist, are driving more than 3,700 miles to explore the reopening of the European continent after coronavirus lockdowns. Read all their dispatches.

headline: Black Americans Have a Message for Democrats: Not Being Trump Is Not Enough
abstract: Joe Biden wants to heal the soul of the country in this moment of protest and loss, and win the White House. Simply telling people to vote in November may not help with either goal.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — In an on-camera address after a week of destructive protests, former vice president Joseph R. Biden Jr. pleaded with his audience to imagine life for black people in America. Imagine, he said, “if every time your husband or son, wife or daughter left the house, you feared for their safety.” Imagine the police called on you for sitting in Starbucks.

abstract: Nationwide demonstrations resume, officials in several states reinforce their National Guard presence and anger mounts at increasingly aggressive tactics by the police.

headline: Coronavirus Turns a Spanish Sea Delicacy Back Into Daily Fare
abstract: With high-end restaurants closed, the price of prawns has tumbled, allowing fishmongers to pick up the shellfish at a discount and offer them to a much broader clientele.
lead_paragraph: LLANÇÀ, Spain — With an intensity of flavor to match their color, the big, bright-red prawns caught off Spain’s eastern coast are the kind of delicacy that someone might eat once or twice in a year and remember fondly for the rest of it.

headline: Rogue Trip by Boris Johnson Aide Makes U.K.’s Spectator Part of the Story
abstract: A senior editor of the magazine, Britain’s oldest, did not disclose in an article that her husband, Dominic Cummings, had taken a 260-mile trip that breached the nation’s stay-at-home order.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Boris Johnson became the editor of The Spectator in 1999, he declared that he planned to make the weekly magazine, Britain’s oldest, a “refuge for logic, fun, and good writing.” It would, he promised somewhat paradoxically, “continue to set the political agenda, and to debunk it.”

headline: The Week in Business: The Post-Lockdown Office
abstract: President Trump’s feud with Twitter, explained.
lead_paragraph: For a four-day workweek, this past one sure felt long. Catch up on what you missed in the business and tech worlds, and get some rest this weekend.
